chapter.title: CHAPTER 1
chapter.p: In the name of God who commands
that a fire offering be brought before him.
I begin to explain the book
And The Lord Called Unto Moses.1

1. AND THE LORD CALLED. We find two reasons for the covenant made with an individual.2 It is also possible for one commandment to have many reasons. The commandment regarding the burnt offering and the sacrifice3 are examples of the latter, for when the officiant offers each part4 in its proper time, then the part5 which has a part6 in the world to come is saved.7 Therefore the meaning of le-khapper (to make atonement) (v. 4) is to give ransom. The opening of the Torah portion Ki Tissa8 is proof.9 Scripture therefore reads, lest He10 fall upon us with pestilence11 (Ex. 5:3). There is also a secret12 regarding the future in the burnt offering.13 One can also learn from each sacrifice the secret of nature.14 The purpose of the sin offering15 and the unleavened bread16 is to sustain the teachers of the Torah.17

The reason And the Lord called unto Moses follows And Moses was not able to enter18 (Ex. 40:35) is that the Glory19 called to Moses from the tent of meeting and told him to come there, and there He would speak with him.20 The Glory was on the other side of the curtain21 and Moses entered there.22 The latter is clearly stated in Scripture.23 This is the meaning of and the similitude of the Lord doth he behold (Num. 12:8).

The reason Scripture mentions the sacrifices before the commandments24 is that God’s presence will return to its place25 if Israel does not keep the law of the burnt offering.26 The latter came to pass.27 Far be it from God to require a burnt offering.28 Scripture clearly states, If I were hungry, I would not tell thee…(Ps. 50:12).29 On the contrary, it30 has a secret meaning.31

2. OF YOU. The word mikkem (of you) is placed at the end of the clause.32 The clause should be read as if written, adam mikkem ki yakriv (when any man of you bringeth an offering). There are many such examples.33 On the other hand, the word mikkem might mean from your property.34 The term mikkem might also hint that one is not permitted to bring an offering that is stolen,35 for Scripture states, I hate robbery with iniquity (Is. 61:8).36

OF THE CATTLE. Shall the sacrifice be. This37 is a general term. Scripture then gives the particulars and states, even of the herd,38 or of the flock.39 The flock refers to the species of the sheep and the goat. Your offering40 is also a general term.
3. IF HIS OFFERING BE A BURNT–OFFERING. This41 is a particular. The term olah (burnt offering) is self-explanatory.42

OF THE HERD. Fully grown or young but more than eight days.43 The burnt offering is brought from the choicest animals because it is entirely for God. The male is chosen above the female. Therefore a female animal is not brought for a burnt offering.

WITHOUT BLEMISH. Tammim means without blemish.44 After stating he shall offer it, Scripture goes on to explain the place where the celebrant is to bring it. It states that he is to enter into the courtyard of the tent of meeting.45
BEFORE THE LORD. This is to be understood as connected to he shall bring it to the door of the tent of meeting.46
THAT HE MAY BE ACCEPTED47 BEFORE THE LORD. He shall offer it willingly, not by coercion.

4. AND HE SHALL LAY HIS HAND. It would appear from the plain meaning of the text that the celebrant lays one hand48 on the animal about to be sacrificed, for the manner of the scapegoat49 is unlike all sacrifices.50 Scripture therefore changed [the manner of the laying of the hands with regard to it].51 However, we find that the sages who transmitted the laws to us stated that all “laying” is done with two hands.52 We rely on them.

The body53 which is offered to atone for that which comes (ha-olah) into the mind54 is called an olah (burnt offering). The sacrifices brought for sins and guilt are also called chattat (sin offering) and asham (guilt offering).55
AND IT SHALL BE ACCEPTED56 FOR HIM. He will obtain favor from God.
TO MAKE ATONEMENT FOR HIM.57 To serve as a ransom for the punishment due him.
5. BEFORE THE LORD. Like the burnt offering of the flock, on the side of the altar northward, opposite the table.58

The meaning of and he shall kill is that the kohen shall kill. One slaughters59 and many dash the blood.60 Scripture clearly states this i.e., and Aaron’s sons delivered unto him the blood (Lev. 9:12).
Scripture states, that is at the door of the tent of meeting because it wants to exclude the altar of incense.61
6. AND HE SHALL FLAY. A kohen or a Levite accompanies him.62
7. AND THE SONS OF AARON THE PRIEST. Levites shall not approach.63 This commandment was given to the kohanim. Not less than two64 are required.65

8. AND THE SUET. Many wise men of the generation explain that the word pader (suet) refers to the carcass. However, in my opinion the pader refers to the fat. Our verse is to be understood as follows: And Aaron’s sons, the priests, shall lay the pieces, that is, the pieces of the carcass;66 and the head, and the suet, that is, the fat. A connective vav is missing from the word ha-rosh (and the head).67 This is in keeping with the style of the language.68 Compare, odem pitidah69 u-vareket (carnelian, topaz, and smargd) (Ex. 28:17).
And he shall cut it into its pieces (v. 12)70 and along with the pieces, its head and its suet.
On the other hand, et ha-rosh (and the head) might mean with the head.71 There are many such instances.72 The proof of this73 is: Moses made the head, and the pieces, and the suet smoke (Lev. 8:20).
SHALL LAY THE PIECES. Scripture reads ve-arekhu (shall lay)74 because it speaks of a bullock, a large animal.75 Regarding a sheep,76 Scripture states, and the priest shall lay77 them (v. 12).
9. SHALL HE WASH WITH WATER. A kohen or a Levite. Scripture therefore has to add the word kohen to shall make the whole smoke.78
A BURNT-OFFERING. The word isheh (burnt offering) is an adjective. It means a fire offering. It describes the word hakol (the whole).79
A SWEET SAVOUR. The word nicho’ach (a sweet savour) is self-explanatory.80

11. ON THE SIDE OF THE ALTAR. On the outside.81 Similarly [Even mount Zion], the uttermost part (yarkete) of the north82 (Ps. 48:3). For many err and say that the tower of Zion83 was in the midst of Jerusalem.84
14. TURTLE-DOVES. Fully grown, not young.
YOUNG PIGEONS. Scripture reads bene yonah (young pigeons) because it wants to exclude fully grown pigeons. It therefore does not say yonim (pigeons).85
15. PINCH. The word malak (pinch) has no brother in Scripture.86 We know the laws of “pinching” from our tradition.87
AND THE BLOOD THEREOF SHALL BE DRAINED OUT. Ve-nimtzah (shall be drained out) is a nifal. It is related to the word matzit (drained) (Is. 51:17).
16. ITS CROP. The meaning of murato (its crop) is known.88 The word more’ah (filthy) in Woe to her that is filthy and polluted (Zeph. 3:1) is similar.89
WITH THE FEATHERS THEREOF. The meaning of be-not-zatah is, with the feathers thereof.90 The word notzah (feathers) in Full of feathers (Ezek. 17:3) is similar.
BESIDE THE ALTAR. On the outside.91
ON THE EAST PART. For it is far from the place of the Glory.92
IN THE PLACE OF THE ASHES. They shall also place it there.93
17. AND HE SHALL REND IT. The word ve-shissa (and he shall rend it) is related to ve-shosa’at shesa (and is wholly cloven) (Lev. 11:3). The meaning of shissa is split.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Vat. Ebr. 38. This poem is omitted in the printed editions of I.E.

2 Hebrew, berit yachid. The reference is to the covenant of circumcision that God made with Abraham (Gen. 17:9). The commentaries on I.E. differ as to what these two reasons are. Scripture tells us that circumcision is a sign that the Lord will be God to Abraham and his seed after him (Gen. 17:7). I.E. believes that circumcision is also a sign not to act promiscuously. I.E. writes, “The excision of the foreskin of the flesh is a sign of the covenant between man and his creator not to defile one’s soul by engaging in an act of sexual intercourse that is not in accordance with the way of truth” (Yesod Morah, (Strickman translation, p. 102).
3 The other sacrifices.
4 Of the sacrifice.
5 The person. The individual Jew is a part of the people of Israel and of the human species. Hence I.E. refers to the individual as a part.
6 A portion.

7 According to I.E. the sacrificial animal serves as a substitute for the celebrant. “All these acts are performed in order that when they are done, a person should realize that he has sinned against his God…and that his blood should really be spilled and his body burned, were it not for the loving-kindness of the Creator, Who took from him a substitute and a ransom, namely, this offering, so that its blood should be in place of his blood, its life in place of his life, and that the chief limbs of the offering should be in place of the chief parts of his body” (Nachmanides, Chavel translation, Lev. 1:9, p. 21).

9 That le-khapper means to offer a ransom, for we read there that each male Israelite was to give a half shekel as a ransom for his soul (kofer nefesh) (Ex. 30:12). Scripture goes on to say, that there be no plague among them.
10 God.
11 If we do not sacrifice to God.
12 In addition to the one just given.
13 When accepted by God, it ensures one’s future (Weiser).
14 The sacrifices inspire the celebrant. His mind is opened to study the secrets of nature.
15 Whose flesh was eaten by the kohanim.

16 From a thanksgiving offering (Lev. 7:14) or a meal offering (Lev. 2:3; 7:9). Our text reads ve-ha-matzot. Vat. Ebr. 38 and some editions read veha-manot (and the portions), i.e., the portions of the sacrifices which are to be eaten by the kohanim.
17 The kohanim, who teach Torah to the Jewish people. See Lev. 33:10; Mal. 2:7.
18 The sanctuary.
19 God’s glory.

20 The end of the Book of Exodus tells that when the construction of the tabernacle was concluded, Moses could not enter the tabernacle because God’s glory filled it. (Ex. 40:35). Leviticus picks up where Exodus leaves off and tells us at its opening, And the Lord called unto Moses; that is, God invited Moses to the tabernacle.
21 The parochet which separated the Holy of Holies from the holy. The Glory was in the Holy of Holies.
22 Into the Holy of Holies.

24 The Book of Leviticus opens with the laws dealing with sacrifices and then goes on to legislate laws of purity, prohibited sexual relations, interpersonal relations, etc. I.E. raises the question why the laws dealing with the sacrifices are given priority.
25 In heaven. See Hos. 5:15, I (God) will go and return to My place.
26 Hebrew, olah.
27 The destruction of the temples, which resulted in the cessation of the burnt offering, signified the removal of the manifestation of God’s presence over Israel (Weiser).
28 For His own purposes.
29The verse continues, For the world is mine…Do I eat the flesh of hulls or drink the blood of goats? These two verses completely dispel the idea that the sacrifices were food for God.
30 The burnt offering.
31 According to I.E. the burnt offering causes “a power from on high to rest on man,” Gen. 8:21 (Vol. 1, p. 119).
32 Our clause reads, adam ki yakriv mikkem. The latter literally reads, when any man bringeth an offering of you. Hence I.E.’s comment.
33 Where a word placed at the end of clause should be read as if placed earlier.

34 In other words, mikkem (of you) means of your property. In this case the word mikkem does not have to be moved, for the meaning of the clause is, when any man bringeth an offering of your (that is, his) property.
35 In this case our verse is to be read as follows: When any man bringeth an offering of you, that is, it shall be of yours. It shall belong to you.
36 Hebrew, be-olah. Be-elah may be rendered iniquity or burnt offering. I.E. translates it as burnt offering.
37 Cattle. Hebrew, behemah.
38 Hebrew, bakar.
39 Hebrew, tzon.
40 Which concludes our verse.
41 The term burnt offering.
42 It comes from the root ayin, lamed, heh, which means to go up. The term olah is thus connected in meaning to the word oleh (going up).
43 An animal younger than eight days is unfit to be brought as a sacrifice. See Lev. 22:27.
44 The word tammim literally means whole. This might be taken to mean not missing an organ. Hence I.E. comments that whole means without blemish.
45 The door of the tent of meeting was located in the courtyard of the tent of meeting.
46 Our verse is to be understood as follows: he shall bring it to the door of the tent of meeting before the Lord.
47 Hebrew, li-retozno. I.E. renders this as, of his own free will. Hence I.E.’s comment.
48 For Scripture reads yado (his hand).
49 Literally, the goat which is sent, the scapegoat which is sent into the wilderness on Yom Kippur. Scripture explicitly tells us that two hands are to be laid on the scapegoat. See Lev. 16:21.

50 The scapegoat is not treated as all other sacrifices. Its blood is not sprinkled on the altar, and none of its flesh is offered on the altar. It is sent away into the wilderness. Hence we cannot generalize from it.
51 Unlike other sacrifices, it requires the laying of two hands.
52 Whenever Scripture speaks of laying the hand it refers to the laying of two hands.
53 The body of the animal which serves as a sacrifice.
54 According to the sage, Rabbi Simeon bar Yochai, the burnt offering is brought to atone for improper thoughts. See Va-Yikrah Rabba 7:3.
55 Their names also explain the reason for these sacrifices.
56 Hebrew, ve-nirtzeh (literally, he will be favored). Hence I.E.’s comment.
57 Hebrew, le-khapper alav.
58 The table of showbread. The latter was placed in the northern part of the tabernacle.
59 Ve-shachat (and he shall kill) is in the singular.
60 Ve-zareku (and dash) is in the plural and thus refers to Aaron’s sons.
61 Which was inside the tent of meeting.
62 In order to assist him.
63 To perform the service described in our verse.
64 Kohanim.
65 For the verse speaks of sons of Aaron.

66 It is possible to read our verse as follows: And Aaron’s sons, the priests, shall lay the pieces, the head, and the suet. In other words, the pieces refers to the head and the suet. Hence I.E.’s comment.

67 Ha-rosh (literally, the head) is to be read as if written ve-ha-rosh (and the head). In other words, our verse is to be read as follows: And Aaron’s sons, the priests, shall lay the pieces, and the head, and the suet.
68 Scripture occasionally omits the connective vav. However, the text is to be understood as if it were present.
69 Pitidah is to be read as if written u-pitidah (and carnelian). See I.E. on Ex. 1:4 (Vol. 2, p. 6).

70 And cut it (the burnt offering) into its pieces. I.E. points out that a parallel verse literally reads, And he shall cut it into its pieces and its head (ve-et rosho) and its suet (v. 12). We thus see that its pieces refers to the carcass of the animal, not to its head and suet.
71 In this case a connective vav need not be placed before ha-rosh, for the meaning of our verse is: And Aaron’s sons, the priests, shall lay the pieces, with the head and the suet.
72 Where et has the meaning of with. See I.E. on Gen. 1:1 (Vol. 1, p. 27).
73 That the pieces do not include the head and the suet.
74 Ve-arekhu (shall lay) is a plural. It literally means, and they shall lay.
75 And it requires more than one person to handle it.
76 Which is a small animal.
77 Hebrew, ve-arakh, which is in the singular.
78 For only the kohen may perform this work.
79 All of it shall be offered as a burnt offering.

80 It is obviously related to the word menuchah (rest). See I.E. on Gen. 5:8 (Vol. 1, p. 118). He explains nicho’ach as meaning that the sacrifice assuages God’s anger, or that it causes a power from on high to rest on man.
81 In other words, yerakh which literally means side of, at times can mean beyond the side.
82 The northern part of Jerusalem. The verse literally reads, Even mount Zion, the side of the north.
83 Which was located on Mount Zion. See Ps. 48:13.
84 The side means on the outside, next to.
85 Which would indicate fully grown pigeons.
86 The word is not found again in Scripture.
87 The kohen “cuts with his nail against the nape of the neck of the fowl and cuts its neck until he reaches the organs and severs them” (Rashi). Also see Zevachim 65a; Chulin 21b.
88 Everybody knows that it refers to the crop.
89 The contents of the crop are filthy. Hence the term murah (crop).
90 There is an opinion that notzatah means its entrails (see Rashi). Hence I.E.’s comment.
91 Of the altar.
92 The altar (Weiser). The crop and its feathers were not placed on the altar, but outside of it.
93 Among the ashes, which were removed far away from the altar.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 2
chapter.p: 1. AND WHEN ANY ONE BRINGETH. The word nefesh (anyone) means a person. Scripture mentions nefesh1 because the meal offering is a free will offering and nefesh is called “willing.”2 Compare, And let a willing spirit uphold me (Ps. 51:14).3

FINE FLOUR. The meaning of solet (fine flour) is pure wheat flour. It is the same as that which is called samid in Arabic. Look, it is not fitting that a meal offering brought to the Most High come from anything than which nothing better exists.4
2. AND HE SHALL TAKE. Ve-kamatz (and he shall take) is related to the word li-kematzim (in heaps) (Gen. 41:47).5 Our sages explained that melo kumtzo means a handful.6 Their words are true.
OF THE FINE FLOUR THEREOF. A little of it, and so too of the oil. However, he shall burn all of the frankincense.

THE MEMORIAL-PART THEREOF. The alef of azkaratah (the memorial part thereof) is superfluous.7 Azkaratah is so called because the meal offering by the celebrant serves as a memorial before God.8 Others say that azkaratah means its scent. It is like scent of the incense.9 Compare, The scent thereof (zikhro) shall be as the wine of Lebanon (Hos. 14:8).
3. SHALL BE AARON’S AND HIS SONS’. And to all kohanim equally.10
4. UNLEAVENED CAKES. The word challot (cakes) means thick cakes.11 Others connect challot to the Rabbinic term chalilah (circle).12

5. A GRIDDLE. Machavat (griddle) refers to a plate covered with a plate.13 Its tav is in place of a heh,14 like the tav of ve-shavat (it shall return) in then it shall return to the prince (Ezek. 46:17).15

7. THE STEWING-PAN. Marcheshet (the stewing pan) means fried.16 Some connect the word marcheshet to rachash (speaks) in My heart speaks (Ps. 45:2).17 Marcheshet is so called because it emits sounds.18
10. AARON’S AND HIS SONS’. After him.19 That is, to the kohen who places it upon the fire, for Scripture states so with regard to the two meal offerings.20

11. LEAVEN. Se’or refers to leaven. It is the same case with honey. Some say that our verse speaks of date honey. The same is true whenever Scripture speaks of a land flowing with milk and honey. There is what appears to be proof of their opinion in the Book of Ezra.21

12. AS AN OFFERING OF FIRST-FRUITS YE MAY BRING THEM UNTO THE LORD. As the two wave-loaves of two tenth parts of an ephah which were waved before God on the festival of Shavu’ot (Lev. 23:17). The meaning of unto the Lord is, even though they are holy unto the Lord they are food for the kohen.
13. THE COVENANT OF THY GOD. God caused you to enter the covenant and made you swear that you would not offer anything which is unsalted and inedible, for that is an insult.22

14. AND IF THOU BRING A MEAL-OFFERING OF FIRSTFRUITS.23 Many say that the word im (if) indicates an obligation.24 I believe that there is no need for this explanation, for there is an obligation to bring the first25 of the grain26 and not the first grain. One who wishes to bring a meal offering from the first grain27 as a free will offering may do so.28
CORN IN THE EAR. Aviv (com in the ear) is so called because it is first.29 It is related to the word av (father).30

GROATS. The meaning of geres (groats) is known. It is close to being related to the word garesah (breaketh) in My soul breaketh (Ps. 119:20).31 The latter is so even though the word garesah is spelled with a samekh.32
FRESH EAR. The word karmel (fresh ear) is related to the word karmel (fresh ears) in and fresh ears of corn in his sack (II Kings 4:42).
chapter.ftnote: 1 Scripture here refers to a person by the term nefesh. However, in chapter 1, it refers to a person by the term adam (man). See Lev. 1:2. Hence I.E.’s comment.
2 Nefesh also means spirit.

3 Thus the deeper meaning of our verse is, when a willing spirit brings a free will offering unto the Lord. For another interpretation of why Scripture here employs the term nefesh and not adam see Rashi on verse 1.
4 In other words, it is unfit that a meal offering brought to the Most High come from anything but the best.
5 According to this interpretation, ve-kamatz (and he shall take) means and he shall gather.
6 See Menachot 9a, 18b.
7 According to this opinion azkaratah comes from the root zayin, kaf, resh. The alef serves no purpose.
8 In other words, azkaratah means the memorial part thereof. God recalls the celebrant because of his meal offering.
9 The portion of the meal offering offered on the altar is similar to the incense offered on the altar.
10 Unlike the meal offerings that are baked in the oven which belong to the priest who offers them (Lev. 7:9), a meal offering mingled with oil is shared by all the kohanim (Lev. 7:10) (Filwarg).
11 Thus challot matzot (unleavened cakes) means thick unleavened cakes.
12 They say that challot means rounded cakes. See Sukkah 5:6.
13 It refers to a pan with a cover.
14 A variant of machavah. Machavah comes from the root chet, bet, heh, meaning to hide. A machavah is a utensil in which the food is hidden (Weiser), i.e., covered.
15 The tav of ve-shavat is in place of a heh, for ve-shavat is a variant of veshavah.

16 Contra other commentaries, I.E. does not believe that marcheshet (stewing pan) describes a utensil. It refers to a type of meal offering. I.E. renders our clause: And if your offering be a fried meal offering (minchah marcheshet).
17 Translated according to I.E.
18 When an oil-saturated mixture is fried, it emits sounds.
19 The generations that followed Aaron.
20 The meal offering baked on a griddle and the one baked in an oven.

21 The reference is probably to II Chron. 31:5, viz., the children of Israel gave in abundance the first-fruits of corn, wine and oil, and honey, and all the increase of the field. The latter seems to place honey among the produce of the field. Others say that the reference is to Neh. 10:36.
22 To God.
23 Hebrew, bikkurim. To be understood here as the first grain.

24 They render and if thou bring a meal-offering of first-fruits as when you bring a meal offering of the first grain. See Rashi: “Im here has the meaning of ki (when), for this offering is not optional.” Rashi believes that our verse deals with the omer (measure) of barley offered on the second day of Passover. This offering was obligatory. It was offered from the very first of the harvest. See Lev. 23:9-14.
25 The very first.
27 From the first grain harvest.
28 However, he is not obligated to do so.
29 Aviv thus means the first grain.
30 The father comes before the son.
31 According to I.E. geres means broken grain. See Rashi: “geres means breaking or grinding.”
32 And the word geres is spelled with a sin.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 3
chapter.p: 1. PEACE-OFFERINGS. The term shelamim (peace offerings) is self-explanatory.1
4. BY THE LOINS. The meaning of the term kesalim (loins) is known. It is related to the word kesilehem2 (constellations thereof) in and the constellations thereof (Is. 13:10).3

HARD BY THE KIDNEYS. The term al (hard by) means with,4 as in And they came, both men with (al) women (Ex. 35:22).5 Kelayot (kidneys) are so called because they are the source of lust and sex. The word kelayot is related to the word kaletah (pineth) in My soul yearneth, yea, even pineth (Ps. 84:3).
9. THE FAT THEREOF, THE FAT TAIL ENTIRE. The meaning of chelbo ha-alyah temimah (the fat thereof, the fat tail entire) is, the fat as it is,6 for the tail is called fat.7

The Sadducees, as I will explain to you in the next Torah portion,8 err. The Gaon9 also errs, for he says that chelbo haalyah is to be interpreted as the fat thereof and the tail.10 The latter is contrary to the rules of grammar, for11 the phrase should have read chelbo ve-alyato (its fat and its tail) or hachelev ve-ha-alyah (and its tail and its fat).
THE RUMP-BONE. The meaning of atzeh (rump-bone) is known from its context. It has no brother.12 There is a commentator who far-fetchedly connected it to the word etz (tree).13
11. THE FOOD14 OF THE OFFERING MADE BY FIRE. I have previously explained that the meaning of lechem is food.15 It is found in reference to fruit16 and meat.17

12. AND IF HIS OFFERING BE A GOAT. Any animal classified as a goat, be it male or female,18 as is the case with a sheep.19 Scripture does not mention the fat tail with regard to the herd. It only mentions it with regard to the lamb because the tail of a goat or a bull is small. Furthermore, the lambs in the Land of Israel have a large tail.20 The latter is well known.21

16. ALL THE FAT IS THE LORD’S. This is a general statement. Now, since the fat and the blood belong to God, they are prohibited to you. I will expostulate at length on the phrase a perpetual statute in the next Torah portion.
chapter.ftnote: 1 It is related to the word shalom (peace). Unlike other sacrifices, shelamim are not offered for sin but rather for the continued peaceful existence of the celebrant. See I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 29:27.
2 According to I.E. the literal meaning of kesilehem is, their flanks.
3 According to I.E. the reference is to the stars that flank the heavenly north and south poles. This was the current knowledge of astronomy in those days. See I.E. on Is. 13:10.
4 Its usual meaning is on. Hence I.E.’s comment.
5 Translated according to I.E.
6 In its entirety.
7 In other words, the meaning of chelbo ha-alyah is, the fat thereof, that is, the tail.
8 The Torah portion Tzav. Literally, in the second portion.
9 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.
10 In other words, Scripture speaks of two organs.
11 According to Rabbi Saadiah Gaon’s interpretation.
12 The word is not found again in Scripture.
13 For the atzeh (rump-bone) is as hard as wood.
14 Hebrew, lechem.
15 It does not refer only to bread. See I.E. on Ex.16:4 (Vol. 2, p. 316).
16 See Jer. 11:19.
17 In our verse.
18 In other words, the term ez (goat) takes in both males and females.
19 Hebrew, keves. The term keves applies to both males and females. See verse 7.
20 A large fat tail.
21 See Sabbath 5:3.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 4
chapter.p: 2. IF ANY ONE SHALL SIN. By inadvertently transgressing one of the negative commandments, the penalty for which is excision1 or flogging [for a deliberate act].2
The word nefesh3 (any one) takes in Israelites and strangers,4 for it is so stated.5 Scripture then goes into detail.6 It begins with the kohen gadol, the anointed kohen.

3. TO BRING GUILT ON THE PEOPLE. The kohen gadol taught incorrectly and the people were guilty, all of them having acted inadvertently.7 On the other hand, the meaning of leashmat ha-am (to bring guilt on the people) might be, because of the guilt of all of the people.8 It9 is mentioned here10 because the kohen is the bearer of the Torah and he is very careful and holy unto God.11
FOR HIS SIN. Al chattato (for his sin) means because of his sin.12 Since the kohen gadol is great he must offer a bullock, which is the largest animal of all that are offered on the altar.

6. AND THE PRIEST SHALL DIP. The anointed kohen himself. You will find the reason for seven times in the Torah portion Va-Yar Balak (Num. 22:2-25:9).13 The kohen gadol sprinkles some of the blood of the sin offering in front of the veil of the sanctuary14 and on the incense altar15 because of his exalted status.16 The kohen gadol burns the entire bullock, aside from the various fats,17 outside [of the camp]18 because it is not a burnt offering.19
12. WHERE THE ASHES ARE POURED OUT. It should be burned in the place where the ashes of the altar are found.20

14. WHEN THE SIN WHEREIN THEY HAVE SINNED IS KNOWN. The same law,21 even though it is not mentioned,22 applies to the kohen gadol, for if the sin not be known to the kohen gadol, then he does not bring a sin offering. Others say that the kohen gadol shall bring this sacrifice23 every year because he may have sinned.24

Scripture mentions the sin…is known with regard to the whole congregation of Israel, for it is possible that the kohen will inform them. However, there is no one to inform the kohen; he informs himself.25 The sin offering of the congregation is the same as that of the kohen gadol in all details. The kohen gadol is thus equivalent to all of Israel.26

15. AND THE ELDERS OF THE CONGREGATION. The elders are the leaders. They will lay their hands27 on their behalf and on behalf of all of Israel, for it is impossible for all of Israel to place their hands.28
21. IT IS THE SIN-OFFERING. The bullock.29 If Israel errs and they do not do one of the positive commandments, then they shall bring a bullock as a burnt offering and a he-goat as a sin offering.30

22. WHEN A RULER SINNETH. The words are inverted.31 Our verse should be read as if written, when the sinner is the ruler.32 It is connected to that which is written above,33 that is, And if the whole congregation of Israel… (v. 13). Our verse, as it were, states, and if the one who sins is the ruler of a tribe or the ruler of a father’s house.

23. IF HIS SIN…BE KNOWN TO HIM.34 Scripture employs an abridged style.35 It is similar to the verse dealing with the kohen.36 Its meaning is, if the ruler knows on his own that he has sinned or someone else who has seen him37 makes it known to him.38

The following is the grammatical explanation of hoda elav (be known to him): Hoda (be known) is a verb39 in the perfect.40 Compare, ve-hetzar41 lekha (and he shall besiege thee) (Deut. 28:52). The one who informs is omitted.42 Compare, whom she bore43 (Num. 26:59).44

Rabbi Moses the Kohen says that hoda (be known) is a hofal,45 for the cholam and the shuruk interchange.46 Hoda follows the paradigm of hurad47 (was brought down) in And Joseph was brought down to Egypt (Gen. 39:1).

The ruler offers a he-goat as a sacrifice in keeping with The greyhound; the he-goat also (Prov. 30:31).48 The latter is in accordance with the interpretation of the Gaon in the Book of Proverbs. The offering consists of a male, in keeping with the status of the ruler. However, its blood is not brought inside of the sanctuary.49
The kohanim, as is stated in Scripture,50 eat of the ruler’s sin offering to atone for the ruler. The kohen gadol does not eat of his sin offering.51
27. OF THE COMMON PEOPLE. The reference is to all of Israel, the ordinary kohanim and the Levites.
AND BE GUILTY. Ashem (guilty) is a verb in the perfect. It is like zaken (was old) in when Isaac was old (Gen. 27:1).
28. A GOAT, A FEMALE. For his status is lower than that of the ruler.52
I will explain the meaning of ve-nislach lo (and he shall be forgiven) (v. 26) in the Torah portion Send Thou (Num. 13:1).53
32. AND IF HE BRING A LAMB. If he brings a sin offering from the lamb species then he shall bring a female, as in the case of the she-goat.54
[35. AS THE FAT OF THE LAMB IS TAKEN AWAY.] Scripture states the aforementioned because it wants to indicate that one is to offer the fat tail,55 for a she-goat has no fat tail.56
chapter.ftnote: 1 Such as eating leaven on Passover (Ex. 12: 15). There are thirty-six transgressions for which the penalty of excision is prescribed. They are listed in Keritot 1:1.
2 For such a transgression as eating food which is not kosher.
3 Literally, a person or a soul.
4 Non-Jews living in the Land of Israel. See notes on I.E. Lev. 13:3.
5 The term nefesh is used in reference to a stranger in Ex. 23:9. It is widely used in Scripture to refer to Israelites. See Ex. 12:15.
6 It goes on to describe the sin offerings to be brought by the various strata of society.
7 The people inadvertently sinned by following the wrong ruling of the kohen gadol.
8 The kohen gadol is responsible for the people’s sin. He did not sufficiently admonish the people.
9 The phrase le-ashmat ha-am (to bring guilt on the people). According to this interpretation our verse reads: If the appointed priest shall sin because of the people’s guilt.
10 After the word yechete (shall sin). In other words, le-ashmat ha-am (to bring guilt on the people) qualifies yechete (shall sin).
11 He himself would not sin inadvertently.
12 Al chattato (for his sin) literally means on his sin. Hence I.E.’s comment.
13 See I.E. on Num. 23:1, Vol 4, p. 191.
14 The veil (parokhet) separating the holy from the Holy of Holies.
15 Which stood in the holy.
16 In the case of other sin offerings the blood is not sprinkled in front of the veil and on the incense altar. Hence I.E.’s comment.
17 Which are burned on the altar. See verses 8 and 9.
18 Verses 11 and 12.
19 Hence, unlike the burnt offering, it is not burnt on the altar which stood in the temple courtyard. See Lev. 1:13.
20 In the place where the ashes of the altar are put.
21 A person shall bring a sin offering only after learning that he has sinned. The same law applies to the kohen gadol.
22 Scripture doesn’t state, “when their sin is known” in the law dealing with the kohen gadol.
23 A sin offering.
24 Hence Scripture does not state “when the sin wherein he sinned is known” with regard to the kohen gadol.
25 The kohen gadol realizes by himself that he has sinned.
26 Hence their sacrifices are equal.
27 On the head of the bullock.
28 On the head of the bullock.

29 The verse reads, chattat ha-kahal hu. Hu is in the masculine. Hence it refers to the bullock, not to the sin offering. Thus our text is to be understood as follows: The bullock is the sin offering of the assembly.

30 Our text tells us that if the congregation sins in error they then bring a bullock as a sin offering. However, Num. 15:22-24 tells us that if the congregation sins in error they shall bring a bullock as a burnt offering and a he-goat as a sin offering. Hence I.E. points out that our text deals with the violation of a negative precept while Numbers deals with the violation of a positive precept, for the text reads, and do any of the things which the Lord hath commanded not to be done while Num. 15:22 reads, and not observe all these commandments.
31 Our verse reads, asher nasi yechete (when a ruler sinneth).

32 In other words, our text should be interpreted as if written, asher yechete nasi. I.E. interprets thus because he believes that asher (when) is connected to the verb (yechete), not to the noun (nasi).
33 Hence our verse does not open with ve-im (and if) but with asher (the one who).
34 Hebrew, o hoda elav chattato (literally, or if someone made known to him his sin).
35 Or, indicates a second possibility. However, Scripture does not record the first possibility. Hence I.E. assumes that Scripture omits the first possibility. It must be supplied by the reader.
36 The kohen gadol. There too Scripture employs an abridged style. See I.E.’s first comment on verse 10.
37 Sin.
38 Our verse is to be interpreted as if written: The ruler realizes that he has sinned or if someone makes his sin known to him.
39 A hifil.
40 It is a variant of hodi’a (he made known).
41 Hetzar is a hifil. It is a variant of hetzir. The same is true of hoda, hodi’a.
42 The subject governing hoda is omitted. Scripture does not read, o hoda ish elav chattato.
43 Translated according to I.E.
44 Scripture does not identify who did the bearing.
45 A passive. In other words, hoda should be rendered, be known.
46 The usual form of the hofal for this word is huda. Hence I.E. notes that hoda is a variant of huda.
47 Which is a hofal.

48 The complete verse reads: The greyhound; the he-goat also; And the king, against whom there is no rising up. The verse speaks of those who walk haughtily. The he-goat walks with its head held high, as does the king. Hence a goat was chosen as the animal to be offered by the ruler (the king) as a sin offering.
49 In contrast to the blood of the bullock brought by the kohen gadol and the congregation.
50 See Lev. 6:19.
51 See I.E. on Lev. 6:16.
52 Hence the sinner brings a female goat, which is on a lower level than a he-goat.
53 See I.E. on Num. 14:19 (Vol. 4, p. 110).
54 When one brings a goat as a sin offering, he brings a she-goat. Similarly, when one chooses to bring a lamb as a sin offering he must bring a female.
55 When a lamb is offered.
56 Hence Scripture omits the law of the fat tail when it deals with the offering of a she-goat, which does not have a fat tail.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 5
chapter.p: 1. AND IF ANY ONE SIN, IN THAT HE HEARETH THE VOICE OF ADJURATION. Alah (adjuration) refers to a curse. Similarly alit (thou didst utter a curse)1 in about which thou didst utter a curse (Jud. 17:2). Scripture employs an abridged style.2 Scripture warns that the witness is obligated to testify, for if he does not testify then he is liable for punishment from God, for he bears his iniquity. If he forgets and does not testify and then reminds himself [then he brings a guilt offering].
2. OR IF ANY ONE TOUCH ANY UNCLEAN THING. [WHETHER IT BE THE CARCASS OF AN UNCLEAN BEAST.] The reference is to the carcass of any of the four mentioned,3 namely, the swine4 and his compatriots.5
OR THE CARCASS OF UNCLEAN CATTLE. Unclean for food such as horses or asses.6
The carcass of unclean swarming things refers to the carcass of the eight swarming things mentioned in Scripture.7
IBN EZRA
IT BEING HIDDEN FROM HIM. He learned of this8 afterwards.9

[3. OR IF HE TOUCH THE UNCLEANNESS OF MAN.] He touched a man that suffered a flux,10 or someone who was unclean because he touched a dead body,11 or a woman who suffered from a flux,12 or a menstruant.13
4. UTTER CLEARLY WITH AN OATH. Le-vatte visefatayim (utter clearly) means to utter with the lips.14

TO DO EVIL. To a guilty person,15 or, as the Gaon16 explains, to fast.17 Scripture mentions these sins18 because the violator is obligated to confess these sins. He is not obligated to confess before the kohen for other sins which consist of the violation of negative commandments.19 The sacrifice is the same.20
7. AND IF HIS MEANS21 SUFFICE NOT.22 For all manner of work is done by the hand. It is the means by which one acquires. The clause23 alludes to one who does not have the means.24

ONE FOR A SIN-OFFERING, AND THE OTHER FOR A BURNT-OFFERING. Rabbi Isaac25 says the reason that one bird is brought for a burnt offering is that an unseemly thought may have entered his mind because his means do not suffice.26 However, I believe that the bird brought as an offering corresponds to the organs of the sacrifice offered on the altar.27 The second bird is a sin offering, as the law requires.28
11. THE TENTH PART OF AN EPHAH. The amount of food a person eats in one day.29

15. COMMIT A TRESPASS. The reference is to something which covered the offender.30 Timol ma’al (commit a trespass) is related to the word me’il (garment).31 The reason why he shall bring a ram32 worth silver shekels33 is that he sinned against that which is sanctified to God. The minimum of the plural shekalim (shekels) is two.

16. HE SHALL MAKE RESTITUTION. He shall make restitution for sinning by using a holy object and add a fifth.34 This is a guilt offering brought by one who errs at first and then becomes cognizant of his sin.

17. AND IF ANY ONE SIN.35 And violates one of the negative commandments and does not know that what he did is prohibited,36 he shall bring a ram.37 Many believe38 that the ram is brought as a “doubt guilt offering.” He brings a ram if he does not know whether he violated the law or not.39 A sin offering is brought if he did not know that he sinned and then became aware of it. Observe,40 a sin offering is brought if he did not know that a certain act is prohibited until he was informed of it. A guilt offering is brought if he knew that it is prohibited but forgot, and then reminded himself. On the other hand, our verse might be speaking of a “doubt guilt offering.”41
19. HE IS CERTAINLY GUILTY BEFORE THE LORD. This explains why it is called a guilt offering. It is so called because he is guilty.42
21. AND COMMIT A TRESPASS AGAINST THE LORD. By violating one of the negative precepts governing the relationship between a man and his neighbor.43
IN A MATTER OF DEPOSIT.44 Partnership. He joined hands with him.
OR OF ROBBERY.45 Involving force. Compare, and plucked (va-yigzol)46 the spear out of the Egyptian’s hand (I Chron. 11:23).
OR HAVE OPPRESSED. In secret.47
HIS NEIGHBOR. Amito means his neighbor. It most probably means the one who is beside him.48

22. AND SWEAR TO A LIE. The meaning of ve-nishba al shaker (and swear to a lie) is, or swear to a lie49 regarding money that one seeks from him. The fact that Scripture states, or any thing about which he has sworn falsely (v. 24)50 is proof of this.
The heh of va-hennah (therein) is superfluous.51
24. IN FULL. Be-rosho (in full)52 means in itself,53 or its worth.
THE FIFTH PART. The minimum of a plural is two. Thus chamishitav54 (the fifth part) means two fifths. I will explain it later.55
IN THE DAY OF HIS BEING GUILTY. Its meaning is, in the day that he turns away from his guilt56 he shall bring a ram.

25. ACCORDING TO THY VALUATION. As the first one.57 Scripture adds fifths58 because this guilt offering is brought for a deliberate sin. There is an individual opinion that this guilt offering is also59 a “doubt-offering.”
26. TO BE GUILTY THEREBY. Ashmah (guilty) is a noun in the kal. Scripture employs it in place of the infinite.60
chapter.ftnote: 1 Alit is the verbal form of alah.
2 Before laying down the law regarding one who refuses to testify, it first should have stated that there is an obligation to bear witness (Filwarg).
3 The four beasts explicitly mentioned in Lev. 11:4-7.
5 The camel (Lev. 11:4), the rock-badger (Lev. 11:5), and the hare (Lev. 11:6).
6 These are not explicitly mentioned in the Torah.
8 That he was unclean.
9 After coming into contact with what is sacred.
10 Hebrew, zav. See Lev. 15:2.
11 See Num. 19:11.
12 See Lev. 15: 25.
13 See Lev. 15:19.
14 Sefatayim means lips. Hence I.E.’s comment.

15 To a person who is guilty of a capital crime or guilty of an offence that is punished by flogging. So Krinsky and Sarim. I.E. comments thus because a person would not be held to be violating an oath to harm an innocent man.
16 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.
17 In other words, to do evil means to do evil to himself. See Rashi.

18 The point is: Scripture stated earlier that if one sins, he has to bring a sin offering (Lev. 4:27-35). It now lists a number of sins, i.e., refusing to testify, breaking an oath, coming into contact with that which is sacred when one is unclean. It then goes on to say that one who violates the latter brings the same sacrifice as those mentioned earlier in Lev: 4:27-35. The question thus arises: Why list these sins when they are apparently dealt with in Lev. 4:27-35?
19 In other words, the sins alluded to in Lev. 4:27-35.
20 For the sins alluded to in Lev. 4:27-35 and for those mentioned in verses 1-4.
21 Hebrew, yado (literally, his hand).
22 Literally, and if his hand does not acquire. Hence I.E.’s comment.
23 And if his hand does not acquire.
24 To buy a lamb or a goat. In other words, And if his hand does not acquire means: And if his means do not suffice.
25 According to Weiser the reference is to Rabbi Isaac Gaon of Sura.
26 He might have been angry at God for his poverty. According to I.E. an olah, a burnt offering, is offered in atonement for improper thoughts. See I.E. on Lev. 1:4.
27 See Lev. 3:9,10; 14:5. The bird brought as a burnt offering takes the place of the organs of the lamb or goat brought to the altar.
28 For those who sin and repent.
30 The offender is compared to a person who covers himself with a garment which does not belong to him.
31 Thus, timol ma’al literally means to garment a garment that is, to cover oneself with a garment.
32 And not a lamb or goat, which is a less expensive offering.
33 Hebrew, shekalim.
34 A fifth of its value.
35 According to Lev. 4:27,28,32 when a person sins he brings a female lamb or a she-goat. However, according to our verse one who sins brings a ram. Hence the interpretations which follow.
36 And then learns that what he did was prohibited. However, if he knows that the act is prohibited but forgets the law and then reminds himself he brings a sin offering.
37 As a guilt offering.
38 This is the opinion of the rabbis. See Keritot 23a.

39 “This speaks of a person who is in doubt whether he has inadvertently committed an act of such a character as to be punishable with excision. For example, forbidden fat (chelev) and permitted fat (shuman) lay before him, and he believed that both were permissible fat and he ate one of them. Afterwards, however he was informed that one of these was forbidden fat, and he does not know whether he has eaten the forbidden fat. Such a person has to bring a guilt-offering in doubt” (Rashi).
40 According to the latter opinion (Krinsky).
41 In other words, if we accept the opinion that a sin offering is brought for ignorance of the law, then we still have two options regarding the guilt offering spoken of in our verse.
42 The offering is called a guilt offering because he is guilty before the Lord.
43 As Scripture goes on to explain.
44 Hebrew, tesumet yad (literally, a placing of the hand). Hence I.E.’s comment.
45 Hebrew, gazel.
46 Va-yigzol and gazel come from the same root.
47 Harming his neighbor secretly in any way (Krinsky).
48 I.E. connects the word amit (neighbor) to the word le-ummat (close by) (Ex. 25:27).
49 The vav prefaced to va-nishba means or, rather than and.
50 And then goes on to state that he must return the money regarding which he has sworn falsely.
51 Henneh is a variant of hen.
52 The word rosh literally means a head. Thus be-rosho literally means for its head.
53 Head is a metaphor for the entire body. It thus can be taken to mean the entire thing.
54 Chamishitav is a plural.

55 See I.E. on Num. 5:7 (Vol. 4, p. 35): “If he confesses on his own (then he adds a fifth part). However, if there are witnesses then he shall add two fifths. Those who transmitted the law say a fifth of a fifth. Their minds are greater than ours.”
56 When he repents.
57 The ram first mentioned in verse 15, i.e., a ram worth two shekalim. See I.E. on verse 15.
58 See I.E. on v. 24.
59 Like the offering spoken of in verse 17. This opinion apparently accepts that Scripture speaks of one who is not certain whether he swore falsely.
60 Le’eshom.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 6
chapter.p: 2. IT IS THAT WHICH GOETH UP. The burnt offering is called an olah1 because it is entirely consumed (olah) on the altar.2 Scripture here hints that the olah should not be offered at night but rather that it shall be on its firewood until the morning.3 The heh of mokedah (its firewood)4 is superfluous. On the other hand, moked and mokedah may be two nouns.5
AND THE FIRE OF THE ALTAR SHALL BE KEPT BURNING THEREBY.6 Not outside.
3. HIS LINEN GARMENT. The word middo means a garment.7 The wise men8 said that it is a garment in keeping with his size.9
UPON HIS FLESH. Flesh alludes to the genitals. Similarly an issue out of his flesh (Lev. 15:2).
WHERETO THE FIRE HATH CONSUMED. Which remains from what the fire consumes.
BESIDE THE ALTAR. Outside of the eastern side.10
5. AND THE FIRE UPON THE ALTAR SHALL BE KEPT BURNING THEREBY. Scripture repeats itself11 in order to add it shall not go out during the day.12
The meaning of ba-boker ba-boker is, every morning.13 The kohen shall first offer the burnt offering and then the organs14 of the peace offering.15
6. FIRE SHALL BE KEPT BURNING UPON THE ALTAR CONTINUALLY. This verse16 was written in order to add the word continually.

7. SHALL OFFER IT. Hakrev (shall offer) is an infinitive.17 The meaning of hakrev otah bene aharon is, the sons of Aaron shall offer it. This means that one of the sons of Aaron shall offer it. Scripture therefore reads, And he shall take up there-from (v. 8).18 This section19 adds to that which is written in the portion Va-Yikra.20
9. IT SHALL BE EATEN WITHOUT LEAVEN IN A HOLY PLACE. Note, Scripture adds two commandments.21 Every male (v. 11)22 is a third.23
[10. IT SHALL NOT BE BAKED WITH LEAVEN.]24 This is the principal rule regarding the Passover matzot.25
AS THE SIN-OFFERING, AND AS THE GUILT-OFFERING.26 So too the meal offering.27
11. WHATSOEVER TOUCHETH THEM SHALL BE HOLY. Whatever touches the meal offering, the sin offering, and the guilt offering shall be holy unto God.28
13. THIS IS THE OFFERING OF AARON. Or one of his sons who takes his place.

IN THE DAY WHEN…ANOINTED. When the anointing oil is poured upon his head. Some say that the bet of be-yom (in the day) is in place of a mem.29 Its meaning is, from the day that he is anointed he has to regularly bring his meal offering.30

14. WHEN IT IS SOAKED. Murbekhet (when it is soaked) has no brother.31 Some say it means soft.32 Others say that murbekhet means quickly. The tav33 of tevi’ennah (thou shalt bring it) is directed at Aaron.34 Similarly the tav of takriv (thou shalt offer).35 I believe that this is also true of the tav of tufine (in broken pieces).36 It means to fix.37 It has no neighbor.38 The ancients39 said that tufine is a combination of the two words, te’afeh and na (it shall be baked raw).40 Rabbi Jonah the grammarian41 says that tufine follows the paradigm of dukhifat (hoopoe) (Lev. 11:19).42 This is a distorted form.43
15. WHOLLY. The word kalil means wholly. It shall be wholly sacrificed unto God.
16. IT SHALL NOT BE EATEN. As all the meal offerings are, for how can a kohen eat his meal or sin offering.44 The place of the slaughter of all the sin offerings was in the north.45
18. IT IS MOST HOLY. It is like one of the other holy things.46

19. THE PRIEST THAT OFFERETH IT FOR SIN. Ha-kohen ha-mechatte (the priest that offereth it for sin) means the kohen who sprinkles the blood. Ha-kohen ha-mechatte is another way of saying the kohen that removes the sin of the sinner.47 Many of the commentaries say that ha-mechatte means who washes or cleans. The word techatteni (purge me) in Purge me with hyssop, and I shall be clean (Ps. 51:9) is similar.

20. WHATSOEVER SHALL TOUCH. Whatsoever shall touch the flesh of the sin offering will be holy unto God, and the kohen shall eat it. The portion of the kohen who sprinkles the blood of the sin offering is therefore48 like49 the portion of all his brothers.50

IS SPRINKLED. Rabbi Mosheh Ha-Kohen says that yizzeh (is sprinkled)51 is similar to the word yitteh52 (shall…bend) (Job 15:29).53 It is a kal. When the yod54 is vocalized with a pattach it is a hifil.55 The swallowed letter56 is a nun.57 We similarly find the word va-yiz (and…was sprinkled) in and some of her blood was sprinkled (II Kings 9:33) vocalized with a chirik, and vayaz with a pattach.58 However, the word natah (turned) is vocalized with a tzereh in the kal.59 We similarly find ve-yez nitzcham (and their lifeblood is dashed) (Is. 63:3).60 He explained it very well.61
The Lord commanded that the place where some of the blood of the sin offering fell on the garment be washed because the sin offering is holy.
[IN A HOLY PLACE.] The reference is to the courtyard of the tent of meeting, for there is a difference between holy and clean.62

THAT WHEREON IT WAS SPRINKLED.63 The word “place” or the word “or” is missing.64 It means: Or if someone shall sprinkle upon it, that is, upon the flesh, then the kohen shall wash the flesh and then eat it. On the other hand, its meaning might be, the place where the blood is sprinkled shall be washed. In this case the word beged (garment) is both masculine and feminine.65 The word yado (his hand) in even as his hand can afford (Lev. 14:31)66 is similar.67 The tav68 of tekhabbes (thou shalt wash) is directed to the kohen.69

21. WHEREIN IT IS SODDEN. Bushalah (sodden), morak (scoured), and shuttaf (rinsed) are all pu’als. Morak is vocalized with a cholam70 because of the resh which, except in a few places,71 does not receive a dagesh.72 Morak follows the paradigm of zorak (dashed)73 in was not dashed against him (Num. 19:13). Morak is related to the word mirku (furbish) in Furbish the spears (Jer. 46:4), for the mem of morak is a root letter.

[22. IT IS MOST HOLY.] Scripture states it is most holy with regard to every male74 because only the perfect may eat from a sin offering whose organs are offered and is brought for atonement for sins.75 Males are more perfect76 than females.77 Even a small child is called a male.78 A male who is thirteen years old [is considered an adult] as our fathers have transmitted.

23. AND NO SIN-OFFERING, WHEREOF ANY OF THE BLOOD IS BROUGHT INTO…THE HOLY PLACE. Note, the place of the “veil”79 is called holy,80 for the courtyard,81 even though it is holy, is not holy in comparison to the tent of meeting.82 Observe, the inside of the curtain is called holy in comparison to the tent of meeting. Compare, Herewith shall Aaron come into the holy place (Lev. 16:3).83
The sin offering spoken of in our verse is the sin offering of the kohen gadol or of the congregation.84
chapter.ftnote: 1 The word olah means goes up. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.

2 For another interpretation of the term olah, see I.E. on Lev 1:4. According to Meijler this interpretation complements the one on Lev. 1:4. That is, the olah goes up on the altar to atone for that which enters (goes up on) one’s mind.
3 For Scripture states that the olah shall remain on the firewood all night, not that it should be brought upon the firewood at night.
4 Mokedah is a variant of moked (fire). Hence I.E.’s interpretation. It should be noted that I.E. renders mokedah “fire” (firewood), not its fire (or firewood), for there is no mappik in the heh.
5 Both meaning firewood.
6 Hebrew, bo (on it). According to I.E. our clause should be rendered: And the fire of the altar shall be kept burning on it (the altar). Hence his interpretation.
7 Not his garment. In other words, the vav of middo is not a pronominal suffix. It is rather superfluous. See the word beno (son of) (Num. 24:3).
8 The sages of the Talmud.

9 See Yoma 23:2. The word middah means a measure. According to the rabbis middo means his measure. Also see Rashi: “This is what is elsewhere termed the ketonet; and why then is it here called middo? To intimate that it (the ketonet) must be made to his measure.”
10 Near the eastern side of the altar. See Lev. 1:16.
11 And the fire upon the altar shall be kept burning thereby repeats what was stated in verse 2.
12 Repetition indicates continuity.
13 Again, the repetition indicates continuity.
14 The organs which Scripture states are to be offered. See Lev. 3:3,4.
15 For our verse states, and he shall lay the burnt-offering in order upon it, and afterwards goes on to say, and shall make smoke thereon the fat of the peace-offerings.
16 Which once again states, fire shall be kept burning upon the altar.
17 Hakrev might be taken to be an imperative.
18 Since the reference is to one of the sons of Aaron, Scripture employs the singular in verse 8, And he shall take up there-from.
19 Verses 7-11, which deal with the laws of the meal offering.

21 Our verse contains two precepts not found in Lev. 2:1-16. The two commandments are: It must be eaten as unleavened bread; and it shall be eaten in a holy place, in the courtyard of the tent of meeting.
22 Only males may eat of the burnt offering.
23 Commandment added here.
24 Hebrew, lo te’afeh chametz. I.E. renders this as it shall not be baked as leavened bread.
25 The matzot eaten on Passover must be unleavened. So too the matzot made out of the meal offering.
26 Are holy.
27 So too is the meal offering holy.
28 The term “them” refers to the meal offering, the sin offering and the guilt offering. Any food which comes into contact with the aforementioned shall be considered as they are.
29 In other words, be-yom (in the day) should be interpreted as from the day.
30 This is the opinion of the rabbis. See Rashi.
31 The word is not found again in Scripture.
32 Murbekhet being a variant of murkhekhet.
33 The tav serves as a second person masculine imperfect prefix.
34 Mentioned in the previous verse.
35 Takriv is directed to Aaron.
36 It is an imperfect prefix directed at Aaron.
37 That is, bake. According to I.E. tufine means you shall bake. See Rashi.
38 The word is not found again in Scripture.
39 See Sifra on this verse.
40 It shall not be fully baked.
41 Rabbi Jonah ibn Janach.
42 According to Rabbi Jonah tufine comes from the root tav, peh, nun. See Sefer Ha-Rikmah, Vol. 1, p. 137, ed. by M. Wilinsky, Jerusalem, 1964.
43 Not all the words in this form (po’il) are vocalized with a cholem. See Sefer Ha-Rikmah, Ibid.
44 It is illogical.
45 See Lev. 1:11.

46 According to I.E. kodesh kodashim (it is most holy) does not mean it is most holy but is to be interpreted as if written, kodesh ke-ha-kodashim (holy like the holy; that is, it is one of the holy things).
47 The word mechatte literally means “removes sins.”

48 For the sprinkling “removes” the sin from the sinner. This comment relates to the previous verse. It is to be understood as follows: The kohen who sprinkles the blood removes the sin from the sinner…the portion of the kohen who sprinkles the blood is therefore equal to the portion of all the other kohanim. (Filwarg).
49 Is equal to.
50 The other kohanim. According to I.E. the kohen who sprinkles the blood of the sin offering receives half of its flesh. The remainder is shared by the other kohanim (Filwarg).
51 From the root nun, zayin, heh.
52 From the root nun, tet, heh.
53 It drops the nun in the imperfect and is similarly vocalized.
54 The yod prefixed to the word in the imperfect.
55 Literally, from the heavy [conjugation] yazzeh or yatteh.
56 The letter swallowed by the dagesh.
57 The first root letter. In other words, the nun of the root nun, zayin, heh is swallowed by the dagesh. Hence the word yizzeh.
58 The word appears both in the kal and the hifil in shortened forms. Va-yiz in place of va-yizzeh and va-yaz in place of va-yazzeh.
59 In the kal imperfect. Compare, yet (stretched) in va-yet moshe et yado (and Moses stretched forth his hand) (Ex. 10:22).
60 I.E.’s point is that the root nun, zayin, heh can be vocalized with a chirik or a tzereh in the kal imperfect.

61 We have followed the reading Vat. Ebr. 38. The reading in the Mikra’ot Gedolot is very difficult to explain and is apparently corrupt (see Filwarg, Weiser, Meijler, Krinsky). It reads, “However, the word natah (turned) in natah mareh el ha-kir is vocalized with a chirik. We find it vocalized with a tzereh in the kal. Compare, ve-yez in ve-yez nitzcham (and their lifeblood is dashed) (Is. 63:3), wherein ve-yez is in the kal. He [Rabbi Mosheh HaKohan] explained it very well.” There is no verse that reads, natah marehah el ha-kir. The above can only be explained by emending the text. For a proposed emendation, see Meijler.

62 A clean place is a place that is ritually clean. Thus if Scripture had read “in a clean place,” it could have referred to any place that is ritually clean. It would not necessarily have meant the courtyard of the tent of meeting.
63 Hebrew, asher yizzeh alehah, literally (that is sprinkled upon it).

64 So Krinsky. The verse literally reads: And when (asher) there is sprinkled of the blood thereof upon any garment, that (asher) it is sprinkled upon it, you shall wash in a holy place. The aforementioned is repetitious and ambiguous. I.E. suggests two possible interpretations. One, our verse is to be interpreted: And when (asher) there is sprinkled of the blood thereof upon any garment, or if one (asher) sprinkles upon it (the flesh of the sin offering), you shall wash it in a holy place. Two: And when (asher) there is sprinkled of the blood thereof upon any garment, the place where (makom asher) something is sprinkled upon it (the garment), you shall wash in a holy place.
65 The word beged (garment) is usually masculine. The word aleha (it) is feminine. Thus if “it” refers to beged (garment) then beged is also a feminine noun.
66 Translated according to I.E.

67 The word yad is treated as both masculine and feminine. It is treated as feminine in Lev. 13:21, for the noun governing it (tasig) is in the feminine. However, it is treated as masculine in Ex. 17:12, where Scripture employs a masculine adjective to describe the hands of Moses.
68 The tav of tekhabbes is a second person imperfect prefix.
69 In other words, the term thou in thou shalt wash is directed to the kohen.
70 Rather than with a kubbutz, as is the case in the pu’al.
71 The massorah records seven instances in Scripture when a dagesh is placed in the resh (Krinsky).
72 A dagesh is placed in the middle root letter in the pu’al. However, the resh does not receive a dagesh. Hence the vowel changes from a kubbutz to a cholam.
73 A pu’al.
74 Scripture states that the sin offering is most holy in verse 18. The question thus arises, Why repeat it again in our verse?
75 Scripture repeats it is most holy with regard to all male kohanim in order to teach us that only the “perfect” may eat from the sin offering because it is most holy.
76 I.E. believed that males are superior to females.
77 No female may eat from the sin offering.
78 In other words, a male under the age of 13 may eat of the flesh of a burnt offering.
79 The curtain (parokhet) separating the “holy” from the “most holy.” See Ex. 26:33.
80 The room containing the menorah, the table, and the altar of incense is called the holy.
81 The courtyard of the tent of meeting.

82 The room containing the menorah, the table, and the altar of incense is called the holy in comparison with the courtyard of the tent of meeting. It is not called holy in regard to the room containing the ark of the covenant.
83 The room containing the ark of the covenant.
84 For blood of a sin offering of a kohen gadol or of the congregation is brought into the tent of meeting. See Lev. 4:3-5; 13-16.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 7
chapter.p: 1. AND THIS IS THE LAW OF THE GUILT-OFFERING. I have previously1 explained to you the difference between a sin offering2 and a guilt offering.3 [There is a difference between the two] even though Scripture employs the term guilt when referring to a sin offering4 and the word sin when referring to a guilt offering.5 Scripture records this section6 because it wants to make mention of the fat,7 to which no reference is made when Scripture earlier records the law of the sin offering.8

8. ANY MAN’S BURNT-OFFERING. The word olat (burnt offering) is penultimately accented9 in accordance with the rules of Hebrew grammar.10 It is so accented because the word that follows11 has the accent on the first part of the word.
Scripture reads to himself even though it earlier stated even the priest12 because it wants to further explain that the skin not be given to another kohen.

9. AND ALL THAT IS DRESSED. The word na’asah (dressed) is an adjective13 in the feminine. It is like the word nirah (seen) in there was no stone seen (I Kings 6:18). The masculine form of the word is found in Now that which was prepared (na’aseh) (Neh. 5:18).
10. OR DRY. As in the case of the “descending” meal offering14 and a meal offering brought about because of jealousy.15
12. IF HE OFFER IT FOR A THANKSGIVING. Its meaning is, if he offers it because he wants to give thanks to God for escaping from some trouble.
UNLEAVENED CAKE.16 As many as he desires.17 However, he cannot bring fewer than two.18 The same applies to the unleavened wafers.19

SOAKED. I believe that the best interpretation of solet murbekhet (fine flour soaked) is chosen flour. The unleavened cakes20 and the wafers21 were baked. The cakes made from chosen flour were not so treated.22
13. WITH CAKES. The meaning of al challot is with cakes.23 Similarly And they came, both men and (al) women (Ex. 35:22).24
14. AND OF IT HE SHALL PRESENT ONE OUT OF EACH OFFERING. Note, there had to be a minimum of four unleavened cakes.25 However, in truth there were ten.26

15. SHALL BE EATEN ON THE DAY OF HIS OFFERING. The one who offers the sacrifice, his family, and all who are clean shall eat it, for the peace offerings are also holy27 even though they are lesser holy offerings.
16. A VOW. A vow uttered by the lips when in trouble.
OR A FREEWILL-OFFERING. His sprit moved him to bring a sacrifice to God, not because he had made a vow, or for thanksgiving.
ON THE DAY THAT HE OFFERETH HIS SACRIFICE. The word hakrivo is an infinitive28 in the hifil.
[AND ON THE MORROW.] On the morrow of that day.29

[THAT WHICH REMAINETH.] The vav of ve-ha-notar (that which remaineth)30 has the same meaning as an unaspirated fa in Arabic.31 The same applies to the vav in va-ya’azov (left) in left his servants (Ex. 9:21)32 and the vav in ve-ha-aretz (now the earth) in Now the earth was unformed and void (Gen. 1:2).33
17. SHALL BE BURNT WITH FIRE. Like the parts of a sacrifice which Scripture designates for burning. However, it should not be burned on the altar.

18. [NEITHER SHALL IT BE IMPUTED UNTO HIM THAT OFFERETH IT.] Its meaning is, since Scripture designates that specific parts of the sacrifice be offered to God, all that remains of the animal is holy. Similarly the stones of the altar.34 Since they are holy, it is unfit that anything that remains from them be used in a non-sacred way. Scripture therefore reads, of unhewn stones (Deut. 27:6).35

ABHORRED. The word piggul (abhorred) is to be rendered as the Aramaic translator does.36 Similarly the word piggulim (abominable things) in And broth of abominable things is in their vessels (Is. 65:4).

Some ask, “Since the sweet savor ascended,37 how can it not be accepted?”38 The answer is that it depends on his intention. According to the law, the peace offerings must be holy. However that which is abhorred is not holy.39 Furthermore,40 the celebrant’s gain41 disappears in his loss42 with regard to a peace offering. In the case of a vow offering, there is a new sin43 corresponding to the first44 if he does not fulfil his vow.45
SHALL BEAR HIS INIQUITY. His punishment.46 Scripture does not mention the punishment.47 One who is unclean and eats sacred flesh is punished with karet (excision).48

[20. HAVING HIS UNCLEANLINESS.] This means if his uncleanliness comes from his body, as in the case of a flux49 or a leper.50 Also because of uncleanliness caused by a nocturnal emission, as Scripture states, for he thought: Something51 hath befallen him52 (I Sam. 20:26). It also applies to uncleanliness that comes from contact with an outside source53 such as a dead body, or a living person who experienced a flux or is a leper, or an unclean beast which may not be eaten, or a detestable thing from among the fowl and that which swarms.54

A Sadducee55 once came to me and asked, “Does the Torah prohibit the fat tail?”56 I answered that it is true that the fat tail is called “fat” (chelev),57 for the Torah states, the fat thereof, the fat tail entire (Lev. 3:9). However, while our sages prohibited all fat, they permitted the fat tail.58

The Sadducee then replied, “Does not the Torah prohibit all fat? Indeed it is written, that ye shall eat neither fat nor blood (Lev. 3:17). The latter is preceded by Scripture’s statement, It shall be a perpetual statute throughout your generations (Ibid.).”

I once again answered him that this verse59 relates to the peace offering. Also, the clause It shall be a perpetual statute throughout your generations60 does not provide complete proof, for we see that Scripture states, And ye shall eat neither bread, nor parched corn, nor fresh ears, until this selfsame day, until ye have brought the offering of your God (Lev. 23:14).61 Now Scripture there writes, it is a statute for ever (Ibid.). Shall we then not eat bread in the Diaspora? For we have not brought the omer offering.62
He, on his part, replied, “Ye shall eat no fat, of ox, or sheep, or goat (v. 23).”63

I again answered that this verse too refers to a peace offering. For whosoever eateth the fat of the beast, of which men present an offering (v. 25) is proof, for the latter excludes the fat of all flesh which is not offered as a peace offering, that is, all secular meat.64 Scripture therefore states in our section, And the fat of that which dieth of itself, and the fat of that which is torn of beasts, may be used for any other service; but ye shall in no wise eat of it (v. 24). It is known65 that the flesh of that which dies of itself and that which is torn of beasts is prohibited. It is the flesh that is prohibited.66 Now since the fat67 is not offered on the altar, one might think that it is permitted. Hence Scripture warns,68 but ye shall in no wise eat of it.69 It is for this reason that Scripture does not mention the blood.70 This section71 was written in order to explain the punishment incurred by one who eats the fat of sacred flesh. The verse relating to any blood (v. 27) was similarly written to add that the blood of fowl is prohibited.72 The fat of fowl is therefore permitted.73 Scripture’s statement in the Book of Deuteronomy (Deut. 1:1)74 with regard to meat eaten out of desire, that is, non-sacred meat (Deut. 12:15-25), is total proof of what I say,75 for Scripture states that non-sacred meat may be eaten in its entirety.76 Only its blood is excluded in three places.77 Fat is totally unmentioned.78

The Sadducee’s eyes opened and he uttered an oath with his lips to the effect that he will never rely on his judgment when it comes to explaining the commandments. He will rely only on the tradition transmitted by the Pharisees.79
33. THE RIGHT THIGH. Is to be given to the kohen who sprinkles the blood, and the breast to all the kohanim.
35. THIS IS THE CONSECRATED PORTION. This is the reward of the consecration of Aaron or of the consecration of his sons. The word mishchat (consecrated portion) means leadership.80
36. IN THE DAY THAT THEY WERE ANOINTED. Be-yom (in the day) is to be rendered, from the day.81 Similarly ba-basar82 u-va-lachem (of the flesh and of the bread) (Lev. 8:32).
37. AND OF THE CONSECRATION-OFFERING. As written in the Torah portion And Thou Shalt Command (Ex. 27:20).

[38.] TO PRESENT THEIR OFFERINGS UNTO THE LORD, IN THE WILDERNESS OF SINAI. For Israel did not offer sacrifices until they came to Mount Sinai. I have previously shown you that the altar which Moses built after defeating Amalek was built in Horeb, which is Mount Sinai.83 Israel camped there for a year minus ten days.84 The latter is clearly stated in Scripture. They did not offer sacrifices in the wilderness, for the prophet clearly states, Did ye bring unto Me sacrifices and offerings in the wilderness forty years, O house of Israel? (Amos 5:25). Israel similarly only offered the Passover sacrifice in Egypt, and for a second time at Mount Sinai,85 for they had no cattle in the wilderness. They did not circumcise on the way after they journeyed from Mount Sinai. Most of them were thus uncircumcised.86 Joshua circumcised them87 so that they could partake of the Passover sacrifice.88
chapter.ftnote: 1 See I.E. on Lev. 5:17.
2 Hebrew, chattat.
3 Asham.
4 See Lev. 5:6, And he shall bring his forfeit (ashamo)…for his sin. Also Lev. 4:13, 14, And are guilty (ve-ashemu)…then the assembly shall offer…a sin-offering.
5 See Lev. 5:17,18, And if any one sin…And he shall bring a ram…for a guilt-offering.
6 The section dealing with the law of the guilt offering (verses 1-7).
7 Of the guilt offering.
8 In the previous Torah portion, Va-Yikra. There the Torah deals with sin and guilt offerings.
9 It is usually ultimately accented. Hence I.E.’s comment.
10 When a word that is ultimately accented is connected to a word that is penultimately accented, it too is penultimately accented.
11 Ish (man).
12 Our verse reads, even the priest shall have to himself. To himself appears redundant. Hence I.E.’s comment.
13 I.E. refers to participles as adjectives.
14 A meal offering substituted for an animal offering by someone of lesser means. See Lev. 5:11.
15 A meal offering brought by a woman suspected of adultery. See Num. 5:11-31.
16 Hebrew, challot (literally cakes).
17 He may offer as many cakes as he wishes.
18 For Scripture employs the plural.
19 Hebrew, rekike matzot.
20 The challot.
21 The rekike matzot.
22 According to the rabbis of the Talmud they were scalded with oil until they were saturated. See Menachot 76b.
23 In other words, the word al should be here rendered as with. The word al usually has the meaning of on. Hence I.E.’s comment.
24 Here too the word al has the meaning of with.

25 A minimum of four unleavened cakes is to be offered by the celebrant, for Scripture says, And…he shall present one out of each (of the four types of unleavened cakes mentioned in verse 12)…for a gift unto the Lord.
26 Of each kind of bread, and one of each was presented for a gift unto the Lord. This is the opinion of the rabbis in Menachot 77a.
27 Hence only those who are clean may eat of it.
28 With a pronominal suffix.
29 That he offered the sacrifice.
30 Literally, and that which remaineth.

31 It does not mean “and” but rather is a particle introducing the principal part of a sentence. In other words, ve-ha-notar is to be rendered, that which remaineth, not and that which remaineth. So too Rashi.
32 Va-ya’azov is to be rendered left, not and he left.
33 See I.E. on Gen. 1:2 (Vol. 1, p. 30) and the notes thereto.
34 The stones used in constructing the altar.

35 The stones used for building the altar were not to be hewn, because when stones are hewn the chips that fall might be employed for non-sacred purposes or might be cast into a filthy place. See I.E. on Ex. 20:22 (Vol. 2, pp. 443-445).
36 Onkelos renders piggul by merachak (removed).
37 When the sacrifice was first offered.
38 In other words, since the sacrifice was properly offered, how can it be disqualified three days later?
39 The slaughterer of the sacrifice disqualified the offering by intending during the slaughter to eat of the sacrifice on the third day. Thus the sacrifice never “ascended.” See Rashi.
40 Even if he did not disqualify the sacrifice by intending to eat of it on the third day when he slaughtered it.
41 For offering the sacrifice.
42 By eating the sacrifice after the proscribed time.
43 Not fulfilling his vow.
44 Eating the sacrifice after the proscribed time.
45 By bringing another animal.
46 According to I.E. the word avon (iniquity) at times has the meaning of punishment. See I.E. on Gen 4:18 (Vol. 1, p. 84).
47 For eating of the flesh of a sacrifice after the proscribed time.
48 In verse 20.
49 Hebrew, zav.
50 Hebrew, metzora.
51 A nocturnal emission.
52 And rendered him unclean.
53 Coming into contact with an outside unclean source.
55 A Karaite.
56 The fat of the tail (Hebrew, alyah).
57 Fat is proscribed by Jewish law.

58 This statement was disconcerting among Biblical commentaries, for according to the Talmud all fat is prohibited by the Torah (not the sages), and the violator incurs the penalty of karet. Nahmanides charged that Ibn Ezra’s position is more heretical than that of the Karaites. Luzzato claimed that I.E. did not really believe that fat (chelev) is permitted. He was merely playing devil’s advocate. However, Nahmanides correctly interpreted Ibn Ezra. I.E. held that biblically speaking only the fat of an animal actually offered on the altar is prohibited. Other fat is prohibited by the rabbis. See I.E. on Deut. 12:15. The importance of I.E.’s comment on this verse for understanding Ibn Ezra’s approach to the halakhah is discussed in the introduction to this volume.
60 This clause may be taken to imply that the fat of animals not sacrificed is prohibited, for throughout the generations implies even in a time when the sanctuary no longer exists.
61 The omer.
62 Thus for ever means as long as the sanctuary exits. Similarly a perpetual statute.
63 The Karaite assumed that this verse applies to all animals forever.
64 All non-sacrificed flesh.
65 From earlier Biblical passages. See Ex. 22:30.
66 Ex. 22:30 speaks only of the flesh. The latter may be taken to imply that the fat of carrion or of an animal that dies of itself is permitted.
67 Of an animal that dies or is torn by another animal.
68 In verse 24.
69 The fat (chelev) of an animal that dies or is torn by another animal.
70 In verse 24, for Scripture earlier prohibited the eating of blood.
71 Verses 20-25.
72 Otherwise there would be no need for this verse, for Scripture earlier prohibited the blood of animals.
73 Only the blood of fowl is spoken of in verse 27. Fat is not mentioned.
74 In other words, Scripture’s statement in Deuteronomy.
75 That only the fat of sacred meat is prohibited.
76 For there Scripture says that non-sacred meat may be eaten, as of the gazelle, and as of the hart (Deut. 12:15). The fat of the latter is permitted.
78 For it is permitted according to Torah law. However, the rabbis prohibited it.

79 One of the leitmotifs of I.E.’s commentary is that when it comes to religious practice we must rely on Rabbinic tradition. He offers the concession of the Karaite as proof of this position. See I.E.’s introduction (Vol. I, pp. 3-10; 18,19).
80 According to I.E. our verse should be explained, this is Aaron’s (or his sons’) reward for holding the office of leadership, i.e., kohen.

81 In other words, the bet of be-yom has the meaning of a mem. The priestly gifts mentioned in verse 34 were given to kohanim from the day that they commenced to minister. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
82 Here too the bet has the meaning of “from” (of), not “in.”
83 See I.E. on Ex 17:15 (Vol. 2, p. 341).

84 Israel came to Sinai on the first day of Sivan (Ex. 19:1). They left Sinai on the twentieth day of the following Iyyar (Num. 10:11). See I.E. on Ex. 19:1 (Vol. 1, p. 370); and on Num. 10:11 (Vol. 4, p. 70).
86 And were proscribed from offering the Passover sacrifice (Ex. 12:48).
87 After entering the Land of Israel.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 8
chapter.p: 2. AND THE BULLOCK OF THE SIN-OFFERING. The word chattat (sin offering) has a heh1 prefixed to it because the sin offering2 is mentioned earlier.3 The same applies to the heh prefixed to elim (rams) and matzot (unleavened bread).4
3. ALL THE CONGREGATION. The heads of the tribes and the elders.

[7.] AND BOUND IT UNTO HIM.5 The word va-yepod means and girded. Just as the golden plate (tzitz) (v. 9) is not the mitre (mitznefet) (Ibid.),6 so the Urim and the Thummim (v. 8) are not the stones of the breastplate (Ex. 28:15-21).7 Similarly, the Tablets were placed in the ark.8 Scripture therefore reads, And in the breastplate he put in the Urim and the Thummim (v. 8).
6. AND MOSES BROUGHT AARON. To the laver (kiyyor).9
AND WASHED THEM. By command.10
10. AND MOSES TOOK THE ANOINTING OIL. It means that Moses had taken the oil11 before the anointing of Aaron.12
13. AND MOSES BROUGHT AARON’S SONS. Scripture notes this a second time13 because it speaks at length.14 On the other hand, this means that when Moses brought Aaron’s sons he dressed them in tunics.15
The word va-yalbishem (and clothed them) is a verb that governs two actions.16
15. AND PURIFIED. I have previously explained this.17
AND SANCTIFIED IT. So that all the sins18 may be atoned upon it.

16. AND HE TOOK ALL THE FAT THAT WAS UPON THE INWARDS. Scripture earlier stated, the fat that covereth the inwards (Lev. 7:3) Another verse states, the fat that covereth the inwards, and all the fat that is upon the inwards (Lev. 3:3). Note, the fat that covereth [the inwards] is substantial.
