However, the fat that is upon the inwards consists of a little from here and there.19 That which covereth [the inwards] is also upon the inwards. Hence Scripture employed abridged terminology.20

17. WERE BURNT21 WITH FIRE. Some say by Moses himself.22 Others say by the command of Moses. They offer as proof, as the Lord commanded Moses (v. 21).23 However, this is no proof, for that is the style of the Hebrew language.24

22. AND THE OTHER RAM WAS PRESENTED, THE RAM OF CONSECRATION, AND AARON AND HIS SONS LAID (VA-YISMEKHU) THEIR HANDS. The first verse reads, and Aaron and his sons laid25 (ve-samakh) (v. 14).26 Note, contra a great grammarian who erred, there is no difference between ve-samakh27 aron u-vanav (and Aaron and his sons laid) (v. 14) and va-yismekhu aron u-vanav (and Aaron and his sons laid). The grammarian said that ve-samakh indicates that Aaron alone shall lay hands, and then his sons.28 Vesamekhu29 means, and they shall all lay together.

23. RIGHT EAR. Ha-yemanit (right) is similar to ha-penimit (inner).30 The meaning of al tenukh (upon the tip) and bohen (toe) will be explained in the section This Shall Be the Law (Lev. 14:2).31 Note, the blood32 atones for Aaron’s life. Similarly for it is the blood that maketh atonement by reason of the life (Lev. 17:11). This means the life in the blood shall atone.33 Life is thus offered for life.34 Then [Zipporah]…cast it35 at his36 feet (Ex. 4:25) has a similar explanation.37

26. ONE UNLEAVENED CAKE. The reference is to the one loaf (kikkar) of bread (Ex. 29:2s).38 It is possible that the term kikkar (loaf) refers to weight.39 It is not the same weight as that of a kikkar (talent) of gold or silver.40

AND PLACED THEM ON THE FAT. Scripture does not mention the lobe41 of the liver and the kidneys, for the lobe was small. The meaning of yoteret (lobe) is similar to the meaning of the word yitron (profit)42 in What profit hath man (Eccles. 1:3).43 The kidneys44 are offered with their fat,45 for Scripture would not refer to the kidneys as fat.46 Only the fat tail is fat.47
27. AND WAVED THEM. Moses waved Aaron and his sons48 as Aaron waved the Levites.49
31. BOIL THE FLESH. Aaron and his sons themselves were to boil the flesh, for and seethe its flesh (Ex. 29:31) is by command.50
32. AND THAT WHICH REMAINETH OF THE FLESH AND OF THE BREAD. Until the morning,51 for Scripture so states.52

33. HE SHALL CONSECRATE YOU. The word ketz (end) was omitted.53 Our verse should be read as if written, at the end of seven days.54 On the other hand, its meaning might be, for a period of seven days.55

Some say that And ye shall not go out…seven days56 indicates that they went out at night57 for their needs.58 However, I believe that they went out during the day and night for their needs.59 A great scholar60 said that they dug a pit61 in the courtyard of the tent of meeting.62 However, this is farfetched.63 Scripture states, And the children of Israel wept for Moses…thirty days (Deut. 34:8), as if there was no moment that they did not weep.64 Scripture clearly states that they shall sit at the door of the tent of meeting day and night (v. 35). Its meaning is that they shall not occupy themselves with any matter and they should not go to another place.65 Similarly neither shall he go out of the sanctuary (Lev. 21:12), as I will explain.66

34. AS HATH BEEN DONE THIS DAY.67 This means, as Moses did on this day, so God commanded to be done during the seven days of consecration. Scripture should have read, as I68 did.69 However, such is the style of the holy tongue.70 Compare, Thus shall Ezekiel he unto you71 (Ezek. 24:24); and Jephthah, and Samuel72 (I Sam. 12:11). The fact that Scripture states, So the Lord hath commanded to do (v. 34); And thus shall you do unto Aaron, and to his sons, according to all that I have commanded thee; seven days (Ex. 29:35)73 is proof of this.74 Furthermore, Scripture states, And every day75 shalt thou76 offer the bullock of sin-offering (Ex. 29:36).77 The latter is similar to two day by day,78 for a continual burnt-offering79(Num. 28:3).80 Scripture there writes, and thou81 shalt do the purification82 upon the altar…and thou shalt anoint it (Ibid.) every day until the end of the days of consecration.83 Furthermore, Scripture states, Seven days thou84 shalt make atonement for the altar (Ex. 29:37).85 It does not mention86 the two rams87 because Scripture employed an abridged style.88 Many are of the opinion that Moses was to offer a bullock of sin offering alone every day.89 I believe that the reason Scripture mentions the bullock90 is that the blood of the burnt offering ram was to be placed on Aaron and his sons,91 and the second ram’s flesh was to be eaten.92 However, the sin offering bullock was to consecrate the altar.93 Scripture clearly states, al hakippurim (beside the other offerings of atonement) (Ex. 29:36), the meaning of which is, for atonement.94
35. AND AT THE DOOR OF THE TENT OF MEETING SHALL YE ABIDE. This is stated once again95 in order to add, that ye die not.

I AM COMMANDED. Tzuvveti (I am commanded) is a pu’al. Some say that the meaning of for so I am commanded is identical to according to all that I have commanded thee96 (Ex. 29:35), even though Scripture does not state there that they are to abide at the front of the tent of meeting.97
chapter.ftnote: 1 Indicating the definite article.
2 Referred to in our verse.
4 The words elim (rams) and matzot (unleavened bread) have a heh prefixed to them because they refer to the rams and matzot mentioned in Ex. 29:1,2.
5 This comment appears to be misplaced.
6 It is clear from verse 9 that the golden plate (tzitz) and the mitre (mitznefet) are not one and the same, for the verse states, and upon the mitre…did he set the golden plate.
7 For Scripture states, And in the breastplate he put the Urim and the Thummim. See I.E. on Ex. 28:5, Vol 2, pp. 591-598.
8 The relation of the breastplate to the Urim and the Thummim was like that of the ark to the tablets; that is, both served as receptacles.
10 Moses commanded that they be washed, or he commanded them to wash themselves. The point is Moses did not personally wash them.
11 And anointed the tabernacle and its furniture.

12 Scripture tells of the dressing of Aaron in the priestly vestments in verses 7-9. I.E. assumes that Aaron was anointed as soon as the garments were placed upon him (see Ex. 40:15). The Torah then goes on to tell of the anointing of the tabernacle and its furniture in verses 10-12. It then tells of the dressing of Aaron’s sons (v. 13). However, Ex. 40:9-12 tells us that the anointing of the tabernacle took place before the anointing of Aaron. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
13 After stating this in verse 6.

14 About other things. In other words, after stating in verse 6 that Moses brought Aaron and his sons to the laver, Scripture drops Aaron’s sons and goes on to speak of Aaron and the tabernacle. Hence, now that it goes on to speak of Aaron’s sons, it once again mentions that Moses brought Aaron and his sons to the laver and goes on to say what followed then.
15 In other words, va-yakrev here does not mean and brought. Rather it means when he brought. In this case there is no repetition in our verse.
16 It is a hifil. Moses caused them to be dressed, and they were dressed.
17 See I.E. on Lev. 6:19.
18 Of Israel.
19 It is not part of the layer of fat that covers the inwards.
20 Our verse only speaks of the fat that was upon the inwards. The latter can be taken to refer to itself and also to the fat that covereth the inwards, for they are located in the same place.
21 Hebrew, saraf (literally, he burnt).
22 For Scripture reads, “he (Moses) burnt.”
23 If “he” in he burnt with fire referred to Moses, the verse would have ended with “as the Lord commanded him,” rather than with as the Lord commanded Moses.
24 Scripture often employs a proper noun in places where we expect it to use a pronoun.
25 Literally, and laid (va-yismokh) Aaron and his sons.
26 The question arises, Is there a difference in meaning between “and laid Aaron and his sons” and “Aaron and his sons laid.”
27 This appears to be an error. I.E. should read va-yismokh, for he is referring to verse 14. Va-samakh is the reading in Ex. 29:10; 19 where the laws of the consecration were first given.
28 Shall lay.
29 Or va-yismekhu (and they laid).
30 In form. Both forms are feminine ending in a yod tav rather than in a heh.
31 See I.E. on Lev. 14:14.
32 Which was dashed about the altar (v. 21). See Weiser and Krinsky.
33 Reading yekhapper as in Vat. Ebr. 38.
34 The life of the sacrifice atones for the life of the celebrant.
35 The bloody foreskin.
36 Moses’ feet.
37 The blood on the foreskin atoned for Moses. See I.E. on Ex. 4:25 (Vol. 2, p. 110).

38 Kikkar usually refers to leavened bread. Hence I.E. explains that Ex 29:3 is to be understood as the one loaf of unleavened bread. I.E. comments thus so that there be no contradiction between the description of the consecration service in our chapter and the one in Exodus.
39 In this case Ex. 29:23 is to be rendered, the one kikkar of (un)leavened bread. This interpretation assumes that the term loaf would not be used in reference to unleavened bread.
40 A talent of gold weighed more than a hundred pounds.
41 Hebrew, yoteret.
42 Or addition.
43 In other words, yoteret means the addition [to the liver].
44 Mentioned in verse 25.
45 Our verse states, and placed them on the fat. The fat takes in the fat that is upon the kidneys. The kidneys were offered along with their fat because they are attached to it.
46 For it does not consist of fat. I,.E.’s point is that the term “fat” in our verse does not directly refer to the kidneys.
47 Hence the term fat cannot refer to the kidneys.
48 In other words, “them” in our verse does not refer to the fat and other items mentioned in the previous verse.
49 When they were consecrated. See Num. 8:5-21.
50 And seethe its flesh means command that its flesh be seethed.
51 Shall be burned.

53 From the last clause in our verse. The latter reads, ki shivat yamim yemalle et yodkham (for he shall consecrate you seven days). The verse may be taken to read, for seven days shall consecrate you. Hence I.E.’s interpretation (Meijler).
54 In other words, ki shivat yamim yemalle et yedkhem means at the end of seven days you will be consecrated.
55 According to this interpretation the word zeman has been omitted from the last clause in our verse. In this case our verse reads, for you shall be consecrated for a period of seven days.
56 From the door of the tent of meeting.
57 For Scripture speaks only of days.
58 To take care of their natural needs.
59 For the Torah would not command them to postpone taking care of their natural needs (Weiser).
60 I.E. does not identify the scholar.
61 And relieved themselves in it.
62 They thus had no reason to leave the sanctuary to relieve themselves.
63 For they would not relieve themselves in the courtyard of the sanctuary.
64 In other words, Deut. 34:8 is hyperbolical, for they obviously did not weep every moment of the thirty days.
65 However, they may leave to take care of their bodily functions.
66 I.E. there notes that the high priest may leave the sanctuary for the purpose of observing a precept.
67 Literally, as he did this day.
68 Moses.
69 Rather than as he (Moses) did.
70 Biblical characters occasionally refer to themselves in the third person.
71 Ezekiel refers to himself in the third person.
72 Samuel refers to himself in the third person.
73 The complete verse reads: So the Lord hath commanded to do; And thus shall you do unto Aaron, and to his sons, according to all that I have commanded thee; seven days shalt thou consecrate them.
74 That “As he did this day” refers to Moses, for the verse states seven days shalt thou (Moses) consecrate them.
75 Hebrew, la-yom (literally, to the day).
76 Moses.
77 This is additional proof that Moses himself performed the consecration ritual during the seven days of consecration.
78 Hebrew, la-yom.
79 The phrase a continual burnt-offering indicates that the word la-yom, which precedes it, means daily. Thus the term la-yom in Ex. 29:36 is to be rendered every day.
80 In other words the meaning of la-yom in Ex. 29:35 is daily. We thus see that Moses offered the bullock of sin offering during the seven days of consecration.
81 Moses.
82 Hebrew, ve-chitteta, i.e. you will offer the sin-offering.
83 For the first part of the verse states, And every day shalt thou offer the bullock of sin-offering.
84 Moses.
85 That is, purification for the altar to consecrate it.
86 In Ex. 29:36. Ex. 29:36 states, and every day shalt thou offer the bullock of sin-offering. It omits the two rams. Hence it appears that Moses did not perform the entire consecration service.
87 One of which served as a sin offering and one as a “ram of consecration.” See Ex: 29:1, 15-34; Lev. 8:2, 18-29.
88 Actually, Moses offered these rams during the seven days of consecration.
89 For Scripture states, And every day shalt thou offer the bullock of sin-offering (Ex. 29:36). It does not mention the rams. This is the opinion of the Karaite Yefet (Krinsky).
90 Only in Ex. 29:36.

91 This comment presents a problem. It was the blood of the second ram, the ram of consecration, that was placed on Aaron and his sons. See Ex. 29:1921; Lev. 8:22,23. It is possible that I.E. erred, for I.E. wrote many of his comments without a text of Scripture before him and he didn’t always edit his works. On the other hand, it is possible that I.E. was of the opinion that the blood of both rams was placed on Aaron and his sons even though Scripture only mentions it with regard to the second ram. Weiser suggests that our reading is due to an error by a copyist. Rabbi Shemu’el Tzartza believes that “I believe, etc.” is a gloss that found its way into I.E.’s commentary.
93 The two rams are not mentioned in Ex. 29:36 because the latter speaks only of consecrating the altar.

94 I.E.’s point is that the bullock was offered on the altar to atone, i.e., to purify the altar in order to consecrate it, while the rams were part of the consecration ritual of Aaron and his sons. Hence Scripture did not speak of them in the verse which spoke of atoning on the altar.
95 In our verse after having been stated in verse 33.
96 In other words, according to all that I have commanded thee refers to the law of abiding at the door of the tent of meeting during the seven days of consecration.
97 During the seven days of consecration.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 9
chapter.p: 1. AND IT CAME TO PASS ON THE EIGHTH DAY. It would have appeared to us that the eighth day is the eighth day of Nisan, for the tabernacle was erected on the first day of the month.1 However, the transmitters of tradition2 said that the reference is to the first of Nisan.3 Moses erected and took apart the tabernacle on each one of the seven days of consecration4 to train and teach.5
THAT MOSES CALLED AARON AND HIS SONS. And they went out from the opening of the tent of meeting.6 On the other hand, the congregation entered the courtyard.7

2. A BULL-CALF.8 During the seven days of consecration a bullock and also a ram were offered for a burnt offering.9 Scripture does not mention whether the bull-calf was “of the year.”10 It appears to me that a bullock11 and a bull-calf12 are one and the same when the term “year”13 is unmentioned.14

3. WITHOUT BLEMISH. This refers to the bull-calf and the ram.15 The bullocks of consecration16 were to purify the altar. This bull-calf was to atone (le-khapper) for Aaron.17 I have already explained this word.18
A HE-GOAT FOR A SIN-OFFERING. For the congregation. Also [for the congregation] a calf that has not reached the age of a complete year,19 and a lamb for a burnt offering.
4. AND AN OX AND A RAM. Fully grown.20
AND A MEAL-OFFERING. Of fine flour for each and every one.21

[6. AND MOSES SAID.] Va-yomer mosheh (and Moses said) is to be understood in a manner similar to that of va-eshal otah (and I asked her) (Gen. 24:47). I have pointed out to you how the latter is to be interpreted.22 The meaning of our clause is that Moses had already said to them, This is the thing which the Lord commanded that ye should do, namely, that you offer a he-goat (v. 3), a calf (v. 3), a lamb (v. 3), and an ox and a ram (v. 4);23 then the glory of God will then appear to them. The latter refers to the fire that came forth from the Lord.24

7. AND MAKE ATONEMENT FOR THYSELF, AND FOR THE PEOPLE. There is a divine command that you make atonement for yourself and for all of the people. You will atone for yourself with a sin offering bullock. Afterwards you will atone for the congregation by offering the people’s sacrifice, for a person cannot atone for another unless he has been purified from all sin.
8. WHICH WAS FOR HIMSELF. It came from his own property. So too the bullock of the Day of Atonement.25
9. THE BLOOD. He poured out the blood which remained.
10. BUT THE FAT. Which covered the innards, which was upon the innards, and which was on the kidneys.26
12. AND…DELIVERED UNTO HIM The word va-yamtzi’u (and…delivered unto him) is related to the word matza (found). Aaron found the blood when it was needed.27
15. AND THE PEOPLE’S OFFERING WAS PRESENTED.28 On the altar.29
AND OFFERED IT FOR SIN, AS THE FIRST. This refers to the sin offering bull-calf.30 The meaning of va-yechattehu (and offered it for sin) is, to atone with it for the sin.31
20. AND THEY PUT THE FAT. With the kidneys and the lobe of the liver, as I have shown you.32
21. AND THE BREASTS. The breast of the ox and the breast of the ram.
AND THE RIGHT THIGH.33 From this one and that one.34 The word shok (thigh) is connected to the word ha-pe’ah (corner), or ha-tazad (side).35
22. AND AARON LIFTED UP HIS HANDS TOWARD36 THE PEOPLE. Toward them.37 From here our ancients transmitted to us the form taken by the “raising of the hands.”38

AND HE CAME DOWN. Va-yered (and he came down) is to be understood in accordance with what I have previously pointed out to you many times.39 It means that Aaron had already come down40 from offering the people’s sin offering, burnt offering, and peace offering. Scripture reads came down because the altar was three cubits in height.41 After this,42 Moses and Aaron came to the tent of meeting. It is likely that they came to pray that a fire would come forth. When they came out43 both of them blessed the people.

24. THE BURNT-OFFERING. The burnt offering of Aaron, the burnt offering of the people, and the continual burnt offering,44 for Scripture states, beside the burnt-offering of the morning (Num. 28:23).45
AND THE FAT. From the bull-calf and the ram of Aaron, and the he-goat, the ox, and the ram
THEY SHOUTED. Va-yaronnu (they shouted) means they raised their voices. Compare, rinnah (cry) in And there went a cry throughout the host (I Kings 22:36).
chapter.ftnote: 1 See Ex. 40:2.
2 The Rabbinic sages.
3 See Seder Olam 7:1.
4 See I.E. on Ex. 40:2 (Vol. 2, p. 754).
5 The kohanim how to do it.
6 The kohanim left the opening of the tent of meeting where they had to stay during the seven days of consecration (Lev. 8:35) and went into the camp of Israel to meet the elders (Filwarg).

7 On the other hand, the elders may have entered the temple courtyard to meet the kohanim. During the seven days of consecration the kohanim and the elders were separated. On the eighth day Moses spoke to them as a group. Hence the two possibilities offered by I.E. as to how they met.
8 Hebrew, egel ben bakar.
10 Hebrew, ben shanah, which means less than a year old. Scripture reads, egel ben bakar. It does not read, egel ben shanah (a calf of the year).
11 Hebrew, par.
12 Hebrew, egel.
13 That is, “of the year.”

14 In other words, the terms egel and par refer to a bull over the age of one. Thus the bull offered during the seven days of consecration and the one offered on the eighth day were similar. They were both over a year old.
15 Hence Scripture employs the plural temimim (without blemish).

17 For any sin or sins that Aaron may possibly have committed. Some interpret for making the golden calf (Weiser). See Sifra, “Let this calf come and atone for the making of the calf.” However, I.E. explicitly rejects this interpretation in Ex. 31:18 (Vol. 2, p. 656).
18 The meaning of le-khapper. See I.E. on Lev. 1:4, “Le-khapper alav: To serve as a ransom for the punishment due to him.”
19 For Scripture reads, bene shanah.
20 For Scripture reads, shor and ayil, not par and keves.
21 For each sacrifice. Scripture employs the singular minchah. Hence I.E.’s comment.
22 According to I.E. the meaning of va-eshal otah (and I asked her) is, I had already asked. See I.E. on Gen. 24:14 (Vol. 1, p. 236).

23 What is recorded in verse 6 occurred before that which is recorded in verse 5. In other words, Moses told the Israelites, This is the thing that the Lord commanded… before Israel brought that which Moses commanded before the tent of meeting.
24 See verses 23 and 24.
25 Offered by the kohen gadol. See Lev. 16:3.
26 See I.E. on Lev. 8:16.
27 In other words, va-yamtzi’u is a hifil, meaning, and they caused it to be found.
28 Hebrew, va-yakrev (literally, and he brought). Thus our clause literally reads, And he brought the people’s offering.

29 In other words, our clause tells us in general terms that Aaron brought the people’s offering on the altar. It then backtracks and describes the aforementioned in detail. Meijler suggests emending al to el. In this case I.E. reads, “to the altar.” In other words, Scripture first tells us that the people’s offering was brought to the altar and then goes on to tell us how Aaron and his sons dealt with it
30 In other words, as the first means as the first sin offering.
31 See I.E. on Lev. 6:19.
32 That Scripture is elliptical. See I.E. on verse 10 and on Lev. 8:26.
33 Hebrew, shok ha-yamin.
34 From the ox and the ram.

35 Our verse should be interpreted as if it read, shok ha-tzad ha-yamin or shok ha-pe’ah ha-yamin. In other words, shok ha-yamin is not to be rendered the right thigh, for ha-yamin (the right) is not an adjective describing shok (thigh). If ha-yamin (the right) were an adjective describing shok (thigh), our phrase would have read, ha-shok ha-yamin, rather than shok ha-yamin.
36 Hebrew, el (literally, to).

37 In other words, el ha-am means towards the people. We have followed the reading in Vat. Ebr. 38. The Mikra’ot Gedolot editions of I.E. read, ra’a nikhecham. The word ra’a has not been explained. It appears to be a copyist’s error. See Filwarg and Weiser.
38 According to the sages we learn here that the kohanim lift their hands when bestowing the priestly benediction. See Sotah 38a.
39 That the vav often introduces the pluperfect. See I.E. on verse 6.
40 Before blessing the people.
42 After the offering of the sacrifices and the blessing.
43 Out of the tent of meeting.
44 Hebrew, olat tamid.

45 The full verse reads, Ye shall offer these (the festival offerings) beside the burnt-offering of the morning, which is for a continual burnt-offering. Hence the burnt offering is to be offered every day. Thus the burnt offering in our verse also includes the continual burnt offering.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 10
chapter.p: 1. EACH OF THEM HIS CENSER.1 Each man took his firepan.2 I believe that this event also took place on the eighth day.3 Behold, this day have they offered their sin-offering (v. 19)4 is proof of this.
AND PUT FIRE THEREIN. Not from the fire that came forth from the Lord.5 This is the meaning of strange fire.
[WHICH HE HAD NOT COMMANDED THEM.] They acted on their own and were not commanded to burn incense and certainly not to employ a strange fire.
2. AND THEY DIED BEFORE THE LORD. They thought that they were doing something favorable before Him.6

3. THIS IS THAT THE LORD SPOKE. God has previously told me that He will demonstrate His holiness through those who are close to Him.7 Our verse is similar in meaning to You only have I known8 (Amos 3:2). I will be exalted when I show My sanctity through those who are close to Me. I will then be glorified before all the people, and they will fear me.

4. CARRY YOUR BRETHREN FROM BEFORE THE SANCTUARY. Some say9 that the incense was before the altar of the burnt offering10 and the Levites entered there.11 Others say12 that the incense was on the altar of incense13 and Moses took them out of the tent of meeting.14
FROM BEFORE THE SANCTUARY. The reference is to the courtyard. The latter, as I have explained, is referred to as the sanctuary, in contrast to the camp.15
6. LET NOT THE HAIR OF YOUR HEADS GO LOOSE. Some say that tifra’u (go loose) means to let the hair grow long.

REND. The word tifromu means rend. Actually the word tifra’u (go loose) is related to the word faru’a (go loose)16 in his clothes shall be rent, and the hair of his head shall go loose (Lev. 13:45).17 Many say that it means18 covered.19 Others say that it means uncovered.20 The words of tradition are true.21

THAT YE DIE NOT. The word ve-lo (that…not) is to be read as if written twice. Compare, And I have not learned wisdom (Prov. 30:3).22 Our verse is to be understood as follows: and that He be not wroth with all the congregation,23 for you will atone for them.
[BUT LET YOUR BRETHREN, THE WHOLE HOUSE OF ISRAEL.] You will find the meaning of this alluded to in the Torah portion Behold, I Set (Deut. 11:26).24

8. AND THE LORD SPOKE UNTO AARON. For Aaron was a prophet.25 Others say through Moses,26 as in And the Lord spoke again unto Ahaz (Is. 7:10).27 God cautioned Aaron and his sons to keep the law28 so that they do not die as Aaron’s oldest sons died.

9. NOR STRONG DRINK. Made from any kind of wheat, honey, or dates, for wine destroys the reason of the one who imbibes it and he confuses things. Hence Scripture states, And that ye may put difference (v. 10).29 Since you are a kohen gadol you will differentiate30 between a holy place and a common place. The word chol (common) is related to the word chillul (profaned).31 It is possible that between the holy and the common means between a holy day and a common day.

10. AND BETWEEN THE UNCLEAN AND THE CLEAN. Among cattle and things that swarm in the water and that fly. Therefore the section opening with the words These are the living things (Lev. 10:11), and then the sections dealing with the woman who gives birth (Lev. 12:1-8) and the leprosy that is found in humans (Lev. 13:1-46), on garments (Lev. 13:47-59) and in houses (Lev. 14:33-53); one who experiences a seminal emission (Lev. 15:16-18); a male or female who experiences a flux (Lev. 15:1-15, 25-33); and a menstruant (Lev. 15:19-24) follow this section. This is the meaning of and between the unclean and the clean.
11. AND THAT YE MAY TEACH THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. The rest of the commandments. Similarly and do according to all that the priests…shall teach you (Deut. 24:8).

12. TAKE THE MEAL-OFFERING. No one aside from those who are holy are fit to eat that which remains from the meal offering after part of it has been burned in honor of God.32 You shall begin to eat the portion which God has given you, to always take of God’s fire-offerings;33 this means34 all meal offerings, part of which was burned in honor of God.

[14. IN A CLEAN PLACE.] Even though it is outside the courtyard. The breast and the thigh shall be eaten by males and females, for Scripture clearly states, every one that is clean in thy house may eat thereof (Num. 18:11). Similarly slaves bought by money and born in the house,35 and a widow36 who returned to her father’s house.37 As you now eat the breast and the thigh, so shall the law be that you take these portions from all the sacrifices of peace offerings.
16. WAS BURNT. Soraf (was burnt) is a pu’al.38 Compare, morak39 (sodden) in it shall be scoured, and rinsed in water (Lev. 6:21).

17. IN THE PLACE OF THE SANCTUARY. At the opening of the tent of meeting, for this is clearly stated in Scripture.40 And He hath given it you [to bear the iniquity of the congregation], for when you eat the sin offering God will bear the iniquity of the congregation.41 Or its meaning42 is, you will bear the iniquity of the congregation; that is, the sins of the congregation will be forgiven through you.43 Hence Scripture states, to make atonement.44

18. BEHOLD, THE BLOOD OF IT WAS NOT BROUGHT INTO THE SANCTUARY WITHIN. Like the bullock brought by the kohen and the congregation for violation of any of the commandments.45 Should one ask, “Look, the bullock of the sin offering46 was burned47 and its blood was not brought into the inner sanctuary,48 the reference being to the place of the curtain and the golden altar?” Know that the sin offering bullock49 was to purify the altar,50 the he-goat sin offering51 was to atone for the people, and the flesh of the sin offering was for the kohen.52
YE SHOULD CERTAINLY HAVE EATEN IT. Akhol tokhelu53 is to be rendered, ye should have certainly eaten it.

[19.] There are grammarians who say that the interrogative heh is not followed by a dagesh when the letter54 is vocalized with one of the seven “kings.”55 The letter following an interrogative heh is found with a dagesh only when it has a mobile sheva beneath it. The heh56 is vocalized with a pattach because two mobile shevas cannot come back to back.57 Now, since they58 found that the yod of ha-yitav (would it have been well pleasing) has a dagesh in it, they said that the heh of ha-yitav is the heh which indicates the direct object,59 like the heh of ha-shavah (that came) in that came back with Naomi (Ruth 2:6); the heh in ha-nimtze’u foh (that are found here) (I Chron. 29:17); the heh in ha-hullalah (the renowned) in The renowned city (Ezek. 26:17). These hehs are in place of the word asher (that). This is the meaning of ha-yitav (would it have been well pleasing).60 They further said that ve-akhalti (and if I had eaten) is a verb in the perfect.61 If the word were an imperfect it would have been ultimately accented like the words vedibbarti (I have also spoken)62 in I have also spoken unto the prophets (Hosea 12:11) and ve-dibbarti (and I will speak) in And I will speak with thee (Ex. 25:22).

The meaning of the first half of our verse is, my sons who were burned today offered their sin offering and their burnt offering, for the bull-calf and the ram63 were offered on behalf of Aaron and his sons.64

AND THERE HAVE BEFALLEN ME SUCH THINGS AS THESE. The reference is to troubles or anxiety because of the death of the sons. It was because of this that I was not able to eat the entire sin offering, but I ate enough of it to find favor in the eyes of God, that is, an amount which is enough to fulfill my obligation.65

However, in the opinion of the transmitters of tradition66 the heh of ha-yitav is an interrogative heh67 and the word is irregular.68 It is also irregular according to the explanation which I mentioned above,69 for we do not find in all of Scripture the definite article heh prefixed to a verb in the imperfect.70

The meaning of ve-akhalti chattat is to be interpreted as, and if I had eaten the sin offering.71 We also find words in the imperfect that are penultimately accented.72 Compare, ve-ganavti (and steal)73 in lest I be poor, and steal (Prov. 30:9). The meaning of our clause74 is, I was mourning, and a mourner does not eat of the sin offering. Its meaning is similar to I have not eaten thereof75 in my mourning (Deut. 26:14).76
chapter.ftnote: 1 Hebrew, ish machtato (literally, a man his censer).

2 In other words, ish machtato is to be interpreted as if written kol ish machtato (each man his censer). Our verse literally reads, And…the sons of Aaron took a man his censer. Hence I.E.’s comment that our verse is to be interpreted, And…the sons of Aaron took each man his firepan.
3 See I.E. on Lev. 9:1.
4 The reference being to the sin offering mentioned in Lev. 9:2. See I.E. on verse 19.
5 See Lev. 9:24.
6 Before the Lord means serving God. Their intention was to serve God.
7 However, Moses did not record this communication (Krinsky). See Rashi for another interpretation.
8 The complete verse reads, You only have I known of all the families of the earth; Therefore I will visit upon you all your iniquities.
9 This is the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer. See the Sifra on this verse.
10 Which stood in the courtyard of sanctuary.
11 The Levites were permitted to enter there. They were not permitted to enter the sanctuary itself.
12 This is the opinion of Rabbi Akiba. See the Sifra on this verse.
13 Which was in the sanctuary.

14 This is the reading of the Mikra’ot Gedolot and Vat. Ebr. 38. Krinsky reads u-misham (and from there) in place of u-moshah (and Moses). According to this reading the Levites removed the bodies of Nadab and Abihu from the tabernacle. See Rabbi Akiba in the Sifra, “They cast a spear of iron [from the courtyard, and speared them.] They [then] dragged them and took them outside.”
15 See I.E. on Lev. 6:23.
16 Both words come from the same root.
17 I.E. offers proof for the opinion which he quotes at the opening of this verse. He does so because he is about to offer differing opinions.
18 The meaning of faru’a and by extension tifra’u.
19 See the Sifra on Lev. 13:45.
20 This is the opinion of Rabbi Akiba. See the Sifra on Lev. 13:45.

21 That the meaning of tifra’u is to grow the hair long. I.E.’s point is that there is no connection between tifra’u in our verse and faru’a in Lev. 13:45. Hence the difference of opinion regarding the latter has no bearing on the definition of tifra’u (Meijler).

22 Prov. 30:3 literally reads: “I have not learned wisdom, I have knowledge of the Holy One.” According to I.E. this should be read, I have not (lo) learned wisdom, I have no (lo) knowledge of the Holy One.

23 Our verse reads, ve’al kol ha-edah yiktzof. The latter literally reads, and that He be wroth with all the congregation. That makes no sense in this context. Hence I.E. suggests that the word lo be inserted into the clause and that it be read as if written: and that He be not (lo) wroth with all the congregation.
24 It is not clear what I.E. is referring to. Weiser suggests that I.E. intended to allude to our verse in his comments on the Torah portion Re’eh, but did not follow through on his intention.
26 God spoke to Aaron through the agency of Moses.
27 God spoke to Ahaz through the agency of Isaiah. See Is. 7:3-10.
28 Regarding drinking wine or strong drink.

29 Since you must differentiate between the holy and the profane you must be able to think clearly. In most of the editions, “hence” opens a new comment on verse 10. However, Sarim’s edition has the comment as a continuation of verse 9. We have followed the latter.
30 In other words, u-le-havdil, which is an infinitive that literally means and to put a difference, is to be rendered, and you shall differentiate (utavdil) in this context.
31 The word chol means profane. Thus our clause is to be rendered, between the holy and the profane.
32 Hence Moses told Aaron and his sons to eat the meal offering.
33 I.E.’s interpretation of verse 13.
34 The meaning of, of God’s fire-offerings
35 Of their master.
36 Who was married to an Israelite or a Levite.
37 Slaves bought by money or born in the house of their master (the kohen) and a widow who returns to her kohen father’s house may eat the breast and the thigh.
38 Soraf is vocalized with a cholam. Pu’als are usually vocalized with a kubbutz. Hence I.E.’s comment.
39 Morak is a pu’al. Morak, like soraf, is vocalized with a cholam.
40 See Lev. 6:19.

41 In other words, to bear the iniquity of the congregation refers to God. The verse is to be interpreted, And He hath given it to you so that God will bear (forgive) the iniquity of the congregation.
42 The meaning of to bear the iniquity of the congregation.
43 In this case, to bear the iniquity of the congregation refers to the kohanim.
44 To make atonement explains the meaning of to bear the iniquity of the congregation; that is, to bear the iniquity means to make atonement for.
45 Which were burned in a clean place outside of the camp. See Lev. 4:1-21.
46 Which was offered during the seven days of consecration. See Lev. 8:14-17.
47 Outside of the camp and its flesh was not eaten.

48 As was the blood of the sin offering brought by the kohen gadol and the congregation, and yet it was not eaten. The point is, Moses implies that if the blood of a sin offering is not brought into the sanctuary, then the flesh of the sin offering must be eaten. However, the case of the sin offering offered during the seven days of consecration shows that this is not necessarily so.
49 Offered during the seven days of consecration.
50 See Lev. 8:15. It did not atone for anyone’s sin. There was no celebrant whose transgression was to be atoned for by the kohanim consuming its flesh. Hence its flesh was burned.
51 Which was brought on the eighth day. See Lev. 9:3.
52 When the kohen eats the sin offering the sins of the people are forgiven. Hence Moses was angry that the flesh was burned and not eaten.
53 Akhol tokhelu literally means you will certainly eat it. Hence I.E.’s comment.
54 Following the interrogative heh.
55 Vowels. The reference is to the kamatz, pattach, segol, tzereh, cholam, shuruk, and chirik (Weiser).
56 The interrogative heh.

57 The interrogative heh is vocalized with a chataf pattach. However, when the interrogative heh precedes a letter vocalized by a sheva na (a mobile sheva), it is vocalized with a pattach, for the chataf pattach has a sheva na within it and two mobile shevas cannot follow each other.
58 The grammarians.
59 In other words, the heh of ha-yitav is not an interrogative heh.
60 The meaning of ha-yitav is, that finds favor.

61 Meaning I ate. It is not an imperfect, meaning and I will eat. According to I.E. the second part of our verse is to be rendered, and I ate (ve-akhalti) an amount that finds favor (ha-yitav) in the eyes of God.
62 Literally, I will speak.
63 Offered on the eighth day. See Lev. 9:2.
64 Hence our verse speaks of their sin offering and their burnt offering.
65 And had the rest burned. According to the rabbis whenever the Torah requires one to eat something, the minimum amount that is to be consumed is the size of an olive.
66 The sages of the Talmud.

67 According to the sages ha-yitav is to be rendered, would it have been well pleasing. See Zevachim 101a. Also see Rashi. The sages render the second half of our verse, and if I had eaten (ve-akhalti) the sin-offering to-day, would it have been well-pleasing (ha-yitav) in the sight of the Lord?
68 For it has a dagesh in the letter following the interrogative heh.
69 That of the grammarians who maintain that the heh of ha-yitav is a definite article.
70 Yitav is an imperfect.
71 Ve-akhalti is a perfect, as it is penultimately accented. According to this interpretation ve-akhalti is to be rendered, and if I would have eaten.

72 Even though such words are usually ultimately accented. Thus ve-akhalti can be taken to be an imperfect. According to this interpretation ve-akhalti does not have to be rendered, and if I had eaten, but rather, if I would eat.
73 Ve-ganavti is an imperfect. It is penultimately accented.
74 The meaning of and if I had eaten (ve-akhalti) the sin-offering to-day would it have been well-pleasing (ha-yitav) in the sight of the Lord?
75 Of the tithe.
76 For a mourner is prohibited from eating anything which is holy.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 11
chapter.p: 1. AND THE LORD SPOKE UNTO MOSES AND TO AARON. For Aaron is the kohen who teaches and who differentiates between the unclean and the clean.1
3. PARTETH. Mafreset (parteth) is an adjective.2 Similarly makrin mafris3 (horned and hoofed) (Ps. 69:32).4 It means all animals which are described as having a hoof.
AND IS WHOLLY CLOVEN-FOOTED. Shosa’at (wholly cloven) is an adjective. The meaning of ve-shosa’at shesa perasot (and is wholly cloven-footed) is, whose hoofs are cloven.

AND CHEWETH THE CUD. Gerah (cud) is related to the word garon (throat).5 The word ma’alat6 (cheweth) is a verb in the present.7 Scripture mentions the camel (v. 4), the rockbadger (v. 5), the hare (v. 6), and the swine (v. 7) because each one has one sign.8 It is the style of Scripture to mention the male of each species because the masculine also takes in the feminine.9 Scripture mentions the arnevet (hare).10 Some say that it does so because the male is not found among them.11 There are others who say that the male turns into a female and vice versa. However, the first interpretation appeals to me.

8. AND THEIR CARCASSES YE SHALL NOT TOUCH. Scripture does not mention that one who touches their carcasses shall be unclean until evening.12 However, we know this from tradition. Now, the one who deliberately touches their carcass incurs the penalty of flogging, for he violated a negative commandment.13

[9. IN THE SEAS.] If we pursue the literal meaning of the verse without the tradition of the rabbis, then the fish that are found in the lakes (agammim) are prohibited, for Scripture specifies the seas and the rivers.
FINS AND SCALES. Snappir ve-kaskeset (fins and scales) is to be rendered as the Aramaic translator does.14

10. OF ALL THAT SWARM IN THE WATERS. They are the small creatures that were created from the water.15 The waters contain living creatures that are both male and female.16 After stating they are a detestable thing unto you Scripture goes on to say, and they shall be a detestable thing unto you (v. 11) in order to explain in what way they shall be detestable namely, ye shall not eat of their flesh (Ibid.). Note, fish are called flesh.17 However, what the sages of blessed memory said with regard to vows18 refers to the custom of their generations.19 Scripture adds, Whatsoever hath no fins nor scales to include all waters, for Scripture earlier mentioned only the seas and the rivers.

13. THE GREAT VULTURE The meaning of nesher (the great vulture) is known. This is also the bird which has the same name in the language of the Ishmaelites.20 There is something of a proof that this is the case, because the two languages are related.

AND THE OSPRAY. Even though there is an individual opinion that it (the osprey) is not found in inhabited places, the Gaon erred in rendering it al enka, for this term in the language of the Ishmaelites refers to something that never existed. It refers to something that was not created and never was. It is only employed metaphorically. The Arab grammarians admit this. This being the case, it is not possible that the Torah would prohibit something that never existed.21

14. AND THE KITE. The term da’ah (kite) is a general term which takes in two kinds, namely, the da’ah (kite) and the dayyah (falcon).22 Compare, tzippor (birds), the word used for a turtle-dove and a young pigeon in but the birds divided he not (Gen. 15:10). Now the transmitters of tradition who said that the ra’ah23 (glede) is to be identified with the da’ah (kite)24 are correct.25 The argument of Rabbi Jonah,26 who asked how is it possible to say be on guard because of the aryeh (lion) and the layyish (lion),27 is turned aside.28

Others say that nesher (the great vulture) is connected to the word ashurennu (I see him) (Num. 23:9);29 peres (bearded vulture) is related to the word pros (deal)30 in Is it not to deal thy bread to the hungry (Is. 58:7);31 ozniyyah (osprey) is related to the word oz (mighty)32 and its nun is superfluous.33 It is the bird which is called akba;34 da’ah (kite) is related to the word yideh (swoopeth) in as the vulture swoopeth down (Deut. 28:49);35 ayyah (falcon) is so called because it is accustomed to dwell in certain well-known islands (iyyim);36 orev (raven) is related to the word erev (evening). It is so called because of its darkness.

16. AND THE OSTRICH. Some say that the bat ha-ya’anah (ostrich)37 is a kind among whom males are not found.38 It is like the hare. There is no argument from the word ka-ye’enim (like the ostriches)39 (Lam. 4:3), for the reference is to females as in the case of ye’elim (wild goats) (Ps. 104:18)40 and rechelim41 (ewes) (Gen. 32:15).
AND THE NIGHT-HAWK. Tachmas (night-hawk) is related to the word chamas (violence) (Gen. 5:11).
THE SEA-MEW. The shachaf (sea-mew) gives birth to consumption (shachefet) (Lev. 26:16).
AND THE HAWK. The netz (hawk) has many feathers.42 It most likely refers to the well-known bird which always spreads its wings to the south,43 for it seeks a warm place.

17. AND THE LITTLE OWL. The word kos (little owl) is similar to the word kos (owl) in as an owl of the waste places (Ps. 102:7). Some say that the bird is hidden (nikhseh) from the eyes of people. It therefore rests in uninhabited places.
AND THE CORMORANT. Some say that the shalakh (cormorant) is so called because its nature is to cast (le-haslikh) its offspring down.
AND THE GREAT OWL. The yanshuf (great owl) is a bird that flies at night (neshef), for it cannot see during the day because of the brightness of the sun light.
18. AND THE HORNED OWL. Whoever looks at the tinshemet (the horned owl) is astonished (yishom). The term tinshemet is also found among the swarming things (v. 30).44
AND THE PELICAN. Some say that the ka’at (pelican) is a bird whose nature is to regurgitate (le-haki) its food.

AND THE CARRION-VULTURE. The Gaon45 says that the racham (carrion-vulture) is the animal which is similarly called in Arabic,46 with the chet interchanging with a khaf, for they are written with the same letter.47 Others say that racham refers to a bird that has pity (merachem) upon its offspring.
19. AND THE STORK. Some say the chasidah (stork) is the bird which appears at certain well-known times in the year. Others say that it scatters loving kindness (chesed).48 This is far-fetched.
AND THE HERON. The anafah (heron) grows angry (yitannef) quickly.49
AND THE HOOPOE. The Sadducees say that the dukhifat (hoopoe) refers to the chicken. However, they are the world’s greatest fools, for who told them this?
AND THE BAT. A small bird that flies at night. The word atalef (bat) is a quadriliteral; that is, it comes from a four-letter root.

Note that the word teshakketzu in teshakketzu min ha-of (these ye shall have in detestation among the fowls) (v. 13) has a slightly different grammatical meaning from teshakketzu in al teshakketzu et nafshotekhem (ye shall not make yourselves detestable) (v. 43). In the latter instance the word nafshotekhem (yourselves) is the object, while in the case of the fowl (v. 13) its meaning is, you shall know that they are detestable and they shall be considered detestable to you.
All winged swarming things that at times fly and at times go upon all fours are detestable.50
21. WHICH HAVE JOINTED LEGS. The main reading is the one that spells lo with a vav.51

TO LEAP. The word le-natter has no brother.52 The Aramaic translator renders le-natter ba-hen by le-kappatza behen; since the word le-kappatza is similar to mekappetz (leaping) (Cant. 2:8),53 its meaning is leaping. He translated correctly.
[22. THE LOCUST.] The word arbeh (locust) is connected to the word ribbuy (large amount).
AND THE BALD LOCUST. The sale’am (bald locust) refers to a kind of locust which climbs on rocks (sela’im).54

AND THE CRICKET. If the word chargol (cricket) is a quadriliteral, then it has no brother.55 If it is a combination of two words56 like the word palmoni (certain one) in unto that certain one who spoke (Dan 8:13), then the nature of the chargal is the reverse of the nature of the sale’am (bald locust).57
AND THE GRASSHOPPER. Its meaning is known from the language of the Ishmaelite.58

23. [BUT ALL WINGED SWARMING THINGS.] Scripture had previously stated, that go upon all fours (v. 20).59 The Torah now states, But all winged swarming things, which have four feet, because it is possible that there is a swarming creature that has four legs but that does not walk upon them but only flies.60

24. AND BY THESE YE SHALL BECOME UNCLEAN. By all winged swarming things that have four feet; And these ye shall have in detestation among the fowls.61 Others believe that the word elleh (these) (v. 24) refers to among all the beasts and to And whatsoever goeth upon its paws (v. 27).62 I believe that the word elleh refers to all those mentioned above.63

YE SHALL BECOME UNCLEAN. The word tittamma’u (ye shall become unclean) is a hitpa’el. The tet receives a dagesh because the tav64 is swallowed. The same is the case with the word middabber (speaking) in then he heard the Voice speaking unto him (Num. 7:89) and the word mittaher (cleansed) in And he that is to be cleansed shall wash (Lev. 14:8).65
SHALL BE UNCLEAN UNTIL THE EVEN. Scripture chose the path of brevity, for the unclean must bathe in water.

25. AND WHOSOEVER BEARETH. Bearing is more serious than touching. Therefore the bearer must wash his garments. How much more so [must he bathe] his body. The same law applies to all beasts.66 Scripture also follows the path of brevity here.67 The verse is to be understood as follows, or is clovenfooted but cheweth not the cud or cheweth the cud but is not cloven-footed.68 Scripture has previously stated, and their carcasses ye shall not touch; they are unclean unto you (v. 8).69

26. [EVERY ONE THAT TOUCHETH THEM.] This means everyone who touches any of the above-mentioned carcasses shall become unclean until the evening, for that is the law regarding the previously mentioned carcasses. There is a type of misbeliever who belongs to the Sadducee heresy who says that every one that toucheth them means whoever touches them while they are alive shall be unclean. There is no need to respond to insane talk, for Scripture only prohibited their flesh.70 It states, and their carcasses ye shall not touch (v. 8).

27. AND WHATSOEVER GOETH UPON ITS PAWS. At first71 the law is the same.72 Similarly And he that beareth the carcass of them (v. 28).73 This verse affirms my explanation of the words And by these ye shall be come unclean (v. 24),74 for Scripture there states, And whosoever beareth aught of the carcass of them (v. 25).75 Both of them are in one section.
The reason Scripture states, They are unclean unto you, is that it wants to include all of Israel: men, women, and children.76 One law applies to all.

29. AND THESE ARE THEY WHICH ARE UNCLEAN UNTO YOU. By touch.77 We also are not able to actually know what these eight creatures78 refer to. This is also true of the fowl.79 We can only know their identity by tradition.
31. [THESE ARE THEY WHICH ARE UNCLEAN.] It means that these alone are the unclean80 which, when dead, defile you.81
The meaning of shall be unclean until the even is, after he bathes he shall be unclean until the evening.82
32. IT MUST BE PUT INTO WATER. The garment or the sack or the vessel which is susceptible of uncleanness. We have a need for tradition regarding these things.83
33. WHEREIN TO ANY OF THEM FALLETH. Me-hem84 is to be rendered, any one of them. Compare, And was buried in the cities of Gilead85 (Jud. 12:7).86

34. AND ALL DRINK. Mashkeh (drink) is a noun.87 Mashkeh in Now I was giving drink to the king (Neh. 1:11) is a verb in the present tense.88 Now, an oven (v. 35) which is used to bake bread and a range (Ibid.) which is used to cook meat shall be broken into pieces,89 for they are unclean. This is the decree of the king.90

[36.] A CISTERN. The Hebrew word be’er (well) is a feminine. It bubbles forth. Compare, As a well (bir)91 welleth with her waters (Jer. 6:7). However, a bor (cistern) is dug or excavated to store the rain from the sky. If so,92 the well is a fountain.93 There is no need to mention rivers.94 Mikveh mayim (a gathering of water) is connected to bor (cistern),95 for there are borot (cisterns) without water.96 Some say that mikveh is missing a vav.97 Compare, Reuben, Simeon (Ex, 1:2),98 and shemesh yare’ach (the sun moon) (Hab. 3:11).99
BUT HE WHO TOUCHETH THEIR CARCASS. The water that touches their carcasses will be unclean.100

37. SOWING. Zeru’a (sowing) is an adjective.101 It is similar to a pa’ul.102 On the other hand, there might be two nouns for the word seed.103 And gave them pulse (zeronim104) (Dan. 1:16) is proof of this.

38. BUT IF WATER BE PUT. If they water their field and aught of their carcasses fall on the seed.105 Some say on the water.106 The word yuttan (be put), which is singular, governs mayim (water).107 We find a similarity in because the water (meh) of sprinkling was not dashed (zorak)108 against him (Num. 19:13). The word yuttan is similar to yukkach (be fetched) in Let now a little water be fetched (Gen. 18:4). It belongs to the heavy conjugation to which a letter is added.109
39. OF WHICH YE MAY. Asher hi la-khem le-okhlah means of which ye may eat.110
SHALL BE UNCLEAN UNTIL THE EVEN. After he bathes in water.111

[40. AND HE THAT EATETH.] The law regarding he that eats112 is stricter.113 It is similar to the law governing he that that carries,114 for both bear.115 One carries outside116 and the other117 inside.118
[41. AND EVERY SWARMING THING.] This means all swarming things of the earth. The eight swarming creatures119 are included. Scripture mentions that they120 are not to be eaten.121
42. THE BELLY. The word gachon (belly) is similar to the word gechonekha (thy belly) in upon thy belly shalt thou go (Gen. 3:14).
AND WHATSOEVER GOETH UPON ALL FOURS. Among the swarming things which are small, as I explained with regard to the swarming things in the water.122
MANY FEET. The word marbeh (many) is an adjective. It is in the construct.123
43. YE SHALL NOT MAKE YOURSELVES DETESTABLE. By being filthy and dirty.124
NEITHER SHALL YE MAKE YOURSELVES UNCLEAN. For it is known that that which is eaten turns into the flesh of the one who ingests it.125

THAT YE SHOULD BE DEFILED THEREBY. The word ve-nitmetem (that ye should be defiled) is missing an alef.126 Compare, reshit127 (beginning) in from the beginning of the year (Deut. 11:12). Others say that they come from two roots.128 The word nitminu (unclean) in And reputed unclean in your sight129 (Job 18:3) is proof. It130 means that you do not become dumb-witted.131

45. YE SHALL THEREFORE BE HOLY, FOR I AM HOLY. Hence I told you neither shall ye defile yourselves (v. 44). The vav132 is similar to the unaspirated fah in Arabic.133 Similarly the vav in va-ya’azov (left) in left his servants (Ex. 9:21).134 There are many such instances.135

[FOR I AM THE LORD.] This means I did not take you out of Egypt for any reason but to be your God. If you will not be holy, I will not be a God to you. Hence if you want Me to be your God you must be holy.
47. TO MAKE A DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE UNCLEAN. Among the fowl and that which swarms in the water.
THAT MAY BE EATEN. That is permitted to be eaten.
THAT MAY NOT BE EATEN. According to the words of the Torah.136
chapter.ftnote: 1 Aaron teaches Israel how to differentiate between the unclean and unclean. Hence God’s word was also directed to Aaron.
2 Even though it has the form of a verb. I.E. renders kol mafreset parsah (whatsoever parteth the hoof) as whatsoever has parted hoofs.
3 Makrin and mafris are adjectives.
4 Translated according to I.E.
5 The root of which is gimel, resh, resh.
6 Literally, brings up.
7 Unlike mafreset and shosa’at.
8 They either chew the cud or have split hoofs. These animals are enumerated in order to emphasize the fact that the law requires a clean animal to have both signs.

9 The masculine form of a noun at times refers to males and females; that is, the term “man” sometimes refers to males and females. Most of the names of the animals mentioned in verses 4-7 are in the masculine. I.E. points out that the same law applies to females of the species. Otherwise only the male animals listed would be forbidden to be eaten.
10 Arnevet is feminine and so does not seem to follow the rule stated by I.E.
11 Some interpret this to mean that the male of the species is rarely seen. However, this opinion seems to be saying that this species has no male.
12 As it does with regard to winged swarming things (v. 24), animals that walk on their paws (v. 27), and other creatures. See verses 31, 32, 39, and 40.

13 This is I.E.’s opinion based on a literal reading of the text. However, in the Yesod Mora (p. 47) I.E. interprets this verse in accordance with the opinion of the rabbis. He writes: “The one who touches them does not incur the penalty of karet or stripes.”
14 Onkelos renders snappir ve-kaskeset as tzitzin ve-kalfin.
15 See Gen. 1:20.
16 I.E.’s interpretation of and of all living creatures that are in the waters.
17 For our verse states, ye shall not eat of their flesh.
18 The rabbis say that fish are not considered flesh. See Hullin 104a, “One who takes a vow not to eat flesh is permitted to eat fish and locusts.”
19 Post-Biblical generations. In Rabbinic and contemporary times fish are not considered flesh.
20 It is called niser in Arabic. Hence we have additional proof of the identity of this bird.
21 Hence the first quoted opinion is superior to that of the Gaon.

22 Which is not in our verse but is mentioned in Deut. 14:13. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: “The term da’ah (kite) is a general term which takes in two kinds, namely, the ra’ah (kite) and the dayyah (falcon).” The latter are mentioned in Deut. 14:13 but omitted in our verse. Thus there is no contradiction between the list of the 20 prohibited birds in our chapter and the 21 in Deut. 14. Also, see I.E. on Deut. 14:11 (Vol. 5, pp. 93,94).
23 Mentioned in Deut. 14:13.
24 Mentioned in our verse. See Chullin 63:2.
25 For the term da’ah (kite) is a general term and takes in the ra’ah
26 In the Sefer Ha-Shoroshim, root resh, alef, heh.

27 According to Rabbi Jonah an intelligent person would not say watch out for the aryeh and the layyish, for both words have one meaning. Rabbi Jonah argues that the ra’ah is not to be identified with the da’ah, for the Torah would not say do not eat the ra’ah and the da’ah if both referred to the same kind (Krinsky).
28 For aryeh is a general term, and layyish is a specific term.
29 Nesher thus means the bird who sees great distances.
30 Literally, break.
31 Peres thus means the bird that breaks.
32 Ozniyyah thus means the mighty bird.
33 For there is no nun in oz.
34 In Arabic.
35 Da’ah means the swooping bird.
36 Ayyah means the island-dwelling bird.
37 Bat ha-ya’anah is feminine.
38 Hence Scripture mentions only the feminine.
39 Ye’enim is a masculine plural form. The singular of this form is ya’an. We thus see that males are found among the ostriches.
40 Ye’elim is a masculine plural form. However, it is the plural of ye’elah, which is feminine.
41 Which is a masculine plural form but is actually the plural of rechelah, which is feminine. We thus see that there are instances in which a feminine singular has a plural masculine form.
42 The Hebrew word for feather is notzah.
43 See Job 39:26, Doth the hawk (netz) soar by thy wisdom, and stretch her wings toward the south?
44 In other words, the word tinshemet refers to both a bird and a reptile. This is an anomaly which I.E. points out.
45 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.
46 The rakham.
47 The Arabic chet and khaf are similarly writtten.
48 See Rashi: “Why is it called “chasidah? It is so called because it acts kindly towards its fellow creatures with regard to food.” See also Chullin 63a.
49 See Chullin 63a.
50 I.E.’s interpretation of verse 20.

51 The kre. The ketiv spells lo with a vav. With a vav the phrase means “which have jointed legs;” without a vav it reads, “which does not have jointed legs.” According to the rabbis the meaning of the latter is: which does not have jointed legs now but will grow them later. See Sifra on this verse.
52 The word is not found again in Scripture.
53 Thus le-kappatza ve-hon means wherewith to leap.
54 Sela means a rock. Thus sela’im means the “rocker,” i.e., the grasshopper that climbs a rock.
55 There is no similar word in Scripture.
56 Charag (trembling). See I. E. on Ps. 18:46 and regel (foot).
57 For the sale’am climbs rocks while the chargal has “trembling feet” and is not adept at climbing.
58 A grasshopper is called chajaba in Arabic.
59 Scripture had previously stated that go on all four are…detestable (v. 21). Why then state here, But all winged swarming things which have four feet are…detestable?

60 Verse 20 teaches that a swarming creature that walks on four legs is detestable. Our verse teaches that a swarming creature that has four legs is detestable even if it does not walk upon them. Our verse thus not repeat verse 20.
61 See verse 13. In other words, verses 24 and 25 refer to that which comes before, that is to unclean fowl and unclean winged swarming things.
62 In other words, verses 23 and 24 introduce that which follows. See Rashi and Rashbam.
63 Unclean fowl and unclean winged swarming things.
64 Of the hitpa’el.
65 Both words are hitpa’els whose tav is compensated for by a dagesh.
66 It does not apply only to unclean fowl and unclean winged swarming things.
67 As it did in verse 24.

68 Our verse seems to imply that only an animal that has two signs of uncleanliness is unclean, for it speaks of a beast which parteth the hoof, but is not cloven-footed, nor cheweth the cud. However, this contradicts verses 4-7 which teache that an animal with only one kosher sign is unclean. Hence I.E. points out that the above clause is short for: a beast which cheweth the cud and parteth the hoof but is not cloven-footed, or a beast that cheweth not the cud but which parteth the hoof and is cloven-footed.
69 Hence Scripture does not mention here that their carcasses are unclean (Weiser).

70 To be eaten. The point is that the law dealing with touching unclean animals only concerns dead unclean animals, for Scripture explicitly states, and their carcasses ye shall not touch (v. 8). Hence the prohibition against touching unclean animals applies only to their carcasses.
71 Before they died.
72 They have the same law as the animals mentioned in verse 26.
73 The law that governs the animals mentioned in verse 28 applies here too.
74 According to I.E., And by these ye shall be come unclean applies to what comes before, not what follows. See I.E. on verse 24.

75 And verse 28 states, And he that beareth the carcass of them. According to I.E., Scripture is not repeating itself, for verse 25 refers to winged creatures while verse 28 refers to animals that walk on all fours.
76 Verse 26 states, Every one that toucheth them shall be unclean. Hence unclean unto you in our verse is not a mere repetition of the same statement.
77 One becomes unclean by touching their dead carcasses.
78 Mentioned in verses 29 and 30.
79 Mentioned in verses 13-19.
80 These eight swarming things alone among the things that swarm upon the earth defile the one who touches them.
81 Hence Scripture enumerates them.
82 See I.E. on verse 25.
83 To tell us which vessels are susceptible to uncleanliness. There is a section of the Mishnah called kelim (vessels) dedicated to this topic.

84 Literally, of them. This might be taken to mean all of them; that is, if all of the creatures mentioned in verses 29 and 30 fall into a vessel it becomes unclean. However, if one or two of them fall into a vessel it is not unclean. Hence I.E.’s comment.
85 Translated literally.
86 The meaning of which is, and was buried in one of the cities of Gilead.
87 Even though it has the form of a verb.
88 Translated according to I.E.
89 If the carcass of one of the eight swarming things falls into it.

90 There does not appear to be any reason for this law. In the Yesod Mora (p. 112), I.E. points out that there are many laws whose meaning only the very intelligent can ascertain. I.E.’s comments here seem to be directed to this group of people.
91 This is the ketiv. Bir is a variant of be’er. Translated according to I.E.
92 If the water in the well bubbles forth.
93 Mentioned in our verse.
94 In our verse, for the waters in the rivers have their origin in underground fountains.
95 Bor mikveh mayim means a cistern wherein is a gathering of water (v. 36).
96 Hence mikveh mayim follows bor.
97 Mikveh mayim should be read as if written, u-mikveh mayim. According to this interpretation our verse reads, or a cistern, or a gathering of water.
98 Which is to be interpreted as if written, re’uven ve-shimon (Reuben and Simon).
99 Which is to be interpreted as if written, shemesh ve-yare’ach (the sun and the moon).
100 Water that is removed from the ground.
101 Modifying zera (seed).
102 It is an adjective vocalized like a verb in the pu’al.
103 Zera and zeru’a. Compare, Rashi: “Zera zeru’a (sowing seed) means any kind of seed. Zeru’a is a noun.”
104 Zeronim is a variation of the plural of zeru’a.

105 The seed is unclean. According to this interpretation the word alav (thereon) refers to the seed. This opinion interprets our verse as follows: But if water be put upon the seed, and aught of their carcass fall upon the seed, the seed is unclean.

106 In other words, the word alav (thereon) refers to the water. This opinion interprets our verse as follows: But if water be put upon the seed, and aught of their carcass fall upon the water, the seed is unclean.
107 Which is a plural. I.E. points this out because verbs governing nouns in the plural are normally in the plural.
108 Zorak is singular. It governs meh, which is plural.

109 I.E. usually refers to the hifil as “the heavy conjugation to which a letter is added.” However, yuttan and yukkach are hofals. We either have a scribal error or I.E. was not exact in his language.
110 Any animal of which you are permitted to eat. Asher hi la-khem leokhlah literally means which is to you for food, i.e., which you are about to eat. Hence I.E.’s comment.
112 Of the carcass of the animal that dies of itself.
113 Than the law regarding one who touches.
114 The carcass of the animal that dies of itself.
115 The carcass.
116 On the outside of the body.
117 The one who eats.
118 Of his or her body.
119 Mentioned in verse 29 and 30.
120 The eight swarming creatures.
121 This was not stated earlier.
122 See I.E. on verse 10.
123 With raglayim (feet).
124 By eating filthy and dirty things.
125 Hence one who eats filthy things turns into a filthy thing himself.
126 Nitmetem is spelled nun, tet, mem, tav, mem. It should be spelled nun, tet, mem, alef, tav, mem, for the root of tame is tet, mem, alef.
127 Which is spelled without an alef, though it should have been spelled with an alef.
128 There are two words in Hebrew for unclean: tet, mem, alef, and tet, mem, heh. The word nitmetem in our verse comes from the latter root. Hence there is no alef in it.
129 Translated literally.
130 That ye should be defiled thereby.
131 In other words, that ye should be defiled thereby means that you do not become dull-witted thereby.
132 In vi-heyitem (ye shall therefore be).

133 It does not always serve as a connective. See I.E. on Gen. 1:2 (Vol. 1, p. 30). In other words, vi-heyitem kedoshim is not a continuation of the first half of the verse. It is an independent clause.
134 Va-ya’azov (left) in Ex. 9:21 is to be rendered as left, not and he left.
135 Where the vav has the meaning of an unaspirated fah in Arabic.
136 In other words, asher lo te’ackhel is to be rendered, that may not be eaten. Asher lo te’ackhel can be rendered, which is inedible. Hence I.E.’s comment.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 12
chapter.p: 2. IF A WOMAN BE DELIVERED.1 After Scripture concludes the law of clean and unclean food, it deals with human uncleanliness. The Torah starts2 with the woman who gives birth, because human life begins at birth. Many say that if the woman produces the seed first,3 then she gives birth to a male.4 Scripture therefore states, and bear a man-child.5 The wise men of the Greeks similarly believed that the seed is of the woman. The seed of the male congeals.6 All of the child is created out of the blood of the woman.7 Note, the meaning of tazri’a (be delivered) means will give seed, for a woman8 is like the ground.9

The vav of ve-tame’ah (then shall be unclean) is like the unaspirated vav in Arabic.10 The reason that she is unclean for seven days is that she must wait until she completes11 a quarter of days.12 We find a similarity in the days of illness, for a change is seen at the end of the seven days.13
THE IMPURITY OF. The word niddat (impurity of) is a noun.14 It follows the paradigm of bizzat (spoil of).15 Both words come from a double root.16
HER SICKNESS. Devotah (her sickness) is a noun in the plural.17 Compare, madveh (diseases) in the evil diseases of Egypt (Deut. 7:15).18 The blood that comes out is an illness in the woman’s body.19

3. AND IN THE EIGHTH DAY. Our wise men, of blessed memory, said during the day, not at night.20 Now a child born a half hour before sunset is circumcised after six and half days,21 for the day of the Torah is not measured by twenty-four hours.22

SHALL BE CIRCUMCISED. Yimmol (shall be circumcised) is a nifal.23 Compare, yikkon24 (be established) in shall not be established (Ps. 101:7). According to this opinion, yimmol is related to the word mullim25 (circumcised) in were circumcised (Josh. 5:5). It is also possible that yimmol is missing a nun26 and is related to the word u-nemaltem27 (and ye shall be circumcised) (Gen. 17:11). Yimmol is like the word yiddor (voweth)28 in When a man voweth a vow unto the Lord (Num. 30:3). Scripture omits the one who performs the circumcision, such as the father or the Beth Din (court).29

HIS FORESKIN. It is known that the foreskin is on the private part.30 This is not the case regarding the foreskin of the heart,31 the lip,32 and the ear,33 for all of them are connected to another word.34
4. [PURIFICATION.] The heh of tohorah35 (purification) is unsounded.36 It should have been pronounced. It is like the heh37 in lah (it)38 in and called it Nobah (Num. 32:43).
The meaning of deme tohorah (the blood of purification) is clean blood.39 This blood, in contrast to dam niddah (menstrual blood), is clean. It does not cause uncleanliness.

The forty days that God decreed regarding a male child40 corresponds to the time it takes for the form of the male to be completed in the womb.41 It takes double that time for a female.42 This is clear and tested.
SHE SHALL TOUCH NO HALLOWED THING. Such as the tithe, trumah,43 and the flesh of peace offerings.

NOR COME INTO THE SANCTUARY. The courtyard of the tent of meeting or into the temple courtyard.44 Be-deme tohorah (in the blood of purification) (v. 4) and al deme tohorah (in the blood of purification)45 have one meaning.

6. OF THE FIRST YEAR. If we did not have tradition, who would explain whether ben shenato (of the first year)46 means exactly one year, or less than a year, or a year plus?47 Some say that the reason a woman who gives birth brings a lamb for a burnt offering is that she may have had some unseemly thought because of her pain when giving birth.48 She brings a sin offering because she might have uttered some unseemly thing with her lips.49

7. AND HE SHALL OFFER IT. This one and the other one,50 the lamb and the turtle-dove or the young pigeon.51 Scripture employed an abridged style. It similarly does not mention the snipping of the head of the fowl brought for a sin offering,52 for53 the kohen does not eat of the sin offering fowl.54
AND MAKE ATONEMENT FOR HER. As I explained.55
AND SHE SHALL BE CLEANSED FROM THE FOUNTAIN OF HER BLOOD. This is a sign that she does not naturally became cleansed until the days that are enumerated arrive.
8. AND IF HER MEANS SUFFICE NOT.56 This means the same as but if his means suffice not57 (see Lev. 5:11).
AND THE PRIEST SHALL MAKE ATONEMENT FOR HER, AND SHE SHALL BE CLEAN. This teaches that if the kohen does not make atonement for her she shall not be clean. This applies only in the Land of Israel.58
chapter.ftnote: 1 Hebrew, tazri’a (literally, produces a seed).
2 Its regulations of human uncleanliness.
3 Before the male.
4 However, when the male produces the seed first then the result is a female. See Berakhot 60a; Niddah 28a.
5 That is, Scripture therefore says, If a woman produce seed and bear a man-child.
6 The Greeks believed that the male seed gives form to the seed of the woman.
7 According to the Greek sages the woman provides the matter and the man the form of the embryo. See I.E. on Deut. 13:7 (Vol. 5, pp. 89,90).
8 Reading he (she) as in Vat. Ebr. 38 rather than hu (it) as in some printed editions.

9 The point is that the field nurtures the seed planted in it. The same is the case with a woman. Compare, And as the garden causeth the things that are sown in it (zeru’ehah) to spring forth (Is. 62:11). Thus ishah ki tazri’a (if a woman be delivered) literally means if a woman gives forth her seed, i.e., the seed planted in her.

10 It does not always indicate the start of a new clause. See I.E. on Gen. 1:2 (Vol. 1, p. 30). In other words, ve-tame’ah is not to be rendered: and she shall be unclean, but, then she shall be unclean.
11 Literally, returns to.
12 The month is divided into quarters. According to the astrologers there is a change in nature and in fate at the end of each quarter. The same is true with each individual.
13 In other words, the quarters do not apply only to lunar months but also to events in life.
14 In the construct.
15 The word is not found in the Bible. It is found in Rabbinic literature (see Rashi, Ex. 15:22).
16 Niddat comes from nun, dalet, dalet. Bizzat from bet, zayin, zayin.
17 It’s the plural of davah plus the feminine pronominal suffix.
18 Devotah (her sickness) and madveh (diseases) come from the same root. Thus devotah means her illness. Some interpret devotah as her flow. See Rashi.
19 A woman feels sick when she experiences the loss of blood. See Rashi, “No woman sees a flow of blood…without first experiencing a heaviness in her head and limbs.”
20 Circumcision is to be performed during the day.
21 The end of the day that the child was born, the following six days, and the morning of the eighth day.
22 It does not consist of twenty-four hours, for part of the day is considered a whole day.
23 From the root mem, vav, lamed.
24 From the root kaf, vav, nun.
25 From the root mem, vav, lamed.
26 In this case yimmol comes from the root nun, mem. lamed.
27 From the root nun, mem, lamed.
28 From the root nun, dalet, resh.

29 If yimmol comes from the root nun, mem, lamed, then the meaning of yimmol (shall be circumcised) is, he shall circumcise. In this case the subject is missing, for Scripture omits who “he” is. Hence I.E. points out that “he” refers to the father of the child, the Beth Din, or any authorized person. For similar comments of I.E., see I.E. on Gen. 25:26; 48:1; 50:26 (Vol. 1, pp. 251, 412, 452).
30 The penis.

34 Which explains them. When the word orlah (foreskin) stands by itself, it refers to the foreskin of the penis. When Scripture uses the term orlah metaphorically, it connects it to another word, as in aral sefatayim (of uncircumcised lips) (Ex. 6:12).
35 According to I. E. tohorah should be rendered, her purification.

36 It does not have a mappik (dot) in it. According to I.E. the heh of tohorah (purification) is a pronominal suffix, and tohorah should be rendered as her purification. Such a heh usually has a dot in it. Hence I.E.’s comment.
37 It too is a pronominal suffix without a mappik in it.
38 Literally, to it.
39 I.E. renders deme tohorah as blood of cleanliness.
40 Our chapter decrees that a woman who has a baby boy has to wait forty days until she becomes “cleansed from the fountain of her blood.”
41 According to Rabbi Ishmael it takes forty-one days for a male child to be formed in the womb (Niddah 3:7).
42 Ibid.
43 The heave offering.
44 Sanctuary does not refer to the sanctuary per se.
45 In our verse.
46 According to Rabbinic interpretation, ben shenato means of the first year. See Mekhilta 4.
47 Under two years.
48 A burnt offering is brought for unseemly thoughts. See I.E. on Lev. 1:4. She might have blasphemed or wished evil upon her husband for causing her this pain.

49 See Niddah 31b: “Rabbi Johanan ben Zakkai’s student asked: Why did the Torah say that a woman who gives birth shall bring an offering? He said to them: when she crouches to give birth she swears that she will not have sexual relations with her husband.”
50 Scripture employs the singular (ve-hikrivo). Hence I.E.’s comment.
51 Our verse does not list in detail what is to be offered.
52 See Lev. 1:15.

53 The term “for” goes back to the first line of I.E.’s quote. Our text should be understood as follows: This one and the other one, the lamb and the turtledove or the young pigeon, for the kohen does not eat of the sin offering fowl (Meijler).
54 Hence it is like a burnt offering and Scripture can use one term (ve-hikrivo) to refer to it and the burnt offering (the lamb).
55 To serve as a ransom for the punishment due her. See I.E. on Lev. 1:4.
56 Literally, And if her hand does not find.
57 Literally, And if his hand does not acquire. The point is that “And if her hand does not find” means And if her means suffice her not.
58 The cleaning rituals described in our chapter apply only in the Land of Israel. Outside of the Land of Israel, immersion in a mikveh suffices.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 13
chapter.p: 1. AND THE LORD SPOKE UNTO MOSES AND UNTO AARON. This commandment was directly communicated to Aaron because all human maladies shall be determined according to his pronouncement.1 Aaron shall declare who is clean and who is unclean.

2. WHEN A MAN. Scripture does notread, “Whosoever… of the house of Israel”2 because it wants to include strangers.3 Similarly When any man of you4 (Lev. 1:2), for there is one law to the native born and to the stranger5 regarding offerings. The Torah includes the stranger [in the laws relating to maladies]6 so that the stranger does not defile another person, for leprosy is a disease that is passed on from the sick to the healthy.7
THEN HE SHALL BE BROUGHT. By his consent or against his will, for one who sees one of these signs8 will force the afflicted [to go to the kohen].
[UNTO AARON THE PRIEST.] The meaning of Aaron the priest is, the kohen who is anointed in his place.9

OR UNTO ONE OF HIS SONS THE PRIESTS. This means one of the common priests outside of the temple10 such as the kohanim of Anatot.11 The meaning of the priests is that they should not be from among those who are disqualified to serve as priests.12

[A RISING.] The word se’et (a rising) means a burn.13 Similarly maset (fire) in But when the fire began to rise14 (Jud. 20:40) and va-yisa’em david (and David burnt them)15 (II Sam. 5:21). The se’et is probably so called because it is the nature of fire to rise upwards.16

A SCAB. The word sappachat (scab) is related to sefachani (put me)17 in Put me, I pray thee (I Sam. 2:36) and ve-nispechu (and they shall cleave) in and they shall cleave to the house of Jacob (Is. 14:1). It refers to a disease which attaches itself to one place.
A BRIGHT SPOT. The word baheret (bright spot) is related to the word bahir (bright) in which is bright in the skies (Job 37:21). It is a known malady which produces a mark and a sign.
[3.] BE TURNED WHITE. Hafakh lavon means be turned white.18
BE DEEPER. Its depth is deeper than the depth of the skin. The word amok (deep) does not mean the same as shafal (lower) (v. 20).19
AND PRONOUNCE HIM UNCLEAN.20 Verbally.21 He shall declare him unclean.
[4.] THEN THE PRIEST SHALL SHUT UP HIM THAT HATH THE PLAGUE SEVEN DAYS.22 The person shall be shut up.23 He shall wait up to seven days, for most illnesses change on the seventh day.24

5. STAY IN ITS APPEARANCE. Amad be-enav25 means stay in its appearance. The term enav26 is employed, for its appearance is seen by the eye. All the commentaries says that beenav (in its appearance) means in its make-up, that is, in the way it was.27
SPREAD. Pasah means spread.
6. AGAIN. Shenit (again) means a second time.

THE PLAGUE BE DIM.
