Many of the wise men say that the word kehah (dim) means dark.28 They offer proof from vatikhhena (were dim) in and his eyes were dim (Gen. 27:1).29 They say that the phrase kehot levanot (dull white) (v. 39) is similar to le-vanah adamdamet (reddish-white) (v. 19)30 in that it contains both colors. However, I believe that the word kehah (dim) is the reverse of pasah (spread).31 It is related to the word va-tikhhena (were dim) in and his eyes were dim (Gen. 27:1). The word khihah (stopped) in and he diminished32 them not33 (I Sam. 3:13) is close to it. The meaning of kahah ha-nega (the plague be dim) is that the plague did not spread to another place. Note, there are two signs, namely, the size of the affliction was diminished and it did not spread to the healthy part of the body.
THEN THE PRIEST SHALL PRONOUNCE HIM CLEAN.34 The kohen shall say that he is clean,35 for it was a scab (mispachat). However, if it spreads afterwards he is unclean.
9. THEN HE SHALL BE BROUGHT. The man having the affliction. Be brought is to be interpreted like its counterpart.36
10. AND IT HAVE TURNED. The black hair white.37
QUICK. The meaning of michyat (quick) is live flesh.38 Flesh which does not feel is not alive.
11. OLD. Of yore.
Yasgirennu (shut him up) governs two actions.39 It means he shall command that the afflicted be shut up.

13. HE SHALL PRONOUNCE HIM CLEAN THAT HATH THE PLAGUE. For the plague has already surfaced and removed itself from the afflicted. The meaning of ve-tiher et hanaga40 (he shall pronounce him unclean that hath the plague) is that he shall verbally clean the affliction; that is, he shall declare that this plague will not make others unclean.
16. BUT IF THE RAW FLESH AGAIN BE TURNED.41 For it is possible that the affliction will return.

19. REDDISH-WHITE. A mixture of the two colors. Or a little of each. The word tzara’at (leprosy) (v. 20) means a disease. Similarly ha-tzirah (the disease)42 in I will send the disease (Ex. 23:28). The fact that the Torah reads, and I will send is no argument against this interpretation,43 for Scripture reads, He sent His word (Ps. 107:20); For I…send all My plagues (Ex. 9:14); and He sent forth upon them the fierceness of His anger (Ps. 78:49).

20. AND, BEHOLD, IF THE APPEARANCE THEREOF. It is not grammatically correct to vocalize the alef of mareha (its appearance) with a long kamatz and a mappik44 in the heh as in the case of yadah (her hand) and raglah (her foot),45 for we do not find words whose roots end in a silent heh to be so treated.46

[21. LOOK ON IT.] The nun of yirennah (look upon it) has a dagesh in it like the nun of yasgirennu (v. 11) to compensate for the missing added heh.47 The same is true with mi-mennah (from her) and mi-mennu (from it).48
23. IN ITS PLACE.49 If the affliction stays in its place,50 for there are afflictions that move from place to place.
SCAR. The word tzarevet (scar) is similar to the word ve-nitzrevu (shall be seared) in and all faces…shall be seared (Ezek. 21:30). It has the meaning of a burning mass, heat, and a flame.51
24. OR WHITE. Alone.

28. AND IF THE BRIGHT SPOT STAY IN ITS PLACE…BUT BE DIM. The word kehah (dim) is to be understood as I explained it earlier (v. 6).52 Scripture does not mention kehah (dim) the first time, But if the bright spot stay in its place (v. 23), because there the bright spot remains as it was.53

[29. AND WHEN…] Scripture mentions a man or a woman54 because it deals with an affliction in the beard55 [and the head]. Also, because the Torah has to use the word ish (man), and not the term adam (a human being) to exclude women from the law of the bald head and the bald forehead (v. 40).56 Note, our verse means, when a man or a woman has an affliction upon the head or a man upon the beard.57
30. YELLOW. The word tzahov (yellow) in Arabic refers to a color that is close to white.
IT IS A SCALL. The word netek (scall) is related to the word yennatek (is broken) in as a string of tow is broken (Jud. 16:9). The reference is to the hair.58
33. THEN HE SHALL BE SHAVEN. The head or the beard shall be shaven. However, the place of the netek (scall) shall not be shaven.
34. AND HE SHALL WASH HIS CLOTHES. It is unnecessary to say that he shall bathe in water.

36. SHALL NOT SEEK. The meaning of yevakker is, he shall seek. Similarly u-vikkartim (and seek them out) (Ezek. 34:11). It is close in meaning to the word separate.59 Similarly He shall not inquire (yevakker) whether it be good or bad (Lev. 27:33).
39. A TETTER. The word bohak (tetter) is known in Rabbinic literature.60 It has no counterpart in Scripture.

40. BE FALLEN OFF. Yimmaret (be fallen off) is similar to moretim (them that plucked off the hair) in And my cheeks to them that plucked off the hair (Is. 50:6).61 The latter62 refers to the hair that is around the cheeks.
HE IS BALD. Kere’ach (bald) is similar to korchah (baldness) in nor make any baldness (Deut. 14:1). The meaning of his head is, his entire head.

41. FOREHEAD-BALD. The word gibbe’ach (forehead-bald) has no neighbor63 except in this section. Gibbe’ach is an adjective. In my opinion kere’ach (bald) refers to the top of the head.64 Scripture does not mention a woman65 because a woman does not become bald as she contains a lot of moisture,66 and hair is similar to grass.67
43. AS THE APPEARANCE OF LEPROSY IN THE SKIN OF THE FLESH. On the rest of the body.68

45. HIS CLOTHES SHALL BE RENT. The word perumim means rent. The leper is to be so dressed so that he may be recognized because of his abnormal garb. Or the leper is to behave like a mourner. Scripture therefore states, his clothes shall be rent, and the hair of his head shall go loose. The reason for the latter is so that the leper mourn for his evil actions, for this plague came upon him because of his deeds.
HIS UPPER LIP. Safam refers to the upper lip. The mem of safam is a root letter. The word sefamo (his beard) in nor trimmed his beard (II Sam. 19:22)69 is proof.70

AND HE SHALL COVER.71 With his garments. The word yateh (he shall cover) is related to the word oteh (coverest) in Who coverest Thyself with light (Ps. 104:2). He shall cover his upper lip so that he does not harm anyone with the breath of his mouth.
AND…UNCLEAN. The word unclean is repeated. When the leper passes on a road in an inhabited area he shall continually announce72 that he is unclean so that people will be on guard and not touch him.
46. ALL THE DAYS WHEREIN THE PLAGUE IS IN HIM HE SHALL BE UNCLEAN. For he is truly unclean. The word badad (alone) is explained73 in the Book of Lamentations.74

48. OR IN THE WARP, OR IN THE WOOF. The meaning of sheti (warp) and erev (woof) is known. It is possible that the word sheti is related to the word shet (buttocks) in ve-chasufe shet (buttocks uncovered) (Is. 20:4) wherein the word shet means the foundation,75 as the clause When the foundations (ha-shatot) are destroyed (Ps. 11:3) proves. The word erev (woof) refers to that which is mixed with the warp.76
OR IN THE SKIN. As it is.77
OR IN ANY THING MADE OF SKIN. Such as a coverlet (II Kings 8:15) or a bottle (Jud. 4:19).

49. GREENISH. The word yerakrak (greenish) is related to the word yerek (green), for the color of the affliction is like it. The word is doubled78 to indicate that it is less than full green. The same applies to shecharchoret (swarthy) (Cant. 1:6).79 Others say that the reverse is true.80

51. MALIGNANT. The word mameret (malignant) is similar to the word mammir (pricking) in a pricking brier (sillon mamir) (Ezek. 28:24). Now, since the word sillon (brier) means a thorn, the word mamir means painful.81 The second mem in mameret is a root letter and the word mameret is not related to the word me’erah (curse).82 It is possible that the reason Scripture does not mention silk and cotton83 is that the Torah speaks of what is contemporarily present.84 Compare, If thou see the ass of him that hateth thee (Ex. 23:5). The same law applies to a horse and a mule. On the other hand, it is possible that the affliction only strikes wool and flax.
55. AFTER THAT THE PLAGUE IS WASHED. The word hukkabbes (is washed) is an infinitive whose subject is not identified. It is in the hofal.

A FRET. The word pechetet (fret) has no brother in Scripture.85 It is known in Rabbinic literature.86 Pechetet refers to a defect which appears in the karachat (bareness…within) or the gabachat (bareness…without) of the garments. The Gaon says that karachat refers to the underside of the garment, for gabachat refers to the face of the garment. If this is the case, then the word kere’ach (bald) (v. 40) refers to the back of the head. He explained well.

57. AND IF IT APPEAR STILL. The word tera’eh (it appear)87 refers to the pechetet (the fret).88 Similarly porachat hi (it is breaking out).89 After stating thou shalt burn [it], Scripture goes on to say that the place of the affliction alone shall be burned.90
58. THEN IT SHALL BE WASHED THE SECOND TIME. There is divine command to wash it twice.

IF THE PLAGUE BE DEPARTED FROM THEM. Ve-sar me-hem ha-naga means if the plague be departed from them.91 I have previously shown you many such instances.92 Ve-khubbas (it shall be washed) is a pu’al.93

59. THIS IS THE LAW OF THE PLAGUE OF LEPROSY IN A GARMENT OF WOOL. Our verse has four words in the construct.94 Elsewhere in Scripture we find five words in the construct.95 Compare, Gibore chayil melechet avodat bet haElohim (very able men for the work of the service of the house of God) (I Chron. 9:13). They all depend (semukhim)96 on God, who supports (somekh) all who fall.97
chapter.ftnote: 1 See Deut. 21:5.
2 I.E. paraphrases Lev. 20:2. His point is that our verse reads “a man,” not an Israelite.

3 According to the Sifra, Scripture employs the term “man” because the latter includes converts to Judaism. According to Krinsky, I.E. interprets similarly. However, this is far from certain, for elsewhere I.E. refers to any non-Jew living in the Land of Israel as a stranger. See I.E. on Ex. 20:8 (Vol. 2, p. 427).
4 Bringeth an offering unto the Lord.
5 See Lev. 22:18: Whosoever he be of the house of Israel, or of the strangers in Israel.
6 The stranger, like the Israelite, is quarantined as long as he has the malady.
7 This comment seems to indicate that I.E., contrary to Krinsky, refers to a non-Jewish stranger.
8 On someone’s body.
9 Aaron means Aaron and those who succeed him as kohen gadol.
10 In the temple period.
11 A city of kohanim. It was the birthplace of the prophet Jeremiah. See Jer. 1:1.
12 Aaron’s descendents are priests by virtue of their pedigree. Why then was it necessary for Scripture to add the priests? Hence I.E.’s comment.
13 Se’et is the name of an illness caused by the burning bile in the body (Nahmanides).
14 Translated according to I.E.
15 Translated according to I.E.
16 The word for fire comes from the root nun, sin, alef, which means to lift up. Hence I.E.’s comment.
17 That is, attach me.
18 Hafakh is a kal. A kal is active. I.E. points out that in our verse, hafakh has the meaning of a passive form.
19 Amok (deep) is deeper than shafal (lower) (Weiser).
20 Literally, and shall make him unclean.
21 In other words, and shall make him unclean should be rendered, and shall pronounce him unclean.
22 Literally, then the priest shall shut the plague (et ha-nega) seven days.
23 In other words, the plague (et ha-nega) means the person who has the affliction.
24 See I.E. on Lev. 12:2 and the notes thereto.
25 Literally, stay in its eyes.
26 Literally, its eyes.

27 See Onkolos: kum ke-dehavah (it remains as it was). Also see Rashi: “In its appearance in its original size.” According to this interpretation amad be-enav (stay in appearance) is to be rendered, remained as it was.
28 According to this interpretation kehah ha-nega (the plague be dim) means the affliction is black.
29 According to this interpretation the clause should be rendered, and his eyes were dark.
30 In other words, kehot levanot (dull white) means black white.
31 It means diminished.
32 Translated according to I.E. See Krinsky.
33 He did not “cut them down to size.”
34 Literally, and the priest shall clean him.
35 In other words, “and the priest shall clean him” means: and the kohen shall declare him clean.
36 In verse 2. It means he shall be brought with or without his consent. See I.E. on verse 2.
37 The illness turned the black hair white.
38 In other words, basar chai (raw flesh; literally, live flesh) explains michyat (quick).
39 I.E.’s term for the hifil.
40 Literally, and he shall clean the malady.
41 Literally, but if the raw flesh return. Hence I.E.’s comment.
42 Translated according to I.E.

43 That tzirah means a disease. There are some who argue that the term “sent” (shalach) applies only to living things. They translate ha-tizirah (the disease) in Ex. 23:28 as the hornet. They render Ex. 23:28 as I will send the hornet.
44 A dot which indicates a pronominal suffix (her or its). The heh of marah is a pronominal suffix. We would therefore expect it to have a mappik. Hence I.E.’s comment.
45 Yadah (her hand) and raglah end in kamatz, mappik heh. If marehah followed their vocalization, the word would read marah.
46 The root of marehah is resh, alef, heh.
47 A pronominal suffix heh. The word should have read yirenhah. Yasgirennu should have read yasgirennhu.
48 Mi-mennah and mi-mennu (from it) should have read mi-mennhah and mi-mennhu. See I. E. on Ex 1:9 (Vol. 2, pp. 11-14).
49 Hebrew, tachtehah (literally, beneath it).
50 Tachtehah is to be rendered, it its place.
51 A tzarevet (scar) is a mark caused by the searing of the skin. It does not indicate disease.
52 According to I.E. kehah means be diminished.

53 In verse 23 if the affliction remains as it was, it is declared clean. However, the affliction in our verse has to diminish, in addition to not spreading, for the afflicted person to be declared clean (Krinsky).
54 Till now Scripture introduced the afflictions with the term adam (man). It now employs ish ve-ishah (a man or a woman). Hence I.E.’s comment.

55 Our verse deals with an affliction in the head and the beard. Had it read adam, then we would have thought that the law spoken of in our verse applies only to males. Hence Scripture speaks of a man and a woman. The law regarding the affliction in the head applies to both a man and a woman, while the law of the beard applies only to a man.

56 The law regarding an affliction in a bald head does not apply to a woman, for women are rarely bald. Hence Scripture could not use the term adam with regard to the aforementioned. Scripture thus wanted to emphasize that the law regarding afflictions in the hairy head applies to both men and women.
57 So Sarim and Krinsky.
58 A netek is so called because the hair is torn or removed from the place of the malady.
59 It means to investigate in order to separate.
60 It has the meaning of shine or glisten. See Yershalmi, Pes. 1: “When the candles burned brightly (mavhikim).”
61 Both words come from the root mem, resh, tet and have a similar meaning.
62 Unlike the similar word in our verse, which refers to the hair on the head.
63 The word gibbe’ach is not found elsewhere in Scripture.
64 From the top of the head backwards to the base of the skull.
65 In introducing this law.
66 A woman’s body contains more water than that of a man.

67 Grass requires water in order to grow. Similarly, hair requires moisture to grow. Thus a well-watered body such as that of a female will not lose its hair. I.E. speaks from the point of view of medieval science. What he says is rejected by modern biology.
68 See Rashi: “As the appearance of leprosy that is stated in the section (treating) of the skin of the flesh (Lev. 13:2).”
69 I.E. renders this as nor trimmed his upper lip.
70 If the mem of safam were not a root letter, then it would not be present when the word is followed by a pronominal suffix.
71 His upper lip.
72 The repetition of the word unclean indicates consistency. It does not mean he should announce twice that he is unclean.
73 Grammatically explained.
74 See I.E. on Lam. 1:1.
75 I.E. renders ve-chasufay shet (Is. 20:4), and with foundations uncovered.
76 The root of erev means a mixture.
77 Unworked skin, raw material.
78 The resh and kof of yerek are doubled in yerakrak.
79 From the word shachar (black). Shecharchoret means blackish.
80 They say that the word yerakrak (greenish) means very green and shecharchoret very black.
81 I. E. renders sillon mamir (Ezek. 28:24) as a painful thorn.
82 For the word me’erah has only one mem in it.
83 When it lays down the laws dealing with plagues in garments.
84 Plagues do not usually strike silk or wool (Weiser).
85 The word is not found again in Scripture.
86 Pachat in Rabbinic literature refers to a cavity, a pit or a defective spot. See Sotah 21a; Betzah 4:3.
87 Which is feminine.
88 Which is feminine, and not to the word nega (plague), which is masculine.
89 Hi (it) is feminine. It too refers to pechetet, not to nega.

90 I.E. renders be-esh tisrefennu et asher bo ha-naga (thou shalt burn that wherein the plague is with fire) as thou shalt burn it (tisrefennu), i.e., the place where the malady is. In other words, “it” refers to the place on the garment, not to the entire garment.
91 Not and the affliction will depart from them.
92 Where the vav does not mean and, but indicates the pluperfect.
93 Literally, a verb whose subject is not identified.
94 In succession. They are zot, torat, negaha, tzara’at (this is the law of the plague of leprosy).
95 In succession.
96 The words in the construct in I Chron. 9:13 are connected to the word God.
97 See Ps. 145:14. This is a word play. The Hebrew word for the construct form samukh literally means connected or dependent. Hence I.E.’s homily.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 14
chapter.p: 1. [AND THE LORD SPOKE.] Scripture states and the Lord spoke1 because it begins the laws of the one who is cleansed. Rabbi Jonah the Spaniard, the grammarian, says that and, behold, if the plague of leprosy be healed in the leper (v. 3) is inverted. It should have read “and, behold, if the leper be healed from the plague of leprosy.”2 Why should we because of our lack of knowledge, invert the words of the living God? Does not Scripture elsewhere read that the scall is healed, he is clean (Lev. 13:37)?3 Furthermore, Scripture also reads, because the plague is healed (Lev. 14:48).

2. [HE SHALL BE BROUGHT.] He shall be brought is to be interpreted like its counterparts,4 for it is possible that after the plague of leprosy is removed the afflicted person will not want to bring what he is obligated to.5

3. AND THE PRIEST SHALL GO FORTH OUT OF THE CAMP. Even though the kohen declared him clean he shall not enter the camp or the city until he brings his cleanliness offerings and completes6 all that he has been commanded to do.
AND THE PRIEST SHALL GO FORTH. The reference is not to the kohen gadol.7 The meaning of or unto one of his sons the priests (Lev 13:2) has now been clarified.8

4. TO TAKE FOR HIM THAT IS TO BE CLEANSED. The kohen shall take of his own.9 Some say that the leper shall give them.10 The tav of the hitpa’el form is swallowed by the dagesh in the tet of mittaher (cleansed). The word mittaher follows the form of mithallel (boasteth himself)11 in he that boasteth himself (Prov. 25:14).
TWO…BIRDS.12 The term tzippor applies to all birds. Note, he shall take any bird that he finds.
LIVING. Not dead.13
CLEAN. He shall not take from the unclean.14

AND CEDAR-WOOD…AND HYSSOP. These are the biggest and smallest among the plants. This is proven by Scripture’s description of Solomon’s wisdom.15 There is no reason to search for the meaning of the word ezov (hyssop), for it is known by tradition.16 Note, the leper and the plagued house and uncleanness caused by a corpse17 are similar.18 They are also similar to the Egyptian Passover.19
5. AND THE PRIEST SHALL COMMAND TO KILL. The priest shall command another kohen or an Israelite.20 Some say he shall command the leper. However, the latter is farfetched.21
IN AN EARTHEN VESSEL. The word el (in)22 is to be rendered as over. Similarly el (for) in For this child I prayed (I Sam. 1:27).23
OVER RUNNING WATER.24 Taken from a bubbling fountain.25
6. AND SHALL DIP THEM. The cedar-wood, the scarlet, and the hyssop.
OVER…WATER. With which the blood was mixed.
7. AND HE SHALL SPRINKLE. From the blood mixed with water after immersing the living bird and the other items mentioned.26

INTO THE OPEN FIELD. An uninhabited place so that the leprosy does not infect anyone. The sprinkling was done with all three.27 On the other hand, it might only have been done with the hyssop as in the case of one who has been made unclean by a corpse.28
8. AND…SHALL WASH HIS CLOTHES AND SHAVE OFF ALL HIS HAIR. A general statement.29

AND BATHE HIMSELF IN WATER, AND HE SHALL BE CLEAN. In the evening, as is the law.30 After stating this,31 Scripture backtracks and explains that this32 occurs after seven days.33 The same law applied to the seven days of Miriam.34 Scripture details35 that he shall shave all his hair on the seventh day. Scripture then goes on to explain that the meaning of all his hair is, the hair on his head, his beard, and his eyebrows. The word gabbot (eyebrows) is close in meaning to the word gav (high place).36
9. EVEN ALL HIS HAIR. The hair of the feet. Some say the hair of his arms, thighs, and chest.

10. TWO HE-LAMBS…AND ONE EWE-LAMB. The leper shall bring a he-lamb for a burnt offering as is the law regarding all who have evil thoughts,37 because the plague of leprosy is a punishment for deeds of the tongue.38 Another he-lamb is brought as a guilt offering as is the law with all guilt offerings.39 A ewe-lamb is offered for a sin offering as is the law with all sin offerings.40 Also three tenth parts of an ephah as is the law, for a tenth part of an ephah is brought with a lamb.41
AND ONE LOG. A measure.42 The term log has no brother.43

[11. AND THOSE THINGS.] This refers to the he-lambs and the ewe-lamb. Also, this guilt offering44 and also the sin offering,45 with the exception of the parts offered on the altar,46 belong to the kohen.47

14. UPON THE TIP. The meaning of tenuch (tip) is understood from its context.48 Now, the one who is cleansed from leprosy, which is an affliction in the body, is similar to the kohen who is installed,49 for sin is like a leprosy in the soul.50 The thumb is the place of connection.51 It is the main component of all acts.52 The right thumb was selected because of the power of the right side. The tip of the ear is a reminder to listen to what God has commanded.53

15. INTO THE PALM OF HIS OWN LEFT HAND.54 The palm in kaf ha-kohen (the palm of his own)55 refers to the palm of the kohen who cleanses. Scripture reads thus56 because such style is considered elegant in the Hebrew language.57 The verse that follows is proof of this.58
16. BEFORE THE LORD. Towards the entrance of the tent of meeting.
17. UPON THE BLOOD OF THE GUILT-OFFERING. Which is upon the tip, the thumb, and the great toe.
19. AND THE PRIEST SHALL OFFER THE SIN-OFFERING. The ewe-lamb as is the law with all sin offerings.59

20. AND THE PRIEST SHALL OFFER THE BURNT-OFFERING. The he-lamb and its meal offering, which consists of a tenth of an ephah.60 Some say that the kohen shall offer the entire meal offering61 with the burnt offering.62 He shall offer the guilt offering first63 because it is more severe.64
AND HE SHALL BE CLEAN. Then65 he shall be clean like all who are clean.

21. AND IF HE BE POOR. The term dal (poor) is found with regard to the body.66 Compare, poor (dal) and very ill-favored (Gen. 41:19); Happy is he that considereth the poor67 (dal) (Ps. 41:2); son of the king, art thou thus becoming leaner (dal) (II Sam. 13:4). The term dal is also found with regard to one who has no money.68
33. AND THE LORD SPOKE UNTO MOSES AND UNTO AARON. Scripture begins explaining the laws dealing with leprosy in a house.69

[34. WHEN YE ARE COME INTO THE LAND OF CANAAN.] Scripture reads thus70 because this law applies only in the Land of Israel because of the great status of the land; for the temple was among them, and the Glory was in the midst of the temple.
AND I PUT. The event71 is contingent on God’s putting.72
[35.] THEN HE THAT OWNETH THE HOUSE SHALL COME. There is a divine command that he73 come to the kohen.
36. THAT THEY EMPTY THE HOUSE. The master of the house and all men of his household.74 Scripture employs the plural75 for it is to be emptied quickly.76
BEFORE THE PRIEST GO IN. For the kohen will close up the house because of its uncertain status.77 The house shall be emptied before its status is declared to be in doubt.

37. HOLLOW STREAKS. The word sheka’arurot (hollow streaks) has no sister.78 We do not know if it is a quadrilateral79 with the last letter80 doubled or if it is a pentaliteral.81 The meaning of sheka’arurot is to be ascertained from its context. Some say that it refers to marks or streaks. Others say that it is a compound word. It is akin to va-tishka (sank down)82 in and the fire sank down (Num. 11:2) and to rorot, which is related to the word rar (run)83 in run with his issue (Lev. 15:3).84 However, this is far-fetched.
AND THE APPEARANCE THEREOF.85 The appearance of each one of them86 be lower [than the wall].
40. THAT THEY TAKE OUT THE STONES. Ve-chilletzu means that they take out. Compare, challetzeni (deliver me) in Deliver me, O Lord, from the evil man (Ps. 140:2).
INTO AN UNCLEAN PLACE. So that no one remove the stones from there.87 So that it be recognized that they88 are unclean.89

41. AND HE SHALL CAUSE THE HOUSE TO BE SCRAPED. The word yaktzi’a (he shall cause…to be scraped) is related to the word maktzu’ot (planes) (Is. 44:13) and the word ketzi’ot (cassia) in Myrrh, and aloes, and cassia (Ps. 45:9). The meaning of ketz’ot (cassia) is cuttings.90 Some say the corner91 shall be peeled.92 However, this is incorrect, for the plague had already spread in the house.93 Actually, he must scrape the whole house. The meaning of mi-bayit94 means within. The word hiktzu (they scrape off) is related to the word katzeh (extremity), for they only removed the upper extremity.95

42. AND SHALL PLASTER THE HOUSE. The word tach (plaster) is the reverse of yaktzi’a (he shall cause…to be scraped) (v. 41).96 It is related to tachim (daub) in they daub it with whited plaster (Ezek. 13:10).
AND HE SHALL TAKE OTHER MORTAR.97 The owner of the house who wants to dwell in the house. If the plague returns (v. 43), then the kohen shall come (v. 44).98

43. AFTER THE HOUSE HATH BEEN SCRAPED. After the stones have first been taken out and the house has been scraped. Scripture employs the plural forms ve-lakechu (and they shall take) and ve-hevi’u (and put them) to indicate haste.99

45. AND HE SHALL BREAK DOWN THE HOUSE. By command.100 Similarly and he shall carry them forth.101 It is most likely that the house was shut up for seven days.102 However, Scripture employed an abridged style.103 He that goeth into the house all the while that it is shut up (v. 46) which applies to the first and second times is proof of this.104
46. SHALL BE UNCLEAN UNTIL THE EVEN. After he bathes his body as the law requires.105

47. AND HE THAT LIETH. This106 is very severe uncleanliness. He that lies in the house must therefore wash his garments107 and bathe and be unclean until evening. Scripture does not mention that he be unclean until evening, for whoever lies and eats in the house, first comes into the house.108
49. AND HE SHALL TAKE. This is to be interpreted as its counterpart.109
57. WHEN IT IS UNCLEAN. The day when the man or the garment or the house will be unclean or clean.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Our chapter continues the theme of the preceding chapter. Thus the statement And the Lord spoke unto Moses in Lev. 13:1 would appear to apply to our chapter as well. Therefore the clause And the Lord spoke unto Moses in Lev. 14:1 seems unnecessary. Hence I.E. points out that our portion begins with And the Lord spoke because it contains a new commandment, viz., the laws of the cleansing of the leper. In other words, our chapter is not a mere continuation of what came before it.
2 In other words, our verse should be interpreted as if written, if the leper be healed from the plague of leprosy, for according to Rabbi Jonah it is the person not the plague who is healed.
3 There is thus nothing wrong in saying if the plague of leprosy be healed (Lev. 14:3).
4 See I.E. on Lev. 13:2, “He shall be brought, by his consent or against his will.”
5 The offerings listed in verse 10.
6 Reading ve-yashlim as in Vat. Ebr. 38. Most Mikra’ot Gedolot read, ve-yeshalem (and pays).
7 For Scripture does not say, and Aaron the priest shall go forth (Weiser).
8 I.E. had previously noted in his comments on Lev. 12:2 that or unto one of his sons the priests refers to kohanim who are not high priests. He notes that our verse proves that his comment is right.
9 The kohen shall command someone to take the items enumerated in our verse from the kohen’s property.
10 The kohen shall command someone to take the items enumerated in our verse from the leper’s property.
11 Which is a hitpa’el. I.E.’s point is that mittaher is a hitpa’el.
12 Hebrew, tzipporim.
13 By “not dead,” I.E. might mean healthy. See Krinsky.
14 Scripture qualifies “birds” by the term clean, for the word tzippor takes in kosher and non-kosher birds.
15 In I Kings 5:13, Scripture describes Solomon’s wisdom in the following way: And he spoke of trees, from the cedar that is in Lebanon even unto the hyssop that springeth out of the wall…
16 See Nega’im 14:6.
17 See Num. 19:18.
18 In that part of their cleansing ritual entails being sprinkled with a hyssop.
19 A hyssop was employed in the Passover ritual practiced in Egypt. See Ex. 12:22.
20 To slaughter the bird.
21 For the leper is being cleansed.
22 Which literally means to.
23 Here too the word el is not to be rendered literally.
24 Literally, over live water.
25 Live water means water from a bubbling fountain.
26 The cedar-wood, the scarlet, and the hyssop.
27 The cedar-wood, the scarlet, and the hyssop.
28 See Num. 19:18.

29 The first half of our verse does not describe what the leper is to undergo on the day that he is sprinkled with the hyssop, but rather describes in general terms what the leper must undergo seven days later in order to be cleansed. The details are given in the next verse.
30 See Lev. 17:15: And bathe himself in water, and be unclean until the even; then shall he be clean. See also Lev. 11:32.
31 And…shall wash his clothes and shave off all his hair, and bathe himself in water, and he shall be clean.
32 The washing and shaving.
33 In other words, But shall dwell outside his tent seven days describes what happens before the bathing and shaving.
34 Miriam, who was struck with leprosy, had to dwell outside of the camp for seven days. See Num. 12:14.
35 In verse 9.
36 See Ezek. 16:24.
37 See I.E. on Lev. 1:4.
38 See Num. 12:1-13. Also see Arakhin 15b.
39 See Lev. 5:18.
40 See Lev. 4:32.
41 See verse 21.
42 The word log refers to a measure.
43 The word is not found again in Scripture.
44 Like other guilt offerings.
45 Like other sin offerings.
46 Which are burned on the altar.

47 The guilt offering and the sin offering brought by the leper are part of a cleansing ritual. One might think that they are not to be treated as all other guilt and sin offerings. Hence I.E.’s comments.
48 It refers to a part of the ear.
49 Part of the installation ritual entailed the placing of the blood of a sacrifice on the tip of the right ear, upon their thumbs and the great toe of their foot.
50 The kohen who is installed is cleansed from leprosy of the soul, i.e., from sin.
51 I.E. believed that the sinews of the fingers are connected to the thumb. See Krinsky.
52 The thumb is necessary for all sophisticated acts of the hand.
53 The placing of the blood of the guilt offering on the tip of the ear serves as a reminder that one should listen to God’s commandments.
54 Literally, into the palm of the priest’s left hand.
55 Literally, the palm of the priest.
56 Into the palm of the priest’s left hand, rather than into his left hand.
57 It is considered poetic to employ a noun where we would expect a pronoun.
58 That our verse speaks of one and the same kohen.
59 Which required a female offering. See Lev. 4:32.
60 According to this interpretation the three tenth parts of an ephah mentioned in verse 10 were divided among the three sacrifices offered by the leper.
61 All three tenth parts of an ephah mentioned in verse 10.
62 For Scripture does not mention the term meal offering with regard to the sin offering and guilt offering.
63 Before the sin and burnt offerings.
64 It indicates that the one who offers it is guilty of a crime. See I.E. on Lev. 5:19.
65 Not before.
66 It is used to describe the state of a person or an animal.
67 That is, the poor in body, the sick.
68 In other words, it means poor.
69 Hence it opens with And the Lord spoke.

ftnote.italic: When ye are come into the land of Canaan…

chapter.ftnote: 71 The house plagues.
72 The house plagues are a result of divine providence. They do not come by accident.
73 The owner of the house.
74 Shall empty the house. Scripture reads, that they empty. Hence I.E.’s comment.
75 That they empty.
76 Hence all men of the household must be involved in emptying the house.
77 It is uncertain whether the house is afflicted or not.
78 The word is not found again in Scripture. I.E. uses the term sister because sheka’arurot is feminine.
79 From the root shin, kof, ayin, resh.
80 The resh.
81 From the root shin, kof, ayin, resh, tav.
82 Translated literally.
83 That is, flow.
84 That is, sheka’arurot is made up of the words shaka (sank down) and rorot (run). According to this interpretation sheka’arurot means running cracks in the skin.
85 Hebrew, u-marehen (literally, and their appearance). Hence I.E.’s comment.

86 The plagues. The verse opens with the singular (the plague). It goes on to speak of “their appearance.” According to I.E. such a combination of the singular and the plural indicates each one of the plural references.
87 From where they are placed.
88 The stones.
89 Therefore not to be used.
90 He renders yaktzi’a he shall cut.
91 Hebrew, miktzo’a (corner).
92 In other words, the meaning of yaktzi’a is, they shall peel the corner. This interpretation connects the word yaktzi’a to the word miktzo’a (corner). See Ezek. 46:21.
93 Why then peel only the corners?
94 Mi-bayit literally means from the house. Hence I.E.’s comment.
95 The top layer.
96 In other words, he shall plaster the place that he peeled (Krinsky).
97 In most editions of I.E. this comment has been placed after verse 43.
98 And declare the house unclean.
99 See I.E. on verse 36 and the notes thereto.
100 The kohen himself does not physically break down the house.
101 Its meaning is, by command.
102 As when the plague is first seen in the house. See verse 38.
103 It omits the law that the house is to be closed up for seven days.
104 That the plague is seen in the house.
106 Eating and lying in the house.
107 Wherein the one who comes into the house does not.
108 And Scripture already stated in verse 46 that whoever comes into the house is unclean unto evening.
109 Verse 4.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 15
chapter.p: AND THE LORD SPOKE UNTO MOSES AND TO AARON. For the kohanim distinguish between a woman who has an issue (zavah) and one who menstruates (niddah).1 Compare the Rabbinic interpretation on between blood and blood2 (Deut. 17:8). Scripture now begins to deal with those who become unclean from a hidden source,3 for until now it dealt with leprosy which is a visible plague.
2. AN ISSUE. The word zav (issue) is similar to the word zavat (flowing) in flowing with milk (Ex. 44:13). Zav refers to dripping drops.4
OUT OF HIS FLESH. A euphemism for the male’s private part.5
HIS ISSUE. Zovo (his issue) is a noun.6
3. AND THIS SHALL BE HIS UNCLEANLINESS. This means the issue takes two forms.7
HIS FLESH RUN WITH HIS ISSUE. The word rar (run) is related to the word riro (his spittle) in, and let his spittle fall down upon his beard (I Sam. 21:14).

OR BE STOPPED. The word hechtim means stopped. It is related to the word chatum (sealed) in that is sealed (Is. 29:11). It means that the issue pools and congeals so that semen is not ejaculated when the afflicted sleeps with a women. The same law applies to what the one who has an issue lies or sits on.8 Similarly, there is one law regarding the one who touches what the afflicted lies on or sits on.9
7. ANDS HE THAT TOUCHETH THE FLESH OF HIM THAT HATH THE ISSUE. Any part without exception.10

8. SPIT. The meaning of yarok (spit) is known. It comes from a double root.11 The fact that the kof of rukki (my spittle) (Job 7:19) has a dagesh is proof of this.12 Note, the spit of the one who suffers an issue is harmful,13 for the issue is one of the infectious diseases. It is not the practice of men to spit in the face of other people.14 What happened occurred unintentionally. The one suffering from an issue expectorated his spittle and it fell on a clean person.15
9. AND WHAT SADDLE. Which, as the transmitters of tradition explained, becomes unclean.16
10. ANY THING THAT IS UNDER HIM. Under the saddle shall become lightly unclean.17 However, the uncleanliness of those who carry them18 is more strict.19

11. WITHOUT HAVING RINSED HIS HANDS IN WATER. It would have appeared to us20 that any food or anything similar, that the one having an issue touched by hand,21 and the hands were washed, is not unclean, for the afflicted did not touch the place of the issue.22 However, since we saw that our fathers23 explained that the hands are like the body24 we accept their words. According to the plain meaning of our verse if the one experiencing an issue touches someone with hands that have been washed the one touched is unclean but his garments are not unclean. However, if the one suffering the issue did not wash his hands then the garments are unclean.25 This law is similar26 to the one regarding he who touches anything which is under the saddle.27
13. FOR HIS CLEANSING.28 From the day of his cleansing.29 The sacrifice consists of a burnt-offering30 and a sin-offering,31 for the issue is a punishment for sin.
16. GO OUT. Involuntarily.32

FLOW OF SEED. Shikhvat (flow) is similar to shikhvat (layer) in the layer of dew (Ex. 16:14).33 It is related to the word yashkiv (pour out) in who can pour out (Job 38:37). It would appear to us34 that the garment or the skin requires washing if it has wet semen or dry semen on it.35 However, the truth lies with the words of tradition.36

Scripture37 concludes the laws of the male.38 It then begins with the female.39 The meaning of And if he be on the bed (v. 23) refers back to the object40 that she sits upon (v. 22). Now the object41 is on the bed or the object42 is on another object.43 The uncleanliness is therefore light.44 Scripture does not mention a saddle with regards to a women for Scripture speaks of what is prevalent.45 The law is the same.46

19. IN HER FLESH. In the women’s private part. Those who explain then he shall bathe all his flesh (v. 16) which is written concerning one who ejaculates as referring to the penis47 err. The word all is proof.48

24. AND IF ANY MAN LIE WITH HER. Without any sinful intent.49 On the contrary, he erred in sleeping with her.50 Behold her menstrual flow came while he was with her. This is the meaning of be upon him, for the one who sleeps with a menstruating women incurs the penalty of karet.51 The same law applies to a women who has an issue,52 even though it is not stated.
AND EVERY BED WHEREON HE LIETH SHALL BE UNCLEAN. For he is unclean for seven days. He also defiles others. The latter is so even though it is not stated.
25. MANY DAYS NOT IN THE TIME OF HER IMPURITY. Every women has fixed periods. Or, she had an issue added to her menstruation.53
29. AND BRING THEM. Ve-hevi’ah (and bring them) is ultimately accented. It is an irregular word.54

31. THUS SHALL YE SEPARATE. Some say that ve-hizzartem (thus shall ye separate) is missing a heh55 and is to be interpreted ve-hizzhartem (and you shall warn). This cannot be so, for the heh is not vowel letter.56 It is only silent at the end of a word.57 On the contrary, ve-hizzartem is related to the word ve-yinnazeru (that they separate)58 in that they separate themselves from the holy things of the children of Israel (Lev. 22:2). The meaning of that ve-hizzartem is, and you shall distance.59 The word nazir (nazirite) is derived from the same root. A nazir is one who has distanced himself from the lusts of the world. Ve-hizzartem is vocalized like the word ve-hippaltem (and you shall divide)60 in, and you shall divide the land (Ezek. 45:1), for the nun61 is swallowed in the dagesh.62
IN THEIR UNCLEANLINESS. Be-tumatam (in their uncleanliness) is to be rendered because of their uncleanliness.63 Its meaning is, when they defile My tabernacle.64
32. SO THAT HE IS UNCLEAN THEREBY. There is a Divine command for him to be in a state of ritual impurity. I will explain this later.65
[33.] Whether it be a man explains the law of him that hath an issue (v. 32). With her that is unclean refers to a women who has an issue or menstruates.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Hence this commandment was also communicated to Aaron.

2 Deuteronomy 17:8-9 states that if there be a dispute regarding blood and blood then the kohen shall decide the aforementioned. The Rabbis interpret between blood and blood as meaning between “between menstrual blood and blood of an issue and blood of childbirth (Sifre, on Deut. 17:8).”
3 Such as an issue.
4 I.E. interprets Ex. 44:13 as “dripping with milk.”
5 Flesh is a euphemism for the penis.
6 With the pronominal suffix.
7 His flesh will run with his issue or be stopped with his issue (v. 3).
8 They have to be immersed in water and are unclean till the evening.
9 He has to immerse himself and his clothes and remains unclean until evening.

10 Unlike earlier (v. 2 and v. 3) where the word flesh refers to the penis here it refers to any organ. Thus the meaning of and he that toucheth the flesh of him that hath the issue means, and he that touches any part of him that has the issue.
11 Its root is resh, kof, kof.
12 For the dagesh compensates for the missing root kof.
13 Hence it is a source of uncleanliness.

14 And if (ve-khi) he that hath an issue spit upon him that is clean could conceivably be rendered, and when (ve-khi) he that hath an issue spit upon him that is clean. “And when” implies that this is the normal course of events. Hence I.E.’s comment.
15 In other words, ve-khi is to be rendered as “and if” that is and if by accident.

16 According to the Rabbis the term mercav (saddle) refers to equipment set aside for riding. See Torat Kohanim, Metzora 3:9. Also see Rashi, “…The hold in front of the saddle…becomes unclean as a part of something for riding on (mercav)…and the saddle…is unclean as being something to sit upon (moshav)” (Rosenbaum and Silverman translation).
17 It does not require immersion of garments (Weiser).
18 The objects earlier mentioned, i.e., that which the one having an issue lies upon, sits upon, or rides upon.
19 It requires the immersion of garments.
20 From a plain reading of the text.
21 In others words, toucheth means touched by hand.
22 The hands most certainly did not have any issue on them, hence his hands do not defile. However, if the hands were not washed they may have come into contact with his issue, hence they defile.
23 The Rabbis of the Talmud.

24 According to the Rabbis the term hands in our verse does not only refer to the hands. It refers to the whole body. According tao the Rabbis without having rinsed his hands with water means without immersing his body. See Niddah 66b; Kiddushin 25a.
25 According to halakhah there is no difference whether the one having an issue touched a person with hands that have or have not been washed.
26 In that at times it entails a light uncleanliness and at times a strict uncleanliness.
27 One who touches that which is under the saddle becomes lightly unclean. However, one carries these objects becomes more strictly unclean. See I.E. on verse 10.
28 Hebrew, le-taharrato, literally, to his cleansing.
29 The lamed of le-taharrato is not to be rendered to, but from. Hence le-tahorrato is to be interpreted, from his cleaning.
30 To atone for evil thoughts. See I.E. on Lev. 1:4. The reference might be to thoughts of forbidden sexual practices. See next note.

31 To atone for transgressions actually committed. According to Krinsky the reference is to prohibited sexual practices. The fact that Scripture goes on to speak of a man having an emission of semen might support this interpretation.
32 For verse 18 speaks of voluntary emission of semen.
33 Which I.E. renders a descent or a pouring down of dew. See I.E. on Ex. 16:14 (Vol. 2, p. 320).
34 From the plain meaning of the text.
35 If it come into contact with wet or dry semen, for the verse does not differentiate among them.
36 The Mishnah in Niddah 7:1 states, “Semen [coveys] uncleanliness when wet but not when dry.”
37 In verse 18.
38 Who has a normal or abnormal discharge from his penis.
39 Who has a normal or abnormal discharge of blood.
40 I.E. renders And if he (hu) be on the bed as, And if it be on the bed, for the word hu may mean he or it.
41 The object which a person touches.
42 The object which a person touches.
43 Upon which the women sits.
44 The one who touches it does not have to immerse his garments.

45 Most of riding was done by men. Some editions read behamah (cattle). According to this version our text reads, for Scripture speaks of [an] animal. The latter is probably to be interpreted, Scripture speaks of one who usually rides on an animal, that is, males, and not females.
46 This law applies to both men and women.
47 They take the word flesh to mean penis. See I.E. on verse 2.
48 That they err, for “all” takes in the entire body. Thus flesh in our verse does not only apply to the penis.
49 He has no intention in engaging in coitus with a menstruating women.
50 He was not aware that her menstrual flow would commence while he slept with her.

51 See Lev. 20:18. Had the man had an evil intention when he had intercourse with the menstruating women then Scripture would have mentioned that he committed a major sin. Scripture appears to state, as a matter of fact, that a man who sleeps with a menstruating woman is unclean. One may take this to imply that one is permitted to sleep with a menstruating woman but is unclean if he does so. Hence I.E.’s comments.
52 The same law applies to one who engages in coitus with a women who has an issue.
53 Her flow continued beyond her menstrual period.
54 It should have been penultimately accented.
55 According to this interpretation ve-hizzartem comes from the root zayin, heh, resh.
56 A vowel letter is occasionally dropped, for it is not sounded.
57 It serves as a vowel letter at the end of the word. However, when it comes in the middle of a word it is sounded. Hence it is not dropped.
58 It comes from the root nun, zayin, resh.
59 Or thus shall ye separate.
60 From the root nun, peh, lamed.
61 The root nuns of ve-hizzartem and ve-hippaltem.
62 In the zayin of ve-hizzartem and the peh of ve-hippaltem.
63 The bet of be-tumatam has the meaning of “because.”

64 When they defile My tabernacle explains because of their uncleanliness. The point is that Scripture does not prohibit being “unclean.” It only does so when one enters the tabernacle in a state of impurity.
65 See I.E. on Lev. 18:20.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 16
chapter.p: 1. AFTER THE DEATH. After God warned Israel not to incur the death penalty1 He also told Moses to caution Aaron not to die as his sons died.2 This section is proof that the sons of Aaron brought the incense within the veil.3

[WHEN THEY DREW NEAR.] The word be-korvatam (when they drew near) is an infinitive.4 Compare, le-korvah (to come unto) in to come unto the work (Ex. 36:2).5 The heh in le-korvah has been turned into a tav in be-korvatam as is the practice with the feminine heh.6 Rabbi Joshua,7 who says that be-korvatam is a noun following the paradigm of chokhmatam (their wisdom) (Jer. 49:7),8 errs.
2. INTO THE HOLY PLACE. In contrast to the tent of meeting.9

FOR I APPEAR IN THE CLOUD.10 It means Aaron shall only enter with incense. He shall produce smoke so that God’s glory will not be seen, and as a result he dies.11 Note, the meaning of ki be-anan era’eh (for I appear in the cloud upon the ark-cover) is, I will not appear to him except through the agency of a cloud.12 There are those who say that the meaning of ki be-anan era’eh al ha-kapporet (for I appear in the cloud) is, because I dwell in a cloud upon the ark-covering.13 For I appear in the cloud is similar in meaning to The Lord hath said that He would dwell in the thick darkness (I Kings 8:12).

3. WITH A YOUNG BULLOCK. Its meaning is not that Aaron should bring the bullock into the holy place14 but rather that he first bring a bullock of his own15 for a sin offering to atone for himself and the kohanim. Others say also for the Levites,16 for they found, And thou shalt write Aaron’s name upon the rod of Levi (Num. 17:18).17 However, this is farfetched. On the contrary, the Levites are considered among the Israelites.

4. THE HOLY LINEN TUNIC. Scripture does not mention the ephod,18 the breastplate,19 and the robe of the ephod,20 for it earlier mentioned, and the sound thereof21 shall be heard when he22 goeth in unto the holy place (Ex. 28:35).23 The men of the second temple who served without the Urim and the Thummim24 learned from this verse [that their practice was proper].25 There were also prophets there.26
6. AND AARON SHALL PRESENT THE BULLOCK OF THE SIN-OFFERING, WHICH IS FOR HIMSELF. To the opening of the tent of meeting as is the law.27

[AND MAKE ATONEMENT FOR HIMSELF.] This means that with it he will make atonement for himself and for his house after he slaughters it.28 There are those who say that presenting the bullock29 is the atonement.30

8. LOTS. We know what they are from the words of our sages.31 The Gaon32 says that Azazel is the name of a mountain. It is so called because of its might.33 God’s name34 is mentioned in Azazel as it is in ke-harere el (the mighty mountains) (Ps. 36:7) and in yakti’el (Joktheel) (II Kings 14:7). The Gaon, the Levite,35 caught him in error. He pointed out that the alef of Azazel is placed between one zayin and the other zayin.36 There are those who say that Azazel is the name of a mountain close to Mount Sinai. God commanded that the goat be led and brought up there until it slipped down the mountain. Later on in the time of the temple, they led it to a different mountain. “And Aaron did” (v. 34) is proof of this.37 The same, in my opinion, as I will explain in its place,38 is true of the festival of Shavu’ot.39 There are those who say that the service40 during the second temple was unlike that of the first, for the kohen41 lacked the garments42 and there was no ark-cover. This commentator says that the goat was sent into the wilderness, for Scripture states, and he shall let go the goat in the wilderness (v. 22).43 The latter is similar in meaning to the bird of the one who is cleansed from leprosy44 which is sent into the open field, an uninhabited place. A land which is cut off45 (v. 22) is proof of this.46 We answered him that they sent the goat into the wilderness as it is written.47 However, the goat was pursued48 until it fled and climbed up a rock. The rabbis therefore said, “and he49 pushes it down.”50 Rabbi Samuel51 says that even though it is written that the goat offered as a sin offering is to be offered to God, the goat that was sent was also offered to God. There is no need for this interpretation, for the goat sent into the wilderness did not serve as an offering since it was not slaughtered. If you are able to understand the secret that follows Azazel52 then you will know its secret and the secret of its name, for it has comrades in Scripture.53 I will reveal a bit of its secret to you in a hint. When you are thirty-three, you will understand it.54
9. AND OFFER HIM55 FOR A SIN-OFFERING. He shall slaughter it.

10. SHALL BE SET ALIVE. The word yo’omad (shall be set) is a hofal.56 The yod57 should have been vocalized with a shuruk.58 However, it was enlarged59 because of the guttural.60 The word yochoram (should be forfeited) in all his substance should be forfeited (Ez. 10:8) is similar.61
TO MAKE ATONEMENT OVER HIM.62 For the atonement shall be upon it.63 It means to send him away.

11. AND AARON SHALL PRESENT. Scripture goes on to explain that after Aaron has presented the bullock and the two goats to the tent of meeting, he shall begin to slaughter his bullock. Scripture does this because64 it dwelt at length on the goats.65
12. A CENSER. The meaning of machtah (censer) is known.
HIS HANDS FULL. Both hands.66

SWEET INCENSE. Mentioned earlier.67 It would have appeared to us that upon the ark-cover (v. 14); and before the arkcover (Ibid.) are to be taken literally. However, the transmitters of tradition said that upon the ark-cover means between the staves.68 The meaning of and before the ark-cover is known from their words.69 What they said is true.

15. THEN SHALL HE KILL THE GOAT OF THE SIN-OFFERING. He shall now, when he goes out,70 slaughter it. There are those who say that he should slaughter the goat before he slaughters the bullock.71 The latter is untrue.72
16. AND HE SHALL MAKE ATONEMENT FOR THE HOLY PLACE. The reference is to the Holy of Holies.
AND SO SHALL HE DO FOR THE TENT OF MEETING. He shall sprinkle seven times before the ark-cover (kaporet)73 and on the horns of the altar of incense.
The meaning of And he shall make atonement for the holy place is that the blood serves as a ransom so that the holy place does not destroy74 because of the uncleanliness of the unclean.
17. AND THERE SHALL BE NO MAN. From among the kohanim.75
TO MAKE ATONEMENT IN THE HOLY PLACE. Inside.76
AND HAVE MADE ATONEMENT FOR HIMSELF, AND FOR HIS HOUSEHOLD. With his sin offering bullock.
AND FOR ALL THE ASSEMBLY OF ISRAEL. With their sin offering goat.
18. AND HE SHALL GO OUT UNTO THE ALTAR. The reference is to the burnt offering altar.77

21. AND HE SHALL PUT THEM. After the sins are removed from Israel they are, as it were, placed on the head of the goat. The sins will go to a place were they will never again be remembered. Scripture speaks in a way that all will understand.78

APPOINTED. Itti (appointed) means prepared for his time.79 Or itti refers to an individual whose custom it was to always lead the goat on the Day of Atonement. The yod80 relates to the word et (time).81 Itti is similar to penimi (internal).82 The interpretation of those who explain itti to mean wise83 does not appear correct to me.84 Our sages, of blessed memory, said that the “bearer”85 was a kohen.86 Their words are true.
24. IN A HOLY PLACE. In the courtyard of the tent of meeting. They used to spread a sheet for the kohen.87

HIS OTHER VESTMENTS.88 With which he serves every day.89 There are those who say that the reference is to the garments mentioned.90 The fact that Scripture does not say and put on other garments (Lev. 6:4) is proof of this.91
HIS BURNT-OFFERING. The reference is to the ram92 and the ram of the people,93 the bullock of the people,94 and the seven lambs,95 for it is so written in Scripture.96

25. AND THE FAT OF THE SIN-OFFERING. The fat of the bullock sin offering97 and the fat of the goat sin offering98 and also the fat of the he-goat sin offering, which is a sin offering belonging to the kohen as is the law, and is not burned. The last named sacrifice is found in the Torah portion Pinechas.99
[26.] AND BATHE HIS FLESH IN WATER. This is sufficient for him,100 for he does not become unclean until evening.
27. SHALL BE CARRIED FORTH101 WITHOUT THE CAMP. By command.102

AND THEY SHALL BURN. The kohanim shall burn them. All those who do the burning shall bathe in water and immediately come into the camp. The fact that Scripture immediately states, and afterward he may come into the camp, is proof of this, for what reason is there to states this.103
29. AND IT SHALL BE A STATUTE FOR EVER UNTO YOU. This service.104

IN THE SEVENTH MONTH, ON THE TENTH DAY OF THE MONTH, YE SHALL AFFLICT YOUR SOULS. Since Scripture writes, And let your soul delight itself in fatness (Is. 55:2), we know that affliction is the reverse of delight and that affliction of the soul refers to fasting.105 Furthermore, Scripture states, And satisfy the afflicted soul (Is. 58:10), the meaning of which is like And if thou draw out thy soul to the hungry (Ibid.), for it is the style of the prophets to repeat themselves.106 Now since we have tradition107 there is no reason to go on searching.108 I afflicted my soul with fasting (Ps. 35:13) is no proof109 because the word fast is mentioned.110 The general rule is, whenever we find in Scripture the word affliction connected to soul, the reference is to a fast.111
THE HOME-BORN, OR THE STRANGER THAT SOJOURNETH AMONG YOU. We are not permitted to let him112 do any work,113 but we do not force him114 to fast.115

30. SHALL ATONEMENT BE MADE FOR YOU. By the kohen. The commentators therefore say regarding the goat which is sent into the wilderness, concerning which it is written, shall be set alive…to make atonement over him (v. 10), that the atonement becomes effective by the placing of the goat before the Lord.116

FROM ALL YOUR SINS. This is to be understood in accordance with my earlier explanation that the noun chattat (sin) is a general term. It is therefore found with reference to both accidental and deliberate sin.

31. IT IS A SABBATH OF SOLEMN REST. Some say that shabbat shabbaton (a sabbath of solemn rest) means rest for the soul and rest for the body.117 Others say that shabbat shabbaton means a rest above which there is no other rest.118 Both words119 are nouns. At times the other word comes first.120 They have one meaning,121 This interpretation is not farfetched.
IT IS A STATUTE FOR EVER. To fast.
32. AND THE PRIEST…SHALL MAKE ATONEMENT. Scripture now goes on to explain what the kohen shall make atonement for.
WHO SHALL BE ANOINTED. By the anointer122 with the anointing oil123 after he has been consecrated.124
AND HE SHALL PUT ON. He125 is the one who shall put on these holy garments, for another person may not wear them.
33. THE MOST HOLY PLACE. Which is located on the inner side of the veil.

AND SHALL MAKE ATONEMENT FOR THE PRIESTS AND FOR ALL THE PEOPLE OF THE ASSEMBLY. The Levites are included among the latter, for the Levites are not called kohanim. On the contrary, every kohen is a Levite126 but every Levite is not a kohen.127
34. AND THIS SHALL BE…UNTO YOU. Scripture already stated this.128 It is repeated to add once in the year.
35. AND HE DID. And Aaron did.
chapter.ftnote: 2 See Lev. 10:1,2.

3 Into the Holy of Holies. The veil separated the Holy of Holies and the rest of the tabernacle. Our chapter relates that after Aaron’s sons died, God told Moses to caution Aaron against entering the Holy of Holies so as not to die as his sons did. The implication of the latter is that Aaron’s sons died because they entered the Holy of Holies.
4 An infinitive with a pronoun suffixed to it.
5 Korvatam is made up of the infinitive korvah plus the pronominal suffix.
6 When a feminine word ending in a heh is connected to a pronominal suffix, the heh changes into a tav.
7 A Karaite Bible commentator.
8 That is; korvatam is made up of the noun korvah plus a pronominal suffix.

9 The tent of meeting is also a holy place. Hence I.E. points out that the holy here refers to the place that is considered holy with regard to the tent of meeting, i.e., it is holier than the tent of meeting.
10 Hebrew, ki be-anan, which I.E. renders: for only with a cloud.
11 This interpretation renders ki be-anan era’eh al ha-kapporet,: for only with a cloud may I be seen over the ark-cover.

12 Aaron is not permitted to look directly at God’s glory. He must screen God’s glory with the smoke of the incense. According to this interpretation ki be-anan era’eh al ha-kapporet means, I may only be seen through the smoke of the incense.
13 Hence Aaron shall come not at all times into the holy place (v. 2).
14 Herewith shall Aaron come into the holy place: with a young bullock might be taken to mean that Aaron should bring the bullock into the Holy of Holies. Hence I.E.’s comment.
15 From his own property.
16 The bullock also atones for the Levites.
17 We thus see that the Levites and the kohanim form one unit.
21 The sound of the bells of the ephod.
22 The kohen gadol.

23 The point is Ex. 28:35 tells us that the kohen must wear the robe when he enters the Holy of Holies. Now, the ephod and the breastplate were attached to the robe. Hence there was no need for Scripture to repeat once again that Aaron shall wear these garments when he enters the Holy of Holies. Rashbam on Ex. 28:35 explains similarly. It should be noted that this interpretation is contrary to the accepted halakhic opinion which rules that the kohen gadol does not enter the Holy of Holies wearing the ephod, its band, the breastplate, and the robe. See Rosh Ha-Shanah 26a. Also see Rashi, “This teaches us that he must not officiate in the interior (the Holy of Holies) robed in the eight garments which were the insignia of the High Priest…in which he performed the service outside…but in the four garments…like an ordinary priest” (Rosenbaum and Silbermann).
24 Which was placed in the breastplate (Ex. 28:30).
25 Since Scripture does not mention the Urim and the Thummim in our verse, it appears that the wearing of the Urim and the Thummim is not essential for the service to be valid.
26 At the beginning of the second temple period. These prophets taught the Israelites that the kohen gadol may officiate without the Urim and the Thumim if the latter are not available.
27 See Lev. 4:4.
28 See verse 11.
29 The confession of his and his family’s sins made by the kohen gadol. See Sifra and Rashi.
30 Spoken of in our verse.
31 See Yoma 36a.
32 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.
33 Hard and rocky. See Yoma 63a. Azazel is a combination of az (strong) and el (tall). Azazel thus means mighty and tall mountain (Krinsky).
34 The divine name El. El means mighty.
35 Neither I.E. nor any of the commentaries identify him.
36 The word Azazel in Hebrew does not have the word alef lamed in it, for the word is spelled ayin, zayin, alef, zayin lamed.

37 I.E.’s paraphrase of and he did. I.E.’s point is that Scripture goes out of the way to state that Aaron did as God commanded him in the wilderness, for later on when Israel entered Israel some parts of the Yom Kippur ritual were performed a bit differently. The sending of the goat to Mount Azazel is an example.
38 See I.E. on Lev. 23:11.
39 According to I.E., God commanded Israel to observe the first Shavu’ot on a Sunday. However, the latter did not apply in succeeding years. See I.E. on Lev. 23:11.
40 The Yom Kippur service.
41 The high priest.
42 The priestly garments, viz., the ephod, its band, the breastplate, and the robe.
43 According to this interpretation the goat was sent into the desert unaccompanied.

44 See Lev. 14:1-7. This bird was sent unaccompanied. According to the rabbis of the Talmud the goat was accompanied by a person set aside for this purpose. This commentator believes that this was not the case in the desert, for the ritual in the second temple period was not exactly the same as the one described in our chapter.
45 Scripture’s description of the place where the goat is sent.
46 That the goat is sent into a wilderness.
47 In verse 22.
48 By a person set aside for this purpose (v. 21), literally, he pursued.
49 The man who pursues it.
50 Yoma 67a. The point is that since a person accompanied the goat it was possible for him to push the goat off the mountain.
51 Rabbi Samuel ben Hofni Ha-Gaon.
52 Verse 10 reads, la-azazel ha-midbarah (for Azazel into the wilderness). According to I.E. the word ha-midbarah is the key to understanding the meaning of Azazel.

53 According to I.E., Azazel is a compound word. It is made up of the two words ez (goat) and azal (to go). There are many such compound names in Scripture. Compare, Emmanuel (God is with us). According to I. E. the meaning of la-azazel ha-midbarah is, for a goat that goes into the wilderness.

54 According Nahmanides what Ibn Ezra means is, if you count 33 verses you will understand why the goat was sent into the wilderness. If we count 33 verses we come to Lev. 17:7. The Torah there prohibits Israel from sacrificing to the se’irim (satyrs). According to I.E. the se’irim were demons that had the shape of goats. Now it is not clear what the purpose was of sending the goat to demons who were shaped like goats. According to Nahmanides the goat was a gift to Satan so that he would not interfere with Israel’s sacrifice. However, it is doubtful that I.E. had this in mind. Weiser suggests that the goat was sent to a place of demons so that the sins which it (literally or symbolically) bore would not contaminate people, for demons dwell in a place which is uninhabited.
55 The goat.
56 Literally, from the heavy conjugation which has a word added to it and whose subject is not mentioned.
57 Prefixed to the root.
58 A kubbutz, for that is the way words in the imperfect are conjugated in the hofal. Compare, yuktzar, yurad
59 It was enlarged from a minor vowel (a kubbutz) to a major vowel (a kamatz).
60 The ayin, for the root of yo’omad is ayin, mem, dalet.
61 It too is vocalized with a kamatz rather than with a kubbutz because of its guttural.
62 Over it, over the goat.
63 The sins will be placed upon the goat, who shall remove the sins by carrying them into the wilderness.
64 After stating in verse 6, And Aaron shall present the bullock of the sin-offering.
65 In verses 6-10. Our verse appears to repeat verse 6. Hence I.E.’s comment.
66 The word for a handful (chofnayim) always comes in the plural form. Hence I.E. points out that here the word is to be taken literally.

68 According to the Talmud the kohen stands between the staves of the ark and sprinkles from there. Furthermore, according to the rabbis the kohen does not actually sprinkle blood on the ark-cover but upward towards the ark-cover. See Yoma 53b.
69 According to the Talmud before the ark-cover means downward in front of the ark-cover. The blood fell on the ground. See Yoma 53b.
70 Of the tabernacle
71 These commentators interpret And Aaron shall present the goat (v. 9) as meaning, and Aaron shall slaughter the goat.
72 For our verse is in chronological order.
73 Some editions read the veil-curtain (parochet).
74 Those who desecrate it. That is, because of those who entered the temple in a state of impurity.

77 Which stood in the courtyard.
78 Scripture pictures the sins as physical objects carried away and deposited in a place where they will be forgotten. In reality, what happens is that God forgives Israel’s sins.
79 See Rashi, “prepared for this since yesterday.”
80 Of itti.
81 It is not a first person pronominal suffix.
82 In that its yod is the yod of relation. The yod suffixed to a word is often a first person pronominal suffix, hence I.E.’s comment.
83 Compare, the wise men, who knew the times (ittim) (Est. 1:13). According to this interpretation a “timely” man is a man who is aware of what is currently happening, i.e., a wise man.
84 For what need is there for a wise man to drive the goat into the wilderness.

86 Yoma 66a.
87 So that people would not see him changing his clothes. See Yoma 3:4.
88 Literally, his garments.
89 The eight garments with which he ministers every day.
90 The four garments mentioned in verse 4.
91 That he put on the vestments he was wearing before he bathed.
92 Brought by the kohen gadol. See verse 3.
93 See verse 5.
94 Mentioned in Num. 29:8.
95 Mentioned in Num. 29:8.
97 Mentioned in verse 3.
98 Mentioned in verse 9.
99 Num. 29:11. It is not mentioned in our Torah portion.
100 He need not do anything more to cleanse himself.
101 Literally, he shall carry.
102 The kohen gadol shall command that they be carried outside of the camp.
103 Except for the purpose of letting us know that he enters the camp immediately after bathing.
104 This service shall be a statute forever unto you.
105 When a person eats, the soul is said to “delight itself.” Thus when Scripture speaks of the soul being afflicted it means the reverse; i.e., the reference is to a fast.
106 The hungry is another way of saying the afflicted soul. We thus see that affliction of the soul refers to a lack of food. Hence it refers to fasting.
107 That affliction of the soul refers to fasting.
108 For proof that our verse speaks of fasting.

109 That afflicting the soul means fasting, for one may argue that since Scripture goes on to explain that the psalmist afflicted his soul by fasting, in cases where the “affliction of the soul” is not qualified, the reference is not to fasting.
110 In the verse.
111 Whenever the Torah speaks of the affliction of the soul the reference is to fasting.
112 The stranger.
113 On Yom Kippur.
114 Reading nachrichennu as in Vat. Ebr. 38 instead of nachritennu (we shall cut him off).
115 For Scripture does not mention the stranger when it speaks of fasting. It only mentions the stranger when it speaks of not doing work on Yom Kippur.
116 In other words, atonement is not affected by driving the goat into the wilderness, for the latter is not done by the kohen gadol.
117 For the word shabbat is repeated in the phrase.
118 It means a total rest.
119 In the phrase.
120 Our verse reads: shabbat shabbaton. However, Ex. 16:23 reads shabbaton shabbat.
121 Shabbat and shabbaton have one meaning.

122 Our verse literally reads: And the priest who shall anoint him (yimshach oto) and who shall be consecrated…shall make atonement. Now the priest who anoints the kohen gadol does not make atonement. Neither is the priest who anoints consecrated to wear the high priestly vestments. Furthermore, the text omits with what the anointed shall do the anointing. Hence I.E. points out that yimshach oto is short for yimshach ha-moshech oto, which means whom the anointer shall anoint. Thus according to I.E. the first part of our verse should be rendered: And the priest whom the anointer shall anoint with the anointing oil.
123 Scripture does not say with what the kohen gadol was anointed. Hence I.E. points out that asher yimshach oto is short for yimshach oto be-shemen ha-mishchah.

127 Only those descended from Aaron are kohanim.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 17
chapter.p: 2. SPEAK UNTO AARON, AND UNTO HIS SONS. For they are the ones who slaughter1 for Israel. If the Torah had read, in the camp (v. 3),2 then it would have been permissible to slaughter it3 outside the camp.4 Also, this5 commandment6 is dependent upon the Holy Temple.7 However, this law applies only to any place that is close to Jerusalem.8 We know how close from the words of tradition,9 for if the place is far, one is permitted to slaughter flesh.10 The latter is so, for Scripture states it.11 Many say that it is forbidden to eat flesh in the exile.12 They explain neither came flesh nor wine in my mouth (Dan. 10:3)13 as referring to the flesh of fish.14 They did not speak correctly. I do not want to dwell on this and answer them.
5. TO THE END THAT THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL MAY BRING. This is the reason for this commandment. And they shall no more sacrifice their sacrifices unto the satyrs (v. 7) explains in the open field.15

7. UNTO THE SATYRS. Se’irim (satyrs) are the demons. They are so called because the body of one who sees them “storms.”16 However, it appears that they are so called because the insane see them in the form of goats (se’irim). The word “more” teaches that the Israelites did so in Egypt.

AFTER WHOM THEY GO ASTRAY. For whoever seeks after them and believes in them strays from under his God, for he thinks that there is someone aside from God the glorious and awe inspiring who does good or bad. This section17 does not mention the stranger, for the commandment regarding sacrifices and burnt offerings falls on Israel. Scripture mentions the stranger18 in order to teach that Israel shall not permit a stranger to sacrifice to idols in the Land of Israel. The law regarding all manner of blood (v. 10) is similar.19 The eating of blood is prohibited20 because it is the very life, for the flesh lives by the blood.21 The truth of the matter is that the life by which a person lives is in the blood which is in the heart.

11. THAT MAKETH ATONEMENT BY REASON OF THE LIFE.22 The blood makes atonement by the life which is in it.23 The reason for the latter is life for life.24 There are others who explain ba-nefesh yekhapper (that maketh atonement by reason of the life) as, to make atonement for your souls.25 However, the latter makes no sense, for what reason is there for Scripture to say this after stating to make atonement for your souls?26
13. THAT TAKETH IN HUNTING ANY BEAST OR FOWL THAT MAY BE EATEN. Such as a deer or a gazelle.

OR FOWL THAT MAY BE EATEN. We also learn from this verse that we should not allow the stranger to eat in our land the flesh of a pig or a horse, or any bird of prey which is unclean. It is possible that God commanded that all blood which is not offered on the altar27 be covered so that the one who sees the blood of the deer, stag, or fowl not think that it comes from a sacrifice that was offered to an idol, for God had commanded that no blood be eaten and that no blood from God’s altar be spilled outside of the altar.28 I will explain the secret of this verse in the Torah portion opening with the words Behold, I set (Deut. 11:26).29

14. THE BLOOD THEREOF IS ALL ONE WITH THE LIFE THEREOF. The blood is coupled with the life thereof,30 for it is known31 that the threads32 that go out from the left side of the heart are divided, half for blood and half for the breath, like the olive oil and the light thereof.33

THEREFORE I SAID UNTO THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. The meaning of va-omar (therefore I said) is, and I have previously said.34 The reference is to the section now mentioned.35 Since Scripture mentions the beast (chayyah) which is not offered as a sacrifice, and similarly the fowl,36 it goes on to speak of every soul that eateth that which dieth of itself (v. 15), which is also not offered as a sacrifice. Scripture also mentions the latter because of its reference to an animal which is taken in hunting.37 If one does so deliberately38 he violates a negative precept39 and is flogged.40 If he does so accidentally, he brings a sin offering. If one should argue,41 does not Scripture state, thou mayest give it42 unto the stranger that is within thy gates, that he may eat it (Deut. 14:21)? The answer is that this43 speaks of a stranger who dwells in the Land of Israel. Scripture similarly reads, or the stranger that sojourneth among you (Lev. 16:29). We shall not allow him to eat anything that dies of itself. However, we may give it44 to the stranger that comes into our gates45 and he will eat it outside.46

16. THEN HE SHALL BEAR HIS INIQUITY. Permanently. He47 will be forgiven for his sin by the punishment which God shall bring upon him. This section48 follows because Scripture mentioned49 the topic of the satyrs which Israel sacrificed to in Egypt. The prohibited sexual practices50 deal with those of the land of Canaan,51 for Scripture so states at the end.52
chapter.ftnote: 1 The sacrifices.
2 That is, if verse 3 had only stated, in the camp.
3 Any one of the animals mentioned in our verse.
4 Hence verse 3 reads, in the camp, or…without the camp.
5 The law codified in verses 3 and 4.
6 Like many others which precede it.
7 It is in effect only when a central sanctuary for the bringing of sacrifices exists.

According to the rabbis, our verse speaks of sacrifices; i.e., sacrifices are not to be offered in any place except for the tabernacle or the temple. See Sifra and Rashi.
9 See Kiddishin 57b.
10 He is permitted to slaughter an animal for the purpose of eating its flesh without presenting it for an offering.

13 Daniel, who lived in Babylon, tells us that he refrained from meat and wine while he fasted. This indicates that he ate meat when he did not fast.

34 In verse 10.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 18
chapter.p: [2. I AM THE LORD YOUR GOD.] The meaning of this verse is, on this condition1 I will be your God.

3. NEITHER SHALL YE WALK IN THEIR STATUTES.2 A person should not habituate himself to walk in this way3 to the point where it becomes a statute for him.4 However, after the doings of the land of Egypt refers to their ordinances.5 Mine ordinances (mishpatai)6 shall ye do (v. 4) is proof of this. The latter refers to the ordinances recorded in the Book of the Covenant,7 which is set forth in the Torah portion that opens with Now these are the ordinances (mishpatim) (Ex. 21:1).8

4. I AM THE LORD YOUR GOD. I will then be your God.9 The reason Scripture states, Ye shall therefore keep My statutes, and Mine ordinances (v. 5) is to make it clear that they are a source of life in both worlds10 to those who observe them. God will give eternal life to the person who understands their secret. He will never die.11 Scripture, as I have explained, therefore reads, I am the Lord your God.

6. NONE OF YOU. Ish ish12 (none of you) means each and every man. Since Scripture does not mention the house of Israel,13 we learn that we are not permitted to allow the stranger to practice in our country any of the abominations mentioned, so that he does not defile the land.

ANY THAT IS NEAR OF KIN TO HIM. She’er14 (near) is a general term for all those with whom one is prohibited to engage in sexual relations. Scripture then goes into detail.15 Rabbi Aaron Ha-Kohen16 says that the reference is to the emission of semen in vain.17
NONE OF YOU SHALL APPROACH. Approach is a euphemism for lying with.18 Similarly And I approached the prophetess (Is. 8:3).19 Our verse is close to come not near a woman (Ex. 19:15).20

NAKEDNESS. Ervah (nakedness) refers to something unseemly which is exposed and has to be covered. The meaning of I am the Lord is that God loves the one who separates himself to serve God and to obey his word. What happened at Mount Sinai is proof.21 The first man is proof.22 This is the secret of man.23 Since the inclination of the heart of man is like that of beasts, it was not possible to prohibit all women.24 Note, Scripture prohibited all women that are found around a person at all times.25 I will reveal to you a hidden and sealed secret in the Torah portion When thou goest forth in camp against thine enemies (Deut. 23:10).26 Observe, whoever defiles himself is distanced from God, from receiving God.27 Scripture therefore mentions, I am the Lord.

7. THE NAKEDNESS OF THY FATHER. Scripture begins28 with the father, who precedes the son.29 Scripture states that anyone who is closely related to his father or mother30 is prohibited. Note, the nakedness of the mother is the one that is mentioned first.31 The nakedness of the father’s wife, who is not the mother, follows. Then comes the sister, who is the daughter of his father or the daughter of his mother.
9. BORN AT HOME. Who was born in accordance with the laws of the house of Israel following the first and second stage of marriage.32

BORN ABROAD. Unconventionally.33 Some say that born at home is similar to were born upon Joseph’s knees (Gen. 50:23).34 It means she grew up with you in the same house. It is possible that born abroad means she is in a different place and a different city and grew up away from you, outside of your father’s house. Scripture next mentions thy son’s daughter (v. 10).35
