11. THE NAKEDNESS OF THY FATHER’S WIFE’S DAUGHTER. There are those who say that this refers to a sister from a father and mother.36 We know37 that the one who sleeps with a sister from a father and mother violates two negative laws.38 There are those who say that our verse was written for emphasis.39 The Sadducees40 say that thy father’s wife’s daughter does not refer to the daughter of one’s mother. They explain that begotten of thy father means whom your father raised. Our verse deals with an instance in which the father took a woman who had a small daughter. They say the same thing regarding Tamar.41 Their proof is, for he will not withhold me from thee (II Sam. 13:13).42 She thus was not begotten by David. Now since the transmitters of tradition said that the daughter of your father’s wife is permitted, we have no need to answer those who invent things in their hearts. It is possible that “the daughter of thy father’s wife” refers to a daughter43 resulting from a rape.44 The word she’er (kin45) and basar (kin)46 are close in meaning.

14. SHE IS THINE AUNT. She is considered as your aunt.47 Similarly “Behold Hanamel, my uncle.”48 Now what will those who rely on the Torah alone for the commandments49 do? For Scripture does not prohibit the wife of the brother of one’s mother, and not the mother of one’s father, or the mother of one’s mother.50 We therefore need tradition. It is possible that the reason that Scripture did not mention that the wife of one’s mother’s brother is prohibited is that we learn this from the prohibition of the wife of the father’s brother. The prohibition of the wife of one’s brother is mentioned in the Torah (Lev. 19:3) portion Ye shall be holy. Also, the reason that those whom I mentioned51 are not listed in Scripture is that the Torah speaks of that which is prevalent.52

16. THOU SHALT NOT UNCOVER THE NAKEDNESS OF THY BROTHER’S WIFE. This is explained in the Torah portion If brethren dwell together (Deut. 25:5). To the one who asks why didn’t Scripture mention a daughter, [I reply] that the daughter is stated in Thou shalt not uncover the nakedness of a woman and her daughter (Lev. 18:17), whether or not it is his daughter, for once he has slept with the mother the daughter is prohibited.
17. THEY ARE NEAR KINSWOMEN. She’er (kin) and sha’arah (kinswomen) are two nouns. If the alef of sha’arah were not a guttural, it would be quiescent like the lamed of salmah (raiment) (Ex. 22:8).53

18. TO BE A RIVAL. Li-tzeror (to be a rival) is related to the word tzaratah (her rival) in And her rival vexed her (I Sam. 1:6). Note, Scripture does not mention in the Torah portion Ye shall be holy (Lev. 19:2)54 the punishment for sleeping with two sisters, and it does not mention the punishment for sleeping with the daughter of one’s son and with the daughter of one’s daughter.55 The one who says that Rachel and Leah56 were not sisters57 errs. His proof is, for all these abominations… (Lev. 18:27).58 However, this is not a rigorous proof. There are those who answer the one who asks, how could God punish for something He did not warn against,59 by saying the sons of Noah were warned about these sexual offenses. Others say60 that even though Scripture makes a general statement, for all these abominations…, the reference is not to all these abominations but to most of them.61 You will learn my opinion62 in the Torah portion And Moses went (Deut. 31:1).63 One who sleeps with a menstruating woman is considered to have slept with a woman whose nakedness one is prohibited from uncovering.64

20. WITH THY NEIGHBOR’S WIFE. This excludes the captive woman.65 There are those who say that she66 was previously prohibited. Those whose sexual craving67 overcame the intelligence of their heart erred in explaining the meaning of le-zara68 (carnally).69 We know that sexual intercourse is divided into three groups. One, to be fruitful and multiply70 and not to satisfy lust. Two, to relieve the fullness of the body.71 Three, for the purpose of lust, which is similar to the lust of an animal.72 Now since Scripture says le-zara (carnally), the meaning of which is even for seed,73 a married woman is prohibited by a very severe prohibition.74 And thou shalt not give any of thy seed to set them apart to Molech (v. 21) is proof.75 Scripture adds to defile thyself with her to let us know that the one who touches her will not be cleansed; he will be defiled forever. This verse76 does not at all prohibit a non-Jewish woman.77 There is no argument from the captive woman,78 for she converts to Judaism.

21. TO MOLECH. Molech is the name of an image. The rabbis interpreted Molech as a general term for all79 whom a person accepts as a king over him.80 It is possible that Molech is the abomination of the Ammonites.81 The word le-ha’avir (to set apart) is to burn, for that was the way Molech was worshipped. Some say that they used to pass82 their sons over the fire. Some lived and some died. In view of the fact that the verse does not mention fire, some explained le-ha’avir lamolekh (to set apart to Molech) as meaning to cause to pass over from the Torah of God to another religion.83 You will defile the Lord who is known as your God84 when you give from the holy seed to Molech. The Gaon says that fornication has eight levels.85 The most severe is intercourse with a beast of another species; afterwards comes the male, the entire gender of which is prohibited; afterwards comes the nakedness of the father’s wife and her companions,86 which are prohibited at all times. I will not dwell on this, for what purpose is there to these words since Scripture says, concerning all of them, even the souls that do them shall be cut off (v. 29).

22. WITH MANKIND. Since we find, Behold, I lay yester-night with my father (Gen. 19:34), we see that the prohibition87 applies to the one who lay and the one who is lain with.88 Rabbi Hannanel, of blessed memory, says that there are those in whose body a female genitalia is newly formed.89 However, this is impossible according to the laws of nature.90 There are those who say that the reference is to an androgynous person. All this pain was caused by the fact that Scripture employs the plural mishkeve ishah (as with womankind).91 There is an individual opinion92 that mishkeve ishah refers to two types of intercourse.93 I believe that the precept is to be taken literally.94 The men of sound wisdom95 also applied the death penalty to those who performed this act.96 Scripture employed respectable language in saying [thou shalt not lie].97 Compare, thou shalt not approach (v. 14).98

Now, since the male was created to make99 and the female to be made,100 Scripture notes that one should not reverse the words of God. There is a type of laying whose aim is to emit semen.101 Hence Scripture employs the term mishkeve which is a plural.102 It is unfit to dwell at length on this. Scripture states it is abomination, for it is an abomination to a holy soul even by the laws of nature.103 I have already explained the word shekhovtekha (lie carnally).104 It is possible that the word shekhovtekha105 is derived from shekhivah (lying), for the emission of semen comes along with lying.106 As Scripture states to defile thyself with her (v. 20) with regard to a married woman, it similarly says so with regard to a beast.
23. AND…ANY BEAST. A female beast.
BEFORE A BEAST. A male beast.
TO LIE DOWN THERETO.107 Le-rivah reverts to the beast, for the woman is the one who is penetrated.108 The word rivah (lie down) is related to the word arba’ah (four).109

IT IS PERVERSION. The grammarians say that the word tevel (perversion) comes from a double root.110 Compare, temes (melteth)111 in which melteth and passeth away (Ps. 58:9). The tav of tevel is superfluous.112 They say that tevel means destruction.113 There are those who say that the word mabbul (flood) is related to it.114 However, the word mabbul is most likely related to the word balal (confound) in the Lord did there confound the language of all the earth (Gen. 11:9). This is the general rule: Scripture prohibits all kinds of women with which it is possible for a person to be alone;115 a married woman, a non-Jewish woman,116 and those with whom intercourse cannot result in children,117 for a kind cannot reproduce except with its own kind and with those like its kind.

24. DEFILE NOT YE YOURSELVES. The tet of tittamme’u (defile ye yourselves) has a dagesh to compensate for the swallowed118 tav of the hitpa’el.119 The dagesh does not compensate for the nun of the nifal.120 The dagesh in the mem of tittamme’u, which is there according to the rules of grammar, is proof of this.121 Observe, Scripture notes that each one of these acts defiles the soul.
WHICH I CAST OUT FROM BEFORE YOU. It means, from the Holy Land, dead or expelled.122
25. AND THE LAND VOMITED OUT HER INHABITANTS. Whatever a person regurgitates is despised in his eyes, and he will not take it back.
26. YE THEREFORE SHALL KEEP MY STATUTES. The very ones that I enumerated123 shall be prohibited to you.
AND MINE ORDINANCES. You shall execute the judgment which I will command, upon the one who violates any of these.

The reason that and shall not do any of these abominations is written a second time124 is to include the stranger, for this precept125 applies equally to the native and to the stranger who dwells in the Land of Israel.
If you have any intelligence126 you can understand why in past days Jacob took two sisters in Haran and later Amram took his aunt in Egypt, and they were not defiled through them.127

The meaning of for all these abominations 128 (Lev. 18:27) is, you and your children shall know this so that you shall keep these precepts, and the land will be pure and the land will not regurgitate you.
27. THESE. Ha-el (these) and ha-elleh (these) (v. 29) have one meaning. Compare, ha-hem (those) and ha-hemah (those). However, this is not the opinion of the Gaon.129

28. AS IT VOMITED OUT. Ka’ah (vomited out) is a verb in the perfect. It is related to the word keyo (spew)130 in Drink ye, and be drunken, and spew (Jer. 25:27), for the letters alef, heh, vav, yod interchange.131 The word eretz is found in the masculine.132 Compare, netam aretz (the land burnt up)133 (Is. 9:18), and ve-lo nasa otam ha-aretz (and the land was not able to bear them)134 (Gen. 13:6).135 On the other hand, the word hiy (it)136 might be missing.137 Our verse should be interpreted as if it read, ka’asher hiy ka’ah (as it vomited out). In this case, ka’ah is similar to ba’ah (cometh) in cometh with the sheep (Gen. 29:6).138
29. EVEN THE SOULS THAT DO THEM SHALL BE CUT OFF. If they do so in public you shall put them to death. If they do so in secret then I will cut them off.
30. THEREFORE SHALL YE KEEP MY CHARGE. This charge. The charge being not to do [any of these abominable practices].

The meaning of which were done before you is, a person shall not say, since the earlier ones did so, I will also do so. I am the Lord your God is connected to My charge.139 One who lacks intelligence140 shall not ask,141 “Why this charge?”142 For I am the Lord your God. Do all that I command you.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Keeping God’s ordinances (v. 4).
2 Hebrew, chukkotehem.

3 The way of the Canaanites. I.E. interprets statutes as referring to the practices of the Canaanites because verses 27 and 28 make it clear that the practices enumerated in our chapter refer to Canaanite mores.
4 It becomes his second nature.
5 Their laws.
6 Not those of the Egyptians.
7 See Ex. 24:7. The Book of the Covenant was given to Israel three months after the Exodus.
8 I.E. interprets our verse as follows: Do not follow the laws of Egypt where you lived, nor the practices of the land of Canaan where I will bring you.
9 If you do not follow the laws of Egypt, nor the practices of the land of Canaan.
10 This world and the world to come.
11 His soul shall live on after the death of the body.
12 Literally, man, man.
13 In our verse.
14 Hebrew, flesh, that is, one’s flesh, i.e., one’s near relative.
15 And lists the people with whom one may not have sexual intercourse.
16 A Gaon in Pumpaditha, author of a commentary on the Torah. Rabbi Hai Gaon was his student.

17 According to Rabbi Aaron Ha-Kohen our verse does not speak of sexual intercourse but deals with approaching a near relative and uncovering her nakedness for the purpose of obtaining sexual pleasure (ejaculation).
18 Engaging in sexual intercourse.
19 The meaning of which is, I had intercourse with the prophetess.
20 The meaning of which is, do not have intercourse with a woman.
21 Before the revelation Israel had to separate themselves from sexual relations and sanctify themselves. See Ex. 19:15.

22 According to I.E., Adam experienced sexual desire only after eating from the tree of knowledge. See I.E. on Gen. 3:6 (Vol. 1, p. 67). He was expelled from the presence of the Lord because of his lust.
23 Man is to separate himself from the pleasures of this world and serve God. See the introduction to Vol. 4. Also, see Yesod Mora 10; 12.
24 Since people have sexual desire, the Torah did not prohibit it. It limited it.
25 If Scripture had permitted close relatives, then a person would indulge in sexual intercourse at all times.

26 See I.E. on Deut. 23:10. So too Maimonides, Guide 3:64, “The female relatives whom a man may not marry…as a rule…(being) constantly together with him in his house; they would easily listen to him, and do what he desires; they are near at hand, and he would have no difficulty in procuring them” (Friedlander translation, p. 376).
27 God can only be received when a person is in a state of purity. God turns away from those who are defiled. See Deut. 23:15.
28 The list of those with whom one is not permitted to engage in sexual intercourse.
29 Scripture begins the list of those with whom one is not allowed to engage in sexual intercourse with those related to one’s closest male relative.
30 Literally, of the nakedness of the father or the nakedness of the mother.
31 For she is the most closely related female.

32 A Jewish marriage is effectuated in two stages, erusin and nusu’in. During the first stage the bride still lives with her parents. In the second step she moves into her husbands house. Today the two stages are combined.
33 Out of wedlock.
34 According to I.E., were brought up on Joseph’s knees means were brought up in Joseph’s house.
35 After mentioning those closest to one’s father, his wives, and his daughters, it mentions those close to one’s son.
36 While verse 9 speaks of a sister from one’s father or one’s mother. Hence our verse is not redundant.
37 From this verse; i.e., we learn from this verse.
38 He transgresses the law prohibiting intercourse with the daughter of one’s father (v. 9) and the law forbidding intercourse with the daughter of the wife of one’s father.
39 It repeats what is written in verse 9 to emphasize that one is not to sleep with one’s sister.
40 The Karaites.

41 Tamar was the daughter of David. She was raped by her brother Amnon. See II Sam. 13:1-22. According to the Karaites, Tamar was not actually David’s daughter. She was his stepdaughter. When David married her mother she was already grown. According to the Karaites, Scripture only prohibits a stepsister that grew up in one’s home. Hence it was permitted for Amnon to take her in marriage,
42 If she were his real sister, she would not have said this to Amnon.
43 Of one’s father.
44 While verse 9 speak of a sister born in wedlock. Hence our verse is not redundant.
45 Literally, flesh.
46 Literally, flesh.
47 For she is the wife of your uncle.

48 There is no such verse. The reference appears to be to Jer. 32:7, Behold Hanamel, the son of Shallum thine uncle. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: in the presence of Hanamel mine uncle (Jer. 32:6). Be that as it may, I.E.’s point is that Hanamel was not Jeremiah’s uncle. He was the son of Jeremiah’s uncle. Nevertheless, Scripture refers to him as his uncle.
49 The Karaites.
50 They are prohibited by Rabbinic dictate. However, the Karaites, who do not accept Rabbinic tradition, have no basis for prohibiting these women.
51 The mother of one’s father and the mother of one’s mother.
52 Sexual intercourse with grandparents is extremely rare.
53 I.E.’s point is, if the alef of sha’arah were not a guttural, it would have been vocalized with a sheva na, rather than with a chataf pattach.
54 The Torah portion Ye shall be holy lists those with whom one is not permitted to have sexual intercourse and the punishment for violating these prohibitions.
55 I.E. notes this. However, he does not explain why.
56 Two sisters whom Jacob married.
57 Hence Jacob was permitted to marry them.
58 Marrying two sisters is thus an abomination. Jacob would not commit an abominable act.
59 Verses 27 and 28 tells us that the Canaanites were punished for practicing the sexual acts that the Torah prohibits. Hence the question arose from the anonymous commentator quoted by I.E.
60 In reply to the problem raised by Jacob marrying two sisters.
61 The phrase does not include two sisters. Thus marrying two sisters is not an abomination. The law prohibiting two sisters did not apply to Jacob, who lived before the Torah was given to Israel.
62 Regarding why Jacob was permitted to marry two sisters.
63 See I.E. on Deut. 31:16 and the notes thereto (Vol. 4, p. 227).
64 Even though the prohibition to have intercourse with her is limited to the time of her menses and the child born from such an act is not considered a mamzer (illegitimate).

66 Our verse does not deal with a non-Jewish woman, for a non-Jewish woman is prohibited to an Israelite whether she is married or not. However, a Jewish woman is prohibited to an Israelite only if she is married. Thus “thy neighbor’s wife” does not stand in contrast to a married captive woman but in contrast to an unmarried Jewish woman (Filwarg). For other interpretations see Rabbi Samuel Zarza, Krinsky, and Weiser.
67 Literally, lust of their inclination.
68 Literally, to give seed.
69 These commentators read our verse as follows: You shall not lie with your neighbor’s wife for the purpose of seed that is to impregnate her.
70 For reproduction.

71 For release of sexual tension. So too Maimonides, M.T. Hilkhot De’ot 3:2, “He will…not engage in sexual intercourse whenever he lusts, but only when he knows that he has to ejaculate for reasons of health.”
72 For pure sexual pleasure.
73 I.E. renders our verse: You shall not lie with your neighbor’s wife even for the purpose of producing seed (children), that is, to impregnate her.
74 For a married woman is prohibited even if the adultery is not committed for the purpose of sexual lust.
75 That le-zara (for seed) means for the purpose of children, for the word seed in verse 21 definitely applies to children.
76 Verse 21.

77 According to this interpretation verse 21 prohibits intercourse with a non-Jewish woman, who will offer her children to Molech (Weiser). See I.E. on Lev. 21:2. Other non-Jewish women are not included in this verse. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: This verse (verse 21) prohibits all non-Jewish women.
78 That one may marry non-Jewish women, for the captive woman is not Jewish and yet an Israelite may marry her.
79 Any idol.
80 For the word Molech is connected to the word melekh (king).
81 God of the Ammonites.
82 The word le-ha’avir (to set apart) literally means to pass over.
83 Our verse literally reads: You shall not give any of your seed to cause them to pass over to Molech.
84 Literally, the Lord who is called over you that He is your God.
86 Other women who are similarly prohibited.
87 Thou shalt not lie.
88 For Lot’s daughter was lain with and yet she said, Behold, I lay yesternight with my father.
89 According to Rabbi Hannanel our verse speaks of anal intercourse and vaginal intercourse with a man who has an artificial vagina.
90 Scripture would not prohibit something which does not normally exist.
91 The literal meaning of mishkeve ishah is “intercourses of a woman.” Intercourses is plural. It implies more than one type of intercourse, i.e., anal and vaginal intercourse.
92 In the Talmud. See San. 55a.

93 Vaginal and anal. This interpretation explains our verse as follows: You shall not sleep with a man by employing one of the two types of intercourse that one employs when having intercourse with a woman. In other words, do not engage in anal intercourse with a male.
94 The reference in our verse is to anal intercourse.
95 The rabbis.
96 See Yevamot 83b.
97 Lie is a euphemism for intercourse.
98 Approach is a euphemism for intercourse.
99 To penetrate the woman and thus impregnate her.
100 To be penetrated and impregnated.
101 The term mishkeve literally means layings of. I.E.’s point is that mishkeve here refers to laying down for the purpose of pouring seed; i.e., it is a euphemism for intercourse.
102 Both partners in the homosexual act emit semen. Hence the plural mishkeve (Krinsky).
103 It is not only prohibited by the Torah, it is unnatural.
104 See I.E. on verse 20.
105 Literally, your laying.
106 Hence laying is a euphemism for ejaculation.
107 Hebrew, le-rivah (to lie her down) i.e., to have intercourse with her.
108 Le-rivah literally means to lie her down, i.e., to have intercourse with her. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
109 An animals lies down on all fours.
110 Its root is bet, lamed, lamed.
111 Whose root is mem, samekh, samekh.
112 It has no translatable meaning. It is a form letter.
113 The seed is destroyed, for conception cannot result.
114 According to this interpretation mabbul means destruction.
115 Close relatives. See I.E. on verse 6.
116 This comment seems to satisfy the reading in Vat. Ebr. 38 quoted in note 77.
117 Bestiality.
118 Missing.
119 Tittamme’u is a hitpa’el.
120 In other words, tittamme’u is not a nifal imperfect.
121 A dagesh is not placed in the middle root letter in the nifal imperfect It is in the hitpa’el.
122 The nations of Canaan either were killed or fled from the land.
123 In this chapter.
124 God had already told Israel not to follow Canaanite practices in verse 3. Why then repeat the same idea in our verse?
125 Not do any of these abominations.
126 Literally, a heart.
127 See I.E. on Deut. 31:16 and the notes thereto (Vol. 4, p. 227).
128 For all these abomination have the men of the land done…and the land…vomited out the nation that was before you.
129 See I.E. on Gen. 19:8 (Vol. 1, p. 204).
130 From the root kof, yod, heh.
131 The alef of ka’ah is in place of a yod.
132 Ka’ah is masculine. Hence the noun eretz, which it governs, has to be masculine.
133 Netam is masculine. Hence the noun aretz, which it governs, is masculine.
134 Nasa is masculine. Hence the noun eretz, which it governs, is masculine.
135 Eretz is usually feminine. Hence I.E.’s comment.
136 Literally, she.
137 In this case, ka’ah is a feminine participle from the root kof, alef, heh, and eretz is feminine.
138 For ba’ah is a feminine participle from the root bet, alef, heh.
139 Not to that ye defile not yourselves therein, which precedes it. The thrust of our verse is, Therefore shall ye keep My charge, for I am the Lord your God.
140 Literally, an intelligent heart.
141 An intelligent person would not ask this question, for the prohibitions are based on reason.
142 What reason is there for this charge?

chapter.title: CHAPTER 19
chapter.p: 2. [UNTO ALL THE CONGREGATION OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL.] The reason that Scripture states unto all the congregation of the children of Israel is to exclude strangers1 since they, like the Israelites, are commanded to abstain from prohibited sexual relations. The reason this chapter follows the one dealing with prohibited sexual relations is that the Israelites should not imagine that they would remain in the land by observing only the laws dealing with the prohibited sexual relations. God informs them that there are other commandments. If they do not observe them, they will be exiled from the land. The aforementioned are the ten statements.2 God warns against idol worship after stating, I the Lord…am holy which, according to many commentators, is parallel to the first statement of the Decalogue.3 And ye shall not swear by my name falsely (v. 12) is parallel to Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain (Ex. 20:7).

3. AND YE SHALL KEEP MY SABBATHS. This parallels Remember the sabbath day, to keep it holy (Ex. 20:8). Ye shall fear every man his mother, and his father is similar to Honor thy father and thy mother (Ex. 20:12). Neither shalt thou stand idly by the blood of thy neighbor (v. 16) is likewise the same as the statement Thou shalt not murder (Ex. 20:13). The law regarding the bondmaid designated for a man (v. 20) is parallel to Thou shalt not commit adultery (Ex. 20:13 with a free woman. Similarly, Ye shall not steal; neither shall ye deal falsely, nor lie one to another (v. 11); Thou shalt not oppress thy neighbor (v. 13) are parallel to the three remaining statements.4 I have previously told you in my comments on the Torah portion Ve-Elleh Ha-Mishpatim (now these are the ordinances) (Ex. 21:1) that each and every precept stands by itself.5 However,6 there is some support for connecting the verses.7 Note, the section that opens with the words Ye shall be holy (v. 2) begins with Ye shall fear every man his mother, and his father (v. 3). Now Scripture tells us that the years of the one who honors his parents will be long (Ex. 20:12). This implies that the days of one who disrespects his parents will be shortened. Scripture therefore says, Ye shall fear.8 The reason Scripture mentions the mother before the father is that a child first recognizes only its mother.9 Then it recognizes its father. The Torah next mentions the Sabbath because, unlike all the other festivals, a child is commanded to keep the Sabbath.10 The child shall then recognize his God who rested on the seventh day.11 Scripture next mentions, Turn ye not unto the idols (v. 4).

We know from tradition what Scripture means by fearing parents.12 Our verse employs the word ish (every man) once13 because it wants to be brief. Scripture employs the plural tira’u (ye shall fear)14 because those who observe the child have to teach him and force him to fear his parents. It is the same case regarding Sabbath observance.15 The meaning of I am the Lord your God is, act as I did, for I rested from all work on the Sabbath.
4. TURN YE NOT. Even in your hearts to look upon them.16

UNTO THE IDOLS.17 The reference is to statues. They are called elilim because they are false objects. Compare the word elil (no value) in Ye are physicians of no value (Job 13:4). It is possibly related to the word al (not). Elilim means things that do not exist.

NOR…MOLTEN GODS. Made to receive power from those who are on high, for there is no need for another god along with Me.18 Scripture therefore states,19 I am the Lord your God. Scripture employs the plurals tifnu (turn ye) and ta’asu (make), for the one who sees idol worship and does not reveal the matter is a partner of the idolater.

5. AND WHEN YE OFFER A SACRIFICE OF PEACE-OFFERINGS. This is connected to what is written above.20 It means that one shall not sacrifice to the demons, no-gods,21 but only unto God. Scripture employs the plural tizbechu (ye offer), for Scripture is speaking about what is most prevalent, for people to join together to offer a sacrifice. Scripture reads li-retzonekhem22 (that ye may be accepted) because they shall not be forced to bring the offering but shall offer it of their own free will.
8. BUT EVERY ONE THAT EATETH IT. The meaning of okhelav is every one that eats of it.23 Similarly But the righteous are secure as a young lion24 (Prov. 28:1).25

BECAUSE HE HATH PROFANED THE HOLY THING OF THE LORD. After he offered the parts designated to God by Scripture, all the flesh26 is holy. Chillel (profaned) is related to the word chol (profane). It is something that has no significance.27 It is like an empty space (challel). In this section28 Scripture explains the punishment,29 namely, and that soul shall be cut off.

9. [AND WHEN YE REAP THE HARVEST.] This follows the law dealing with the peace offering, for as you gave to God the parts designated in Scripture, so shall you, out of respect for God, give what Scripture designates from the harvest of your land30 for the poor and the stranger. The word u-ve-kutzrekhem (and when ye reap the harvest) is grammatically irregular.31 It is an infinitive32 in the kal.
THE CORNER OF THY FIELD. The Israelite shall leave a corner in the field.33
THE GLEANING. The meaning of leket (gleaning) is known.

10. GLEAN. Te’olel (glean) means to cut off the olelot, that is the young grapes. Compare, olel (young child). Very young children are also called yonekot (sucklings).34 This word35 is similar to shereshkha (root thee out)36 in And root thee out of the land of the living (Ps. 52:7), the meaning of which is, to cut the root. Similarly the meaning of mesa’ef37 purah (Is. 10:33) is to lop the boughs.
THE FALLEN FRUIT. The meaning of peret (fallen fruit) is known in the words of tradition.38 It is related to the word poretim (thrum)39 in That thrum on the psaltery (Amos 6:5).
FOR THE POOR. Of Israel.
AND FOR THE STRANGER. Who lives among you.40

11. [YE SHALL NOT STEAL.] Ye shall not steal follows,41 for Scripture, as it were, says I have commanded that you give from your property to the poor out of respect for God.42 You shall certainly not take what belongs to others. Scripture employs the plural Ye shall not steal, for the one who sees and is silent is also a thief.
NEITHER SHALL YE DEAL FALSELY. This applies to something which has been deposited with you. The one who knows and does not testify also deals falsely.43
NOR LIE. Seek money from one who does not owe you anything.44

12. [AND YE SHALL NOT SWEAR BY MY NAME FALSELY.] This follows Ye shall not steal, for the one who is suspected of theft and dealing falsely with regard to a deposit swears.45 Scripture employs the plural ye shall not swear because it wants to include the one who causes an oath to be taken.46 Scripture reads, so that thou profane the name of thy God because, as I have noted,47 the one who swears falsely denies God.
13. THOU SHALT NOT OPPRESS THY NEIGHBOR. In secret.
NOR ROB HIM. Openly by the use of force.

THE WAGES. Pe’ulat means the wages of.48 Compare, Behold, His reward (u-fe’ulato) is with Him (Is. 40:10). It is possible that Scripture is elliptical and that pe’ulat is short for sekhar pe’ulato (the wages of his labor). Many say that Scripture speaks of a person hired for the day.49 One is not permitted to tell him to work the next morning and in the morning say I will pay you for two days’ work. The transmitters of tradition50 say that our verse51 refers to someone hired for a day,52 for the sun is not permitted to set on a worker53 who is hired for the night.54
14. [THOU SHALT NOT CURSE THE DEAF.] Because you have the power to do so.55 You shall likewise not put a stumbling block before the blind.
BUT THOU SHALT FEAR THY GOD. For He is able to punish you and make you deaf and blind.
15. YE SHALL DO NO UNRIGHTEOUSNESS. Scripture speaks of the judges and the witnesses.56
THE PERSON OF THE MIGHTY. Great in money such as Barzillai (II Sam. 19:33).57

16. A TALEBEARER. The word rakhil (talebearer) is similar to rekhulltekh (thy merchandise) (Ezek. 26:12) and rokhel (merchant) in With all powders of the merchant (Cant. 3:6). Rakhil means a slanderer, for the merchant moves goods. He buys from one person and sells to another. The talebearer reveals to one person what he heard from another person.

NEITHER SHALT THOU STAND IDLY BY THE BLOOD OF THY NEIGHBOR. A person should not join bloodthirsty men.58 It is known that many people have been murdered and killed because of slander.59 Doeg the Edomite60 is proof of this. The meaning of I am the Lord is, I see what you do in secret.

17. THOU SHALT NOT HATE THY BROTHER IN THY HEART. This is the reverse of but thou shalt love thy neighbor (v. 18). Now all of these commandments are implanted in the heart.61 Israel will dwell in the land when they observe them, for the second temple was destroyed because of hatred of one’s neighbor for no reason.62
THOU SHALT SURELY REBUKE THY NEIGHBOR. Perhaps you suspected him of something which was not so.63 The meaning of and not bear sin because of him is that you be punished because of him.64
18. THOU SHALT NOT TAKE VENGEANCE, NOR BEAR ANY GRUDGE. This is explained in the words of our rabbis of blessed memory.65

BUT THOU SHALT LOVE THY NEIGHBOR. Many are of the opinion that the lamed of le-re’akha66 (thy neighbor) is superfluous.67 It is like the lamed of le-avner (Abner) (II Sam. 3:30).68 I believe that le-re’akha is to be taken literally.69 Its meaning is that one should love that which is good for one’s neighbor as he does for himself.70 The meaning of I am the Lord is, I the Lord alone created all of you.

19. [THOU SHALT NOT LET THY CATTLE GENDER WITH A DIVERSE KIND.] The reason Scripture states Thou shalt not let thy cattle gender with a diverse kind is to warn us. Since you are holy, in that you do not act violently towards your fellow human being, you must also not do anything to an animal which entails changing God’s work. Scripture therefore reads, Ye shall keep My statutes; that is, each species is to be preserved. A kind is not to interbreed with another kind.

WITH A DIVERSE KIND. Kilayim (a diverse kind) means two kinds. I will yet explain the meaning of kilayim.71 The reason for the law regarding a field and a garment is that they serve as reminders,72 for many commandments serve as reminders. Examples of the latter are: the festival of unleavened bread,73 Sukkot,74 tzitzit,75 shofar,76 mezuzah,77 and tefilin.78 I will hint to you here at a secret. Know that “the complete is very complete.”79 Scripture therefore says with regard to Abraham,80 and kept My charge, My commandments, My statutes, and My laws (Gen. 26:5).81

OF TWO KINDS. The transmitters of tradition said that the word shatnez (two kinds) is made up of three words.82 It may come from a five-letter root.83 The meaning of shatnez is “mixed.”84 It is a noun which stands alone in Scripture.85

20. A BONDMAID, DESIGNATED FOR A MAN. The deniers86 say that the bondmaid is not a Jewess. However, the correct interpretation according to the plain meaning of the text is that the bondmaid is the one mentioned in And if a man sell his daughter to be a maid-servant (Ex. 21:7) and that she is an Israelite. Our verse deals with an instance in which the bondmaid was designated for marriage to her master or his son.87 However, she had not undergone the first stage of marriage.88 The meaning of nor was freedom given her is that she is not free until she undergoes the first stage of marriage as is the practice of young ladies. Many believe that necherefet means designated. However, I believe that necherefet is related to the word cherpah (reproach) because she is an unmarried virgin maidservant under the control of a stranger.
REDEEMED. Hofdeh (redeemed) is an infinitive in the hofal. The meaning of and not at all redeemed is that her father or any other family member did not redeem her before she became a young woman.

FREEDOM. The shuruk89 in chufshah (freedom) is in place of a furtive kamatz, for the individual form of the word is chofesh.90 Scripture states, nor was freedom given her, because it was traditional to write a writ of manumission91 if her father sold her for a set time. The transmitters of tradition said that our verse speaks of a woman who was half free and half servant.92 What they said is true.

THERE SHALL BE AN INQUISITION. Some say that bikkoret (inquisition) means a concubine.93 They say that the same applies to the word biykkrotekha (among thy favorites) in Kings’ daughters are among thy favorites (Ps. 45:10).94 However, they did not explain it correctly, for the meaning of biykkrotekha is, among the precious handmaidens.95 The yod96 is missing97 because the bet, which serves as a preposition, is vocalized with a chirik.98 It is vocalized with a chirik because of the confluence of two mobile shevas,99 the first beneath the prefix100 and the second beneath the first root letter of the word yikkrotekha, which is in the feminine.101 The tongue does not have the power to enunciate two mobile shevas in succession.102 The same is true for the entire language.103 There is no exception to this except for the word mi-yeshene (that sleep) in And many of them that sleep in the dust (Dan. 12:2),104 according to the reading of Ben Naphtali.105 There are those who say that bikkoret is related to the word yevakker (seek) in shall not seek (Lev. 13:36). The meaning of bikkoret106 is that the matter shall be searched out. The transmitters of tradition say he107 incurs the penalty of being lashed with a strap made from the skin of cattle (bakar).108 This is true by way of tradition.109 The word bikkoret is used as a support for the tradition.110 This section is placed here because the one who sleeps with the bondwoman oppresses the master of the bondwoman.111 He therefore brings a ram as a guilt offering.112 Furthermore, this type of intercourse can be interpreted midrashically as mixing diverse kinds, namely, a free man and a bondwoman.113

22. AND HE SHALL BE FORGIVEN.114 I will explain this later.115 The reason Scripture now discusses forbidden fruit is that Scripture had previously mentioned the seed of the field116 and the seed of the woman,117 who is likened to the ground.118 Scripture therefore119 now mentions that which is planted. It is known that fruit which grows before three years have passed is of no value and is harmful to the body. It is like all fish that have no fins and scales that are injurious to the body,0 and like all flesh of birds of prey and unclean animals that harm the wise soul. The intelligent will understand this.120

23. [THEN YE SHALL COUNT THE FRUIT THEREOF AS FORBIDDEN.] The meaning of ve-areltem et orlato (then ye shall count as forbidden) is that the fruit is counted as a foreskin121 which is harmful and serves no purpose, such as the “foreskin” of the lips,122 the ear,123 and the foreskin of the penis. The meaning of ve-areltem (then ye shall count) is, you shall consider it as a foreskin. It is also beautifully explained in the Aramaic translation.124
SHALL IT BE AS FORBIDDEN125 UNTO YOU.126 This explains the meaning of ve-areltem (then ye shall count).127
24. SHALL BE HOLY, FOR GIVING PRAISE. For giving praise to the Lord. The kohen shall eat it.

[25. THAT IT MAY YIELD UNTO YOU MORE RICHLY THE INCREASE THEREOF.] That it may yield unto you more richly the increase thereof is connected to shall be holy, for giving praise (v. 24) even though it is some distance from it.128 If he have nothing, then he shall be sold for his theft (Ex. 22:2) is similarly connected to he shall pay five oxen for an ox (Ex. 21:37). There are many other similar instances. The meaning of I am the Lord your God is, I will place a blessing upon the produce.

26. YE SHALL NOT EAT WITH THE BLOOD. This is connected129 to what is written above it.130 Scripture warned against eating from the fruit of any planted tree until the fifth year. It similarly also prohibited one, if he is in the proximity of the sanctuary, to eat from any permitted flesh unless its blood first be sprinkled on the altar of God. The account of King Saul is a faithful witness to this interpretation, for the ark of the Lord was with Saul, and Scripture explicitly states, “Behold, the people are eating with the blood.”131 As I explained,132 it was as if the people were sacrificing to the demons, for this was their custom in Egypt. There they were accustomed to sacrifice in the name of the demons. Now this is clear,133 since the blood was not poured on the altar in the worship of God. Neither shall ye practice divination is connected to ye shall not eat with the blood because they used to eat with the blood and go astray after the demons in Egypt, and they used to practice divination and soothsaying in Canaan. The aforementioned is clearly stated in Scripture.134 This too was like the doings of the land of Egypt;…and…the doings of the land of Canaan (Lev. 18:3). The word menachesh means divines. Compare, I have observed the signs (nichashti), And the Lord hath blessed me (Gen. 30:27). Divinations take many forms. There are types of divination that employs images,135 sticks,136 actions,137 movements,138 days,139 and hours.140

SOOTHSAYING. Some say that the word te’onennu (soothsaying) is related to the word anah (answer). The soothsayer imagines something in his heart and inclines his ear to hear what the speaker will answer.141 However, the rule of grammar rejects this interpretation.142 There are those who say that te’onennu comes from the word onah (time). It is similar to the word onatah (her conjugal rights)143 in and her conjugal rights, shall he not diminish (Ex. 21:10).144 However, it appears to me that te’onennu is related to the word anan (cloud), for it is known that the one who practices divination looks at the clouds and observes their forms and their movements. Te’onennu probably comes from a verb with a doubled root.145 It is like the word tesovevu (you will go round about),146 for we find, And with soothsayers (onenim) like the Philistines (Is. 2:6).147 [I note this] for it is possible that te’onennu is a doubled form.148 Me’onen (one that uses divination) u-menachesh (Deut. 18:9) is proof.

[27. YE SHALL NOT ROUND THE CORNERS OF YOUR HEADS.] Scripture states, Ye shall not round the corners of your heads as the non-Jewish nations do, so that you will be separated from them. Now since the hair on the head and the beard serve to glorify a person it is unfit to destroy them. Some say that this verse is connected to Ye shall not make any cuttings in your flesh for the dead (v. 28), for there are people who destroy the hair on the corner of their heads and also on the corner of their beards for the dead.

28. CUTTINGS. We know the meaning of the corners of the head and of the beard from the words of tradition.149 The word le-nefesh means for a dead body. It is also so rendered in the Aramaic translation.150 This is its true meaning. The nun151 does not receive a dagesh152 in order to simplify enunciation.

IMPRINT ANY MARKS. Some say that this is connected to Ye shall not make any cuttings in your flesh, for there are people who, employing fire, mark their bodies with a recognizable form for the dead.153 Even today there are those who, while young, mark their faces so that they [may] be recognized.154 The word ka’aka (marks) is doubled.155 Compare, He that spread forth the earth and that which cometh out of it (ve-tze’etza’ehah)156 (Is. 42:5). Ka’aka is related to the word ve-hoka (and hang)157 in and hang them up (Num. 25:4).158 According to the Aramaic translator, it is also an irregular word. He is also correct [in translating ka’aka as engraved].

29. [PROFANE NOT THY DAUGHTER.] Scripture now mentions profane not thy daughter because it earlier stated Ye shall not make any cuttings in your flesh (v. 28). The import of our verse is, your daughter shall not be displayed before the public.159 Now the voice of a woman is like her nakedness.160 A cutting is certainly so.161
LEST THE LAND FALL INTO HARLOTRY. The reference is to the harlotry of the people of the land.162 Compare, when a land sinneth against Me (Ezek. 14:13).163

30. [YE SHALL KEEP MY SABBATHS.] Scripture now says, Ye shall keep My sabbaths, because it earlier164 dealt with the dead, for there is no mourning on the Sabbath. And reverence My sanctuary is to be understood as referring to the kohen gadol; he shall not act as other mourners do.165 There is a similar prohibition upon all the people of the sanctuary.166 The meaning of I am the Lord is, God will punish you if you do not revere the sanctuary and respect it. Scripture similarly next mentions the ghosts and the familiar spirits (v. 31) because of the dead.167 It similarly writes in Isaiah on behalf of the living unto the dead (Is. 8:19).168
31. THE GHOSTS. Ovot (ghosts) is related to the word ovot (wineskins) in Like new wine-skins (Job 32:19), for wineskins are the main instruments in this “art.”169

NOR UNTO FAMILIAR SPIRITS. Yidonim (familiar spirits) is related to the word da’at (knowledge). Those who turn to yidonim seek to know the future. The empty heads say if there were no truth in the ovot (ghosts) and in various magical practices, then Scripture would not have prohibited them. However, I say the reverse. Scripture would not have permitted that which was true. It only prohibited that which is false. The idols (elilim)170 and the images (v. 4) are proof of this. Were it not that I do not want to go on at length, I would have explained the incident of the woman who was an expert in divining by ghosts.171 I would have brought unquestionable proof to my explanation.
The meaning of Turn ye not is, do not turn to the one who knows the art.172 The meaning of seek them not out is, do not inquire of them as king Saul did.

The meaning of I am the Lord your God is, you shall not seek except for the Lord alone. Note, Scripture reads, to be defiled by them, because the soul of the one who inquires of a ghost or a familiar spirit is defiled, for it does not cleave to the Lord.

32. [THOU SHALT RISE UP BEFORE THE HOARY HEAD.] Scripture mentions the hoary head because it earlier mentioned the dead173 and the aged are close to death, for the bodies of the old are considered dead.174 Note, our verse refers to all the old and to every hoary head.175 The meaning of and thou shalt fear thy God is, fear the Lord who shall punish you in your old age.176

33. AND IF A STRANGER SOUJORN WITH THEE. Scripture mentions the stranger after the old man. It does so to, as it were, to say, as I warned you to respect the old Israelite because he has no strength, I warn you not to wrong the foreigner because you are stronger than he is, or who has no power because he is in your country and subject to you.177
34. AND THOU SHALT LOVE HIM AS THYSELF. This has been explained.178

35. [YE SHALL DO NO UNRIGHTEOUSNESS.] Scripture states, Ye shall do no unrighteousness because it earlier dealt with the stranger. Our verse is similar to and judge righteously between a man and his brother, and the stranger that is with him (Deut. 1:16). You shall similarly not cheat in measurements; that is, you shall not deceive in measuring cubits, for the cubits vary.179 It is also possible that the meaning of in judgment is according to the known practice of the land.180
36. JUST BALANCES, JUST WEIGHT. Avne tzedek181 means just weights.
A JUST EPHAH. For that which is dry.
AND A JUST HIN. For liquid. A just hin explains in measure (v. 36).

Scripture states, I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, because it earlier mentioned for ye were strangers in the land of Egypt (v. 34). Therefore, you are obligated to keep My statutes and ordinances in mind and observe them. The meaning of I am the Lord is, you shall pursue my statutes which I placed upon you, for they are all righteous.
chapter.ftnote: 1 So Vat. Ebr. 38. Mikra’ot Gedolot reads, The reason why Scripture states unto all the congregation of the children of Israel is to include the strangers. The reading in Vat. Ebr. 38 appears correct, for unto all the congregation of the children of Israel seems to imply that what follows only applies to the children of Israel. Furthermore, in his comments on Lev. 20:1, I.E. explicitly says that our chapter applies only to the children of Israel. By strangers I.E. means non-Jews living in Israel. See I.E. on Ex. 20:9 (Vol. 2, p. 427).
2 In our chapter. Our chapter, as I.E. goes on to explain, contains ten precepts which parallel the Decalogue.
3 For I the Lord…am holy (Ex. 20:7).

4 Of the Decalogue. Ye shall not steal is parallel to Thou shalt not steal (Ex. 20:13). Neither shall ye deal falsely, nor lie one to another is parallel to Thou shalt not bear false witness (Ibid.). Thou shalt not oppress thy neighbor is parallel to Thou shalt not covet (Ex. 20:14).
5 Each and every precept is an independent statement. It is not connected to what comes before nor to what follows. See I.E. on Ex. 21:2 (Vol. 2, p. 448).
6 Hebrew, lakhen (literally, therefore). However, I.E. occasionally uses the term lakhen in the sense of however (Filwarg). It is also possible that we should read akeh rather than lakhen.
7 If we try, we can find a reason that the commandments follow each other.

8 Ex. 20:12 reads, Honor thy father and thy mother, that thy days may be long. The implication is that one who disrespects his parents will suffer premature death. According to I.E. the meaning of Ye shall fear every man his mother, and father is, be afraid of disrespecting your parents, for if you dishonor them you will suffer dire consequences. Our verse is thus parallel to Ex. 20:12.
9 According to I.E. our verse is directed at a child. Hence it mentions the mother first. When the Bible mentions the father first (Ex. 20:12) it is directed at an adult.
10 According to I.E. a father is obligated to prevent his child from doing work on the Sabbath. See I.E. on Ex. 20:8 (Vol. 2, p. 426).

11 By resting on the Sabbath the child will come to know that there is a God in the world. Hence our verse concludes with I am the Lord your God. I.E. speaks of a progression. The child learns to recognize its mother, then its father, and then God.
12 According to the Sifra fearing one’s father refers to sitting in his place, speaking in his turn, and contradicting him. See Sifra on this verse.
13 Elsewhere the Torah uses the term ish ish. See Lev. 17:3,10,13; Lev. 15:2.
14 Ish is in the singular. Thus the verb governing it should be in the singular. Hence I.E.’s comment.
15 Those who observe the child violating the Sabbath have to correct him.
16 Do not even think about looking at idols.
17 Hebrew, elilim.
19 At the end of our verse.
20 The previous verse.
21 I.E.’s paraphrase of Deut. 32:17’s description of idols.
22 Literally, in accordance with your will.
23 Okhelav is a plural. It literally means they that eat of it. Our verse thus literally reads, they that eat of it shall bear his iniquity. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
24 Translated literally.
25 According to I.E. the meaning of Prov. 28:1 is, each one of the righteous is secure as a young lion. See I.E. on Gen. 49:22 (Vol. 1, p. 44, notes 156,157).
26 Of the sacrifice.
27 Literally, meaning.
28 Unlike Lev. 7:18.
29 For eating on the third day from that which remains of a peace offering.
30 In verses 9 and 10.
31 The word should have been vocalized with a kamatz katan rather than with a kubbutz. In other words, u-ve-kutzrekhem should have read u-ve-kotzrekhem.
32 With a pronominal suffix.
33 In other words, thou shalt not wholly reap the corner of thy field means you shall leave a corner of the field.
34 See Lam. 2:11, olel ve-yonek (young children and the sucklings).

35 Olel means a young child or a young plant. Te’olel thus appears to mean to plant a young shoot. However, it has the opposite meaning. It means to harvest a young plant. Thus a word coming from a root meaning a young plant can, in the pi’el, have the opposite meaning, i.e., to destroy a young plant.
36 Shereshkha comes from the stem meaning root. Thus the word might be taken to mean to root. However, it has the opposite meaning in the pi’el.
37 Mesa’ef comes from the same root as se’if (a branch). However, in the p’iel it means to cut the branches.

38 The word perat is often used in Rabbinic tradition and there has the meaning of that which is singled out. See Sotah 37b; Chagigah 6a. Thus peret means the single grapes that fall off the vine. See Pe’ah 6:5, Two grapes are peret; three are not peret.
39 According to I.E. ha-poretim…al ha-navel means those that pluck on each one of the strings of the psaltery.
40 The non-Jewish stranger. See I.E. on verse 2 and the notes thereto.
41 The laws of leaving part of the produce to the poor.
42 I.E.’s interpretation of I am the Lord your God (v. 10) which concludes the laws of leaving part of the produce to the poor.
43 Hence the plural, “ye.”
44 The verse deals with appropriating someone else’s property. Hence I.E.’s comment.
46 One is not permitted to concoct a story and force someone to take an unnecessary oath (Krinsky).
48 The word pe’ulat literally means labor of. Hence I.E.’s comment.
49 According to this opinion a person hired for the day must be paid as soon as the day is over.
50 See Bava Metzi’a 61a.
51 Which states that a worker must be paid before the morning.
52 According to the rabbis a person hired for the day must be paid before the arrival of the next morning.
53 An unpaid worker.

54 That is, the verse in Deut. 19:24 which states that a worker’s wages are to be paid before the sun sets speaks of a worker hired for the night; that is, the employer has the entire following day to pay him.
55 Hence our verse follows verse 13, which speaks of the misuse of power to oppress and rob.
56 Hence it employs the plural.

57 Barzillai the Gileadite, a friend of King David. Scripture described Barzillai as a very great man. The context makes it clear that the reference is to great wealth, for Barzillai sustained King David when David dwelt in Mahanim.
58 Literally, men of blood, persons who resort to violence to gain their end. See Prov. 29:10.
59 Hence Neither shalt thou stand idly by the blood of thy neighbor follows the law prohibiting tale-bearing.
60 Doeg told King Saul that Achimelech, the kohen of Nob, fed David. This resulted in the destruction of the city of Nob. See I Sam. 22:19.
61 They are rational laws. See I.E. on Ex. 20:1 (Vol. 1, pp. 407,408); Yesod Mora, Chapter 5.
63 If you rebuke your neighbor he may explain himself and you will learn that you had no reason to be angry at him.
64 If you suspect him of something of which he is innocent (Weiser).

65 See Rashi on this verse. “If one says to another, Lend me your sickle, and he replies, No. The next day the latter says to the former, Lend me your hatchet, and he replies, I am not going to lend it to you, just as you refused to lend me your sickle—this is taking vengeance…If one says to another, Lend me your sickle, and he replies, No! and the next day the latter says to the former, Lend me your hatchet, and he replies, Here it is; I am not like you, because you would not lend me—this is called bearing a grudge.” See also Yoma 23a.
66 Le-re’akha literally means to thy neighbor.

67 If we take le-re’akha literally, then our verse reads, but thou shalt love to thy neighbor as thyself. This does not appears to make sense. Hence this interpretation means that we should ignore the lamed prefixed to re’akha and interpret our verse as reading, but thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself.
68 Le-avner is to be interpreted as if written avner.
69 That is, the lamed of le-re’akha (thy neighbor) is not superfluous.

70 I. E. interprets the lamed of le-re’akha as meaning “for.” He interprets our verse as follows: You shall love for your neighbor what you love for yourself (Krinsky). Weiser claims that I.E. interprets the lamed of le-re’akha as meaning “of.” He interprets our verse as follows: You shall love of your neighbor’s welfare as you love your own welfare.
71 I.E. apparently never got around to this (Weiser).
72 They remind us not to alter the species, which God has created, by crossbreeding or cross-planting.
73 The unleavened bread serves as a reminder of Exodus. See Deut. 16:3.
74 The sukkot serve as a reminder of booths in which the Israelites dwelled during their sojourn in the desert (Lev. 23:43).
75 The tzitzit serve as a reminder of God’s commandments (Num. 15:39).

76 Scripture speaks of Rosh Ha-Shanah as being a memorial proclaimed with the blast of the horn. The commentaries offer various interpretations of what the sounding of the shofar is to serve as a reminder, among them, God’s revelation, to repent.
77 To study and to teach Torah to one’s children. See Deut. 6:4-9; 13-21.
78 The tefilin serves a reminder of the Exodus (Ex. 13:9) and of our obligation to study and to teach Torah to our children (Deut: 6:4-9; 13-21). See Yesod Mora, Chapter 5.
79 A person who is spiritually perfect does not need any reminder of what God desires of him, for on his own he knows God’s will.
80 Who was complete.
81 Abraham on his own knew and kept God’s charge, commandments, statutes, and laws
82 According to the rabbis the term shatnez is a combination of shu’a (hackled), tavuy (spun), and nuz (twined).
83 It comes from the root shin, ayin, tet, nun, zayin.
84 It refers to a garment made out of a mixture of linen and wool. See Deut. 22:11.
85 It is not found in the construct, and no word is found to be in the construct with it (Weiser).
86 The Karaites.

88 In ancient times marriage was effectuated in two stages. The first stage was called erusin. During the period of erusin, which lasted for a year, the bride remained with her family. In the second stage, called nesu’im, the bride went to live with her husband.
89 The kubbutz.

90 Nouns that are vocalized cholam, segol are vocalized with a kamatz katan when declined. Compare, kotel, kotlah; chodesh, chodshah. Thus chufshah should have read chofshah, for the word chufshah (freedom) is the word chofesh plus the pronominal suffix.
91 When she was released from bondage.
92 See Keritot 2:5. “What manner of bondwoman [does Scripture speak of in Lev. 19:20]? She that is half bondwoman and half freedwoman.”
93 This interpretation renders bikkoret tiheyeh (there shall be an inquisition) as she shall be a concubine; that is, she shall not be considered a fully married woman.
94 This interpretation renders Ps. 45:10, Kings’ daughters are your concubines.

95 In other words, biykkrotekha is the word yikkrotekha (your precious ones), i.e., your precious maidens plus the bet prefix. There is no connection between bikkoret and biykkrotekha, for the former comes from the root bet, kof, resh and the latter from the root yod, kof, resh.
96 In biykkrotekha.
97 Is silent.
98 The yod of yikkrotekha is swallowed up by the chirik.
99 Biyikkrotekha is a combination of the prefix be plus the word yekkrotekha. In such cases the prefix is vocalized with a chirik and the yod is not sounded.
100 The bet.
101 Yikkrotekha.
102 It is hard to pronounce two mobile shevas back to back.
103 This rule does not apply only to the word biyikkrotekha. It applies to all cases where we have two furtive shevas in succession.
104 According to the rule, mi-yeshene should have read miyyshene.
105 A tenth-century Massoretic scholar who lived in the Land of Israel. He edited the punctuation and accentuation of Scripture according to the tradition of his school.
106 According to this opinion.
107 The one who sleeps with the bondwoman. There appears to be a scribal error in the text, for according to Keritot 11a it is the bondwoman who is lashed. Hence some emend alav to aleha.

108 Miscreants were lashed with a whip made of calf hide. See Makkot 3:12. This interpretation renders bikkoret as cattled, i.e., lashed with a strap made of cattle hide. In our texts of Rabbinic literature there is no such interpretation. Radak quotes this interpretation in the name of Rabbi Saadiah Gaon. See Weiser.
109 The law that the bondwoman is whipped with a strap made from cattle hide is true. The latter is known from tradition. It is not derived from the plain meaning of the text.
110 The literal meaning of bikkoret is not “lashed by cattle skin.”
111 The previous verses speak of wronging one’s neighbor.
112 One who oppresses his neighbor brings a ram as a guilt offering. See Lev. 5:21-26.
113 The verse immediately preceding deals with the prohibition of mixing different kinds.
114 Hebrew, ve-nislach lo.
115 In his comments on Num. 14:19, I.E. explains that the meaning of ve-nislach is that punishment shall be delayed until the person fully repents. See Volume 4, p. 110.
116 Verse 19.
117 Verse 20.
118 See I.E. on Lev. 12:2.
119 Because it had previously mentioned seed with regard to the field and a woman.
120 See I.E. on Lev. 11:43.
121 I.E. renders ve-areltem et orlato as, and you shall consider its fruit as foreskin. Orlah means a foreskin. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
122 A “foreskin of the lips” is a metaphor for a speech impediment. See Ex. 6:12.
123 A metaphor for something which interferes with hearing. See Jer. 6:10.
124 Onkelos renders ve-areltem et orlato, you shall surely distance.
125 Hebrew, arelim (literally, foreskins).
126 I.E. renders this, it shall be as foreskins forbidden unto you.
127 According to I.E. the meaning of ve-areltem is, then you shall consider it as a foreskin.
128 That it may yield unto you more richly the increase thereof is connected to shall be holy, for giving praise even though it does not immediately follow it.
129 That is, related.
130 To the law which precedes it.
131 See I Sam. 14:33. The exact reading of the latter is, Behold, the people sin against the Lord, in that they eat with the blood.
132 See I.E. on Lev. 17:7.
133 That the animal was sacrificed to the demons (Weiser). Or I.E.’s interpretation of Ye shall not eat with the blood is clear (Krinsky).
135 Making predictions based on the images drawn on cards (Krinsky).
136 Such as making predictions based on the way sticks fall.
137 Making predictions based on whom a person meets or what happens to something a person owns, i.e., a black cat crossing one’s path or a mirror breaking.
138 Bodily movements.
139 Lucky days.
140 Lucky hours.

141 The practitioner of this type of divination has a question in mind. He does not reveal the question to the person whom he is speaking to. However, he divines an answer to his question from what the person with whom he is conversing says. According to this interpretation ve-lo te’onennu means “and do not practice answering.”
142 Anah (answer) comes from the root ayin, nun, heh. Verbs from this root do not double their middle stem.
143 The time set aside for conjugal rights.
144 The meaning of ve-lo te’onennu is, and do not set times; that is, do not divine by setting aside lucky days.
145 Its root is ayin, nun, nun.
146 Which comes from the root samekh, bet, bet.
147 Onenim is a kal. There is no question that onenim comes from the root ayin, nun, nun.

148 A word from the root ayin, vav, nun. A verb which has a vav as it middle letter has its last stem letter doubled in the pi’el. In other words, the root of te’onennu is ayin, vav, nun. The last stem letter is doubled in the pi’el. Compare, te-komem from kof, vav, mem.
149 See Kiddushin 32b.
150 Onkelos renders la-nefesh, al mit.
151 Of la-nefesh.

152 A preposition prefixed to a stressed syllable of a noun can be vocalized with a sheva, pattach, or kamatz. If it is vocalized with a pattach, the letter which follows it receives a dagesh. I.E. explains that Scripture chose to vocalize la-nefesh with a kamatz to simplify enunciation (Weiser). However, it should be noted that if the lamed of la-nefesh was vocalized with a sheva, then the nun would also not receive a dagesh. Thus I.E.’s interpretation does not explain why the lamed of la-nefesh was not vocalized with a sheva. It is possible that in I.E.’s version of the Torah la-nefesh was vocalized with a pattach and that I.E. is explaining why, contrary to the laws of grammar, there is no dagesh in the nun of la-nefesh.
153 They brand an image of the deceased into their flesh (Weiser).
154 This is still practiced among certain Arab tribes (Weiser).
155 The kof and ayin root letters are doubled.
156 The tzadi and alef of the root yod, tzadi, alef are doubled in ve-tze’etza’ehah
157 From the root resh, kof, ayin.
158 So too Rashi. “[ka’aka] is a writing dug into the flesh. Ka’aka is related to ve-hoka in and hang them up (Num. 25:4)…” They were hanged upon poles which were driven into the ground.
159 Your daughter shall not make markings upon her flesh for the dead because she may expose the place of the mark to show that she cut her flesh as a sign of mourning.
160 Berachot 24a.
161 If it is prohibited to hear a women’s voice, it is certainly prohibited to look upon any part of her body that is exposed.
162 In other words, lest the land is short for lest the people of the land.
163 The meaning of which is, when the people of the land.
164 In verse 28.
165 The kohen gadol is not to observe mourning customs. See Lev. 21:10-12.
166 And reverence My sanctuary applies to all those who serve in the sanctuary.
167 Scripture earlier spoke of the dead. It now tells us that we are not to inquire of the dead by employing a ghost or a familiar spirit.

168 The full verse reads: And when they say unto you: Seek unto the ghosts and the familiar spirits, that chirp and that mutter; should not a people seek unto their God? On behalf of the living unto the dead; i.e., instead of seeking ghosts and familiar spirits and the dead concerning the welfare and future of the living, a people should inquire of God.
169 The practitioners of this “art” use wineskins to make ghost-like sounds.
170 According to I.E. elilim means something which does not exist. See I.E. on verse 4.
171 The witch of En-dor. See I Sam 28:15. According to I.E the witch did not actually bring up the prophet Samuel. She employed trickery. See I.E. on Ex. 20:3 (Vol. 2, p. 418, and the notes thereto).
172 Of communicating with the dead.
173 Verse 28.
174 They do not fully function.
175 Contrary to the opinion that our verse refers only to an old man who has acquired wisdom. See Kiddushin 32b. Also see Rashi.
176 If you do not respect the aged when you are young.
177 But is otherwise not powerless.
178 See I.E. on verse 18.
179 From person to person.
180 Use a measure which is accepted in the land. Do not use a foreign measure.
181 Literally, just stones.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 20
chapter.p: 1. [AND THE LORD SPOKE UNTO MOSES, SAYING.] Scripture earlier1 stated, unto all the congregation…of Israel, because the commandments, which followed, are obligatory upon all of Israel.2 Strangers have no part in them.3 Scripture now begins to mention the punishment for harlotry, which will befall anyone who lives in the Land of Israel, be he native born4 or resident alien.5 It begins with the most severe of them all, namely, with the individual who gives of his seed to Molech, that is, the one who has intercourse with a woman who worships idols.6
The meaning of the people of the land is, the people of the land wherein the culprit resides, be he a native or a resident stranger.7 This8 applies to one who publicly offers his offspring to Molach.
3. I ALSO WILL SET MY FACE AGAINST THAT MAN. If the sin was committed secretly.9 Others say that the reference10 is to the extirpation of the culprit’s seed.
TO DEFILE MY SANCTUARY. Which is in the Land of Israel.
AND TO PROFANE MY HOLY NAME. For nations will hear.11

It would have appeared to us that ba-even (with stones)12 (v. 2) is a collective noun.13 Compare, And I have oxen (shor),14 and asses (chamor)15 (Gen. 32:6).16 However, the words of tradition are correct.17 They are true. Rabbi Jonah the Spanish grammarian who rests in paradise says that and against his family (v. 5) means all those like him.18 Who brought us into this trouble?19 Our verse is to be taken literally. The people of the land20 will hide their eyes because they are of his family.21
5. [AND ALL THAT GO ASTRAY AFTER HIM.] This means others will go astray if the culprit is not put to death.

6. AND THE SOUL THAT TURNETH UNTO THE GHOSTS. This means as I will cut off the one who gives from his seed to Molech in secret or in public if the people of the land do not kill him, so will I cut off the one who strays from me and turns to ghosts. We find the term nefashim (souls) (Ezek. 20:13) in Scripture.22 We also find all the souls (nefesh) were fourteen (arba’ah asar)23 (Gen. 46:22). We similarly read,24 and will cut him25 (oto) off.

7. SANCTIFY YOURSELVES THEREFORE, AND BE YE HOLY; FOR I AM THE LORD YOUR GOD. Ki ani Adonai Elohekhem (for I am the Lord your God) means for I the Lord your God am holy. I have given you statutes to observe in order to sanctify you.26 Scripture has already mentioned this.27 It repeats this command so as to include the strangers residing among Israel, for they too are obligated to be holy so that they may continue to be allowed to dwell in a holy land. Scripture begins the list of punishments at the beginning of the section28 with the person who curses his father in the same manner that Scripture earlier starts with Ye shall fear every man his mother, and his father (Lev. 19:3).29 Our verse mentions the father before the mother out of respect for the father. It is unlike Ye shall fear every man his mother, and his father,30 for he is not put to death if he has not reached the age of mitzvah observance.31

9. FOR WHATSOEVER MAN THERE BE THAT CURSETH HIS FATHER OR HIS MOTHER SHALL SURELY BE PUT TO DEATH.32 The phrase asher yekallel (that curseth) is to be read as if written twice. Our verse is to be read as if written, “and whoever curses his mother.”33 He hath cursed his father or his mother is another way of saying he has committed a great abomination.

HIS BLOOD SHALL BE UPON HIM. Compare, his blood shall be upon his head (Josh. 2:19).34 The blood of those who are stoned and strangled is upon them.35 I will now state a general rule concerning all executions. We cannot derive the manner of execution from Scripture. Hence we need the tradition of our fathers.36 Scripture similarly does not state at what age one is obligated to observe the commandments.37

10. [AND THE MAN THAT COMMITTETH ADULTERY WITH ANOTHER MAN’S WIFE.] Scripture next mentions, and the man that committeth adultery with another man’s wife,38 for she was prohibited.39 The meaning of even he that committeth adultery with his neighbor’s wife is similar to he hath cursed his father or his mother (v. 9). It means he committed an evil act.
AND THE ADULTERESS. Women who are raped would not be so termed.40
11. HE HATH UNCOVERED HIS FATHER’S NAKEDNESS. He has committed a great sin.
12. HIS DAUGHTER-IN-LAW. Kallato means his daughter-in-law.
CORRUPTION. I have previously explained the meaning of tevel (corruption).41
13. BOTH OF THEM HAVE COMMITTED ABOMINATION. If the one who was penetrated was not raped.
14. AND IF A MAN TAKE WITH HIS WIFE ALSO HER MOTHER, IT IS WICKEDNESS. Zimmah (wickedness) means a promiscuous thought.42
AND THEY. This one or that one. If the mother43 was his wife, then the daughter is burned.44 The same is true in the reverse.
15. AND YE SHALL SLAY THE BEAST. So that it not cause another to sin.45 Others say, to hide the shame.46

16. AND LIE DOWN THERETO. Le-rivah (and lie down thereto) is an infinitive even though it is vocalized with a chirik,47 for the forms of the infinitive change. Compare, be-shivri (when I break) (Lev. 26:26).48

17. AND IF A MAN SHALL TAKE HIS SISTER, HIS FATHER’S DAUGHTER. In a place where he is unknown and afterwards the facts become known.49 The meaning of and see50 her nakedness is, or see her nakedness.51 It is like he hath cursed his father or his mother (v. 9).52 See means uncover. The meaning of and she see his nakedness is that they both agreed to this.

IT IS A SHAMEFUL THING. The word chesed (shameful thing) is related to yechassedkha (revile thee) in Lest he that heareth revile thee (Prov. 25:9). Chesed hu (it is a shameful thing) means it is an inflated act of harlotry.53
HE HATH UNCOVERED HIS SISTER’S NAKEDNESS. Employing force.54

HE SHALL BEAR HIS INIQUITY. He alone shall bear his iniquity. The reason scripture mentions these things55 regarding the sister is that they grew up in one house and are young people who play. The brother is always alone with his sister. Scripture does not mention the punishment for intercourse with the daughter of one’s son or the daughter of one’s daughter, for it relied on the oral Torah.56 It is possible that they are not mentioned because of the father’s lack of desire,57 for he is advanced in years when he has a mature daughter. It is for this reason that Scripture does not mention the mother of one’s father and the mother of one’s mother, for they are aged.58

18. SICKNESS. She is ill because of her blood.59 And shall uncover her nakedness means that he committed a great abomination. The meaning of and she hath uncovered is that she willingly uncovered, for if she was forced to have intercourse the man alone is cut off.

19. AND…THE NAKEDNESS OF THY MOTHER’S SISTER. Its meaning is, I have previously60 warned you not to uncover the nakedness of thy mother’s sister.61 Now the one who uncovers the nakedness62 has made naked his near kin.63

THEY SHALL BEAR THEIR INIQUITY. If they willingly acted thus. Scripture does not mention the punishment for having intercourse with the sister of one’s father. It also does not even hint at the punishment for taking two sisters.64 The intelligent will understand why.65 The words of tradition are also true.66
20. WITH HIS UNCLE’S WIFE. Dodato refers to his uncle’s wife.67

THEY SHALL DIE CHILDLESS. The Sadducees68 say that aririm (childless) means naked and that the meaning of yamutu (they shall die) is, they shall be put to death.69 They did not speak the truth. The correct interpretation is found in the words of the Aramaic translator,70 for aririm is similar to ariri (childless) in I go hence childless (ariri) (Gen. 15:2).71 I have previously explained Write ye this man childless (ariri) (Jer. 22:30).72

[21. IT IS IMPURITY.] Scripture employs the term niddah (impurity) with regard to a brother’s wife. The meaning of niddah hiy (it is impurity)73 is, it is fitting for him to distance himself from her.74 Similarly, Your brethren that hate you, that cast you out (menaddekhem)…have said (Is. 66:5).75 Note, there is no mention of niddah in all of the prohibited sexual partners76 except with regard to a brother’s wife. A niddah77 is prohibited.78 However, a time comes when she is permitted.79 This possibility,80 as I will explain in the section If brethren dwell together (Deut. 25:5), also arises in the case of a brother’s wife. My reply to those who say,81 as it is prohibited to marry the sister of the father (v. 19) so it is prohibited for a woman to marry her uncle82 is: this is not the way of Scripture.83 It is the males who are dominant84 with regard to the prohibited sexual practices.85 No one dominates the male.86 Let those who accept the faulty logic of those who offer the above interpretation87 show us why we should not accept the testimony of two women.88 If they89 argue from the laws of evaluation90 then four women should be equal to two male witnesses. We therefore need tradition.
22. YE SHALL THEREFORE KEEP ALL MY STATUTES. Not to violate the laws regarding these prohibited sexual practices.
AND ALL MINE ORDINANCES. The laws governing the punishment of those who engage in prohibited sexual practices.
[VOMIT YOU OUT.] I will explain this in the Torah portion Va-Yelech.91

23. AND THEREFORE I ABHORRED THEM. This was stated metaphorically.92 Compare, and His soul were grieved (Jud. 10:16). The meaning of a land flowing with milk and honey (v. 24) is, there is no land like it.
24. WHO HAVE SET YOU APART FROM THE PEOPLES. With these statutes.93 Furthermore, Ye shall…separate between the clean beast…(v. 25).94

[25. THE CLEAN.] The ten mentioned beasts.95 All the others are unclean. The unclean fowl means the unclean fowl which are mentioned.96 All others are clean. The meaning of to hold unclean is that you shall know in your mind and in your speech97 that it is unclean. Similarly, ye shall have in detestation among the fowls (Lev. 11:13).98 A resident alien99 shall therefore not eat that which is unclean in the clean land. He shall dwell in the land on this condition.100 If you keep all that I command you, you will then be holy. You are obligated to follow Me,101 for I the Lord am holy.

[27. A MAN ALSO OR A WOMAN.] The reason Scripture states A man also or a woman that divineth by a ghost or a familiar spirit, shall surely be put to death is that the Torah earlier had said concerning ghosts and familiar spirits, seek them not out to be defiled by them (Lev. 19:31). Scripture now says, be holy and put to death the one who defiles himself with a ghost or a familiar spirit. Previously it did not mention the punishment for publicly turning to a ghost. Scripture mentions woman, for this art is mostly practiced by women. Similarly, Thou shalt not suffer a sorceress to live (Ex. 22:17).102
chapter.ftnote: 2 That is, only upon Israel.
3 Non-Jews do not share these laws with Israel.
4 An Israelite.
5 A non-Jew living in Israel. Hence our chapter explicitly notes that what follows applies to both an Israelite and a non-Israelite.

6 This interpretation is rejected by the Mishnah. See Megillah 4:9: “If a man says And thou shalt not give any of thy seed to set them apart to Molech (Lev. 18:21) means, and thou shalt not give of thy seed to make it pass to heathendom, they put him to silence with a rebuke.”
7 The term “the land” indicates a specific land. Hence I.E.’s comment.
8 Stoning.
9 For if the sin is committed in public, the culprit is executed (v. 2).
10 I also will set my face against that man.
11 Of the sin that was committed in the Land of Israel.
12 Literally, with a stone.
13 Hence ba-even is to be rendered with stones.
14 Literally, an ox.
15 Literally, an ass.
16 Literally, and I have an ox and an ass.

17 The rabbis took ba-even literally. According to the Midrash the culprit was first stoned by one stone. See Sanhedrin 6:4, “The place of stoning was twice the height of a man. One of the witnesses knocked him down…If he died that sufficed; but if not, the second witness took a stone and dropped it on his heart. If he died that sufficed; but if not, he was stoned by all Israel.”
18 Rabbi Jonah was bothered by God’s threatening the family of the sinner with punishment when they apparently did not commit any sin.
19 Of not interpreting our verse literally.
20 Spoken of in verse 4.
21 In other words, the family spoken of in our verse is to be identified with the earlier mentioned (v. 4) people of the land who hid their eyes from the sinner

22 Nefashim (souls) is masculine. Nefesh (soul) is usually feminine. However, our verse reads, ve-hikhratti oto (and will cut him [the soul] off). It thus treats nefesh as masculine. I.E. therefore points out that nefesh is sometimes treated as a masculine in Scripture.
23 Arba’ah asar (fourteen) is masculine. Thus Gen. 46:22 treats nefesh as masculine.
24 In our verse.
25 The soul.
26 That is, I who am holy have given you statutes in order to sanctify you.
27 See Lev. 11:44.
28 That is, the list of punishments for the sins following verse 7, which reads, Sanctify yourselves therefore and be holy.
29 The preceding verse is, Ye shall be holy; for I the Lord your God am holy (Lev. 19:2).
30 Where the mother is placed before the father.

31 Hence our verse speaks of an adult. Scripture thus places the father before the mother. However, Lev. 19:3 speaks of a minor. Hence it places mother before father. See I.E.’s comment on Lev. 19:3: “The reason Scripture mentions the mother before the father is that a child first recognizes only its mother. Then it recognizes its father.”
32 Literally, For whatsoever man there be that curses his father and his mother shall surely be put to death.
33 Our verse should be interpreted as if written: For whatsoever man there be that curses his father or that curses his mother shall surely be put to death.
34 He, not the one who executes him, is responsible for his death.
35 They are responsible for their deaths.
