36 If we want to know how the death penalty is applied.
37 And is subject to the death penalty.
38 Shall be put to death.

39 Scripture earlier prohibited adultery (Lev. 18:20). However, Lev. 18:20 does not describe the punishment for this sin. Our verse does. The prohibition against adultery is not stated in our verse, for it was stated in Lev. 18:20.
40 A married woman who is raped is not executed, for a raped woman is not an adulteress.
41 See I.E. on Lev. 18:23.
42 Such an act is the result of promiscuous thinking or planning. The word zimmah comes from the Hebrew root zayin, mem, mem which means to plan, devise, purpose. Hence I.E.’s comment.
43 Of the woman with whom he had intercourse.
44 If the daughter of the woman with whom he had intercourse was his wife, then the mother is burned.
45 If the animal had intercourse with a human being it might let another person approach it for sexual purposes.

46 People looking at the animal will be reminded that a human being committed a sexual act with it. See Mishnah, San. 7:4, “Lest the beast should go through the market and people say, this is the beast by reason of which so and so was stoned.”
47 Le-rivah (and lie down thereto) is vocalized with a chirik rather than with a kamatz katan (le-rovah). Compare, le-korvah (Ex. 36:2).
48 Be-shivri is vocalized with a chirik rather than with a kamatz katan (be-shovri).
49 A person would not dare to marry a woman whom everyone knows to be his sister.
50 Hebrew, ve-ra’ah.
51 Engage in intercourse outside of marriage (Krinsky). According to I.E. our verse is to be understood as follows: If a man marries his sister or has sexual intercourse with her outside of marriage.
52 Hebrew, ve-et immo (literally, and his mother). Here the vav has the meaning of or. See I.E. on verse 9.
53 Chesed usually has the meaning of an act of kindness, which is beyond the norm. Here it means an especially perverse evil act.
54 Hence this additional clause.
55 Marriage, consensual intercourse outside of marriage, and rape. It does not mention all three with regard to the other prohibited relations.
56 See Sanhedrin 51a.
57 For his granddaughter.
58 Hence their grandsons have no desire to have intercourse with them.
59 She is menstruating.
61 All the other verses open with, And the man that… And if a man lie… And if a man take… However, our verse reads, And…the nakedness of thy mother’s sister… Why the anomaly? Hence I.E.’s comment.
62 Of his mother’s sister or his father’s sister.
63 For he hath made naked his near kin is another way of saying he has committed a heinous act. See I.E. on verse 9.
64 Regarding the one who marries his aunt, Scripture writes, they shall hear their iniquity. However, there is no mention of the punishment for marrying two sisters.
65 For Amram married the sister of his father and Jacob married two sisters (Krinsky; Weiser).
66 According to the rabbis they shall be punished with karet (excision). See Sifra on the Torah portion Tzav 13:2.
67 The wife of his father’s brother. See Lev. 18:14.
68 This is the opinion of Anan and other Karaites (Krinsky). I.E. often refers to the Karaites by the term Sadducees.
69 They shall be executed naked.
70 Onkelos renders aririm yamutu, they shall die childless.
71 In other words, aririm means childless.
72 We do not have I.E.’s comment on Jeremiah.
73 I. E. renders niddah hiy, she is distanced. The term niddah usually refers to a menstruating women.
74 The word niddah comes from the root nun, dalet, dalet, which means to wander.
75 The word menaddekhem, which is related to the word niddah, has the meaning of to distance.
76 None of the prohibited sexual partners is termed a niddah.
77 A menstruating woman.
78 Verses 18,19.

79 Seven days after the start of her menstrual flow. See Lev. 15:19. It should be noted that today all women experiencing a menstrual flow are considered zibbot, and they immerse themselves seven days after the cessation of their menstrual flow, with 12 days being the minimum.
80 The possibility of permissibility.
81 The reference is to the Karaites.

82 The Karaites believe that it is prohibited for a woman to marry the brother of her father. They argue that there is no difference between a man taking his aunt, which is explicitly prohibited by Scripture (v. 19), and a woman marrying her uncle.

83 Scripture does not legislate prohibitions of choosing sexual partners upon women, for it is the man who does the “taking” (Weiser). Or, the male plays the dominant role in the marriage. Thus it is proper to dominate a niece. However, it is unseemly for a nephew to dominate the sister of his father or his mother (Filwarg).
84 See Gen. 3:16, And he (your husband) shall rule over thee.
85 It is the male who does the taking. If Scripture had wanted to prohibit a man from marrying the daughter of his brother it would have said so.
86 No female legally dominates a male.
87 That as it is prohibited to marry the sister of the father, so it is prohibited for a woman to marry her uncle.

88 If we argue that as males may not marry their aunts so nieces may not marry their uncles, then we are in effect saying that what applies to males also applies to females. Applying this logic we should argue that as males are fit to be witnesses so are females. However, the Karaites like the Rabbinites do not accept the testimony of women.
89 The Karaites.
90 That women are inferior to men and therefore cannot serve as witnesses. According to Lev. 27:3 a male’s valuation is 50 shekels and a female’s 30.
91 See I.E. on Deut. 31:16 (Vol. 5, pp. 227,228).
92 According to medieval Jewish philosophy God does not have emotions. Hence I.E.’s comment.
93 The statutes describing those with whom sexual relations are prohibited.
94 Not only are you to be distinguished from people by your social codes, but you shall also be distinguished from them by observing dietary laws.
95 The ten clean beasts mentioned in Deut. 14:4,5.
97 When you speak about these animals it shall be clear that they are unclean.
98 Similarly, the meaning of ye shall have in detestation among the fowls is, you shall know in your mind and in your speech that these fowl are unclean.
99 A non-Jew living in the Land of Israel.
100 This is the literal meaning of the verse according to I.E. It is not so according to halakhah.
101 Follow My word. The literal translation is, walk after Me.
102 Scripture mention a sorceress because women practice sorcery more than men. See I.E. on Ex. 22:17 (Vol. 2, p. 487).

chapter.title: CHAPTER 21
chapter.p: 1. SPEAK UNTO THE PRIESTS. After charging the Israelites, and the sons of Aaron who are included among them, to be holy,1 the Lord told the sons of Aaron that they are commanded to keep themselves from other things, for they are the ministers of God. It is possible that speak unto the priests refers to the section which is mentioned above,2 for the Torah is in the hands of the kohanim.3
AND SAY UNTO THEM. This refers to the commandments which they alone are obligated to keep.4

FOR THE DEAD. Le-nefesh (for the dead) refers to the dead.5 The word yittamma (defile) is a hitpa’el. The tet6 receives a dagesh because the tav7 is, swallowed.8 The meaning of be-amav (among his people) is among all of Israel, who are his people.9

2. EXCEPT FOR HIS KIN. It had appeared to us that the meaning of she’ero (His kin) is similar to she’er (near of kin) in None of you…to any that is near of kin to him (Lev. 18:6). In other words, she’ero is a general term,10 with the details for his mother, and for his father following. The meaning of ba’al be-amav (a chief man among his people) (v. 4) is that a husband11 shall not defile himself for his wife. However, since we saw that our teachers transmitted to us the law that a kohen is permitted to defile himself for his wife,12 the first interpretation falls away. They employed the word she’er as a support,13 as I explained in my comments on the phrase unto a foreign people (Ex. 21:8).14 The rabbis said that the meaning of ba’al is, a chief who rules over the people, as in the owner thereof (be-alav) not being with it (Ex. 22:13).15 The reason Scripture mentions the mother of the kohen before the father is that in most cases the male lives longer than the female.16

3. THAT IS NEAR UNTO HIM. In that she is his sister from his father and his mother.17 Now, aside from those mentioned,18 a chief (v. 4) shall not defile himself for any of his people, be they kohanim or Israelites.
[4.] TO PROFANE HIMSELF. The lamed19 has a dagesh in it to compensate for the missing other lamed.20 Le-hechallo (to profane himself) is an infinitive in the nifal.
5. THEY SHALL NOT MAKE BALDNESS UPON THEIR HEAD. Over the dead.

THE CORNERS OF THEIR BEARD. Over the dead, as is the practice in places in the land of the Chaldeans. The meaning of the corners of thy beard (Lev. 19:27) is thus clarified.21 Saratet (cuttings) means even one cut.22 Israel has already been cautioned not to do these things.23 The reason Scripture warns the kohanim24 about this is that one who has a bald head, or whose beard has been shorn, or whose flesh is cut shall not serve before the Lord.
6. AND NOT PROFANE THE NAME OF GOD. The reason being, for the offerings made by fire…they do offer.25

7. WOMAN THAT IS A HARLOT. If we follow the plain meaning of the text then we do not find in all of Scripture the word zonah (harlot) to have any but its literal meaning.26 The meaning of and have given a boy for a harlot (zonah) (Joel 4:3) is also as I have explained.27

OR PROFANED. A woman who is not known as a harlot.28 According to the plain meaning, it would appear from the words of Ezekiel29 that the widow of a kohen30 is permitted to marry other kohanim.31 The words of tradition32 are thus true.33
8. THOU SHALT SANCTIFY HIM THEREFORE. In mind34 and in speech.
THE BREAD35 OF THY GOD. Food36 which is offered to God.
I THE LORD, WHO SANCTIFY YOU.37 All of you.

9. IF SHE PROFANE HERSELF BY PLAYING THE HARLOT. Many believe that techel (profane) is related to techillah (beginning).38 However, I believe that it is related to the word chillul (profane) but it is a hifil. Compare, he shall not break (yachel)39 his word (Num. 30:3). According to both interpretations the word comes from a double root.40 However, it is irregular.41 It is possible that the word hechel (profaned) (Ezek. 20:9) and the word techel are both irregular in that the tav42 is vocalized with a tzereh43 so that it not is confused in meaning with techillah (beginning).44 Similarly, hechel (profaned)45 in that it should not be profaned (Ezek. 20:9).
AND THE DAUGHTER OF ANY PRIEST…SHE SHALL BE BURNT WITH FIRE. If she profaned herself by harlotry, for she profaned the honor of her father.
SHE SHALL BE BURNT WITH FIRE. Whether she is either married or betrothed.46
10. THE GARMENTS. The reference is to the holy garments.
SHALL NOT LET THE HAIR OF HIS HEAD GO LOOSE, NOR REND HIS CLOTHES. We learn from this verse what our sages transmitted regarding the laws of mourning.47

11. NEITHER SHALL HE GO IN TO ANY DEAD BODY. Nafshot met is to be read as if written nafshot guf met (dead body). The word guf (body)48 is missing, for met (dead) is an adjective.49 Similarly, But the rich answers impudent50 (Prov. 18:23)51 and and their food plenteous52 (Hab. 1:16),53 where the word lamb is missing. The meaning of he shall [not] go in is, he shall not go into a tent or a house where the dead body is located. The meaning of for his father, or his mother is, for his father and mother, whom he is obligated to respect while they live and after their death. The kohen gadol may certainly not defile himself over his brother or his son.54

12. NEITHER SHALL HE GO OUT OF THE SANCTUARY. After the dead, so said the transmitters of tradition.55 What they said is correct. Some say that the reference is to the seven days of consecration. However, this cannot be so, for Scripture has already stated, and [the kohen] that is consecrated (v. 10).56 It is also possible that the meaning of our verse is that the kohen gadol shall not go out of the sanctuary except for the purpose of observing a precept.

13. IN HER VIRGINITY. There are nouns in Hebrew that never come in the singular. Compare, ne’urim (youth), zekunim (old age), alumim (youth), and betulim (virginity). There are other words which never come in the plural, i.e., taf (children), shekhem (shoulder), zahav (gold), and barzel (iron).
14. A WIDOW, OR ONE DIVORCED. Any woman widowed or divorced from a kohen or an Israelite.

OR A PROFANED WOMAN, OR A HARLOT. The connective vav before the word zonah (harlot) is missing.57 Compare, The sun moon (shemesh yare’ach) stand still in their habitation58 (Hab. 3:11).59 The reason Scripture reads but a virgin60 is that it wants to add of his own people, for a captive virgin61 and a convert62 are prohibited to him.

15. AND HE SHALL NOT PROFANE HIS SEED. By taking a widow or a divorced woman in secret. These shall he not take (v. 14) means he shall not publicly take any of these women.63 After Scripture mentions the sanctity of the kohanim it begins to list the blemishes.64

17. THE BREAD OF HIS GOD. The reference is to the sacrifices offered on the altar. The kohanim spoken of in our verse refer to common priests. Scripture therefore states anyone who is of the seed of Aaron the kohen.
18. MAIMED. Charum (maimed) is the reverse of saru’a (too long). Note, charum is related to the word cherem (destruction).65
TOO LONG. Saru’a (too long) is related to the word me-histare’a (to stretch himself) (Is. 29:20).

20. OR CROOK-BACKED. The word gibben (crook-backed) is most probably related to the word gavnunnim (peaks) in ye mountains of peaks (Ps. 68:17).66 The nun67 is a root letter.68 Gibben is an adjective. Similarly the word dak (a dwarf) is to be interpreted according to the plain meaning.69 Dak means short of stature.70

HATH HIS EYE OVERSPREAD. Some say that tevallul (overspread) is related to the word tevel (corruption) in they have wrought corruption (Lev. 20:12). Tevallul means a corruption.71 Others say that tevallul is related to the word belullah (mingled) in mingled with oil (Lev. 2:5).72 According to both interpretations the tav of tevallul is superfluous.73 According to the opinion of many the scab (garav) is also in the eye.

OR SCURVY. Yalefet (scurvy) means sticking.74 It is related to the word va-yilpot (took fast hold) in And Samson took fast hold (Jud. 16:29). There are others who say that yalefet means crooked.75 It is related to the word va-yillafet (turned) in that the man was startled, and turned (Ruth 3:8). The yod of yalefet is superfluous.76 It is like the yod of yitzhar (oil) (Num. 18:12).77
CRUSHED. Mero’ach (crushed) is an adjective. It is related to the word ru’ach (wind).78

STONES. Ashekh (stones) refers to the testicle. After listing specific blemishes the Torah issues a general statement and says, no man…that hath a blemish (v. 21). The meaning of hath a blemish is similar to he hath cursed his father or his mother (Lev. 20:9).79
22. THE BREAD OF HIS GOD…OF THE MOST HOLY. The showbread, the guilt offering, and the sin offering, which in comparison to the peace offerings are most holy, for the peace offerings are also holy.
AND OF THE HOLY. The tithe and the first-born.
23. ONLY HE SHALL NOT GO IN UNTO THE VEIL. Although he is a kohen gadol.80 He shall also not approach the altar.

24. [AND UNTO ALL THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL.] If it were not for the tradition81 we would interpret and unto all the children of Israel as meaning that those who are blemished should not slaughter peace offerings for the children of Israel. Now, since Scripture mentions that a blemished kohen may eat that which is holy, it warns82 that the one who eats sacred food must be clean.
chapter.ftnote: 1 In chapters 18, 19, and 20.
2 That is, in the above-noted chapters.
3 It is the duty of the kohanim to teach these laws to the children of Israel. See Deut. 31:9; 17:8-13.
4 The laws, which follow.
5 The word nefesh usually refers to a living body.
6 Of yittamma.
7 Of the hitpa’el.
8 By the tet. In other words, the dagesh compensates for the missing tav of the hitpae’el form.
9 Be-amav (among his people) literally means in his people. Hence I.E.’s comment.
10 Meaning a close relative.
11 Who is a kohen.
12 Yevamot 22b.

13 She’ero (his kin) literally means his flesh. According to the rabbis the reference is to a wife. The sages render ki im le-she’ero (except for his kin), except for his wife. According to I.E. the plain meaning of she’ero is not his wife. He believes that the rabbis used this verse as a support for a law which they knew by tradition.

14 According to the rabbis unto a foreign people means to any stranger. According to I.E. this is not the literal meaning of this phrase. The rabbis merely used this verse as a support. See I.E. on Ex. 21:8 (Vol. 2, pp. 458,459).

15 According to the rabbis the meaning of lo yittamma ba’al be-amav (He shall not defile himself, being a chief man among his people) is: “Seeing that he is fit to become the highest and most honored one among his people [i.e., a high priest], it (Scripture) warns him not to profane his distinction with the impurity of the dead” (Nachmanides, Chavel translation).
16 In most cases the kohen will mourn for his mother before he does so for his father. Hence she is mentioned first.
17 That is near indicates that the sister spoken of is a full sister.
18 In verses 2 and 3.
19 Of le-hechallo.
20 Hechallo is spelled with one lamed. However, it comes from a root that has two lameds. The dagesh in hechallo compensates for the missing root letter.
21 It too refers to an act of mourning. See I.E. on Lev. 19:27.
22 Saratet (cuttings) is singular. Hence I.E’s. comment.
23 Not to cut their flesh, to shave the corners of their beards, or to make themselves bald. See Lev. 19:27,28.
24 After already having told the Israelites.
25 For the offerings made by fire…they do offer refers to and not profane the name of God, not to They shall be holy unto their God.

26 That is, a zonah is a woman who sells her body. According to the rabbis a zonah is a woman who had intercourse with an individual whom she is not permitted to marry, i.e., a woman who has relations with a close relative or with a non-Jew. Such a woman is considered a zonah even if the intercourse was not with her consent. Hence I.E.’s comment.
27 In other words, zonah in Joel 4:3 refers to a harlot. It means that they gave a young man in payment for sexual favors.

28 A woman who is not a harlot but has been defiled. I.E. does not define how the woman was profaned. However, from the context it appears that I.E. refers to a woman who is not a prostitute but had intercourse with someone who is not a kohen. It is also possible that I.E. refers to a woman who is promiscuous but not a prostitute. It should be noted that according to the rabbis the reference is to a woman born of a marriage between a kohen and a woman prohibited to him (Kiddushin 77a).
30 That is, only the widow of a kohen.

31 Ezek. 44:22 seems to imply that the only widow a kohen may marry is the widow of another kohen, for Ezekiel states, Neither shall they take for their wives a widow…but they shall take…a widow that is the widow of a priest.
32 To the effect that a kohen may marry any widow. See Kiddushin 78b.

33 Despite the plain meaning of Ezek. 44:22, for our chapter (v. 7) does not prohibit a kohen from marrying any widow. We thus must interpret Ezek. 44:22 as follows: Neither shall a kohen gadol take for their wives a widow…but some of the kohanim, that is, a common kohen, may take a widow (any widow, not only the widow of a kohen). See Kiddushin 78b.
34 Think of the kohen in a respectful manner.
35 Hebrew, lechem.
36 Lechem usually refers to bread. Hence I.E.’s comment.
37 Hebrew, lakhem, which is plural.
38 This interpretation renders ki techel li-zenot (if she profane herself by playing the harlot) as if she begins to play the harlot.
39 Or profane.
40 Its root is chet, lamed, lamed.
41 For its prefix is vocalized with a tzere rather than with a kamatz as similar roots are in the hifil. Compare, achel (I will begin), tachel (she will begin), etc.
42 The tav of techel
43 Literally, a small kamatz.
44 Beginning and profane both come from the same root, chet, lamed, lamed. If both were similarly vocalized, we would confuse them.
45 Hechel is vocalized with a tzere rather than with a kamatz so that it not be confused with hachel (begin) (Deut. 2:24).
46 Hebrew, arusah. The reference is to the first stage of marriage. During this phase the woman lives in the house of her parents.
47 According to the rabbis a mourner has to rend his garments and is prohibited from cutting his hair. Our verse shows that the latter are mourning practices.
48 Guf is masculine.
49 Modifying guf. Met is masculine. It cannot modify nafshot, which is feminine. Hence I.E.’s comment.
50 Translated literally.
51 The term “words” is missing from the verse. The clause should be read as if written: But the rich answers [with] impudent words.
52 Literally, and his food fat.
53 And his food fat should be read as if written: and his food a fat lamb.
54 Our verse only mentions the kohen gadol’s father and mother. However, if he cannot defile himself over the latter he certainly cannot defile himself for his brother or son.
55 San. 18a. Also see Rashi.
56 In other words, our verse speaks of a kohen who is already consecrated.

57 From before the word zonah (harlot). Our verse reads, va-chalalah zonah. This literally means or a profaned woman harlot. I.E. believes that the latter should be read as if written, va-chalalah ve-zonah (or a profaned woman or a harlot).
58 Translated literally.
59 Here too a vav is missing. The verse should be read as if written: The sun and moon (shemesh ve-yare’ach) stand still in their habitation.
60 The law mandating that a kohen gadol may only marry a virgin was stated in the previous verse. Why repeat it again in our verse?
61 A foreign woman taken captive as a result of war. See Deut. 21:10-14.
62 Who is a virgin.
63 Since Scripture has already stated that he may not publicly take a divorced woman, a widow, a harlot, or a profaned woman. Hence our verse refers to secret intercourse with these women.
64 Which disqualify a kohen from offering sacrifices.
65 According to I.E. saru’a refers to a person who has an extra-large limb while charum refers to a person who has a limb that is undersized.
66 According to I.E. gibben is someone who is extremely tall.
67 Of gibben.
68 Hence we can relate gibben (crook-backed) to gavnunnim (peaks).
69 Of the verse.
70 Dak stands in contrast to gibben. If gibben means a peak, then dak is its opposite.
71 A blemish.
72 A streak of white going into the iris or pupil. See Rashi and Ibn Janach (Sefer Ha-Rikmah).
73 For the root of tevallul is bet, lamed, lamed.
74 It refers to boils which stick to the body.
75 A kohen with a crooked hand, foot, fingers, etc.
76 For its root is lamed, peh, tav.
77 The root of which is tzadi, heh, resh.
78 See Nachmanides: “One who has wind [and a result of which] his testicles are swollen” (Chavel translation).
79 The repetition is for emphasis. See I.E. on Lev. 20:9.
80 If the kohen gadol is struck with a blemish he is prohibited from going unto the veil. A common kohen may not go unto the veil. Hence I.E.’s comment.
81 Which permits kohanim who are blemished to slaughter peace offerings for the children of Israel
82 In the section which follows.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 22
chapter.p: 2. THAT THEY SEPARATE THEMSELVES. Ve-yinnazeru (that they separate themselves) is similar to ve-hizzhartem (thus shall ye separate) (Lev. 15:31).1 Ve-yinnazeru is a nifal. It means they shall distance and separate themselves. It is related to the word nazir (nazirite).2

AND THAT THEY PROFANE NOT. And that they profane not applies to what immediately follows it and to what follows later. Our verse is to be read as follows: And that they profane not My holy name, and that they profane not that which they hallow unto Me. The meaning of I am the Lord is, I the Lord am holy.
[3. FROM BEFORE ME: I AM THE LORD.] This means since he is cut off from God, he will cease to exist.3 I have explained the latter in my comments on the secret of God’s name.4
4. UNTIL HE BE CLEAN. Until the days necessary for his cleansing have passed.
5. WHEREBY HE MAY BE MADE UNCLEAN. The word lo means whereby.5 Compare the word li (of me)6 in say of me: He is my brother (Gen. 20:13). All those mentioned7 shall become unclean until evening.

7. AND WHEN THE SUN IS DOWN, HE SHALL BE CLEAN. It is known that he shall be clean refers to the unclean, for there is no mention of the word day in the verse.8 Compare, and the priest shall make atonement for her, and she shall be clean (Lev. 12:8). However, the rabbis of blessed memory transmitted to us the law that even if the sun sets he shall not eat until it is completely dark.9 They used this verse as a support.10 I have explained the latter11 in my comments on the verse unto a foreign people (Ex. 21:8).12 The rabbis therefore13 said that ve-taher (he should be clean) means that the day shall be clean.

BECAUSE IT IS HIS BREAD. His food.14 I have previously explained this.15 Those whose brains are empty explain the verse in Ezekiel, which reads, The priests shall not eat of any thing that dieth of itself, or is torn, whether it be fowl or beast (Ezek. 44:31), as meaning that the priests shall not eat anything brought down or torn by animals or fowl.16 However, this is nonsense, for the Torah states all that dies of itself or is torn he17 shall not eat.18 The meaning19 is if he eats20 he shall not minister.21
9. THEY SHALL THEREFORE KEEP MY CHARGE. Mishmarti (my charge) alludes to the sanctuary. Scripture therefore reads, lest they bear sin for it (alav), and die therein (vo).
10. THERE SHALL NO COMMON MAN. One who is not of the seed of Aaron.
11. THEY MAY EAT OF HIS BREAD. Males and females.
12. THAT WHICH IS SET APART FROM THE HOLY THINGS. The thigh and the breast (Lev. 10:15).
13. SHE MAY EAT OF HER FATHER’S BREAD. As at first.
BUT THERE SHALL NO COMMON MAN EAT OF IT. The reference is to a son, if she has one. She cannot eat of the holy food because of her son.

14. AND SHALL GIVE UNTO THE PRIEST THE HOLY THING. The meaning of ve’et ha-kodesh (the holy thing) is, with22 the holy thing.23 On the other hand, and shall give unto the priest might apply to what precedes it and to what follows it. Our verse is to be interpreted as follows: Then he shall put the fifth part thereof unto it and shall give it unto the priest, and he shall give unto the priest the holy thing. I believe that there is no need for this interpretation, for Scripture reads unto it.24
16. AND SO CAUSE THEM TO BEAR. Ve-hisi’u (and cause…to bear) is a hifil. Its meaning is, they shall caution them and teach them so that they do not err.25
After mentioning the holy things of the children of Israel26 Scripture goes on27 to caution the Israelites to not bring the holy things from blemished animals.

[18. STRANGERS.] Scripture reads or of the strangers for it is stated that there is one law for the Israelite and the stranger who offer a vow or freewill offering.28 The sages differentiated between a vow offering and a freewill offering.29 All vow offerings are freewill offerings. However, not all freewill offerings are vow offerings.30 It is fitting that all sacrifices that are offered in their entirety31 on the altar be unblemished.32
21. CLEARLY UTTERED. Le-fale means to clearly utter.

22. BLIND. Avveret (blind) is an adjective relating to the eye. Some say that shavur (broken) means a break in the hand and charutz (maimed) refers to an injury in the foot. Charutz is related to charatzta (hast decided it) in So shall thy judgment be; thyself hast decided it (I Kings 20:40). Charutz means cut.33
A WEN. Yabbelet (wen) is similar to tevallul (overspread) (Lev. 21:20). The general rule is: we rely on tradition,34 not on our deficient minds.
YE SHALL NOT OFFER THESE UNTO THE LORD. In fulfillment of a clearly uttered vow. Nor shall the kohen take the organs from these.35
23. TOO LONG. Saru’a (too long) has the same meaning as when first mentioned (Lev. 21:18).36
TOO SHORT. Kalut (too short) is the opposite of saru’a (too long). Kalut is related to the word miklat (refuge) in the city of refuge (Josh. 21:13).37
24. BRUISED. Ma’uch (bruised) is related to mo’akhu (pressed) in their bosoms pressed (Ezek. 23:3).
OR CRUSHED. Katut (crushed) is related to va-ekkot (beat) in and beat it in pieces (Deut. 9:21). Crushed and bruised refer to wounds in the testicles.
OR TORN. Natuk (torn) is related to yinnatek (broken) in as a string of tow is broken (Jud. 16:9).
NEITHER SHALL YE DO THUS IN YOUR LAND. To change God’s work.38
25. FROM THE HAND OF A FOREIGNER. One should not think as follows: I will not hesitate to offer this sacrifice, for it is the offering of a foreigner.39

THEIR CORRUPTION. The mem of moshchatam (their corruption) is not a root letter. However, its tav is a root letter. Moshchatam is related to the word hashchatah (destruction).40 On the other hand, the mem of moshchatam (their anointing) (Ex.40:15) is a root letter and the tav is not.41

BE ACCEPTED. Yeratzu (be accepted) is a nifal. After stating that a blemished sacrifice will not be accepted, Scripture goes on to say that any sacrifice brought from an animal less than eight days old will also not be accepted.

27. WHEN A BULLOCK, OR A SHEEP, OR A GOAT. The newborn animals are called by what they ultimately become. Compare, And stripped the naked42 of their clothing (Job 22:6); “the dead43 shall be put to death”44 (Deut. 17:6); “for the one who falls shall fall from it”45 (Deut. 22:8). On the other hand, Scripture may have been referring to the name of the species.46
[BUT FROM THE EIGHTH DAY AND THENCEFORTH.] Like a child that is circumcised, that is, until a quarter of the month has passed.47
THENCEFORTH. Hale’ah (thenceforth) means afterwards. The arrow of Jonathan is proof.48
28. AND WHETHER IT BE COW49 OR EWE.50 I have previously explained this.51 The commandment pertains to both males and females.52

[29. AND WHEN YE SACRIFICE A SACRIFICE OF THANKSGIVING.] The reason that And when ye sacrifice a sacrifice of thanksgiving…On the same day it shall he eaten follows is that Scripture earlier noted it is prohibited to kill a cow or a ewe [and its young together] in one day.53 Scripture adds to what is written in the Torah portion Tzav (Lev. 6:2),54 that ye may be accepted.55
[30. I AM THE LORD.] Scripture reads I am the Lord to teach that the thanksgiving offering is to be “whole.”56
31. AND YE SHALL KEEP MY COMMANDMENTS. In your hearts.
AND DO THEM; I AM THE LORD. For I investigate what is in the heart, and I see everything that is done.

[32. AND YE SHALL NOT PROFANE MY HOLY NAME.] This is directed to the sons of Aaron, for this section57 is connected to what is earlier stated.58 They59 are commanded not to sacrifice for themselves or for Israel a cow and its offspring on one day. It is also possible that And when ye sacrifice a sacrifice of thanksgiving (v. 29) is directed to the kohanim.60 The fact that the following section opens with Speak unto the children of Israel (Lev. 23:2) is proof of this.61 But I will be hallowed among the children of Israel is a second witness.62

33. THAT BROUGHT YOU OUT. The verse ends with I am the Lord. This the first statement of the Decalogue63 and the root of all the commandments.64 After mentioning the holy things of the children of Israel,65 the Torah notes66 the days that Israel shall offer burnt offerings. It starts with the Sabbath.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Both words come from the root nun, zayin, resh.
2 A nazir separates himself from wine and uncleanliness.
3 God is the cause and sustainer of existence. To be cut off from God thus means to be cut off from the source of life; i.e., his soul following his death ceases exist.
4 The name YHVH indicates that God alone exists forever and the existence of all things is contingent upon Him. See I.E. on Ex. 3:15 (Vol. 2, p. 67).
5 Lo literally means to him, or to it. Hence I.E.’s comment.
6 Li literally means to me.
7 In our verse.
8 Hence ve-taher (and he shall be clean) cannot refer to the day.
9 According to the rabbis ve-taher (and he shall be clean) refers to the day. They render ve-taher as, and it shall be clean; i.e., the day shall be cleared away. See Berakhot 2a,b.
10 The Rabbinic interpretation is not the real meaning of the verse.
11 The Rabbinic use of a verse as a support for their traditions.
12 See Vol. 2, p. 458.
13 Because they used this verse as a support.
14 His bread means his food.
15 That lechem (bread) means food. See I.E. on Ex 16:4 (Vol. 2, p. 316).

16 Ex. 22:30 prohibits an Israelite from eating that which is torn (terefah). Deut. 44:21 prohibits an Israelite from eating meat which dies of itself (nevelah). Ezek 44:21 seems to limit the prohibition to eat nevalah and terefah only to kohanim. In order to harmonize Ezekiel and the Torah, there were those who claimed that Ezekiel spoke of an animal that has been properly slaughtered and then ripped apart and befouled by birds and beasts. In other words, the Torah prohibits any Israelite from eating the meat of any animal that has been ripped apart by an animal of prey, while Ezekiel adds that a kohen is also prohibited from eating kosher meat that has been befouled. It should be noted that according to this interpretation the word nevelah is not to be taken literally but means flesh which is as disgusting as meat that dies of itself (Filwarg). For other interpretations see Sarim and Meijler.
17 The kohen.
18 I.E.’s paraphrase of verse 8, which literally reads: that which dies of itself, or is torn, he shall not eat.
19 Of verse 8 and Ezek. 44:21.
20 That which dies of itself or is torn.
21 The meaning of our verse and that of Ezekiel is, if a kohen eats that which was torn or died of itself he is ritually unclean and shall not serve in the tabernacle or eat sacred food.
22 In other words, et here has the meaning of with.

23 According to I.E. our clause is to be interpreted as follows: And shall give the fifth part thereof along with the holy thing. And shall give unto the priest the holy thing implies that only the holy thing is to be given to the kohen. The question thus arises, what is to be done with the fifth part? Hence this interpretation.
24 Unto the holy thing. Thus, and shall give unto the priest the holy thing takes in the fifth part.
25 If the kohanim do not teach the Israelites they cause them as it were, to bear the iniquity of profaning the holy food.
26 The offerings of the children of Israel. See verse 2.
27 In the next section.
29 See Kinnim 1:1.
30 One can set aside a freewill offering without taking a vow to bring a freewill offering.
31 A burnt offering.
32 The same applies to other offerings. I.E. speaks of a burnt offering because our verse does.
33 The term “cut” can also be applied to decree or decision. This is its meaning in I Kings 20:40.
34 With regard to the interpretation of the blemishes mentioned in our chapter.
35 And make an offering by fire of them.
36 See I.E. on Lev. 21:18.
37 Kalut means compressed or held back. A city of refuge limits or holds the refugee back in that he may not leave.
38 By harming the sexual organs of an animal.
39 Hence one need not be so strict,
40 It comes from the root shin, chet, tav.
41 For its root is mem, shin, chet.
42 Scripture refers to the one who is to be stripped as naked, even though he is not naked until stripped.
43 Scripture refers to the one who is to be put to death as “dead.” We thus see that Scripture refers to people or things by what they ultimately become.
44 Translated literally.
45 Translated literally
46 When a bullock, or a sheep, or a goat is brought forth means when an animal that belongs to the species of bullock, sheep, or goat is born.
47 See I.E. on Lev. 12:2 and the notes thereto.
48 Jonathan referred to his arrow as being beyond (hale’ah) the young man. See I Sam 20:22.
49 Hebrew, shor (ox).
50 Hebrew, she (male sheep).
51 In the previous verse. I.E.’s point is that shor and seh are the names of the species. In other words, they do not apply only to males.
52 Even though the verse is in the masculine.
53 The law codified in our verse and the law dealt with in the previous verse both deal with “one day.”
54 Regarding a sacrifice of thanksgiving.
55 Hence verses 29 and 30 are not redundant.
56 It cannot be brought from a blemished animal. The meaning of our verse is, it is unfit to offer a blemished animal as a thanksgiving to Me, for I am the Lord.
57 Verses 26-33.
58 To verse 18 which is directed to Aaron, to his sons, and to all of Israel. In other words, verses 26-33 are directed to the sons of Aaron.
59 The sons of Aaron.
60 For the entire section (verses 26-33) is directed to the kohanim.
61 That our chapter (verses 26-33) is directed to the kohanim.
62 This is directed to the kohanim. Had it been directed to the Israelites, Scripture would have read: But I will be hallowed among you.
63 Our verse, which connects God to the Exodus, is parallel to the first of the ten statements of the Decalogue, which does the same.
64 See I.E. on Ex. 20:1 (Vol. 2, p. 393).
65 In our chapter.
66 In the following chapter.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 23
chapter.p: [2. EVEN THESE ARE MY APPOINTED SEASONS.] Scripture reads, even these are My appointed seasons (mo’adai) because there are many Sabbaths in the year.1
3. IN ALL YOUR DWELLINGS. In your country and outside of your country, at home and on the way.

I have previously explained the meaning of it is a sabbath unto the Lord.2 Scripture then mentions the festivals (v. 4). The Torah says, even these are My appointed seasons, with regard to the Sabbath and in their appointed season with regard to the festivals. The meaning of in their appointed season is, in any day of the week in which they fall. Note, I will now lay down a general rule with regard to the festivals. During the time of the Temple the festivals were in the hands of the Beth Din. Do you not see that Scripture says, For the king had taken counsel (II Chron. 30:2), with regard to the Passover proclaimed by Hezekiah.3 After Hezekiah established the new moon of Nisan he proclaimed a leap year.4 Our sages, of blessed memory, criticized him for this, for he should not have added a Nisan on Nisan.5

The transmitters of tradition said that the Beth Din took many things into consideration in estabhshing the year.6 They said, regarding Rabbi Akiba, that he established two leap years back to back according to the needs of the hour.7 There is no proof in Scripture as to how Israel established the months and the festivals. The Gaon’s statement to the effect that they relied on the intercalational calculation8 is not true, for there are proofs in the Mishnah and also in the Talmud that Passover fell on a Monday, Wednesday, and Friday.9 There are also two stories in the Talmud [which show that they did not rely on a fixed calendar].10 Leap years11 come close to compensating for the additional days which a solar year has over a lunar year.12 The latter does not follow the way of the ancients.13

The calculation14 starts with the end of 14 hours of the sixth day;15 that is, add four days, eight hours, and 876 parts16 to five hours and 204 parts of an hour of the second day of the week.17 Then the birth of the new moon will occur at the end of 14 hours of the sixth day.18 A year is added,19 for we start counting from five hours and 204 parts of an hour of the second day of the week20 because of the five days which preceded the creation of Adam, for a day into a year is considered a year.21 This presents no problem.22 You cannot add an additional year,23 for it did not yet exist. Note, an additional month was added to the year after a year and a half.24 The intercalation is based on the average25 movement of the moon.26 The sages therefore said that sometimes the birth of the moon comes at longer intervals; at times it comes at shorter intervals.27 The establishment of the month28 is not tied to the sighting of the moon in Jerusalem,29 or in the far east,30 or in the west [of the world].31 The place of the average conjunction of the moon32 is proof of this,33 for look, it is reckoned when occurring over Jerusalem.34 Furthermore, we have seen the moon many times on the second night of the month of Nisan. It was similarly seen in the entire world. However, the month was established on the third night [of the week].35 The same thing happened in the three months preceding Nisan. This occurs when the birth of the new moon of Tishri occurs at nine hours and 204 parts of an hour of the third day [of the week].36 It was enacted37 because of the postponement.38 There are also times when the month of Tishri was established on the fifth day [of the week] and the moon was not seen on the night of the Sabbath. Now, the air was then clear. This occurs every year when the birth of the new moon39 is close to half of the day40 and the moon is in half of its sphere’s apogee. The establishment41 is also not dependent on the time of the conjunction42 of the sun and moon. It is not even dependent on their mean conjunction, for note, the conjunction43 of the sun and moon at 15 hours and 599 parts44 of the hour on the second day45 and similarly the conjunction at nine hours and 204 parts of the third day46 is proof of this.47 If I did not want to go on at length I would explain the secret of the calculation of the calendar and the secret of the very difficult law, i.e., the rule regarding a moon born before midday.48 The general principle is: our wise men, of blessed memory, transmitted to us the rule that we are to rely on the intercalated calendar in exile. We received the same from the mouth of the prophets. We cannot do anything better than it. The sages ruled that the festivals be observed for two days in the Diaspora because of uncertainty.49 Those who fast for two days in observance of Yom Kippur50 fast in vain51 due to the “postponements.” For in a year when the birth of the new moon52 occurs at nine hours and 204 parts of the hour on the third day of the week, they should fast on what is the eighth day of the month according to our calculation if they rely on the conjunction.53 Why54 manipulate the date of the start of one year55 because of another year?56 This would happen to them57 if the month is established by seeing the new moon.58
[5.] AT DUSK. I have previously explained this.59

8. AN OFFERING MADE BY FIRE. These are described in the Torah portion Pinechas.60 Scripture reads, When ye are come into the land (v. 9),61 so that Israel would observe all the Sabbaths in the wilderness and the Passover62 at Mount Sinai.63 This section was given close to the [time of the] erection of the tabernacle.64
[10. SPEAK UNTO THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL.] This means speak unto the children of Israel and tell them to gather. Afterwards,65 say unto them…66

11. ON THE MORROW AFTER THE SABBATH. The sages said that on the morrow after the sabbath means on the morrow after the festival.67 Those who contradict the sages68 say that the word Sabbath is be taken literally.69 Those who believe in the Rabbinic tradition offer proof from the Sabbatical year,70 the Jubilee, the great fast,71 and the day of shofar sounding,72 for the word shabbaton (a solemn rest) is employed with regard to them.73 Scripture similarly employs shabbaton with regard to Sukkot74 and Shemini Atzeret.75 They also say that the meaning of sheva shabbatot (v. 15) is seven weeks.76 The same is true of ba’eh shabbat im yotze’eh shabbat (those that were to come in on the sabbath, with those that were to go out on the sabbath) (II Kings 11:9).77 The same word78 is employed with two meanings in one verse.79 Note, we find a similarity in sheloshim ayarim (thirty ass colts) (Jud. 10:4).80 They81 offer proof from the word complete (v. 15).82

A wise man in Rome83 offered proof84 from on the morrow after the passover, unleavened cakes and parched corn (Josh. 5:11).85 He did not know that it cost him his life,86 for the Passover falls on the 14th87 and the morrow following it is on the 15th.88 Scripture similarly reads, And they journeyed from Rameses in the first month (Num. 33:3).89 The eating of parched corn is prohibited until the waving of the omer.90 The Gaon91 says that there are two Passovers, a Passover of the Lord and a Passover of Israel. The Passover of God is on the night of the 15th.92 Now, the day after the Passover in Joshua refers to the 16th day.93 It follows from this that the interpretation of on the morrow after the passover (Num. 33:3), is on the morrow following the sacrifice of the Passover.94 What he said has no value. The festival95 is called Passover only because God skipped over the houses.96 Its morrow is the morning of the 15th.97 Scripture similarly writes, all that day, and all the night, and all the next day (yom ha-mochorat)98 (Num. 11:32). The Gaon further states that the unleavened cakes and the parched corn were from the old grain.99 This is not far-fetched, for Scripture says that the waving of the omer should begin from the time the sickle is first put to the standing corn (Deut. 16:9). If the omer was waved on the 15th100 when did they harvest and make unleavened bread?101 Furthermore, there was no harvest,102 for the omer is brought from the first of the barley harvest.103 There is also what appears to be proof of the Gaon’s opinion,104 for Scripture states, of the produce (meavur) of the land (Josh. 5:11). It is possible that the term avur refers to the produce of the year that has passed.105 The meaning of the produce of the land is the produce of the land of Sihon and Og.106 The fact that Scripture afterwards states, of the fruit of the land of Canaan (Josh. 5:12), is proof.107 Furthermore, kaluy (parched corn) (Josh. 5:11) is not the same as kali (parched com) (Lev. 23:14).108 Now, Scripture says, And ye shall eat neither bread nor parched corn (kali), nor fresh ears (v. 14). The verse which reads kaluy ba-esh (parched with fire) (Lev. 2:14)109 cannot serve as an argument to the contrary,110 for it describes the act111 since corn in the ear parched in fire is called kaluy.112 We can also ask:113 From where do we know that the kohen waved the omer on the other side of the Jordan,114 for the verse states, which I give unto you (v. 10)?115 However, the land was not yet given to them.116 Scripture mentions matzot and corn only because the manna ceased. This is the meaning of the entire verse.117

The Gaon118 further says: If the word Sabbath119 is to be taken literally120 then from which Sabbath shall we start to count? Joshua121 answers that there are 18 days aside from the Sabbath whereon sacrifices are offered. These days are called mo’adim (festivals). Now, since there is a sacrifice122 on the day that the omer is offered123 it is a sign and a witness that the waving takes place on one of the days of the spring festival.124 Note, he125 forgot the sacrifices that are offered on the new moon, which are not mentioned.126 Furthermore, Scripture states, After this manner ye shall offer daily,127 for seven days (Num. 28:24). Scripture should have stated, aside from the offering of the omer.128 This129 too130 is no argument against us, for we rely on tradition when it comes to the commandments. Now, Scripture does not state “aside from the he-lambs brought for a peace offering,” when it lists in the Torah portion Pinechas the offerings to be brought on the festival of Shavu’ot.131 It states above,132 and one young bullock, and two rams (v. 18). However, Pinechas reads, two young bullocks, one ram, seven he-lambs of the first year (Num. 28:27).133 The believer can also answer134 that Moses prophetically knew the day that the omer would be waved.135 He knew that the first day of the month136 would be established on the Sabbath.137 The arrangement of the bread which took place on the Sabbath is proof of this.138 Scripture notes139 how they calculated the first year.140 They then141 brought the peace offerings and the burnt offerings which are mentioned [in our Torah portion] and then142 the ones mentioned in the Torah portion Pinechas.143 Scripture then goes on to say,144 in your feast of weeks (Num. 28:26) and seven weeks (Deut. 16:9); it does not state Sabbaths.145 There is no proof that the beginning of the week146 starts with the first day.147 In fact, then she148 shall be unclean two weeks (Lev. 12:5) shows that this is not the case.149 Look, I will hint at a secret.150 All the festivals are contingent on a specific day of the month. Scripture does not give a date for the festival of Shavu’ot151 because of the counting, which is a commandment. The rabbis, of blessed memory, transmitted the tradition that the Torah was given on the festival of Shavu’ot and that it is concerning this day that Scripture states, for we must hold a feast unto the Lord (Ex. 10:9).

Some say that whenever the Torah uses the term li-retzonekhem it means to be accepted from you,152 for Scripture reads, And he shall wave the sheaf before the Lord, to be accepted for you (li-retzonekhem) (v. 11). The meaning of the aforementioned is that you shall wave it willingly.153 This means you shall offer a he-lamb154 of the first year so that you will be accepted.155

Those who deny the Rabbinic tradition156 say that ben shanah (of the first year) (Ex. 12:5) does not have the same meaning as ben shenato157 (of the first year), for ben shanato refers to a lamb under a year and ben shanah refers to a lamb of a complete year. Note, they did not read the section dealing with the dedication of the altar. The latter reads, one he-lamb of the first year (ben shenato), for a burnt offering (Num. 7:15). However, in the final section158 it reads, the he-lambs of the first year (bene shanah) twelve (Num. 7:87).159

14. BREAD. From the new grain.160 The fact that the Passover offering is eaten with matzot and bitter herbs is proof of this.161 If it were not for tradition162 it would have appeared that the counting of the days is similar to the counting of the years163 of the Jubilee.164 Those who deny the Rabbinic tradition say that the meaning of complete is that the first Sabbath from the morrow on which the count begins is not to be considered in the count.165
16. SHALL YE NUMBER FIFTY DAYS. For this is the way the Torah counts.166 Similarly, in all cases of the eighth day.167
[17. YE SHALL BRING OUT.] The word tavi’u (ye shall bring out) is irregular in that its alef has a dagesh in it. We do not know the reason for this.
OF YOUR DWELLINGS. We need tradition to teach us from which place it was brought168 and when it is to be brought.169
TWO WAVE-LOAVES. For the kohen along with the peace offering lambs.170

It is possible that Scripture changed the sacrifices in the first year171 because it was the beginning of the beginning.172 Some say that the kohen shall offer173 either a bullock and two rams174 or two bullocks and one ram.175 It depends on the will of the kohen.176 We do not find such a commandment again.177 I will give its true explanation in the Torah portion Pinechas.178 Now, since the slaughtering of the peace offerings took place on the festival of Shavu’ot and it is a day of holy assembly, it is thus permissible to slaughter179 on all the festivals. The latter is contrary to the opinion of the Sadducees.180

[22. AND WHEN YE REAP.] The reason Scripture mentions And when ye reap the harvest of your land… a second time181 is that Shavu’ot is the festival of the first-fruits of the wheat harvest (Ex. 34:22). Scripture cautions: Do not forget what I commanded you182 to do at this time.

[23. SPOKE.] The reason the statement And the Lord spoke precedes the law dealing with the day of the sounding of the shofar183 is that the latter is a festival unto itself.184 However, the festival of Shavu’ot is connected to the day the omer is waved.185 And the Lord spoke is similarly written in connection with the great fast186 and the festival of Sukkot.

24. IN THE SEVENTH MONTH. We begin the count of months from Nisan,187 for we then left Egypt. Furthermore, the festival of the new ears of barley188 comes first,189 next come the first-fruits of wheat harvest (Ex. 34:22),190 and then the time when you gather in the produce of your work (Deut. 16:13).191 These festivals are contingent upon the days that are mentioned.192 Scripture commands that trumpets are to be sounded on all new moons.193 It follows from the aforementioned that zikhron tru’ah (a memorial proclaimed with the blast of horns) and yom tru’ah (a day of blowing the horn) refer to the sounding of a shofar.194 Similarly, on Yom Kippur.195 I will hint at some secrets to you. Pay attention. Perhaps you will understand them.

The transmitters of tradition said that Rosh Ha-Shanah is a day of judgment and that the sounding of the shofar proclaims the kingdom of God.196 Now, since the new moon197 is the most important [day of the month], the first month of Nisan198 is the most glorious month because the tabernacle was erected then. Ezekiel in speaking of the future says, In the first month, in the first day of the month (Ezek. 45:18). Similarly, And so thou shalt do on the seventh day of the month (Ezek. 40:20) because of the quarter.199 Note,200 the 15th day of the month201 corresponds to the time when one half of the month faces the other half.202 The seventh day203 is also a quarter.204 On the second Passover205 the great206 and the small207 interchange.208 The day of Rosh Ha-Shanah is therefore greater209 than all of them. Now, even though it is the Day of Judgment it is prohibited to fast on it. The Book of Ezra shows that this is the case.210 On Yom Kippur the small light211 is in the conjunction.212 Note, Sukkot is like Passover.213 However, its eighth day, not its seventh, is a festival. From this, the secret214 and the secret of the Sabbath215 will become clear to you.

27. [HOWBEIT.] Scripture reads, Howbeit on the tenth day, because a day of solemn assembly (v. 24) is a joyful day.216 The Book of Ezra similarly reads, Go your way, eat the fat, and drink the sweet (Neh. 8:10).217
AND YE SHALL AFFLICT. I have previously explained the meaning of afflict.218
28. TO MAKE ATONEMENT FOR YOU. Its meaning is, it is a day of atonement for you alone.219

29. FOR WHATSOEVER SOUL IT SHALL BE THAT SHALL NOT BE AFFLICTED. Te’unneh (be afflicted) is a pu’al. This220 is a sign that if we know of a person who does not observe this precept as we observe it, then we shall force that individual to fast.221 The reason Scripture says that no manner of work is to be done on Yom Kippur is so that people will not be engaged in anything but seeking atonement for sins.
30. THAT SOUL WILL I DESTROY. There is a difference between “destroy” and “cut off” (v. 29). I cannot explain the difference.222
[31. NO MANNER OF WORK.] Scripture repeats, Ye shall do no manner of work,223 in order to add, it is a statue for ever throughout your generations.
32. SHALL YE KEEP YOUR SABBATH. Scripture reads your sabbath, for the Sabbath day is not called the Sabbath of Israel but the Sabbath of God.224
36. SEVEN DAYS YE SHALL BRING AN OFFERING MADE BY FIRE. Even though it is not the same as the offering made by fire that is brought on Passover.225

IT IS A DAY OF SOLEMN ASSEMBLY. Some say that atzeret (solemn assembly) means an assembly as in azteret bogedim (an assembly of treacherous men) (Jer. 9:1). Azteret refers to the gathering of all of Israel on the three pilgrimage festivals. However, they did not speak correctly, for look, Scripture states with regard to Passover, and on the seventh day shall be a solemn assembly (atzeret) (Deut. 16:8). However, it also states and thou shalt turn in the morning,226 and go unto thy tents (Deut. 16:7).227 It appears that atzeret is similar to netzar (detained)228 in detained before the Lord (I Sam. 21:8). Atzeret means that the Israelite shall not be involved in any worldly affairs.229
The meaning of atzeret is, ye shall do no manner of servile work.230 Scripture writes similarly with regard to the atzeret of the festival of Passover.231

37. THESE ARE THE APPOINTED SEASONS OF THE LORD. Whereon you are obligated to bring an offering made by fire. Scripture explains232 that on all of these festivals a burnt offering, a meal offering, a sacrifice,233 and libations are to be brought, for until now Scripture only mentioned an offering made by fire, and it is possible that an offering made by fire refers only to a burnt offering or only to a meal offering.234
38. AND BESIDE YOUR GIFTS. On the three pilgrimage festivals.235 Similarly, And the vows of the congregation and of the individual and their freewill offerings.236

39. [HOWBEIT.] Scripture reads howbeit because it mentioned the affliction of the soul in the preceding section. The Torah prohibited fasting on the festival of Sukkot, for Scripture reads with regard to this festival, And thou shalt rejoice (Deut. 16:14)…and thou shalt be altogether joyful (Deut. 16:15).
WHEN YE HAVE GATHERED IN THE FRUITS OF THE LAND. From the fields and vineyards.
YE SHALL KEEP THE FEAST. Tachoggu (ye shall keep the feast) comes from a double root.237 The reference is to the sacrifices.238

ON THE FIRST DAY SHALL BE A SOLEMN REST.239 Shabbaton (a solemn rest) is a noun. The words “shall be unto you” are missing.240 If shabbaton were an adjective, the word yom (day) would have a heh rather than a bet prefixed to it.241

40. AND YE SHALL TAKE. We shall believe in the words of the transmitters,242 for they do not contradict Scripture.243 The latter is so even though we find, they shall take to them every man a lamb (Ex. 12:3).244 They245 also transmitted to us the tradition that the fruit of goodly trees (v. 40) refers to the etrog (citron). In truth, there is no fruit of the tree more beautiful than the etrog. The rabbis interpreted the phrase etz hadar (goodly trees) to mean [a fruit] which dwells on its tree.246 They used the verse as a support for their tradition. I have explained the latter247 in my comments on to sell her unto a foreign people (Ex. 21:8).248 The Sadducees249 say that the sukkah shall be built from these plants.250 They brought proof from the Book of Ezra.251 However, they are blind of heart. Do they not see that the Book of Ezra252 does not at all mention willows of the book and fruit of the tree?253 It only mentions the leaves of five kinds of branches.254 The mention there of myrtle branches and branches of thick trees is no argument against our ancients.255 Similarly the kind called myrtle does not grow on a tall tree.256 There are thus two kinds,257 one growing on a tall tree and one on a low tree. The person who wanders from the land of Kedar258 to the land of Edom259 will know the secret of this commandment260 if he has eyes.261

43. THAT…IN BOOTHS. The Israelites made booths after they crossed the Sea of Reeds. They certainly did so in the wilderness of Sinai, where they dwelt close to a year. This is the manner of all the camps. This festival too262 is thus in memory of the Exodus263 from Egypt.264 Should someone ask why this commandment is to be observed in the month of Tishri,265 then one can answer: God’s cloud was over the camp during the day266 and the sun did not strike them.267 However, they started to make sukkot from the days of Tishri onwards because of the cold.268

44. UNTO THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. Not to all of the children of Israel, for Moses could not talk to all of them.269 Scripture similarly reads, Speak unto the children of Israel. (verses 2, 10, 24, 34). The verse unto all the congregation of the children of Israel (Lev. 19:2) is no argument to the contrary,270 for all of Israel is not called a congregation.271
chapter.ftnote: 1 According to I.E. verse 2 refers only to the Sabbath. That being the case, the verse should have read this is My appointed season. I.E. thus points out that My appointed seasons refers to all the Sabbaths (of the year. After stating that all the Sabbaths are God’s appointed seasons, Scripture goes on to speak of the weekly Sabbath in verse 3. For another interpretation see Rashi.
2 See I.E. on Ex. 16:23 (Vol. 2, p. 325). It is called “a sabbath day unto the Lord…because He rested from all His work on the seventh day.”
3 Hezekiah put off the observance of Passover for a month. According to I.E., Hezekiah’s actions were based on a ruling of the Bet Din. See Vol. 1, pp. 9,10.
4 And proclaimed that Passover be observed in the next month.
5 See Berakhot 10b.
6 See Sanhedrin 11a,b. The Bet Din had to consider many things in deciding whether or not to make a year a leap year.

7 San. 12a. However, the text there speaks of three years. Hence Krinsky suggests emending I.E. to read three years. Vat. Ebr. 38 omits the word two. It reads, “He established leap years back to back.”
8 The rules governing the establishment of the fixed Jewish calendar.
9 Which cannot occur under the rules of the fixed Jewish calendar.

10 The Mishnah, Rosh Ha-Shanah 2:9 records a controversy between Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Joshua as to when Yom Kippur fell in a certain year. If the rabbis of the Mishnah had used a fixed calendar there would be no place for this difference of opinion. The Mishnah (Ibid. 2:8) also reports an instance of two sets of witnesses contradicting themselves as to the position of the new moon. The latter shows that the month was established by actually seeing the new moon and not by calculation. See Weiser and Krinsky.
11 Of which there are seven in an 19 year cycle.
12 The solar year is about ten days longer than the lunar year. The extra month added during the leap year comes very close to closing this gap.
13 Who established the new moon visually, not by calculation.

14 Of the fixed calendar. What follows is a bit complicated. Hence a few words are in order. The Jewish months begin with the conjunction of the sun and moon. The calculation starts with the very first conjunction. That conjunction theoretically occurred at the end of five hours and 204 parts of an hour of the second day of the week (the rabbis divided an hour into 1,080 parts). The latter is known as molad tohu, or molad baharad, which is the Hebrew abbreviation for five hours and 204 parts of an hour of the second day of the week. How do we arrive at this calculation? Ibn Ezra explains that we do so by counting back a year from the conjunction which occurred on the day that Adam was born. It should be noted that that year, except for the five days preceding the birth of Adam, did not exist in reality. It was a theoretical year.
15 Adam was born on Friday. That day was the first day of the month of Tishri. According to the rabbis the moon was then in conjunction with the sun at the end of 14 hours of the day.
16 The days between the start of one simple lunar year to the next lunar year. See Maimonides, M.T., Laws of the Sanctification of the New Moon, 6:4,5.

17 There were five days preceding the birth of Adam. Those days belonged to the previous year. In that year the conjunction of the sun and the moon (had they existed) would have taken place at five hours plus 204 parts of on hour of the second day. The calculation is as follows. A lunar month consists of 29 days, 12 hours, 44 minutes, and 3 1/3 seconds. A year consists of 12 months. If we work backwards from the birth of Adam, who was born on a Friday, a day which we mark as the New Year, then the previous New Year which came 12 months earlier had to fall on a Monday. For 12 times 29 1/2 days and 44 minutes comes to 50 weeks plus four days and some five hours.
18 Adam was born on a Friday. The day of Adam’s birth started a new year.
19 To the year which started with the birth of Adam.
20 Of the “year” which preceded the birth of Adam.
21 The five days preceding the birth of Adam count as part of a separate year.
22 To the calculation of the calendar.

23 To the year preceding the birth of Adam and declare the year in which Adam was born a leap year. I.E.’s point is that our calendar is accurate. It is based on a 19-year cycle. The 3rd, 6th, 8th, 11th, 14th, 17th, and 19th year of the cycle are leap years. In those years we add a second month of Adar. According to current calculations the first leap year occurred a year after Adam was born (the third year from creation). If we begin the calendar two years before Adam was born, our calendar would have to be accordingly readjusted. However, we cannot do so, for there was nothing in existence two years before Adam’s birth. Hence the calendar must begin a year before the birth of Adam, not before.

24 A real year and a half following the birth of Adam, for that was the “third” year from creation. The three years are calculated as follows. The “year” of tohu (or yetizrah, creation), the year in which Adam was born (molad adam), and a half of the following year.

25 “The moment that the moon would have the same longitude as the sun, if both moved uniformly” (W.M. Feldman, Rabbinical Mathematics and Astronomy, p. 123). Also see Maimonides, M.T., Laws of the Sanctification of the New Moon, 6:1. The length of a junction varies. Its average time is 29 days, 12 hours, 44 minutes, and 3 and 1/3 seconds. The average movement (or conjunction) stands in contrast to the true conjunction of the sun and moon.
26 The average conjunction of the moon and sun.
27 Rosh Ha-Shanah 25a.
28 In the post-calendar period.
29 In the post-calendar period the month is established by calculation, not by the actual sighting of the new moon.

30 Literally, edge of the east. During the Middle Ages, before the Western Hemisphere was discovered, the Jews, in common with others, believed half of the globe to be covered by water (the Great Ocean) and the other half to be dry and habitable. Thus R. Abraham bar Chiya of the 11th century begins his work on the Jewish Calendar by stating that “the earth is round like a sphere. The water of the Great Ocean covers half of it, which is uninhabitable, the other half is dry and habitable” (W.M. Feldman, Rabbinical Mathematics and Astronomy, p. 104).
31 That is, to the actual sighting of the new moon at the edge of the East or the West of the world.
32 Which determines the start of the new year.
33 That the new moon is not contingent on the actual sighting of the new moon at the edge of the East or the West of the world.
34 The new moon begins when it is calculated that the moon would be in conjunction with the sun over Jerusalem if both moved uniformly.
35 If the new moon were based on sighting the moon, then the month would be established when the moon was actually seen.
36 On an ordinary year, that is, not a leap year.
37 By those who established the calendar.

38 Hebrew, dechiyot. “There are five separate occasions which necessitate the postponement of New Year’s day by one or even two days,” Feldman, op. cit, p. 191. For these dechiyot, see Maimonides, M.T., Laws of the Sanctification of the New Moon, Chap. 7. Also see Feldman, pp. 191-194.
39 In the month of Tishri.

40 Another example of a postponement. This postponement is called dechiyat yach (yod chet = 18), i.e., the 18th hour. “If the molad of Tishri occurs at or past noon (i.e., the 18th hour of any day. Noon is the 18th hour of a day which consists of 12 hours of daylight and 12 hours of night. Such a day begins at 6:00 P.M. New Year (Rosh Ha-Shanah) is postponed to the following day. Such a molad is called an Old Molad (molad zaken) because on the day of the new month, the moon is already old” (Feldman, pp. 191,192).
41 Of the new month.
42 The true conjunction of the sun and the moon.
43 The mean conjunction.
44 The printed editions read 204 parts. However, the commentaries point out that this is a scribal error.

46 This postponement is called dechiyat gatrad (gimel-tet, resh-dalet), which stands for three days, nine hours, 204 parts.

49 Whether the Bet Din in Jerusalem declared the new month on the 30th or 31st day from the start of the previous month. This was in the time before the fixed calendar.

51 They fast an extra day in vain. I.E. will point out that one should follow Rabbinic law with regard to the calendar. Thus if the rabbis say that one does not have to fast for two days to ensure that one fasts on the true Yom Kippur, it is not necessary to do so. See I.E., Sefer Ha-Ibbur, pp. 11,12.
52 Of Tishri.

53 For in this instance the first day of the month falls two days after the birth of the new moon. The point is that those who fast for two days do so because they want to be certain that they observed Yom Kippur on the real astronomical day. However, in a year when the birth of the new moon of the month of Tishri in an ordinary year occurs at nine hours and 204 parts of the third day, the new month should begin on Tuesday, not Thursday as in the intercalated calendar. However, since these people want to be certain that they celebrate Yom Kippur ten days from the start of the “real” New Year they should fast on what is the 8th day of the month according to the intercalated calendar.
54 According to those who fast two days on Yom Kippur because of doubt.
55 Literally, why should we pervert the calculation of our year?

56 The start of the new year is postponed when the birth of the new moon in the month of Tishri occurs at nine hours and 204 parts of an hour on Tuesday so that there not be a difference of six days between that year and the next. See Maimonides, Hilchot Kiddush Ha-Chodesh 7:4. Those who fast for two days believe that our festivals should be based on astronomical reality. If that is the case, then all the rules of establishing the calendar should be discarded.
57 They would have to fast on what is the eighth day of the month according to our calculation in a year when the birth of the new moon occurs at nine hours and 204 parts of the third day.
58 If they established the month by the actual sighting of the new moon and not only by calculating the birth of the new moon.

85 Josh. 5 describes Israel’s first Passover in the Land of Israel. Josh. 5:11 relates: And they did eat of the produce of the land on the morrow after the passover, unleavened cakes and parched corn, in the selfsame day. This scholar believed that the term “passover” in Josh. 5:11 refers to the 15th of Nisan. Hence the morrow after the passover refers to the 16th. This scholar also assumed that the unleavened cakes and parched corn came from the new produce. Now, since eating of new produce is forbidden till the omer is offered, and Scripture tells us, And they did eat of the produce of the land, we must assume that the eating of the new grain was preceded by the offering of the omer. We thus see that the omer is brought on the 16th of Nisan. Furthermore, Josh. 5:11 shows that on the morrow after the sabbath means on the morrow following the first day of the festival.

86 This is metaphorical. That is, he trapped himself. See Prov. 7:23, As a bird hasteneth to the snare–And knoweth not that it is at the cost of his life. The “proof” offered by this scholar does not prove that which he intended. In fact, the Karaites or Sadducees can, as we shall see below, use his interpretation for their own purposes.
87 Of Nisan.

88 Day of Nisan. I.E.’s point is that in Scripture the term Passover is limited to the 14th of Nisan when the Passover sacrifice was offered. The seven days following are referred to as the Festival of Unleavened Bread (chag ha-matzot). Thus if we interpret Joshua 5:11 as alluding to the bringing of the omer, then we have to assume that the omer was brought on the 15th of Nisan, which we today call the first day of Passover. This is not in keeping with Rabbinic tradition. On the contrary, it supports the Karaites, for they believe that the morrow after the sabbath in Leviticus 23:16 refers to the first Sunday following the start of Passover. In other words, the Karaites say that in the year that Israel celebrated the first Passover in Canaan, the 15th of Nisan fell on a Sunday and Israel therefore offered the omer on that day.

90 Hence Josh. 5:11 cannot refer to the new grain.

91 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon interprets And they did eat of the produce of the land on the morrow after the passover, unleavened cakes and parched corn as follows: And they did eat of the produce of the land on the morrow after the Passover of the Lord, i.e., the morrow following the 15th day.

92 While the Passover of Israel is on the 14th. The Passover of the Lord falls on the 15th, for that is when God killed the first-born of Egypt. The Passover of Israel falls on the 14th because that is the day that Israel sacrifices the paschal lamb.
93 Of Nisan.
94 The paschal lamb.

I.E.’s point is that Josh. 5:11 does not state, And they did eat of the produce of the land on the morrow after the passover, unleavened cakes and parched corn, to inform us that they waved the omer and then ate matzot and grain from the new produce. It rather tells us, And they did eat of the produce of the land on the morrow after the passover, unleavened cakes and parched corn, because the manna ceased.

121 A Karaite scholar.

124 One of the days of Passover. In other words, the omer is waved on the first day of the Passover holiday that follows a Sabbath.
125 Joshua.

126 The new moons are not listed among the festivals. We thus see that a day on which an additional offering is brought is not necessarily a festival. The same should apply to the day that the omer is waved. In other words, the fact that the Torah does not specify the day of the omer waving as a festival does not mean that it falls on the festival of Passover. Hence if we reject the Rabbinic tradition and take the word Sabbath literally, we do not know from which Sabbath to start the count of seven weeks.
127 On the Festival of Unleavened Bread.
128 According to Joshua, Scripture should have stated: After this manner ye shall offer daily, for seven days aside from the offering which accompanies the waving of the omer.

132 In the verse preceding verse 19.
