144 With regard to the observance of the omer in all the other years.
145 Deut. 16:9 speaks of weeks, not of Sabbaths, for the count does not start from the morrow after the Sabbath.
146 Of the seven weeks that commence with the waving of the omer and conclude with shavu’ot.
147 Sunday. In other words, there is no proof that the beginning of the seven weeks that commence with the waving of the omer and conclude with shavu’ot starts on a Sunday as the Karaites maintain.
148 A woman who gives birth to a baby girl.

149 Lev. 12:5 shows that the term week does not apply only to a week which starts on Sunday and concludes on Saturday, for the women who deliver start counting their two weeks from the time of delivery. The same is true of the week which begins when the omer is counted. It does not start on a Sunday.

150 Regarding the festival of Shavu’ot. The secret is what follows: All the festivals are contingent on a specific day of the month. Scripture does not give a specific date of the month for the festival of shavu’ot (so Weiser). The question arises, what sort of secret is this? This is obvious. It is possible that I.E. is hinting that the establishment of the observance of Shavu’ot 50 days from the second day of Passover is not of Pentateuchal origin. The Torah states that the counting of the seven weeks starts from the day of putting the sickle to the corn. It does not date when the counting is to begin. See Judah Ha-Levi, The Book of Kuzari 3:41, “…The Synhedrion and all the sages found that this period [of 50 days] was fixed with the intention to create an interval of fifty days between ‘the first fruits of harvest of the barley and the harvest of wheat,’ and to observe ‘seven weeks,’ which are seven complete Sabbaths.’ The first day of the week [the morrow after the Sabbath] is only mentioned for argument’s sake in the following manner: should the day of putting ‘the sickle to the corn’ be on a Sunday, you count till Sunday…The date of putting of the sickle from which we count is left for us to fix” (The Book of Kuzari, translated by H. Hirschfeld, N.Y., 1946, p. 153).
151 It does not state on which day of the month Shavu’ot falls.
152 That is, so that God will accept it from you.
153 In other words, li-retzonkhem means willingly.

154 Along with the sheaf. This seems to contradict what came before, for up to now li-retzonkhem was interpreted as meaning to be accepted for you. Filwarg suggests emending “the meaning of the aforementioned is not that you shall wave it willingly.” Meijler suggests the following: However, the meaning of the aforementioned is that you shall wave it willingly; in other words, our sentence introduces a new interpretation.
155 According to Meijler it means you shall offer a he-lamb willingly so that you will be accepted.
156 The Karaites.
157 Literally, of his first year.
158 Which summarizes the number of sacrifices offered when the altar was dedicated.
159 We thus see that Scripture refers to the same lamb by either phrase. There is thus no difference between them; they mean the same.
160 That when Scripture states, And ye shall eat neither bread…it refers to bread from the new grain.
161 If our verse refers to bread baked from grain from the previous year, it would not command that unleavened bread be eaten along with the Passover sacrifice.
162 That requires us to count the days between the waving of the omer and Shavu’ot.

163 Hebrew, ki-shenot. Some editions read bi-shenot. According to this reading, “the counting of days only applies in the days of the Jubilee.” In other words, the omer is not counted when the Jubilee is not observed.

164 Forty-nine years (seven weeks of years) are counted and the 50th year declared as the year of Jubilee. Similarly, seven weeks would be counted from the offering of the omer and the 50th day declared as the festival of Shavu’ot.
165 In other words, the Sabbath preceding the day on which the omer is waved is not to be considered in the count.

166 The 50th day is in the count; i.e., Shavu’ot does not fall on the 49th day, but on the 50th day. In other words, when the Torah gives a count of days it does not mean up to the last day of the count, it means including the last day mentioned.

167 When the Torah tell us to count 50 days and bring an offering, it does not mean to count 50 full days and bring the offering on the 51st day. Similarly, with circumcision, which the Torah requires to be performed on the eighth day from birth. One does not wait till the eighth day is concluded and then perform the rite of circumcision. The ritual is to be performed on the eighth day (Motot). According to Filwarg, I.E.’s point is that the Torah tells us to count seven weeks and to offer the sacrifice on the 50th day. Similarly, when Scripture requires seven days to pass (as in the case of one experiencing an issue, or a Nazirite who defiled himself) and then to offer a sacrifice, it means count seven days and offer the sacrifice on the eighth day.
168 Whether the two loaves must brought only from grain of the Land of Israel or if it can be brought from grain grown outside of the Land of Israel (Krinsky).
169 The date that the two loaves are to be waved.
170 The two wave-loaves and the peace offering lambs are to be eaten by the kohen.

171 In the first year of Israel’s entering the Land of Israel. There is a discrepancy between our Torah portion and Num. 28:27. Our chapter states that one bullock and two rams are to be offered on Shavu’ot. Num. 28:27 states that two bullocks and one ram are to be offered. According to I.E. our Torah portion refers to the order of sacrifices to be offered by Israel after first entering the Land of Israel, and Numbers, to the years that followed.
172 It was the first Shavu’ot in Israel’s first year in the Land of Israel.
173 On Shavu’ot.
174 In accordance with Lev. 23:18.
175 In accordance with Num. 28:27.
176 In other words, Lev. 23:18 and Num. 28:27 do not contradict. They are options.
177 Where the Torah offers an option as to how a commandment should be observed.

178 According to I.E. one bullock and two rams were offered along with the two loaves on Shavu’ot, while two bullocks and one ram were offered on Shavu’ot as burnt offerings. Thus there is no discrepancy between Leviticus and Numbers. See I.E. on Num. 28:26 and the notes thereto (Vol. 4, p. 235), “The two wave-loaves were the main offerings. The seven lambs, one young bullock, two rams (Lev. 23:18)…were brought along with it. The burnt offerings (two bullocks and one ram) in our chapter (Num. 28:26) refer to the obligatory sacrifice of the festival day.”
179 An animal for meat.
180 I.E.’s term for the Karaites. The Karaites claim that it is prohibited to slaughter an animal on a festival.
181 The same is stated in Lev. 19:9.
183 Which it does not do with regard to the festival of Shavu’ot.
184 The laws dealing with the festival of Rosh Ha-Shanah opens with And the Lord spoke unto Moses saying. The preceding festival of Shavu’ot does not have this introduction. Hence I.E.’s comments.
185 Hence it does not open with And the Lord spoke unto Moses saying.
186 Yom Kippur.
188 The omer.
189 Scripture lists it first. Or it is first in the agricultural year.
190 Shavu’ot.
191 Sukkot.
192 In our Torah portion.
194 Not to trumpets, for otherwise Scripture would have referred to the new moon as a yom tru’ah, or Scripture would have explicitly stated that trumpets be sounded on Rosh Ha-Shanah.
195 The Torah commands that a shofar tru’ah be sounded on Yom Kippur of the Jubilee year. See Lev. 25:9.
196 See Rosh Ha-Shanah 16a.
197 The first day of the month.
198 The first month. The point is just as the first day of the month is special, so is the first month.
199 The seventh day of the month marks a quarter of the month. That day has astrological significance.
200 I.E. points out that the days on which the festivals fall have astronomical significance.
201 When Passover falls.
202 The 15th day of the month marks half a month.
203 Of Passover.
204 Of the month.
205 Those who for certain stated reasons could not observe it in the first month slaughtered the paschal lamb on the 14th day of the second month and ate it on the eve of the 15th. See Num. 8:6-12.
206 The true Passover.

207 Those who could not observe the first Passover offer the Passover sacrifices on this day. I.E’s point is that the second Passover, like the first, is observed in the middle of the month which he believed had astronomical significance.
208 The substitute or second Passover is then observed (Weiser).

209 It falls at the time of the new moon, it falls on the first day of the first quarter of the month, and it is the day on which the world was created. That day is thus more significant than the other days mentioned (Weiser).
210 Ezra told the people to eat and enjoy themselves on Rosh Ha-Shanah. See Neh. 8:2-10. I.E. considered Ezra and Nehemiah as one book.
211 The moon.

212 In a propitious heavenly conjunction. Some interpret I.E. as referring to the end of the first third of the month. If we divide the month into three parts then the moon is most powerful on the 10th day of the month, for on the 20th it is waning and at the 30th it is invisible. Others say that the moon and sun are then in Saturn’s “house,” which is good for the moon and unfavorable for the sun.
213 Both fall in the middle of the month.
214 Of why the festivals fall on certain days.

215 Why the Sabbath falls on the seventh day. According to I.E. the Sabbath falls on the seventh day because the seventh day has astrological significance. See I.E. on Lev. 13:2 and Gen. 8:5 (Vol. 1, p. 114).
216 This verse refers to Rosh Ha-Shanah. We thus see that a day of holy convocation is a joyful day.
217 This verse occurred on Rosh Ha-Shanah. However (Howbeit), Yom Kippur does not have these characteristics. I.E. considered Ezra and Nehemia one book.
218 See I.E. on Lev. 16:29.
219 It is a day of atonement for Israel alone.
220 The use of the pu’al te’unneh (be afflicted).
221 Be afflicted implies that one is forced to fast.

222 I am not permitted to explain. According to I.E. “cut off” means death either by execution or by the hand of God (see I.E. on Lev. 18:29). In Ps. 1:6 he explains that “destruction” refers to the obliteration of the soul following death. “I cannot explain” might mean that I.E. cannot explain how the soul is destroyed.
223 The prohibition to do work on Yom Kippur was previously stated in verse 28.
224 See I.E.’s comment on verse 3 and the notes thereto.

225 The Torah tells us that on Passover and Sukkot the Jews are to bring an offering made by fire. However, there is a difference in the sacrifices offered on Passover and Sukkot. Thus an offering made by fire does not refer to a specific sacrifice.
226 On the second day of Passsover. See I.E. on Deut. 16:7 (Vol. 5, p. 112).
227 There was thus no gathering of all Israel on the seventh day of Passover. Yet the Torah refers to this day as an atzeret.
228 Or held back. From the root ayin, tzadi, resh.
229 The Israelite shall hold himself back from doing work.
230 Ye shall do no manner of servile work explains the term atzeret.
231 Deut. 16:8 reads: “And on the seventh day [of Passover] shall be an azeret…thou shall do no work therein.”
232 That is, Scripture now explains.
233 The festival offerings.
234 Hence our verse explains that the term burnt offering refers to an offering made by fire.
235 See Deut. 16:17.
236 Which people were wont to bring when they came to God’s house on the festivals.
237 Its root is chet, gimel, gimel.
238 The peace offerings.
239 Literally, On the first day a solemn rest.
240 In other words, On the first day a solemn rest should be read as if written: On the first day shall be a solemn rest unto you.
241 Our verse reads, be yom ha-rishon shabbaton (on the first day…a solemn rest). If shabbaton were an adjective, then our verse would read ha-yom ha-rishon shabbaton (the first day a solemn rest).
242 The transmitters of tradition, the Talmudic sages.
243 The rabbis of the Talmud teach that the four types of plants mentioned in our verse are to be actually taken by hand.
244 Here the word “take” does not mean one has to ritually take the animal in one’s hand. Or here the word take means buy. See Mekhilta on Ex. 12:3.
245 The transmitters of tradition.

246 It doesn’t fall off the tree. The Talmud (Sukkah 33a) connects the word hadar (goodly) to the word dar (dwells). It interprets our verse as meaning a fruit which dwells ((or remains) on its tree from year to year.
247 The use of Biblical verses as supports.
249 The Karaites.
250 The plants mentioned in our verse.
251 Neh. 8:15 tells us that the Israelites made sukkot out of olive branches, branches of wild olive, myrtle branches, palm branches, and branches of thick trees.
252 That is, Neh. 8:15.
253 That is, fruit of a goodly tree.
254 Olive branches, branches of wild olive, myrtle branches, palm branches, and branches of thick trees.

255 The fact that myrtle branches and branches of thick trees were used in the days of Ezra and Nehemiah to build a sukkah does not disprove the Rabbinic tradition that these plants are to be ritually taken in the hand on sukkot.

256 The Karaites claim the “boughs of thick trees” refers to a plant that grows on tall trees. According to the rabbis the “boughs of thick trees” refers to the myrtle. The latter does not grow on a tall tree.

257 Branches of thick trees (ale etz avot) (Neh. 8:15) and boughs of thick trees (anaf etz avot) are not the exact same plant. The first-mentioned plant grows on a tall tree and the latter on a low tree. There is thus no proof from Neh. 8:15 that myrtles are to be employed in building the sukkah.
258 A dry land. Kedar was one of the sons of Ishmael (Gen. 25:13). Kedar in I.E. usually refers to Moslems. The descendants of Ishmael dwelt between Egypt and Assyria. The latter area is semi-dry.
259 The Land of the Christians, i.e., Europe.
260 The commandment of taking the four kinds mentioned in verse 40.

261 The land of Israel, which is located in the Middle East, is a semi-dry land and required special prayers for rain. The “four kinds” serve to induce rainfall. See Ta’anit 2:2. So Weiser. For other interpretations see Motot, Krinsky, and Filwarg.
262 Like Passover.
263 As noted in verse 43.
264 Even though it is not observed in the month of Nisan.
265 The month Israel left Egypt.
266 When they left Egypt.
267 They thus had no need of booths.
268 I.E.’s point is that Israel had no need of booths for shelter until the cold weather set in. The latter occurred in Tishri. Hence booths are constructed in Tishri.
269 He spoke to the heads of the people.
270 It does not teach that Moses spoke to all of Israel.
271 The term congregation (edah) refers to the heads of the people who gathered (no’adu) to hear the words of Moses.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 24
chapter.p: [2. PURE OLIVE OIL.] The reason Scripture now mentions the section1 dealing with the pure olive oil is that the Torah earlier recorded the fire offering of each festival2 and now has to mention the show bread.3 The menorah stood opposite the table.4

[4. UPON THE PURE CANDLESTICK.] Scripture in our section adds upon the pure candlestick.5 The latter refers to the known candlestick,6 which was constructed by Betzalel7 and was completely made of gold.8 It does not refer to any other candlestick. [As to the menorah], which was made of iron,9 it was done so in time of need10 by the word of the prophets.11
5. AND THOU SHALT TAKE FINE FLOUR. By command.12 Similarly, and bake…thereof.13 Ve-afita (and shalt bake) is ultimately accented. It is irregular.14

[6.] IN TWO ROWS. Corresponding to the number of the tribes.15 This is similar to the secret of the ephod and the breastplate.16 The17 two tenth parts (v. 5) corresponded to the arrangement of the two rows.18

UPON THE PURE TABLE. In contrast to the other tables that were there. This table alone was covered with gold and its crown was of gold.19 It was the frankincense that was with the bread that served as an offering made by fire unto the Lord. The bread was for the kohen. It is possible that Scripture mentioned this section20 because there is an obligation on Israel to provide the festival burnt offerings, the oil, and the bread, which was always on the altar.
9. FOR AARON AND HIS SONS. His entire household.
10. AND THE SON OF AN ISRAELITISH WOMAN…WENT OUT. From his tent. Compare, came out, and stood at the door of their tents (Num. 16:27).
WHOSE FATHER WAS AN EGYPTIAN. Who converted to Judaism.21

AND A MAN OF ISRAEL. Ve-ish ha-yisra’eli (and a man of Israel) is similar to le-ish he-ashir (unto the rich man) (II Sam. 12:4) and to et yom ha-shevi’iy (the seventh day) (Gen. 2:3).22 We do not know why this section23 was connected to that which comes before it. Perhaps the blasphemer spoke improperly with regard to the bread, the oil, and the sacrifices.

11. BLASPHEMED. Some say that the meaning of va-yikkov (blasphemed) is enunciated. Compare, Which the mouth of the Lord shall mark out (yikkavennu) (Is. 62:2) and that are pointed out (nikkevu) by name (Num. 1:17). Others say that va-yikkov is similar to ekkov (I curse) in How shall I curse (Num. 23:8). However, I believe that the first interpretation is correct.24
12. IN WARD.25 In a known place in the camp.26
14. AND LET ALL THAT HEARD. For he was stoned because of their testimony.
16. ALL THE CONGREGATION. The reference is to the magnates of the land who are the great ones of Israel.27
Some say that Whosoever curseth his God (v. 15) means whosoever curseth his God in secret.28

The correct interpretation is as follows. The term Elohim (god) is an adjective. The angels are called elohim.29 So are the judges.30 Who can know what is in the mind of the one who curses? However, if he enunciates the glorious name of God, which stands by itself and is not an adjective and is not intertwined with any noun, [he shall be stoned]. Its meaning is,31 when one curses and enunciates the Name he shall be put to death if he enunciates the Name as the son of the Egyptian did.32 The Name33 is not mentioned34 out of respect for God. Scripture reads, as well the stranger, as the home-born…shall be put to death. It is possible that the ones who quarreled (v. 10) struck each other. This section35 was therefore written.36 It37 had previously been mentioned. However, our chapter adds, as well for the stranger, as for the home-born (v. 22).
[17. AND HE THAT SMITETH.] Scripture begins38 with and he that smiteth any man mortally.39 He is not participating in war and deliberately smites any man, be that man a stranger or a native
18. AND HE THAT SMITETH A BEAST MORTALLY SHALL MAKE IT GOOD. Note, the phrase life for life,40 serves two verses.41

19. SO SHALL IT BE DONE TO HIM. Samson said, so have I done unto them (Jud. 15:11).42 The Gaon43 brought proof from logic that breach for breach (v. 20) cannot be taken literally. The first wound was made unintentionally. How can we justify making a similar wound?44 If the wound is in a vital area, the person will die. The same applies to the eye. How are we to do the same to one who injured his neighbor by causing him to suffer the loss of a third of the sight of an eye?45 The words of tradition are thus true.46 Scripture is to be understood as follows. Ransom money is to be paid in all of these cases. It is fitting to remove his eye if he does not ransom it.47 Should one argue against us and say, what happens if the injurer is poor? Then we answer, Scripture speaks about the majority of cases.48 It is possible for the poor to become rich.49 This also answers those who argue, what shall we do in instances when the injurer of the eye is blind?50

20. SO SHALL IT BE RENDERED UNTO HIM.51 There are instances where the bet has the meaning of on.52 Compare, the beast that I rode upon (bah) (Neh. 2:12). There are many such instances. On the other hand, its meaning might be, so shall it be rendered unto him if he does not pay ransom.53

[21. AND HE THAT KILLETH A BEAST.] Scripture repeats And he that killeth a beast…54 because it wants to mention the stranger, for when Scripture speaks of maiming (v. 19) it speaks of an Israelite, for the Torah clearly says,55 his neighbor. However, there is one law for both the stranger and the native regarding he that kills a person and he that kills a beast.

I have previously informed you that Scripture is being brief when two cafs come together.56 Scripture also chooses to employ brevity when it does not add “and he dies” to u-makkeh adam57 (and he that killeth a man), for it is known that the culprit is not executed unless the one who is struck dies.

Another interpretation for the repetition58 is that Scripture earlier mentions “mortally” (v. 17).59 The latter refers to a blow struck in a vital area. Scripture then lays down60 the following general law: A person who kills shall be put to death whether the blow was struck in a vital area or in a non-vital area. The word nefesh (mortal) is thus not mentioned.61
[22. YOUR GOD.] The God of the native and the God of the stranger.
23. AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL DID. They did from this day and onward to one who injures his neighbor, in accordance with this law.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Verses 1-4.
2 In the previous chapter.
3 The show bread was similar to the offerings. Hence Scripture mentions the show bread after listing the festival offerings.
4 Of the showbread. See Ex. 40:24.
5 After stating that Aaron shall light the lamp (v. 2), Scripture adds that Aaron shall light it upon the pure candlestick.
6 Known from earlier references in Scripture. See Ex. 25:31-40.
8 Ibid.
9 According to the Talmud the menorah used by the Hasmoneans in the Chanukkah period was made of iron. See Avodah Zarah 43a.
10 It was an emergency, or the gold menorah was defiled and they did not have the means to make a menorah out of gold.
11 An oral tradition handed down from the later prophets (Weiser), for there were no prophets in the Maccabean period.
12 Moses shall command that fine flour be taken.
13 The meaning of and bake…thereof is and bake…thereof by command.

14 Words in the perfect whose roots end in a heh and have a conversive vav prefixed to them maintain their penultimate accent. However, ve-afita (and shalt bake) is ultimately accented. Hence it is irregular.
15 The 12 loaves which were arranged in two rows corresponded to the 12 tribes of Israel.
16 The names of the 12 tribes of Israel were inscribed on the ephod and the breastplate.
17 So Filwarg. The text reads “or.” “Or” in this context is difficult. Filwarg emends to “the.” Weiser suggests emending to “perhaps.”

18 I.E. believes that there is a correspondence between the contents of each one of the loaves and the arrangement of all of the loaves. Thus each of the loaves consisted of “two” tenth parts. Each one of the two tenth parts corresponds to the “two” rows into which all the loaves were divided.
20 Verses 5-9.
21 Our verse literally reads, “whose father was an Egyptian in the camp of Israel.” According to I.E. the Egyptian was living among Israel because he was a convert

22 When an adjective has a heh prefixed to it, the noun which it modifies also has a heh prefixed to it. I.E. points out that there are instances in Scripture where the above is not followed, viz., our verse, II Sam. 12:4, and Gen 2:3. See I.E. on Gen 1:31 (Vol. 1, p. 47).
23 Verses 10-12.

24 Our verse reads va-yikkov et ha-shem va-yekkalel (and blasphemed the Name and cursed). If va-yikkov means “and cursed,” then our verse is repetitious. Hence it appears that our verse should be interpreted as, and enunciated the Name of God and cursed it.
25 Literally, in the ward (ba-mishmar).
26 Hence the use of the direct object (ba).
27 See I.E. on Lev. 23:44.
28 For our verse does not specify the punishment of the one who curses God.
29 See I.E. on Gen. 1:1 (Vol. 1, p. 26).
30 Ibid.
31 The meaning of Whosoever curseth his God.
32 In other words, verses 15 and 16 are connected to each other.
33 God’s name.
34 In verse 17.
35 Verses 17-22.
36 At this point. In other words, the laws dealing with personal injuries follow the laws of the men who quarreled because the latter came to blows.
37 The section about the laws dealing with personal injuries. See Ex. 21:12-27.
38 The laws dealing with personal injury.
39 Shall be put to death.
40 Which concludes verse 18.
41 Verses 17 and 18. I.E. reads verse 17 as follows: And he that smiteth any man mortally shall surely be put to death, life for life.

42 The full clause reads, As they did unto me, so have I done unto them. The latter is not to be taken literally, for Samson did not repay his enemies exactly tit for tat. We thus see that as he hath done, so shall it be done to him is not necessarily to be taken literally. It rather means punishment is to be inflicted.
43 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.

44 The Torah does not distinguish (except for murder) between one who harms his neighbor intentionally and one who harms him unintentionally. This being the case, if someone wounded his neighbor unintentionally, how can we justify making a similar wound in him? It should be noted that Rabbi Saadiah Gaon held that the Torah does not contain laws that contradict reason.
45 How can we be sure that we are only removing a third of the eye’s vision of the one guilty of doing the same to his neighbor?
46 That as he hath done, so shall it be done to him is not to be taken literally. It rather means that he shall make commensurate compensation.
47 According to I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 21:24 the eye of the one who blinds his neighbor is removed if he refuses to pay ransom.
48 Most people are not poor.
49 That is, furthermore it is possible for the poor to become rich. In other words, the poor will pay when they eventually have the means to do so.

50 And the law of an eye for an eye cannot be applied literally. I.E. in his commentary on Ex. 21:24 (Vol. 2, p. 476) quotes Saadiah Gaon as arguing that an eye for an eye cannot be taken literally, for what shall we do in instances when the injurer is blind? I.E. here counters that argument by saying that Scripture speaks of what is usual, and in cases where a blind person blinds someone the penalty of an eye for an eye is not applicable.
51 Hebrew, bo (literally in him). Hence I.E.’s comment.
52 In other words, bo means unto him. I.E. renders our clause, “so shall it be rendered upon him,” i.e., a penalty shall be placed upon him.
53 In this case bo means unto him.

ftnote.italic: And he that killeth a man…

chapter.ftnote: 55 In verse 19.

56 That is, when two words with a kaf prefix follow each other. Our verse reads ka-ger ka-ezrach (as well for the stranger, as for the home-born). According to I.E. ka-ger ka-ezrach is short for ha-ger ke-ezrach, ve-ha’ezrach ka-ger (the stranger is like the home-born and the home-born is like the stranger). See I.E. on Gen. 44:18 (Vol. 1, p. 396).
57 Literally, and he that strikes a man.
58 Why verse 21 repeats verses 17 and 18.
59 Hebrew, nefesh.
60 In our verse.
61 In our verse.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 25
chapter.p: 1. IN MOUNT SINAI. There is no chronological order in the Torah.1 This section2 precedes, And the Lord called (Lev. 1:1) and all the sections that follow it, for the words recorded in our section were told to Moses on Mount Sinai.3 Moses now4 made the covenant recorded in the Torah portion Now these are the ordinances (Ex. 21:1).5 Moses inserted this portion6 at this point to place in proximity the conditions under which the Israelites could dwell in the land.7 He said that the land would spit out the Israelites if they violated the laws of prohibited sexual relations.8 He said a similar thing in the Torah portion If ye walk in My statutes (Lev. 26:3) with regard to the Sabbaths of the land. Moses first mentions the Sabbaths.9

2. THEN SHALL THE LAND KEEP A SABBATH UNTO THE LORD. There is a commandment upon the Israelite not to allow a stranger to sow in the Sabbatical year.10 This is similar to the commandment that we not allow a stranger to do work on the Sabbath.11 Scripture commands this, for the stranger is in our power.12
A sabbath unto the Lord is similar in meaning to the Sabbath day.13 The secret of the days of the world is alluded to in this place.14
3. THE PRODUCE THEREOF. Of the land mentioned in the first verse.
4. A SABBATH OF SOLEMN REST. I previously explained the meaning of shabbat shabbaton (a Sabbath of solemn rest).15

5. THAT WHICH GROWETH OF ITSELF. It is known that the word safi’ach (that which groweth of itself) is connected to the word sefacheni (put me)16 in Put me, I pray thee (I Sam. 3:36).17 It is also known that the word nezirekha (undressed vine) is related to the word nazir (nazirite).18
A YEAR OF SOLEMN REST. Its meaning is, because it is a year of solemn rest for the land; that is, the land is not in your possession in this year.

6. AND THE SABBATH-PRODUCE…SHALL BE FOR YOU. Sabbath-produce refers to all that the land brought out by itself. The meaning of lakhem (for you) is, for everyone.19 The meaning of lekha (for thee) is that the owner of the field is permitted to eat of that which grows of itself.20
7. AND FOR THY CATTLE. Which are under your control.
AND FOR THE BEASTS. Which are not under your control.

9. THEN SHALT THOU MAKE PROCLAMATION WITH THE BLAST OF THE HORN. There is a difference of opinion as to whether the world was created in Nisan or in Tishri.21 There is no need to dwell on this, for the transmitters of the law ordained that we are to say in the Rosh Ha-Shanah prayer which they established for us, “This day marks the beginning of Your works, it is a memorial of the first day.”22 We also read in Scripture that the shofar is to be sounded in the Jubilee year in the month of Tishri at the beginning of the year.23 Furthermore,24 the Torah, in the portion commanding the people to gather to hear the Torah read states that the Torah is to be read on the festival of Sukkot.25 Scripture writes, that they may hear, and that they may learn (Deut. 31:12).26 It is not possible for this27 to take place after half a year has passed.28 Furthermore,29 Scripture states, and the feast of ingathering, at the end of the year (Ex. 23:16). Similarly, and the feast of the ingathering at the turn of the year (Ex. 34:22).30 The faithful proof is the Sabbatical year, regarding which it is written, ye shall not sow (v. 11). They start sowing in the month of Marcheshvan in the Land of Israel. If the beginning of the year started in Nisan, then they would not harvest that which they sowed in the sixth year31 and they would not sow,32 for it is the Sabbatical year. Since they will not harvest33 what they planted in the sixth year, they will not sow twice.34 However, Scripture states that they should not sow in the seventh year alone.35

Judah Ha-Parsi36 said that Israel employed a solar calendar.37 Now if this were so [then we do not know the exact time that a year begins] for, note, Moses did not explain the length of a complete year and so far the astronomers are unable to bring the length of a solar year to light. For example, the wise men of India add a fifth of an hour to the quarter of the day.38 Ptolemy and his friends say that 1/300 of the day is missing.39 This is close to that of the intercalated calendar. Those who came after him said one part of 106.40 Others said 110.41 Still others said 130.42 There are those who say 180.43 For there are those who calculate the year when the sun concludes a cycle around the constellations from a visible point.44 Others calculate it from a point on the sphere which inclines to the right and the left.45 We need tradition.46 Furthermore, the meaning of the word chodesh (month) contradicts the Persian.47 The Sadducees48 say that the Jewish religion is based on a lunar year.

Note, there is no year at all to the moon.49 However, as the sun has no months, the calculators50 sought51 a number of months close to that of a solar year.52 They found them to be 12.53 The calculators54 sought a number of days for the month55 that would be close to the number of days into which a lunar month is divided. Our months are therefore lunar months and our years return56 at the end of a solar year.57 Our sages therefore transmitted to us a law given to Moses from Sinai that the Bet Din always made seven leap years in every cycle58 even though they used to establish every month by sighting the moon.59 The secret of the cycle60 is known from the science of the stars.61
The meaning of shall ye make proclamation is that they should sound the shofar in all the roads.62
10. AND YE SHALL HALLOW THE FIFTIETH YEAR. All the inhabitants with regard to working the land.63

LIBERTY. The meaning of the word deror is known. It means liberty. As the flying swallow (deror) (Prov. 26:2) refers to a small bird that produces music when it is free.64 However, if it is taken captive it refuses to eat and starves to death.

JUBILEE. The word yovel (Jubilee) means sent.65 The sages, of blessed memory, said that the meaning of yovel is a lamb. Shoferot ha-yovelim (rams’ horns) (Josh. 6:4) is proof of the latter. The year66 is called by the name of the shofar.67
[BE UNTO YOU.] To the Israelites alone.
AND YE SHALL RETURN EVERY MAN UNTO HIS POSSESSION. As Scripture goes on to explain,68 in the year of Jubilee the land that is sold shall return to its owners.69
AND YE SHALL RETURN EVERY MAN UNTO HIS FAMILY. The servant70 sold to an Israelite.71
11. A JUBILEE SHALL THAT FIFTIETH YEAR BE. Since it is the year of Jubilee you shall not sow.
12. IT SHALL BE HOLY UNTO YOU. For it is distinguished from the other years.
YE SHALL EAT THE INCREASE THEREOF OUT OF THE FIELD. You shall eat what the land produces of itself. It is the same as is written regarding the Sabbatical year.72
13. IN THIS YEAR OF JUBILEE. Its meaning is in the beginning of the year.

14. OR BUY. Kanoh (buy) is an infinitive.73 A word is missing.74 Kanoh is in place of kenitem kano (you will surely buy).75 Compare, zakhor (remember) in Remember the sabbath day (Ex. 20:8).76 There are many such instances.77
The word timkeru (thou sell) is in the plural because it shall be sold in front of witnesses.78 The same is true of al tonu (ye shall not wrong).79
[15. ACCORDING TO THE NUMBER OF YEARS.] Only according to the number of years.
16. THOU SHALT INCREASE THE PRICE THEREOF. The reverse of thou shalt diminish.
[17. AND YE SHALL NOT80 WRONG ONE ANOTHER.] This is to be understood as a warning to the seller,81 for the first injunction82 is directed to the buyer.83

FOR I AM THE LORD YOUR GOD. As I am your God, I will exact punishment from the two of them,84 from the one who wrongs his neighbor. If you observe My statutes the earth will bring forth its produce. Scripture mentions this85 because it earlier spoke of the number of crops86 (v. 16).

[20. OUR INCREASE.] The Sadducees87 say that our increase88 proves that the year begins in Nisan.89 This is no proof, for it is possible that the meaning of our increase is what the earth produces of itself.90 If they91 say that what the earth produces of itself is not called tevu’ah (increase)92 but safi’ach,93 then ye shall eat the increase thereof (tevu’atah) out of the field (v. 12) contradicts them.94 Furthermore, let them inform us how the Israelites were to act in the Jubilee year, for they would not sow in the sixth, seventh,95 and eighth year.96 They would only sow in the ninth year and harvest in the tenth. Why didn’t Scripture mention this, for Scripture only mentions for the three years (v. 21).97 It appears to me that the meaning of and it shall bring forth produce (v. 21) is, I will place a blessing on the sixth year98 that it will be sufficient for the sixth and an additional year.99 However, in the Jubilee year there will be food for three years and no more.100

[21. AND IT SHALL BRING FORTH.] The word ve-asat (and it shall bring forth) is irregular.101 Compare, ministered (mesharat) unto the king (I Rings 1:15).102 Scripture reads thus because it drops one of the tavs to simplify enunciation when two tavs are joined.

22. THE OLD STORE. The word yashan (the old store) adverts to the word min (of).103 The meaning of min (of) is, of the very thing. Similarly, with (min) the ark-cover104 shall ye make the cherubim (Ex. 25:19).

23. IN PERPETUITY. The word tzemitut (perpetuity) is similar105 to keritut (divorcement) (Is. 50:1). The tav106 is a root letter. Tzemitut is related to the word yatzmitem107 (will cut them off) in The Lord will cut them off (Ps. 94:23).108

FOR THE LAND IS MINE. This is an important reason.109 Moses similarly said in his prayer, Lord, Thou hast been our dwelling-place (ma’on) (Ps. 90:1). [The meaning of the latter is, God, You are like a permanent dwelling-place. However, One generation passeth away, and another generation cometh (Eccles. 1:4).
24. THE LAND OF YOUR POSSESSION. Which you inherited in the land of Canaan. Also in the land of the Amorite.110
25. BE WAXEN POOR. Yamukh (be waxen poor) comes from a root which consists of two stem letters that are sounded and one silent letter placed between them.111 Its meaning is poor and destitute.112
THAT IS NEXT UNTO HIM. From his family.
27. THEN LET HIM COUNT. The word ve-chishav (then let him count) is a pi’el.113

28. IT SHALL GO OUT.114 That which is sold shall go out. Note, a noun115 is used in place of an adjective.116 There are many such instances.117 Since Scripture states a dwelling-house in a walled city (v. 29),118 we know that and sell some of his possession (v. 25) refers to a field or a vineyard.
29. IN A WALLED CITY. A city surrounded by a wall.119

A FULL YEAR. The word yamim120 means a year. Yamim means until the days return to their point of departure after completing their cycle of cold and hot, summer and winter, for the return of the sun to its place121 is the cause of this cycle.122 Now, we need tradition as to what determines a full year,123 whether it is a solar year, or a lunar year, or an intercalated year.124
31. SHALL BE RECKONED WITH THE FIELDS OF THE COUNTRY. Al (with) in our verse is similar to al (and) in And they came, both men and (al) women (Ex. 35:22).125 The meaning of al126 is with.127

THEY MAY BE REDEEMED.128 The reference is to each and every house.129 Compare, Its branches (banot) run (tza’adah130) over the wall (Gen. 49:22), and for her children, (baneha) Because they are not (enennu) (Jer. 31:15).131
32. A PERPETUAL RIGHT OF REDEMPTION. Olam (a perpetual right) means forever.

Scripture reads, va-asher yigal (and if a man purchase)132 (v. 33), because our verse reads ge’ulat olam.133 The meaning of yigal is shall purchase. There are those who say va-asher yigal means even if the redeemer is a Levite.134
The vav of ve-yatza (then…shall go out) (v. 33) has the same meaning as the unaspirated fa in Arabic.135
A house and a city (v. 33) have one law.136

35. AND HIS MEANS FAIL. The word u-matah (and…fail) is related to the word yimmot (he shall…be moved) in he shall never be moved (Ps. 112:6). The mem is a root letter.137 Similarly, the word matah (slippeth) in If I say: My foot slippeth (Ps. 94:18).
THY BROTHER. An Israelite.
WITH THEE. For you are obligated to the one who is found with you, the one that you see.
AS A STRANGER AND A SETTLER. If he is from your country or is a stranger and a settler.138
SHALL HE LIVE. Va-chai (shall he live) means he shall live.
THEN THOU SHALT UPHOLD HIM. The reverse of and his means fail (matah).139 You shall uphold him so that he does not fall.

36. INTEREST…OR INCREASE. These terms140 are explained in the words of tradition. The tav of tarbit (increase) is superfluous.141 It is like the tav of tarmit (deceitful) (Zeph. 3:13).142 Tarbit is related143 to the word rav (many).144 However, it is a verb that comes from a root whose last letter is silent and hidden.145 It is similar146 to the word takhlit (utmost)147 in utmost hatred (Ps. 139:22). Scripture next148 explains the terms neshekh (increase) and tarbit (increase). The mem of marbit (increase) (v. 37) is also superfluous. It is like the mem of maskit (figured)149 in any figured stone (Lev. 26:1).

38. [I AM THE LORD YOUR GOD, WHO BROUGHT YOU FORTH OUT OF THE LAND OF EGYPT.] Where you were strangers. Note, I gave you an inheritance. Our verse is connected in meaning to as a stranger and a settler shall he live with thee (v. 35).150 It is also connected to the already mentioned section,151 for it152 deals with the redemption of the land. Scripture mentions the section containing and his means fail with thee (v. 35) because it will go on to state that an Israelite who is in such great need that he sells himself153 shall go out in the year of Jubilee.154 All the sections of the Torah portion are thus connected.
39. AND SELL HIMSELF UNTO THEE. He sells himself to you or he stole from you and he was sold by the Bet Din.
41. HE AND HIS CHILDREN WITH HIM. The transmitters of tradition based themselves on this verse when they explained the meaning of and he shall serve him for ever (Ex. 21:6).155
42. [FOR THEY ARE MY SERVANTS.] Because I bought them from the house of bondage.
43. THOU SHALT NOT RULE OVER HIM. Tirdeh means you shall rule.
WITH RIGOR. Be-farech (with rigor) is to be explained as the Aramaic translator does.156
44. OF THE NATIONS THAT ARE ROUND ABOUT YOU. Such as Amon, Moab, Edom, and Aram.

45. MOREOVER OF THE CHILDREN OF THE STRANGERS THAT DO SOJOURN AMONG YOU. Who dwell in the land of Canaan, which is your country, and they are from the nations that are mentioned.157 Or the reference is to Egypt and every nation aside from the seven nations,158 for Scripture commanded regarding the aforementioned, thou shalt save alive nothing that breatheth (Deut. 20:16). Note, it is prohibited to even feed them.159 It is possible that when the sages, of blessed memory, spoke of a Canaanite slave160 they spoke of someone who lived in Canaan, not of a person of Canaanite ancestry. On the other hand, it is possible that the sages were able to ascertain the truth of the matter,161 for our mind is insignificant when measured against their minds.162

46. AND YE MAY MAKE THEM AN INHERTANCE. Ve-hitnachaltem (and ye may make them an inheritance) is a hitpa’el. Similarly, ve-hitavvitem (and ye shall mark out a line) in and ye shall mark out your line (Num. 34:10).
OF THEM MAY YE TAKE YOUR BONDMEN FOR EVER. One is permitted to do so. However, since we find that the sages say that it is a commandment to do so, we accept what they say.163
[BUT OVER YOUR BRETHREN THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL.] Its meaning is, you will make a difference between your brother and the stranger.

47. OR TO THE OFFSHOOT. Eker (offshoot) means a root. The reference is to a person who accepted the Jewish religion. He himself is from the family of a stranger. The word eker has no neighbor.164 However, it is similar in meaning to ve-shereshkha (and root thee out) (Ps. 52:7). It means the opposite of its stem.165 Similarly, te’akker (thou shalt hough) in thou shalt hough their horses (Josh 11:6).166

49. OR IF HE BE WAXEN RICH. He found a lost object or he inherited the money of a deceased member of his family. Scripture first mentions the brother and the family167 because that is what is most usually the case.168
50. HIM THAT BOUGHT HIM. Konehu (him that bought him) has the same meaning whether spelled with a heh or not.169
HE SOLD HIMSELF. Himakhero (he sold himself) is an infinitive170 in the nifal. The years that he was with his master shall be like the days of a hired man.171

[51. IF THERE BE YET MANY YEARS.] The vav in If there be yet many years…and if (ve-im) there remain but few years (v. 52) is like an unaspirated fa in Arabic.172 It means173 whether the remaining years be many or few.
ACCORDING UNTO THEM, HE SHALL GIVE BACK THE PRICE OF HIS REDEMPTION. It174 shall be so considered with regard to the money that he was bought for.175
53. AS A SERVANT HIRED YEAR BY YEAR. This176 is repeated177 in order to add that which follows.178
HE SHALL NOT RULE WITH RIGOR OVER HIM IN THY SIGHT. We shall not permit the stranger to rule over him with rigor.179
54. AND IF HE BE NOT REDEEMED BY ANY OF THESE MEANS.180 The years remaining until the Jubilee.181 Others say by those mentioned earlier.182
55. FOR UNTO ME THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL ARE SERVANTS. This means you shall inform the stranger who buys an Israelite as a servant that the children of Israel are My servants.
chapter.ftnote: 1 This concept is first found in the Talmud and Midrash. See E. Z. Malamud, Meforshe Ha-Mikreh, Jerusalem, 1978, pp. 18-21.
