7 Lev. 18:28 and 20:22 tell us that Israel will dwell in the Land of Israel on condition that they refrain from perverse sexual practices. Lev. 26:34-43 tells us that Israel will dwell in the land only if they observe the Sabbatical year. Our section which deals with the Sabbatical year was inserted here to place these two conditions in the same portion.
9 The section opens with the Sabbatical year. The law of the Jubilee, which follows seven Sabbatical years then follows.
10 For Scripture tells us that the land shall keep a Sabbath unto the Lord.
11 See Ex. 20:8 and I.E.’s comments thereto (Vol. 2, p. 427).
12 Hence we can prevent him from working on the Sabbath and sowing during the Sabbatical year.
13 The Sabbath day is also referred to as a sabbath unto the Lord (Ex. 20:10).

14 See I.E. on Gen. 1:5, “There is a secret meaning to the Midrashic statement to the effect that the world will exist for six thousand years” (Vol. 1, p. 33). Also see I.E. on Gen. 8:22 (Vol. 1, p. 119). Also see Sanhedrin 97a,b.
15 See I.E. on Lev. 16:31.
16 Or attach me.
17 Safi’ach (that which groweth of itself) refers to produce which fell to the ground at the time of the harvest and attached itself to the ground (Weiser).

18 A nazirite distances himself from a vineyard, for he is not permitted to eat of its fruit. An undressed vine is referred to by the term nazir because the owner of the vineyard distanced himself from the vine and did not dress it (Weiser).
19 Lakhem (for you) is plural. Hence I.E.’s comment.
20 Lekha (for thee) is a singular. Hence I.E.’s comment.
21 See Rosh Ha-Shanah 10a, 11a.
22 In other words, the accepted opinion among the sages is that the world was created on Rosh Ha-Shanah.
23 Verse 9.
24 This sentence and the following sentence are omitted in some editions of I.E. The Mikra’ot Gedolot places it in parentheses.
25 At the start of the Sabbatical year. This is the way I.E. interprets Deut 31:10. See Vol. 4, p. 225. See Deut. 31:10-13.
26 According to I.E. that they may hear, and that they may learn means that they may hear, and that they may learn the entire year. See I.E. on Deut. 31:12 (Vol. 5, p. 225).
27 The reading and the study of the Torah.

28 If Nisan is the beginning of the year then the public reading of the Torah which initiates a mass study of the Torah takes place six months after the start of the New Year. According to I.E. this makes no sense, for the study of the Torah in the Sabbatical year is similar to the study of the Torah on the Sabbath (I.E. on Deut. 31:12). Now the study of the Torah on the Sabbath starts with the onset of the Sabbath. It does not start at midday. Similarly, the study of the Torah in the Sabbatical year. Furthermore, why waste half of a year that could be devoted to Torah study.
29 This and the following sentence are omitted in the Margali’ot Tuva edition of I.E. The Mikra’ot Gedolot places it in brackets.

30 We thus see that the Festival of Sukkot comes at the turn of the year, not six months earlier. According to I.E. and other commentaries, the year in these two verses is agricultural, so “turn of the year” and “end of the year” have a similar meaning. See Vol. 3, pp. 503,723.
31 In the fall preceding the Sabbatical year, for harvesting is prohibited in the Sabbatical year.
32 In the seventh year.
33 In the seventh year.

34 In the sixth and in the seventh year. There is no point to sowing in the sixth year if what is planted cannot be harvested. Hence they will not sow in the sixth year. They will thus not sow in the sixth and seventh years.
35 In other words, Scripture speaks only of not sowing in the seventh year.
36 An early Karaite. See I.E. on Ex. 12:2 and the notes thereto (Vol. 2, p. 203).
37 I.E. earlier dealt with the start of the year He now goes on to explain how the year is calculated.

38 A solar year consists of about 365 and 1/4 days. The wise men of India add a fifth of an hour to the aforementioned. They claim that a solar year consists of 365 and 1/4 days plus a fifth of an hour.
39 According to Ptolemy a solar year consists of 365 and 1/4 days minus 1/300 of the day.
40 Parts are to be subtracted from the quarter of the day.
41 Parts are to be subtracted from the quarter of the day.
42 Parts of the day are to be subtracted from the quarter of the day.
43 Parts of the day are to be subtracted from the quarter of the day.

44 In other words, when the sun concludes a cycle around the constellations from any given point. This is the opinion of those who believe that the year consists of 365 days plus 1/4 of a day and a fifth of an hour (Krinsky).

45 Others calculate it from a point on the inclined sphere. That is the sphere of the constellations. This is the opinion of those who believe that a year consists of 365 days plus a little less than 1/4 of the day (Krinsky).
46 To determine what Scripture means by a year.
47 The word chodesh literally means new moon. I.E. will soon show that a solar calendar has no true months, for the new moons play no role in establishing a solar year.
48 The Karaites.
49 If we follow a lunar calendar then strictly speaking there is no year, for a year is determined by the cycle of the sun.
50 Of the calendar.
51 For practical reasons.
52 Those who employed a solar calendar wanted to divide the year into months.
53 Twelve cycles of the moon come close to one cycle of the sun.
54 Of the calendar.
55 Of a solar year.
56 Begin once again.
57 The Jewish calendar is both solar and lunar.

58 Of 19 solar years. The following is the order of leap years: 3, 6, 8, 11, 14, 17, and 19. The numbers indicate the location of the leap year in the cycle. At the end of 19 years the solar and “lunar” years equalize.
59 In other words, even though they employed a lunar calendar with regard to the months, they harmonized the lunar with the solar calendar.
60 The 19-year cycle.
61 It was first discovered in the fifth century by the Greek astronomer Meton.
62 Hebrew, mesilot. Some emend to gevulot (borders) (Meijler). Others to chuztot (streets). Some texts read mazalot (constellations). This is obviously wrong.
63 Hallowing in our context means abstaining from working the land.
64 I.E. renders Prov. 26:2 as the flying free bird.
65 The Jubilee is the year when people are set free.
66 Of Jubilee.
67 The year is called “the ram’s horn,” i.e., the year in which the ram’s horn is sounded.
68 In verses 14-16.
69 And ye shall return every man unto his possession means that each person shall regain the land that he sold.
70 The reference is to a Hebrew servant.
71 Every man means every servant.
72 Verse 6 and 7.
73 Employed as an auxiliary verb. I.E. comments thus because an infinitive by itself is out of place here.
74 For, as noted, kanoh is employed as an auxiliary verb.
75 Kanoh is short for kenitem kano.
76 Zakhor is an infinitive. It is short for zakhor tizkor.
77 Where Scripture employs an infinitive and leaves out the major verb.
78 The witnesses are part and parcel of the act of selling. Hence the use of the plural.

79 Cheat. Tonu is in the plural. It is so because it applies to the buyer or seller and to the witnesses. One is not permitted to be a witness to a transaction in which the buyer or seller is cheated.
80 I.E. reads ve-al. The Torah reads ve-lo. If not a scribal error, then I.E. quoted from memory and erred.
81 For it follows doth he sell.
82 The first time Scripture mentions ye shall not wrong one another (v. 14).
83 For ye shall not wrong one another in verse 14 follows or buy of thy neighbor.
84 From the buyer or from the seller.
85 For I am the Lord.

86 Scripture states in our verse, but thou shalt fear thy God; For I am the Lord because it earlier said according unto the number of years of the crops he shall sell. (v. 15). In other words, the thrust of our verse is fear God and do not cheat in calculating the years.
87 The Karaites.
88 Hebrew, tevu’atenu.

89 For what is planted in the fall is harvested in the spring. However, if the year begins in Tishri the land is not sown and there is nothing to harvest in the spring. However, our verse indicates that this is not so, for it states, nor gather in our increase.
90 That which grows of itself.
91 The Karaites.
92 The term used in our verse.
93 See verses 5 and 11.
94 For the previous verse speaks of what grows of itself (safi’ach).

95 In the sixth and seventh years of the seventh cycle of Sabbatical years. They wouldn’t sow in the sixth year because they couldn’t harvest in the seventh year. Sowing was prohibited in the seventh year.
96 The eighth year from year one of the seventh cycle of Sabbatical years, that is, the year of Jubilee.

97 Verse 21 says that the sixth year will produce food for three years. However, according to the Karaites, Scripture should have said that the land would produce food for four years, i.e., for the sixth, seventh, eighth and ninth years. It should be noted that I.E. interprets the three years in verse 21 as referring to the seventh, eighth and ninth years.
98 Of every Sabbatical year.
99 The seventh year.

100 Verse 21 reads, then I will command My blessing upon you in the sixth year, and it shall bring forth produce for the three years. I.E. interprets the aforementioned as: then I will command My blessing upon you in the sixth year. Now in all Sabbatical years the land will produce food for the sixth and seventh years. However, the sixth year shall bring forth produce for precisely three years when it precedes the year of Jubilee. I.E. comments thus because our verse seems to imply that God will bless the sixth year only when it precedes the Jubilee.
101 Ve-asat is short for ve-asetat, which is a variation of ve-asetah. See Krinsky and Filwarg.
102 The usual form is mesharetet.

103 Not to the word tevu’ah (produce), which precedes it, for tevu’ah is feminine and yashan (old store) is masculine. I.E. says that min ha-tevu’ah yashan (of the produce, the old store) is to be interpreted as if written min yashan ha-tevu’ah (of the very old store of the grain).
104 I.E renders With (min) the ark-cover shall ye make the cherubim as, of the very ark-cover shall ye make the cherubim
105 In meaning. According to I.E. the literal meaning of our verse is, the land shall not be sold in such a way that it is permanently cut off (divorced) from its owners.
106 Of tzemitut. Its root is tzadi, mem, tav.
107 From the root tzadi, mem, tav.
108 I.E. interprets our verse as follows: the land shall not be sold in such a manner that it is permanently cut off from its owners.
109 For why the land is not to be sold in perpetuity.
110 Located on the eastern side of the Jordan.
111 An ayin vav, a verb whose middle root letter is a vav. Its root is mem, vav, kaf.
112 The meaning of yamukh is to become poor or to become destitute
113 Literally, from the heavy form, which receives a dagesh.
114 Hebrew, ve-yatza. The latter can be rendered he shall go out, or it shall go out. Hence I.E.’s comment.
115 Mimkaro.

116 Nimkar (that which is sold). Our verse reads ve-hayah mimkaro… which literally means, then his sale (mimkar) shall remain in the hand of him that has bought it. This makes no sense. Hence I.E.’s comment that it should be interpreted as, then that which he hath sold shall remain in the hand of him that hath bought it.
117 Where Scripture employs a noun in place of an adjective.

118 Since Scripture states that a dwelling-house in a walled city (v. 29) cannot be redeemed after a year has passed, then the verses that speak of property always being redeemed and if not redeemed, returning to its owners in the year of Jubilee, must speak of land.
119 Our verse reads bet moshav ir chomah (a dwelling-house in a walled city). Bet moshav ir chomah literally means a dwelling-house in a city wall. Hence I.E.’s comment.
120 Literally, days.
121 The movement of the sun to its place of departure.

122 A year means a full cycle of the sun. The question arises, Why does the Torah refer to a year as days? The answer is, the cycle of the sun is responsible for the full complement of days. Hence a full cycle of the sun can be referred to as days.
123 Spoken of in our verse.

124 If the year in which the house is sold contains 13 lunar months, can the house be redeemed in the 13th month or do we consider it to be a year after 12 months have passed? See Arakhin 9:3, “Rabbi says: He is allowed a year and its intercalary month (i.e., the extra days by which the solar year exceeds the lunar year).”
125 I.E. renders this as: And they came, men with women.
126 In our verse and in Ex. 35:22.
127 Al usually means on. Hence I.E.’s comment.
128 Literally, redemption shall be to it (lo).
129 Hence the use of the singular it (lo).
130 Banot is plural. Tza’adah is singular. According to I.E. the meaning of Gen. 49:22 is, each one of its branches (banot) run (tza’adah) over the wall. See I.E. on Gen. 49:22 (Vol. 1, p. 442).
131 Baneha is in the plural. Enennu is singular. I.E. renders Jer. 31:15, For her children (baneha) because each one of them is not (enennu).
132 Rather than va-asher yikneh. Yigal literally means to redeem.
133 Yigal and ge’ulat come from the same root. In other words, Scripture employs the word to mean to purchase for poetic reasons.

134 In other words, va-asher yigal min ha-leviyim (and if a man purchase of the Levites) means, and if a man of the Levites purchases. In other words, if a Levite buys a house from another Levite, even in a walled city, that house goes out in the Jubilee. One might think that the law governing a purchase of a house in a Levitical city by one Levite from another is the same as that governing the sale of a house in a walled city by one Israelite from another Israelite, i.e., that the house can only be redeemed during the first year of its purchase.
135 The vav is not to be rendered as “and” but as “then” or “the like.” For the meaning of the Arabic fa see Vol. 1, p. xvi; p. 30.

136 In other words, bayit ve-ir (the house…in the city), which literally means a house and a city, is to be rendered a house or a city. Both the house or the city sold by a Levite reverts to the Levite seller in the Jubilee year. See Eruvin 59a, which speaks of a city owned by an individual.
137 Its root is mem, vav, tet.
138 I.E.’s paraphrase of our verse. You are obligated to help the inhabitant of your country whether he is an Israelite or a stranger and a settler.
139 Matah literally means fall. Since Scripture earlier employed the term fall, it now employs the term uphold.
140 The meaning of neshekh and tarbit.
141 It is a form letter, not a root letter. It does not have any grammatical meaning.
142 Which is a form letter and does not have any grammatical meaning.
143 In meaning.
144 From the root resh, bet, bet.
145 A heh. Its root is resh, bet, heh.
146 In form.
147 From the root kaf, lamed, heh.
148 After stating that one is not to take interest and increase (v. 36), Scripture goes on to explain these terms (v. 37).
149 From the root sin, kaf, heh.

150 Our verse, as it were says help the individual who falls, be he an Israelite or a stranger because I am the Lord your God, who brought you forth out of the land of Egypt where you were strangers, and I gave you an inheritance.
151 The section which precedes verses 36 and 37, which deal with the redemption of the land.
152 The section, which precedes our section.
153 To be a slave.
154 See verses 47-55.

155 According to the rabbis, and he shall serve him for ever means until the Jubilee year. See I.E. on Ex. 21:6 (Vol. 2, p. 458): “And he shall serve him for ever means, and he will serve him until the year of Jubilee, for there is no season of Israel that is longer than it.”
156 Onkelos renders be-farech, be-kashyu (with hard work, i.e., backbreaking work).
157 In I.E.’s comments on verse 44. I.E. comments thus because the Torah does not permit the Israelites to allow Canaanites to dwell in the Land of Israel.
158 The seven Canaanite nations.
159 I.E.’s interpretation of thou shalt save alive nothing that breatheth.
160 Scripture prohibits Canaanites from living in the Land of Israel. However, it appears from the Talmud that Israelites kept Canaanite slaves. This contradicts Biblical law. Hence I.E.’s comments.

161 According to the rabbis the prohibition against keeping a Canaanite slave applies only to the offspring of a Canaanite father. It does not apply to the offspring of a female Canaanite and a non-Canaanite male. Such people were permitted to live in the Land of Israel and they provided the Canaanite slaves. See Kiddushin 67b. Also see Rashi.
162 In other words, when it comes to Jewish law we accept Rabbinic tradition.
163 Actually the sages Rabbi Akiba and Rabbi Yishma’el differ on this point. See Gitin 38b; Sotah 3b.
164 The word is not found again in Scripture.

165 Shoresh means a root. However, ve-shereshkha means, and uproots you. Similarly, eker comes from the Hebrew stem meaning a root. However, its meaning is someone who has been uprooted, i.e., a stranger.
166 I.E. renders this clause, you shall uproot their horses.
167 With regard to the redemption of the slave.
168 It is more usual for a family member to redeem a slave than for the slave to redeem himself.
169 Konehu has the same meaning as kono. The latter is the form most used.
170 Plus the pronominal suffix.

171 In calculating the redemption money, the years served by the slave shall be deducted from the amount of money paid for the slave. The value placed upon the years that the slave served shall be assessed in accordance with what a hired man is paid.

172 In other words, the vav in ve-im (v. 52) does not mean and. It means or, for verse 52 is not a continuation of verse 51. However, there are editions of I.E. which read: “If (ve-im) there be yet many years…and if (ve-im) there remain but few years.” The latter is also the reading in Vat. Ebr. 38. If the latter is correct then I.E.’s version of the Torah reads ve-im while our Torah in verse 51 reads im. It is possible that I.E. quoted from memory and erred. For the unaispirated fa, see I.E. on verse 34 and the notes thereto.
173 The meaning of verses 51 and 52.
174 The remaining years.
175 The remaining years until the Jubilee.
176 As a servant hired year by year.
177 Scripture had already told us in verse 40 that the Hebrew slave is to be treated as a hired servant.
178 That is, he shall not rule with rigor over him in thy sight.

179 He shall not rule with rigor over him means you will not permit him to rule with rigor over him. See I.E. on verse 43 and the notes thereto for the definition of rigor. Verse 43 prohibits an Israelite from ruling over an Israelite slave with rigor. Scripture now prohibits the Israelites from allowing strangers to rule over Israelites with rigor.
180 Hebrew, be-elleh (literally, in these or by these).
181 This interpretation renders our clause, and if he be not redeemed in any of these, i.e., in any of these years.

182 This interpretation renders our clause, and if he be not redeemed by any of these, i.e., by any of the relatives mentioned in verses 48-49. According to the first interpretation be-elleh is to be rendered in these. According to the second interpretation ba-elleh is to be rendered by these.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 26
chapter.p: 1. YE SHALL MAKE YOU NO IDOLS. Scripture speaks of an Israelite who was sold to a non-Jew.1 It therefore warns the Israelite against the worship of idols. He (the Israelite slave) must not serve his master in anything relating to an idol. The Israelite shall also not serve his master on the Sabbath.2 The foreigner can purchase an Israelite only under these conditions.
2. AND REVERENCE MY SANCTUARY. By coming to the sanctuary during the three pilgrimage festivals.

It is possible that Scripture states Ye shall make you no idols because Scripture had earlier stated, they are My servants (Lev. 25:55). Now, since they are My servants they shall serve Me alone and not other gods.
NEITHER…A GRAVEN IMAGE. The meaning of pesel (a graven image) is known.
OR A PILLAR. For a graven image.3

FIGURED. Maskit (figured) is a noun. It is similar to marbit (increase) (Lev. 25:36).4 Maskit refers to a stone with figures on it. It is related to the word maskiyyot (imaginations) in the imaginations of their heart (Ps. 73)5 and sekhiyyot (imagery) in delightful imagery (Is. 2:16).
NEITHER SHALL YE PLACE…IN YOUR LAND. This6 is the way pagans worship Mercury.
FOR I AM THE LORD YOUR GOD. You shall bow to Me. It7 is so explained in the Jerusalem Targum.8
YE SHALL KEEP MY SABBATHS. The Sabbatical years.
AND REVERENCE MY SANCTUARY. The year of Jubilee, for Scripture clearly states, it9 shall be holy unto you (Lev. 25:12).

I believe that Scripture employs My sabbaths in the sense of And from one sabbath to another, Shall all flesh come to bow before Me10 (Is. 66:23),11 for Scripture mentions to bow down unto it12 (v. 1).13 The meaning of Ye shall keep My sabbaths is you shall come every Sabbath to bow before Me, and not to a stone with figures on it. You shall come to My sanctuary alone. Note, Scripture mentions the chosen day,14 for this day, as I have previously noted,15 was chosen for the worship of God. Scripture also mentions the chosen place.16
The meaning of for I am the Lord is, for I rested from all work on the Sabbath and My glory dwells in the sanctuary. Scripture therefore says and reverence.17
3. IF YE WALK IN MY STATUTES, AND KEEP…AND DO. This is a commandment to study, to teach, and to observe.

[4. THEN I WILL GIVE.] The vav in ve-natati (then I will give) is like the vav in ve-ha’aretz (now the earth) in Now the earth was unformed and void (Gen. 1:2).18 When a word which has a vav prefixed to it19 is ultimately accented,20 the word is an imperfect. When it is penultimately accented it is in the perfect. The above is, aside from a few instances, always the case.

HER PRODUCE. The word yevulah (her produce) is related to the word vul (food) in Surely the mountains bring him forth food (Job 40:20). We do not know whether the yod in yevul is a root letter or is like the yod in yekum (living substance) (Gen.7:23),21 which is not a root letter.
5. THRESHING SHALL REACH UNTO THE VINTAGE. Note, when thou gatherest in thy labors out of the field (Ex. 23:16) is now explained as meaning from the field and the vineyard.22
YE HAVE ENOUGH. Sova (enough) is an infinitive.23

SAFELY. La-vetach (safely) has the same meaning whether spelled with a lamed or not.24 The same is true of the word levadad (alone) (Num. 23:9).25 Note, Scripture mentions sova (enough) first,26 for that is most important.

Scripture states, and dwell in your land safely, because people wander from their place in days of famine. Its meaning is similar to it shall not henceforth yield unto thee her strength; a fugitive and a wanderer shalt thou be (Gen. 4:12).
6. AND I WILL GIVE PEACE IN THE LAND. Among yourselves.

AND NONE SHALL MAKE YOU AFRAID. No evil beast and no enemy.27 On the contrary, you will chase your enemies and they shall fall before you. The greater wonder shall be that a small number of you shall pursue a large number of your enemies. I have previously informed you in my book Moznayim that ten, one hundred, a thousand, and ten thousand are round numbers.28 It is customary for one who magnifies a number to say “one to ten.”29 Compare, but thou art worth ten thousand of us (II Sam 18:3).30 Scripture here mentions that a hundred shall be chased by five.31 Note, Scripture doubled the number used by the one who magnifies.32 Each one of a hundred Israelites shall chase a hundred of their enemies.33 There are those who say that Scripture adds to the number because the number is increased when the individuals come together.34 Similarly, How should one chase a thousand (Deut. 32:30).35 There is no need for this.36
8. AND YOUR ENEMIES SHALL FALL. This is stated a second time.37 The repetition indicates that they will fall time after time. They will not rise again.

9. AND I WILL HAVE RESPECT UNTO YOU. To greatly increase your wealth, to make you fruitful, and to multiply you with sons and daughters. It appears to me that and make you fruitful is the reverse of the barren womb (Prov. 30:15).38
AND WILL ESTABLISH MY COVENANT WITH YOU. In that you will be as the stars of heaven for multitude (Deut.1:11) and as the dust of the earth (Gen. 13:16).

10. AND YE SHALL EAT OLD STORE LONG KEPT. Amazingly, even though you shall be numerous there shall be so much produce that whoever will want to, shall eat from the old store and also from the old store long kept, which is older than the old store. The word noshan (long kept) is a nifal. There will be those who shall remove the old store from their house to make room for the new produce, for they will have no place to store it.39 There is a commentator who says that the meaning of and ye shall bring forth is you shall take it out to the field.40

11. AND I WILL SET MY TABERNACLE. You will not fear that you might ever lack anything, for My glory shall dwell among you. I am not like a human being who abhors to dwell in one place.41 Furthermore, when you go into the land of your enemies42 and the temple is no longer among you,43 My glory shall go with you. Note, I shall be your God. You shall be My people, for I took you out of the land of Egypt for that purpose.

13. AND I HAVE BROKEN THE BARS OF YOUR YOKE. Scripture employs the metaphor of a plowing bullock44 that works the land of its owner, for Israel was forced to work as slaves in improving the land. The latter is clearly stated.45

UPRIGHT. Kommemiyyut means upright. The empty heads say that there are more curses than blessings. However, they do not speak the truth. What Scripture does is to speak of the blessings in general terms. However, it lists the curses in detail in order to frighten and scare the listeners. What I say will be clear to the one who reads the text carefully.
14. ALL THESE COMMANDMENTS. These that are written.46
15. BUT BREAK. The word le-hafrekhem (but break) is grammatically irregular,47 for the forms of verbs change.48
16. AND I WILL APPOINT…OVER YOU. As one who is appointed over another does whatever he wants, to him.

TERROR…EVEN CONSUMPTION AND FEVER. Common diseases. The meaning of et49 (even) is “with”. The meaning of behalah (terror) is that you will be terrified and will not know what to do. There are those who say that behalah (terror) means suddenly.50 Many say that shachefet (consumption) and kadachat (fever) are diseases of the seed like blasting51 and mildew,52 for Scripture clearly states that the latter are such diseases (Amos 4:9).53 They say this54 because our verse states, and ye shall sow your seed in vain. However, there is no need for this,55 for the meaning of our verse is that they shall be struck with illnesses56 and if marauders shall come to the villages they shall then eat their seed, for there will not be anyone to go out and scatter the raiders.57 The meaning of that shall make the eyes to fail is that these diseases will darken the eyes and languish the soul. The alef is missing in the word medivot (languish) in and the soul to languish. It is similarly missing in the word mezin (giveth ear) in And a liar giveth ear (Prov.17:4). Some say that the eyes to fail speaks of the eyes of the body58 because it goes on to say and the soul to languish.59 However, there is no need for this interpretation.60

17. AND I WILL SET MY FACE AGAINST YOU. My wrath and My anger.61 Compare, and her countenance62 was no more (I Sam. 1:18).63 The meaning of our verse is that those that remain and are not stricken by disease will be smitten before their enemies, should they go out to fight them. At other times they will flee when no one pursues them as in the case of the Aramean camp.64
18. AND IF YE WILL NOT YET FOR THESE THINGS. The plagues.

SEVEN. The number seven is used for “many” because it is a complete number.65 Similarly, For a righteous man falleth seven times (Prov. 24:16); While the barren hath born seven (I Sam. 2:5). Al chatatekhem (for your sins) does not add the number seven to each sin.66 Its meaning is, I will punish you again for each sin. Ve-yasafti (then …more) is similar to yasaf (more) in and it went on no more (Deut. 5:19). The meaning of al chatatekhem67 is, because of your sins. Some say that the number seven is to be taken literally.68 However, the first interpretation69 is correct, for if we count And I will break…(v. 19) as one; your heaven as iron (v. 19) as two; and your earth as brass (v. 19);70 And your strength shall be spent in vain71 (v. 20); for your land…her produce72 (v. 20); the trees of the land…their fruit (v. 20), then we have six. Note, the plague of beast of the field (v. 22) makes seven.73
19. THE PRIDE OF YOUR POWER. The satiated,74 as in But Jeshurun waxed fat, and kicked (Deut. 32:15). When the proud are broken they fall and are brought low.
20. AND YOUR STRENGTH SHALL BE SPENT IN VAIN. The strength which you expended in working the soil.

21. CONTRARY. Many say that the meaning of keri (contrary) is power and might. You will act like a person who hardens his heart and is not afraid that he will be defeated.75 The word keri has no neighbor.76 Other say that the word keri is related to korot (befallen) in all that had befallen (Gen. 42:29). Its meaning is found in what Scripture says in the account of the Philistines wherein we read, it is not His hand that smote us; it was a chance (mikreh) that happened to us77 (I Sam. 6:9). According to both interpretations the word keri is missing a bet.78 It is like the word sheshet79 (six) in for in six days (Ex. 20:11).80 Or, ve-im telekhu immi keri (and if you walk contrary unto Me) is to be read as if written ve-im telekhu immi halikhat keri (if you walk, a contrary walk, unto Me).81 I have already shown you many such instances.82 Note, our verse reads according to your sins. God will not add to the sins.83 Al chatatekhem (for your sins) (v. 18) is connected to le-yasserah etkhem (chastise you). The meaning of al chatatekhem (for your sins)84 is because of your sins.
22. AND I WILL SEND…AMONG YOU. Ve-hishlakhti (and I will send) is related to the word mashli’ach (send) in behold, I will send (Ex.8: 17).85
WHICH SHALL ROB YOU OF YOUR CHILDREN. By killing your little ones.
AND MAKE YOU FEW IN NUMBER. By the death of adults.
AND YOUR WAYS SHALL BECOME DESOLATE. For there will be no way that will be secure from the fear of wild animals.86 I have previously explained this.87
23. YE WILL NOT BE CORRECTED. Tivvaseru (be corrected) is a nifal imperfect.88
24. FOR YOUR SINS. Al chatatekhem (for your sins) is connected to ve-hikketi (and I will smite).89

25. THE VENGEANCE OF THE COVENANT. Our verse mentions the covenant.90 On the basis of this I earlier said91 that our Torah portion contains the covenant referred to in the Torah reading Now these are the ordinances (Ex. 21:1). The covenant was made on the day Israel promised [All that the Lord hath spoken] will we do, and obey (Ex. 24:7). The covenant was then made and Moses told them this portion.92

AND YE SHALL BE GATHERED TOGETHER WITHIN YOUR CITIES. Because of the sword.93 There I will send the pestilence and the famine. The pestilence and the famine will cause you to desire to be delivered into the hand of the enemy. This is the meaning of and ye shall be delivered into the hand of the enemy. Ve-nittattem (and ye shall be delivered) is a nifal.

26. WHEN I BREAK. Shivri (I break) is an infinitive. It is vocalized with a chirik.94 Compare, shikhvah (she lay down) in when she lay down, nor when she arose (Gen. 19:33).95 The Torah employs the term break because it speaks of the staff of bread.96 The latter is a metaphor. We find that Isaiah employs the phrase stay97 of bread (Is.3:1), for bread stays man’s heart (Ps. 104:15).

TEN WOMEN. Scripture says ten women, for ten is the last of the numbers.98 It was the custom of Israel for each family to bake99 one oven full of bread for them to eat for the entire week.100 The arrangement of the Sabbath bread101 is proof of this.102
AND THEY SHALL DELIVER YOUR BREAD AGAIN BY WEIGHT. For it will consist of a small amount.103
AND YE SHALL EAT, AND NOT BE SATISFIED. There are hungry people who are satisfied by eating a little amount of food. However, you will not be satisfied from eating much food.104
27. AND…FOR ALL THIS. By being smitten by this plague. And if in…these things (v. 23) similarly means, and if because of the previously mentioned plagues.
28. FOR YOUR SINS. This is connected to and I also will chastise you.105

29. AND YE SHALL EAT THE FLESH OF YOUR SONS… There is no famine worse than this one.106 You will not have a place to cry out and pray to be saved from the famine, for I will destroy your high places, the place of the sacrifices.

30. YOUR SUN-PILLARS. Chammnekhem is related to the word chammah (sun).107 Chammnekhem refers to structures built for the purpose of bowing down to the sun. The nun of chammnekhem is superfluous.108 It is like the nun of rachamaniyyot109 (compassion) in women full of compassion (Lam. 4:10).
YOUR CARCASSES. Pigrekhem means your carcasses. Compare, As a carcass (peger) trodden under foot (Is. 14:19).

YOUR IDOLS. Gillulekhem (your idols) is a disparaging term for idols. Gillulekhem is related to the word galal (dung) in sweepeth away dung (I Kings 14:10).110 The meaning of our verse is that when Israel joins themselves to temples dedicated to idol worship they will be killed there and their enemies will destroy the images of their idols. I (God) will not help them.

AND MY SOUL SHALL ABHOR YOU. The divine presence shall be removed and your cities will then be destroyed and your sanctuaries desolated. Your sanctuaries (v. 31) refers to the temples, which were at first My (God’s) sanctuaries.111

31. AND I WILL NOT SMELL THE SAVOR OF YOUR SWEET ODORS. Scripture states this for the heaven and earth are full of God’s glory.112 Scripture writes with regard to Noah, And the Lord smelled the sweet savor (Gen. 8:3).113 Its meaning is,114 I will not accept a burnt offering from you after this.115 After stating your cities and your sanctuaries, Scripture mentions the land. The reference is to all of the Land of Israel.
32. SHALL BE ASTONISHED AT IT. There will be so much destruction that the enemies who dwell there will also be astonished. Our verse is in contrast to The joy of the whole earth (Lam. 2:15).
33. WILL I SCATTER. Ezareh (will I scatter) is a pi’el. Not only will you be scattered but I will also draw out the sword after you. The meaning of draw out is draw out from its sheath.

AND YOUR LAND. This is connected to the verse which follows it. Its meaning is, when your land shall be desolate it will then be paid for its Sabbaths.116 The word tirtzeh means pay. Compare, Till he shall accomplish117 (yirtzeh), as a hireling, his day (Job 14:6); That her guilt is paid off (nirtzah) (Is. 40:2).
34. HER SABBATHS. Sabbatical years and Jubilees. It is similarly written, until the land had been paid her sabbaths (II Chron. 36:21). I have explained it there.118
DESOLATE. Hashammah (desolate) is a noun. The forms of the nouns change.119

The meaning of as long as it lieth desolate, and ye are in your enemies’ land is that the land will be desolate, for you will not inhabit it. Then the land will not be worked and it will find rest and complete its Sabbaths.
[35. AS LONG AS IT LIETH DESOLATE.] The meaning of as long as it lieth desolate is, the number of years that it shall not be worked. This is explained in Ezekiel.120
36. AND AS FOR THEM THAT ARE LEFT OF YOU. Scripture says this because it previously stated, and I will draw out the sword after you (v. 33).121

A FAINTNESS. Morekh (faintness) comes from a double root.122 Similarly, the word mo’al (lifting up) in with the lifting up of their hands (Neh. 8:6).123 The word morekh is related to the word rakh (faint) in and faint-hearted (Deut. 20:8). They will be so scared that the sound of a driven leaf shall chase them. Niddaf (driven) is an adjective in the nifal. The root nun is swallowed.124
37. ONE UPON ANOTHER. Whom he loves.

TO STAND. Tekumah (stand) is a hifil.125 It comes from a root whose middle root letter is a vav.126 The aforementioned is so because of the tav.127 It is the same case with the word terumah (offering).128
38. SHALL EAT YOU UP. It is the norm for most of those exiled to other places to die because of the effect that the change in the air and the water has upon them.
39. AND THEY THAT ARE LEFT. And from those that are left.

[SHALL PINE AWAY.] Yimmakku (shall pine away) follows the form of yissabbu (turned) in they turned not (Ezek. 1:9). Both words come from a double root.129 Yimmakku is related to the word hamak (consume away) in Their flesh shall consume away (Zech. 14:12) and mak (rottenness) in there shall be rottenness (Is. 3:24).
AND ALSO IN THE INIQUITIES OF THEIR FATHERS SHALL THEY PINE AWAY WITH THEM. Its meaning is like that of Our fathers have sinned (Lam. 5:7). I explained this in my commentary on Lamentations.130
40. AND THEY SHALL CONFESS. Ve-hitvaddu (and they shall confess) is a hitpa’el.
IN THEIR TREACHERY WHICH THEY COMMITTED AGAINST ME. Which their fathers committed against Me.
AND ALSO THAT THEY HAVE WALKED CONTRARY UNTO ME. These, their children, have walked contrary unto Me.
41. I ALSO. Did the same thing to them.131 I punished them by bringing them into the land of their enemies until their uncircumcised heart will be humbled. I will explain it132 later.
THEY THEN BE PAID THE PUNISHMENT OF THEIR INIQUITY. Yirtzu (be paid) means they will compensate and pay.

42. THEN WILL I REMEMBER MY COVENANT. My covenant is to be read as if written twice. Then will I remember My covenant with Jacob133 is to be interpreted as if written, Then will I remember My covenant, My covenant with Jacob. Compare, even the prophesy, Oded the prophet134 (II Chron. 15:8), which is to be read as if written, even the prophesy, the prophesy of Oded the prophet; your heads, your tribes (Deut. 29:9), which is to be read as if written, your heads, the heads of your tribes.
The Gaon says that the reason Scripture mentions Jacob first135 is that all of his years were in the covenant.136
43. FOR THE LAND SHALL LIE FORSAKEN WITHOUT THEM. This means I will also remember the land that paid off its Sabbaths and was forsaken without them. I will also remember that they paid for their sin.

BECAUSE, EVEN BECAUSE. The first because corresponds to they rejected Mine ordinances. The second one corresponds to and their soul abhorred My statutes. The bet of ve-ya’an (even because) is superfluous. It is like the bet of ba-rishonah (in the beginning) (Gen. 13:4).137

44. AND YET FOR ALL THAT. Ve-af gam zot (and yet for all that) is an elegant phrase.138 One word would have sufficed. We find this in all of Scripture.139 Compare, ha-rak akh be-mosheh (hath indeed…only with Moses) (Num. 12:2);140 ha-mibbeli en kevarim141 (because there were no graves) (Ex. 14:11).
I WILL NOT REJECT THEM…TO DESTROY THEM UTTERLY. But I will punish them until their hearts are humbled.
NEITHER WILL I ABHOR THEM. Ge’altim (will I abhor them) means I did not turn away from them.142 Or, it means I did not abhor them.
TO BREAK MY COVENANT. Which I made with them by oath. Even though, as Scripture states, they broke My covenant, I will not break My covenant with them, for I am the Lord.
45. BUT I WILL FOR THEIR SAKES REMEMBER. Forever.

THE COVENANT OF THEIR ANCESTORS.143 The reference is to the covenant made at Sinai. Scripture refers to this generation as “the first,”144 in contrast to their descendants who will be exiled in the land of their enemies. Some say that the reference is to the “patriarchs of the world,”145 and the meaning of whom I brought forth146 is those to whom I swore that I would free their children from slavery. The first interpretation appears to me to be the correct one.

46. THESE ARE THE STATUTES AND ORDINANCES. These statutes and ordinances are recorded in the Torah portion Now Jethro…heard (Ex. 18:1); Now these are the ordinances (Ex. 21:1), and In mount Sinai (Lev. 25:1).

WHICH THE LORD MADE BETWEEN HIM AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. This alludes to the covenant made at Sinai, for after the tabernacle was erected and the glory was present in the tent of meeting, Moses did not ascend Mount Sinai. Scripture also mentions the section of valuations here because it was related to Moses at Mount Sinai. The latter is clearly stated at the end of the portion.147 For148 the beginning of the Book of Numbers, And the Lord spoke unto Moses in the wilderness of Sinai, in the tent of meeting (Num. 1:1), is similar149 to the opening of the Book of Leviticus.150
chapter.ftnote: 2 Hence the Sabbath was mentioned in verse 2.
3 According to I.E. Scripture only prohibited a pillar made for the purpose of idol worship. See I.E. on Deut. 16:22 (Vol. 5, p. 117).
4 Both words are nouns that come from a root that end in a heh and have similar forms. The root of maskit is sin, kaf, heh. The root of marbit is resh, bet, heh.
5 That which their hearts see.
6 Setting up a stone with figures on it.
7 The meaning of even maskit.
8 The reference is to what is now referred to as Targum Jonathan. The latter renders even maskit by setatyu chakik be-tziyurin (a stone engraved with images).
9 The year of Jubilee.
10 Translated literally.
11 In other words, My sabbaths refers to the seventh day of the week, not to the Sabbatical year.

12 So Vat. Ebr. 38 and Filwarg. Mikra’ot Gedolot reads, and not (ve-lo) because Scripture mentioned to bow down unto it. The reading in Mikra’ot Gedolot is very hard to explain and appears to be in error. See Filwarg.

13 To bow down unto it indicates that My sabbaths refers to the seventh day of the week, not to the Sabbatical year. For Is. 66:2 tells us that the Sabbath is the time that people are to come and bow before the Lord.
14 The Sabbath.
16 God’s sanctuary.
17 My sanctuary.

18 In other words, the vav in ve-natati (then I will give), like the vav in ve-ha’aretz (now the earth), does not introduce an independent verse. According to I.E. the meaning of ve-natati is not “and I will give,” but “then I will give.” For the vav in ve-ha’aretz, see I.E. on Gen. 1:2 (Vol. 1, p. 30).
19 Such as ve-natati (then 1 will give).
20 As is the case with ve-natati (then I will give).
21 From the root kof, vav, mem.
22 Field in Ex. 23:16 refers to these two types of produce, for our verse speaks of threshing and vintage.
23 Even though it has the form of a verb. La-sova is a variation of li-sebo’a.
24 Our verse reads vi-yeshavtem la-vetach (and dwell in…safely). I.E. says that the verse would have the same meaning if it read vi-yeshavtem betach.
25 Levadad and levad have the same meaning.
26 The blessing of abundance of food is mentioned before other divine gifts.
27 Shall make you afraid.

28 Literally, are the sum of the count. The ones end in ten, the tens end in a hundred, the hundreds end in a thousand, and the thousands end in ten thousand. I.E.’s point is that if a person wants to exaggerate “ones,” he says ten; if he wants to exaggerate tens, he says a hundred; to exaggerate hundreds he says a thousand; if he wants to exaggerate thousands, he says ten thousand.

29 If one wants to say that one person shall pursue many, one says he shall pursue ten. If one wants to say that a hundred shall pursue many, one says one hundred shall pursue a thousand, and so forth.
30 Ten thousand is not to be taken literally.
31 The usual way of making the point that Scripture is making is to say that ten shall pursue a hundred.
32 If ten chase a hundred, then five chase fifty. However, Scripture tells us that five shall purse a hundred. Hence it doubles the amount that the Israelites would pursue.
33 For Scripture states, and a hundred of you shall chase ten thousand.

34 Five Israelites shall chase a hundred of their enemies but a hundred Israelites shall chase ten thousand of their enemies because a hundred Israelites fighting together can achieve a greater victory per person than five Israelites fighting together.
35 The verse continues, And two put ten thousand to flight. Here too the Israelites accomplish more when they fight together.
36 For Scripture employs exaggerated numbers which are not to be taken literally.
37 Scripture had already stated in the previous verse that Israel’s enemies would fall before them.
38 In this case our verse is to be understood as, I will ensure that you are not barren and I will multiply you.
39 I.E.’s interpretation of and ye shall bring forth the old from before the new.
40 To use as seed for the new crop.
41 I.E. might be hinting here as to why he chose a transient life.
42 When you go into exile.
43 For it will be destroyed.
44 Israel is compared to a plowing bullock who has a yoke attached to its neck.
46 The commandments written in the Torah.
47 The usual form is la-hafirkhem or la-haferkhem
48 That is, Scripture occasionally employs irregular forms.
49 Here. See I.E. on Gen. 1:1 (Vol. 1, p. 27).
50 The diseases will strike suddenly and you will not be able to guard against them.
51 Hebrew, shiddafon.
52 Hebrew, yerakon.
53 We know that blasting and mildew are diseases of the seed because Scripture speaks thus of them in Amos 4:9.
54 That shachefet (consumption) and kadachat (fever) are diseases of the seed.
55 To interpret shachefet (consumption) and kadachat (fever) as diseases of the seed on the basis of the verse’s stating and ye shall sow your seed in vain.
56 That is, with shachefet (consumption) and kadachat (fever).
57 I.E.’s interpretation of and ye shall sow your seed in vain, for your enemies shall eat it.
58 In other words, the eyes to fail is to be taken literally, not as a metaphor.
59 The soul will languish because the eyes fail.
60 For just as and the soul to languish refers to spiritual pain so does the eyes to fail.
61 My face means My anger.
62 Or her face.
63 According to I.E. this is to be interpreted as she no longer was angry.
64 See II Kings 7:6,7. The Arameans panicked and fled because they thought that they were about to be attacked by a superior force. In reality, no one was about to engage them.
65 It has special significance. See I.E. on Num. 23:1.
66 Then I will chastise you seven times more for your sins does not mean that they will be punished seven times for each sin.
67 Al chatatekhem literally means on your sins. Hence I.E.’s comments.
68 This is the opinion of Rashi, Targum Jonathan, and the Sifra.
69 That the number seven is not to be taken literally.
70 As three.
71 As four.
72 As five.

73 Scripture mentions the plague of beast of the field after it states, I will bring seven times more plagues upon you. If Scripture was listing the seven plagues that God would bring upon Israel, then the plague of the beasts would have been mentioned before the statement, I will bring seven times more plagues upon you.
74 From an abundance of food.

75 According to this interpretation our verse is to be understood as follows: And if you behave (walk) as if that which happens occurs by chance. In other words, if you act as if that which happens is not the result of Divine Providence.
76 It is not found again in Scripture.
77 According to this interpretation our verse reads, And if you walk in chance with Me, i.e., believing that all that which happens is by chance.

78 In other words, keri should be read as if written be-keri. According to I.E. our verse literally reads, And if you walk hardened with Me, or And if you walk in chance with Me. Hence I.E.’s comment.
79 Which is to be read as if written be-sheshet.
80 Literally, for six days. Hence I.E.’s comments.

81 According to this interpretation halikhat keri is to be understood as the walk of a person with a hardened heart, or the walk of a person who does not believe in divine providence. In this case the word halikhat is missing from our text.
82 Where Scripture omits a word.
83 I.E. notes this so that we do not render al chatatekhem (v. 18; v. 24) as in addition to or more than your sins.
84 Not in addition to or more than your sins.
85 In other words, “send” here has the meaning of sending misfortune.
86 Literally, animals that are not in the possession of people.
87 See I.E. on Lev. 25:7.
88 From the root yod, samekh, resh.
89 The sense of our verse being, I (God) will strike you because of your sins.
90 The only covenant that God made with Israel up to this point was the covenant at Sinai. Hence I.E.’s comment.
91 See I.E. on Lev. 25:1.
92 The blessing and the curses contained in this Torah portion.
93 Mentioned earlier in the verse, a sword…that shall execute the vengeance of the covenant.
94 Rather than with a small kamatz.
95 It too is an infinitive and is vocalized with a chirik rather than with a small kamatz.
96 A staff breaks.
97 Hebrew, mishan (a staff).
98 Hebrew, sakh ha-cheshbon. It is the last of the single numbers. See I.E. on verse 6.
99 On one day.
100 According to I.E. the meaning of our verse is that there will be so little food that a lot of women will bake their week’s supply of bread in one oven.
101 The show bread, the lecham ha-panim.
102 A week’s supply of show bread was baked every Friday (Sarim).
103 There will be so little food that each morsel will be precious.
104 See Rashi, “This is a curse within the intestines upon (which will affect) the bread.”
105 The import of our verse is, I will curse you for your sins. See I.E. on verse 21.
106 I will bring the worst sort of famine upon you.
107 It comes from the root chet, mem, mem.
108 It is not a root letter and does not serve any grammatical purposes.
109 From the root resh, chet, mem.
110 Gillulekhem literally means your dung.
111 Hence they are referred to as your sanctuaries rather than My sanctuaries.
112 Thus Israel may want to offer sacrifices to God after the destruction of their holy place.
113 The meaning of which is, God accepted Noah’s sacrifice.
114 The meaning of our verse.
115 After I destroy your holy places.
116 See next verse.
117 Or pay, i.e., pay with his labor.
118 We do not have I.E.’s commentary on Chronicles. Radak quotes from it in his commentary on II Chron. 30:18.
119 There are other forms for the word desolate: shemamah (Ex.23:19); shamah (Jer. 51:37).

120 The prophet Ezekiel was commanded to lie on his left side for 390 days and on his right side for 40 days. Each of these days represented a year that the Israelites sinned in not observing the Sabbatical years. See Ezek. 4:4-6. Also see Rashi on our verse and on Ezekiel.
121 And as for them that are left of you (v. 36) refers to those who survive the sword’s destruction.
122 It comes from the root resh, kaf, kaf.
123 From the root ayin, lamed, lamed.
124 The root of niddaf is nun, dalet, peh. The nun in niddaf is the root of the nifal form.
125 That is, a noun in the hifil form.
126 Its root is kof, vav, mem.
127 The tav in tekumah indicates that tekumah is a noun in the hifil form.
128 It is noun in the hifil form.
129 Yimmakku comes from the root mem, kof, kof. Yissabbu comes from the root samekh, bet, bet.

130 I.E. there explains Lam. 5:7 as meaning our sins were joined to the sins of our fathers and the combinations of our and our father’s sins reached the stage where punishment was due. However, when the bill came due our fathers were no longer alive and they thus escaped punishment.
131 I (God) also will walk contrary unto them.
132 The use of the term af (also) in the phrase af ani (I also). The word af appears unnecessary. Hence I.E.’s comment.
133 Our verse literally reads, “Then will I remember My covenant Jacob.” Hence I.E.’s comment.
134 Translated literally.
135 Scripture usually lists the patriarchs in order. It starts with Abraham and concludes with Jacob. However, here it starts with Jacob. Hence I.E.’s comment.

136 The covenant that God made with Abraham. See Gen. 17:1-14. Jacob was born after God entered into the covenant with Abraham. Thus Jacob spent his entire life under the covenant. This was not the case with Abraham. Isaac also was born under the covenant. However, Scripture did not start with him, for one cannot start a list from the middle.
137 According to I.E. the bet of ba-rishonah is superfluous. See I.E. on Gen. 1:1 (Vol. 1, p. 21).
138 It is poetic. Ve-af gam zot literally means, and even, even this. Scripture could have read ve-af zot or ve-gam zot.
139 Scripture employs similar phrases in many other places.
140 Scripture could have read ha-rak be-mosheh or ha-akh be-mosheh.
141 Scripture could have read ha-mibbeli kevarim or ha-in kevarim.
142 I did not treat them as an abhorrent thing.
143 Hebrew, rishonim (literally, the first).
144 At first glance “the first” should refer to the patriarchs.
145 Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
146 God did not take the patriarchs out of Egypt.
148 This refers back to I.E.’s first sentence in his comment on this verse.
149 Reading ke-sefer rather than be-sefer. See Filwarg and Krinsky.

150 It too indicates that God spoke to Moses in the tent of meeting. See I.E. on Num. 1:1 (Vol. 4, p. 4): “This verse informs us that Moses did not go up to Mount Sinai since God’s glory was now present in the tent of meeting.”

chapter.title: CHAPTER 27
chapter.p: 2. SHALL CLEARLY UTTER. Yafli (clearly utter) means to explain1 and to clarify.

A VOW OF PERSONS.2 Its meaning is, he will take a vow saying: If God will do the following for me then I will redeem my life in accordance with its value, or the value of my son’s life, or the value of the life of a beast. The kaf3 of be-erkekha (according to thy evaluation) is, according to all of the grammarians,4 superfluous. However, there is one who says that the kaf is directed to the kohen.5 He explains ke-erkekha ha-kohen (v. 12) as, as thou the priest valuest it.6 He refers to the heh of ha-kohen as a vocative heh.7 He says that the word, he-erkekha (of thy valuation) (v. 23), is an irregular word.8 It is like the word ha-oholi (of my tent)9 in the midst of my tent (Josh. 7:21). However, in my opinion the meaning of ha-oholi is, the tent, mine. Similarly he-erkekha (of thy valuation) (v. 23).10
Nefashot11 (persons) takes in both men and beasts.
3. FROM TWENTY YEARS OLD. Starting when one reaches the age of those who are counted [to go out to war].12

SIXTY YEARS OLD. Old age. According to many, it is the decree of the King13 that from a month until five years he shall give five shekalim;14 that is, if the child is a day past a month, the one who vowed shall give five shekalim (v. 6).15 However, according to the Gaon,16 he shall give a shekel per year17 until five full years have passed.18 Many19 say that these are four valuations20 corresponding to four divisions of life.21 Next22 comes nineteen complete years.23 Then comes24 fifty-nine years25 when one is valued at the amount he started with.26 The fifteen27 are for the completion of seventy-five years corresponding to the four parts.28 However, in truth, they are all complete years.29 Or,30 one day in the year is considered a year.31 We will only rely on the words of tradition.32 For what reason is there to differentiate between a month until five, and from five until twenty since he gives a shekel for each year?33 We can refute the latter from the law regarding a child of a month.34 Note, one who is less than a month old has no value.35 After the age of sixty one goes backwards.36 Furthermore, what should one do after sixty? Shall he always give the same?37 These are all errors.38 The general rule is that it is a Scriptural decree.39 If the amount to be given in valuation was based on the additional shekalim above which the male is valued over the female, then40 note that after the age of sixty a third is added.41 From five to twenty add a half, and from the age of a month until five and from twenty until sixty one adds to42 the half43 its tenth.44

8. AND THE PRIEST SHALL VALUE HIM. He shall be assessed in one evaluation based on every object that he owns.45 The word arokh (compared) in none to be compared unto Thee (Ps. 40:6) is similar to he’erikh (value him).46 He’erikh is a hifil. Similarly ya’arikhennu (value him) in shall the priest value him?47 He’erikh is to be distinguished from ya’arkhennu (he shall set it in order) in he shall set it in order before the Lord (Lev. 24:8).48

[THEN HE SHALL BE SET.49] The kohen.50 Our verse51 should be interpreted as if written; and the kohen shall set him before the kohen.52 It is similar to my interpretation of and pour it into the palm of his own left hand (Lev. 14:15).53 Ve-he’emido li-fene ha-kohen (then he shall be set before the priest) is lyrical.54 On the other hand, then he shall be set might mean that the one who vows shall set him.55
14. SO SHALL IT STAND. Yakum56 means so shall it stand.
16. AND IF…HIS POSSESSION. Which he inherited with the nation of Israel.

A HOMER OF BARLEY. Scripture writes, for ten baths are a homer (Ezek. 45:14). Scripture there writes, The ephah and the bath (Ezek. 45:11).57 Note, the sowing of an ephah of barley is valued at five shekalim.58 This is a decree of the King regarding the monetary value of a slave.59
17. IF…FROM THE YEAR OF JUBILEE. In that very year.60
18. AND AN ABATEMENT SHALL BE MADE FROM THY VALUATION. The time that passed since the Jubilee.61

19. [AND IF HE…WILL INDEED REDEEM.] The vav of ve-im ga’al yigal (and if he…will indeed redeem) is like the Arabic fa.62 It63 is connected in meaning to the verses that are above64 for the valuation is the main thing.65 Its66 meaning is, if he redeems the field or if he does not redeem it.67
20. OR IF HE HAVE SOLD. Ve-im makhar means, or if he have sold.68 The owner of the field cannot redeem the field because he sold it. It is to be holy to God.69
21. WHEN IT GOETH OUT IN THE JUBILEE. Scripture employs the same language70 as it does with regard to all fields,71 for it72 goes out73 in the Jubilee.
AS A FIELD DEVOTED. It belongs to the kohen as a field does which one takes a vow to devote.74 The amount of the valuation75 is the kohen’s, for he assesses it. He does not have to be a kohen gadol.
23. THY VALUATION. Mikhsat (the worth of) is similar to mikhsat (number of) in according to the number of (Ex. 12:4).76
24. OF WHOM IT WAS BOUGHT. The reference is to the seller.77 This is explained by to whom the possession of the land belongeth.

26. WHICH IS BORN AS A FIRSTLING TO THE LORD. Known to be the Lord’s. Yevukkar (which is born as a firstling) is a pu’al. No man shall sanctify it by saying, “I will give the first-born to the Lord.”78 This is its meaning.79

27. AND IF IT BE OF AN UNCLEAN BEAST. The first-born,80 along with the addition of a fifth of its value because he sanctified it.81 He shall also give a lamb,82 for Scripture so writes.83 If he does not sanctify the first-born,84 it may be sold.85 The first-born of an ass shall be exchanged in accordance with its valuation.86 He shall similarly give the sheep.87 Many say that it is not so.88
28. OF ALL THAT HE HATH. Which is in his control.89
OF MAN. Compare, I will devote (ve-hacharamti)90 their cities (Num. 21:2).91
[29. BE PUT TO DEATH.] The word yochoram (shall be devoted) is a hofal. Compare, yo’omad (shall be set)92 in shall be set alive (Lev. 16:10).

32. UNDER THE ROD. The shepherd’s rod.93 Now the number one94 is the chosen one. The tenth is the same as the first.95 However, he may redeem the tenth.96 This is not the case with the first-born.97 Note, the Israelite shall give the first-born and the tenth of the beast, and of the seed of the ground, namely, of the produce, the first fruits98 and the tithe.99
33. HE SHALL NOT INQUIRE. Yavakker (he shall…inquire) means he shall separate. I have previously explained that the word yavakker is related to the word boker (morning).100

34. IN MOUNT SINAI. I have explained this earlier in this Torah portion.101 The person who has the intelligence to understand the secret of the world will understand the secret of the first-born and the tenth.102 Now Abraham gave a tithe.103 Our father Jacob, unto him the peace, did the same.104 If the One who has no second will help me, then I will reveal part of the secret when I mention the second tithe.105
The Book of Leviticus is completed.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Reading yefaresh as in Vat. Ebr. 38, not yafrish (set aside) as in the printed editions.
2 Nefashot, literally, lives.
3 The kaf suffix, which has the meaning of your (thy).

4 They read (be-erkekha) as if written be-erekh. Our verse literally reads: When a man shall clearly utter a vow of lives according to your valuation (be-erkekha) of lives to the Lord. The word “your” does not seem to belong in the verse. Hence these commentaries interpret the verse as follows: When a man shall clearly utter a vow of lives according to the valuation (be-erkekh) of lives to the Lord.

5 In thy valuation refers to the kohen. This commentator explains our verse as follows: When a man shall clearly utter a vow of lives in accordance to what you the kohen shall value lives to the Lord.

6 The first mentioned commentaries interpret ke-erkekha ha-kohen as if written ke-erkekh ha-kohen because they believe that the kaf suffix of be-erkekha (according to thy evaluation) is superfluous, for if the kaf of be-erkekha refers to the kohen, then the word ha-kohen is redundant.

7 If the kaf of be-erkekha refers to the kohen, then the word ha-kohen is redundant. Hence the interpretation that ha-kohen does not mean the kohen but O kohen. This interpretation renders ke-erkekha ha-kohen as, as thou O priest valuest it.

8 The definite article is not placed before a word with a suffix, for he-erkekha literally reads, the valuation yours. Thus the heh in he-erkekha is irregular. The heh in he-erkekha does not present a problem for the first commentaries quoted by I.E., for they claim that the kaf of he-erkekha is superfluous and the word is to be interpreted as if written ke-erekh. He-erkekha is similarly to be read as if written he-erekh.
9 Ha-oholi (of my tent) is irregular, for it is a noun with a suffix with the definite article prefixed to it.

10 It means, the valuation-yours. According to I.E. ha-oholi is not irregular, for the heh serves to emphasize the point made by the word’s suffix (Weiser). However, I.E.’s interpretation presents a problem, for it contradicts the rule that the definite article is not placed before a word with a suffix. See Filwarg.
11 Literally, lives. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
13 God.
14 In other words, it is God’s decree that the valuation of a child from the age of a month and a day until the age of five shall be five shekalim.
15 If someone points at a child a day past a month and says that he will give its valuation, he shall give five shekalim.
16 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.
17 Starting after a month of the first year has passed.
18 Through the age of five. In other words, according to Rabbi Saadiah Gaon, for a child of the first year one gives one shekel, for a child of two years two shekalim, and so on.
19 Unlike the Gaon.
20 Up to the age of five, up to the age of 20, up to the age of sixty, from the age of 60 and above.
21 See verses 1-7.
22 After the first stage of life, that is, from one month and above through the first four years.
23 After the first stage comes the stage which starts at the age of five and lasts through the age of 19.
24 The third stage.
25 Until the age of 60.
26 Literally, to return to the place he started.
27 Given from the age of 60 and above (v. 7).
28 The age of 75 concludes the fourth quarter of life; the quarters are 5, 20, 60, 75.

29 I.E. takes issue with those who say that when Scripture states even unto twenty years old, it means after 19 years have been completed, i.e., until the age of 20. I.E. says that the meaning of even unto twenty years old is, until 20 years have been completed. So too with regard to even unto sixty years old.

30 Or the meaning of even unto twenty years old is, after a day into the twentieth year. So too with regard to even unto sixty years old. I.E.’s point is that it is not clear whether even unto twenty means even unto the completion of 20 or from the start of the age of 20.
31 As it is with regard to other laws such as Bar Mitzvah.

32 To determine the meaning of even unto twenty years old and even unto sixty years old and how many shekalim are to be given from the age of one month until the age of 20. According to the Mishnah Arakhin 4:14, the years mentioned in Scripture are complete years. This means that the thirtieth day is considered less than 30 days; the fifth year is considered under the age of five. The twentieth year is considered under the age of 20; the sixtieth year is considered under the age of 60. Also according to the Mishnah five shekalim are given from a month onward through the age of five, and 15 shekalim from the age of five complete years through the age of 20.

33 Saadiah Gaon states that one gives a shekel per year from one month on. If so, there is no reason to differentiate between a month and five years and between five and 20 years since a child of one year gives one shekel, a child of two, 2 shekalim, and so on till the age of 20. Scripture should have simply said that a shekel per year is given from one month until the age of 20.

34 According to Scripture a child of a month is valuated. However, according to Rabbi Saadiah Gaon a shekel is given per year for the first 20 years. However, a child of a month is less than a year old. Why then should a shekel be given for him?
35 Why should a child less than a month have no valuation?
36 One’s valuation decreased. According to R. Saadiah it should increase.
37 Shall he give a shekel per year until he reaches the age of 75 or is he valued at 15 shekalim beyond the age of 75 for life?
38 The opinions of Rabbi Saadiah Gaon and the other commentaries quoted.
39 The amount of valuation of each age. There is no logic to the amount of valuation.
40 There would be some consistency in the amount given for the prosepective sexes at all stages of their lives.
41 To the amount that a male is valued over the female. A female above the age of 60 is valued at 10 shekalim, and a male at 15 shekalim.
42 The female.
43 Of the male’s valuation.

44 A tenth of the male’s valuation. A female above the age of a month until the age of five is valued at 3 shekalim and a male at 5 shekalim. The female is valued at half of the male, i.e, 2.5 shekalim plus half a shekel. Half a shekel is a tenth of five shekalim. A female is valued at 30 shekalim from 20 to 60 years of age and a male at 50 shekalim. The female is valued at half of the male, i.e., 25 shekalim plus five shekalim. Five shekalim are a tenth of 50 shekalim.
45 Literally, he shall be assessed in one evaluation with such and such.
46 In our verse. It has the meaning of compare, value.
47 Ya’arikhennu means value him.
48 Though both words come from the same root, they have different meanings.
49 Hebrew, ve-he’emido (literally, and he shall set him).
50 The kohen shall set him.
51 Which reads ve-he’emido li-fene ha-kohen [literally, and he (the kohen) shall set him before the kohen].
52 For that is the literal meaning of our clause.

53 Lev. 14:15 literally reads, And the kohen shall take of the log and pour it into the palm of the kohen’s left hand. According to I.E. parts one and two of the verse refer to the same kohen. See I. E. on Lev. 14:15.
54 That is, and he (the kohen) shall set him before the kohen is poetic.

55 That is, ve-he’emido (literally, and he shall set him) refers to the one who vows. In this case ve-he’emido li-fene ha-kohen is to be rendered: and he (the one who utters the vow) shall set himself before the kohen.
56 Literally, it shall arise.
57 The ephah and the bath are equal.
58 The sowing of a homer of barley is valued at fifty shekels. Thus an ephah of barley is valued at five shekalim, for an ephah is a tenth of a homer.

59 This is to be understood as follows: We find a similar divine decree with regard to the monetary value of a slave. A slave is valued at 30 shekalim. (Ex. 21:32). It makes no difference whether the slave in reality is worth more or less than the latter. Similarly with a field. A field is arbitrarily valued at 50 shekels per the sowing of a homer of barley, whether the field is worth more or less.
60 In the very year of the Jubilee.
61 The years that passed shall be deducted from the valuation.
62 It does not introduce a new subject. See I.E. on Lev. 7:15 and the notes thereto.
63 What follows.
64 Which speaks of a field’s valuation.
65 When one dedicates the value of his field.
66 The meaning of the two verses that follow.

67 Verse 19 reads, And (ve) if he…will indeed redeem it. Verse 20 reads, And (ve) if he…will not redeem the field. According to I.E. verses 19 and 20 continue the thought of the earlier verses. Hence the vav is not to be translated, and our verses should be interpreted: If he…will indeed redeem it… Or if he…will not redeem the field.
68 Not “and if he hath sold”. In other words, the vav of ve-im (or if) is not to be rendered as and.
69 After the year of the Jubilee.

70 Scripture employs the same term, yatza (goeth out), with regard to this field, which does not revert to its owner but becomes the property of the Lord, as it does with regard to a field which goes back to its owner.
71 Which return to their owners in the year of the jubilee.
72 The field, which becomes the Lord’s.
73 From the one who bought it.
74 Verse 28.
75 The amount of money which the kohen assesses a dedicated object to be worth belongs to the kohen who estimated its value.

76 See I.E. on Ex. 12:4 (Vol. 2, p. 219): “Mikhsat means a portion.” That is, according to the portions which each one will eat of the Passover lamb. I.E. renders our verse, the portion (i.e., the number of years left until the Jubilee) of your valuation.
77 The original seller.
78 For it already is the Lord’s from birth.
79 The meaning of no man shall sanctify it.
80 According to I.E. the unclean beast spoken of in our verse is a first-born animal.
81 The unclean first-born of the beast.
82 In addition to giving the valuation of the first-born plus a fifth of its value.

83 And every firstling of an ass thou shalt redeem with a lamb (Ex. 13:13). According to I.E. the same law that governs the first-born of an ass applies to all first-born of beasts, which are dedicated to God (Weiser).
84 The first-born of an unclean beast.
85 Like any other unclean beast, for unlike the first-born of an ass it does not require redemption.
86 If he dedicates the first-born of an ass.

87 In addition to its valuation. Normally a first-born ass is redeemed by a sheep. However, if one dedicates the first-born ass he redeems it by giving its value in money. This is in addition to the sheep which he has to give. According to I.E. when the first-born of an ass is redeemed by a lamb, the value of the lamb given in exchange for the ass must be commensurate with the value of the ass. The value of the animals is established by the kohen.
88 They say that our verses do not speak of a first-born animal. See Menachot 102a. Also see Rashi and Ramban.
89 Even if he does not actually own it.
90 Translated in keeping with the meaning of the word cherem (devoted) in our verse.

91 Our verse speaks of objects devoted to God (cherem). So does Num. 21:2. The devoted cities spoken of in Numbers did not belong to the Israelites. Similarly the object in our verse. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
92 Yo’omad is a hofal.
93 All animals that are under the supervision of a shepherd (Filwarg).
94 The first-born.
95 It too is holy.

96 The tithe (v. 31) referenced is probably the second tithe (Weiser). See also Rashi and the Rashbam. The reference cannot be to the tenth of the cattle and flock, for Scripture says that these cannot be redeemed (v. 33).
97 See Num. 18:17.
98 All these are given to the kohen.

100 See I.E. on Lev. 13:36.
101 See I.E. on Lev. 25:1. Be-Har and Be-Chukkotai form one unit. Hence I.E. refers to them as one Torah portion (Weiser).

102 See I.E. on Ex. 3:15 (Vol. 2, pp. 69-71). I.E. there notes that “the number one is the…foundation of all numbers.” He goes on to say that there are ten spheres surrounding the earth: “The tenth sphere is holy because its power is manifest throughout the throne of glory.”
